headline: After New Hampshire, Hillary Clinton Struggles to Find Her Footing
text: HOOKSETT, N.H. — After her unexpected victory in the New Hampshire primary in 2008, Hillary Clinton said she “found my own voice.” She left New Hampshire on Tuesday night, after a double-digit defeat, still searching for it.

headline: 1916: Preparing to Lay a Pacific Cable
text: As the Herald predicted a few days ago the Senate has to-day appropriated $25,000 in the Naval Bill for the taking of soundings between San Francisco, Canton and Honolulu, for the purpose of determining the practicability of laying a Pacific cable. The proposition was adopted with the understanding that it does not commit the Government in any way to lay a cable. The Hawaiian Government has granted the exclusive right for fifteen years to any company connecting the islands with America by cable. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Feb. 11, 1916

headline: As Syria Devolves Further, Allies Criticize American Policy
text: ISTANBUL — Allies of the United States sharply criticized the Obama administration’s Syria policy on Wednesday, when the outgoing foreign minister of France called it “ambiguous” and the president of Turkey said American inaction had allowed the region to descend into a blood bath.

headline: Tempelhof Airport, Once a Lifeline for Berliners, Reprises Role for Refugees
text: BERLIN — The Prussians once paraded on the grounds that are now Tempelhof. Then, in the 1930s, the architect Ernst Sagebiel took what was a modest airfield and conceived the site as a gigantic entrance to Hitler’s new Germany.

headline: Why ‘Diverse TV’ Matters: It’s Better TV. Discuss.
text: “Ladies and gentlemen, welcome to diverse TV.” So said Idris Elba at the Screen Actors Guild Awards last month. It was a reference, of course, to the furor over the Oscars’ all-white acting nominees. But Mr. Elba, who won awards that night for film and TV performances, was probably also aware that in the debate over whose stories get told on the screen, it’s the small one that seems to have the edge as the more inclusive medium.

headline: A House With Two Pools in Provence
text: Built in 2006 with the look of a traditional farmhouse, the six-bedroom home is on the market for $3.9 million.

headline: House Hunting in ... France
text: A HOUSE WITH TWO POOLS IN PROVENCE

headline: Asahi Group Offers to Buy Peroni and Grolsch for $2.9 Billion
text: Asahi Group Holdings of Japan said on Wednesday that it had made a binding offer to buy the beer brands Peroni and Grolsch, as well as certain European operations of SABMiller, for 2.55 billion euros, or about $2.9 billion.

headline: The End of the Merkel Era
text: BERLIN — THE next few weeks will most likely determine the future of Germany’s approach to the refugee crisis — and perhaps the future of the country itself.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Challenge: Peddling Pragmatism
text: Political campaigns are supposed to promise hope and change, but Hillary Clinton is not offering enough of either — one of the most important reasons that she barely won Iowa and lost by a wide margin to Bernie Sanders in New Hampshire.

headline: How a Debate Misstep Sent Marco Rubio Tumbling in New Hampshire
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Everything, it seemed, was breaking Marco Rubio’s way.

headline: Paris Opera Ballet Opts for Silence Over Benjamin Millepied’s Resignation
text: PARIS — About 200 journalists packed into the gilded Rotonde du Glacier in the Palais Garnier here on Wednesday for the Paris Opera’s announcement of its 2016-17 season. But those who attended in hopes of learning more about the unexpected news that the director of dance, Benjamin Millepied, had decided to step down after barely 15 months in the post were left disappointed.

headline: Behind the Makeup and Costumes of ‘Mad Max: Fury Road’
text: Working on “Mad Max: Fury Road” was a lot like working on a carnival; a traditional script was nowhere to be found. Or so it seemed to Lesley Vanderwalt, who oversaw the movie’s Oscar-nominated hair and makeup.

headline: 1941: Britain Breaks With Rumania
text: LONDON — Great Britain today [Feb. 11] broke off diplomatic relations with Rumania, charging that her territory was being used by Germany as a military base. The action followed close on the heels of Prime Minister Winston Churchill’s radio speech last night, in which he asserted that forward units of the German air force had penetrated Bulgaria from Rumania. Official circles here emphasized that the government’s action must not be assumed to mean that the Royal Air Force immediately would bomb Rumanian oil fields, now reported completely in German hands, but they admitted that it put the government in a position to do so ‘‘if we feel like it.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 11, 1941

headline: Who’s Favored to Win the Super Bowl Next Year? Them Again
text: Super Bowl 50 is barely in the books, but it is certainly not too soon to start thinking about Super Bowl LI.

headline: Taylor Stanley, the Calmest Dancer at Lincoln Center
text: As the Creator in Justin Peck’s latest work, “The Most Incredible Thing,” the New York City Ballet soloist Taylor Stanley invents a clock, which is smashed by a Destroyer but magically comes back to life. Eventually, the Creator brings peace to the kingdom and wins the hand of the Princess.

headline: During Primary Season, Gratitude to President Obama
text: To the Editor:

headline: Mitsuko Uchida and the Cleveland Orchestra Play Mozart
text: The pianist Mitsuko Uchida has long been associated with Mozart, a composer she performs with elegance, clarity and a crystalline touch, the melodic lines unfolding with operatic warmth. At 7 p.m. on Sunday, she offers a Valentine’s Day treat, conducting the Cleveland Orchestra from the keyboard. Ms. Uchida performed the Mozart concertos with this superb ensemble while artist in residence there from 2002 to 2007, and their continuing recording collaboration has produced several excellent Mozart discs on the Decca Classics label.

headline: Maxwell, an Elusive Soul Man, Steps Out
text: The R&B songwriter Maxwell, one of the neo-soul pioneers of the 1990s, moves at a pace all his own. Back in 2009, he released his fourth album, “BLACKsummers’night,” a 37-minute set of slowly undulating, structurally adventurous, jazz-infused songs that zoomed into the Top 10 and won Grammy Awards. He said at the time that it was the beginning of a trilogy. The next two segments still haven’t appeared, though last year Maxwell hinted that a new album would be released this winter.

headline: ‘Major Crimes,’ With Ambition
text: Since it was spun off from “The Closer” in 2012, TNT’s “Major Crimes” has become a solid if somewhat unadventurous procedural. When it returns from its winter break on Monday, Feb. 15, however, it gets considerably more ambitious: Instead of serving up a crime of the week, it begins a five-episode arc rooted in a single crime that touches both hot-button real-life issues and a long-dormant murder investigation.

headline: John Kasich, No. 2 in New Hampshire, Turns to an Uncertain South Carolina
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio savored his come-from-behind, second-place finish in the New Hampshire Republican primary on Tuesday night as if it were an outright victory.

headline: Florist-Friendly Marketplaces Help Local Flower Shops Hang On
text: This weekend, florists across the country will send out millions of Valentine’s Day bouquets filled with roses, carnations, tulips and other blooming symbols of love. And some will lose money on almost every single sale.

headline: Easy Midweek Recipes
text: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: North Korea’s Rocket Launch Frays Ties Between South Korea and China
text: BEIJING — When China’s leader, Xi Jinping, visited America’s firm ally South Korea in 2014, it seemed to be the beginning of a promising courtship.

headline: The Year of the Angry Voter
text: I’VE been having a hard time understanding the mood of the country. I turn on the television, and I see a land where to be a citizen means to specialize in the venting of spleen.

headline: Knoedler Gallery and Collectors Settle Case Over Fake Rothko
text: A lawsuit against Knoedler & Co., a once celebrated New York art gallery accused of selling a fake Rothko painting to a pair of collectors for $8.3 million, ended in a settlement on Wednesday, just as the gallery’s former owner and its president were preparing to testify in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

headline: Ayatollah Khomeini’s Grandson Is Disqualified From Elections
text: TEHRAN — After months of political maneuvering, the scion of the powerful Khomeini family and the projected figurehead of Iran’s ailing reform movement was definitively barred Wednesday from participating in parliamentary elections this month, the semiofficial news agency ILNA reported.

headline: Woman and 2 Daughters Fatally Stabbed at Staten Island Motel
text: The man lingered in the hall of a Staten Island motel that has become a bleak way station for people plunged into homelessness. Finally, he entered one of the rooms. Four minutes later, he was gone, a gruesome, wrenching scene left behind.

headline: Cooper Hewitt’s Triennial Asks: What Makes Something Beautiful?
text: Beauty can be a bad word in design, connoting ornament, surface and, that most suspect attribute, pleasure. These are three of the reasons that Ellen Lupton, the senior curator of contemporary design at the Cooper Hewitt, Smithsonian Design Museum, and Andrea Lipps, an assistant curator there, embraced beauty as the title of the museum’s Triennial, opening Friday.

headline: New Writer, Same Goal: Exploring the World on a Budget
text: Last week marked the final Frugal Traveler column for Seth Kugel, who has been bargain hunting and globe jumping for us for almost six years. Next week, he passes the baton to Lucas Peterson. In preparation for the handoff, the new columnist interviewed the outgoing one to find out how cheap travel opens up a new world and about the time he got jumped.

headline: As Bernie Sanders Makes History, Jews Wonder What It Means
text: But is it good for the Jews?

headline: Afghan Policeman, Shot After Firing on NATO Soldiers, Dies of Wounds
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — An Afghan policeman shot by a NATO coalition soldier has died of his wounds after apparently conducting an insider attack, the government said on Wednesday.

headline: Burger King to Add Hot Dogs to the Grill
text: Burger King is going to the dogs — hot dogs, that is.

headline: 12 Nigella Lawson Recipes for Valentine’s Day
text: Romantic main courses and chocolate recipes for Feb. 14.

headline: Brazilians Shrug Off Zika Fears to Revel in Carnival Fun
text: SALVADOR, Brazil — From a mosquito’s point of view, the sweaty, minimally clothed multitudes thronging the streets of this northeastern city on Monday night must have looked especially delectable.

headline: Before Donald Trump, There Was Jan Brewer
text: Donald Trump’s rise from joke candidate to likely Republican nominee surprised all the supposed experts, including me. But 2,000 miles from Washington, in the southwestern American desert, we should have seen an early warning.

headline: Future and Young Thug, Atlanta’s Hip-Hop Workaholics, Go Their Own Ways
text: A few days ago, the Atlanta rapper Young Thug released the video for “F Cancer (Boosie),” a song from his new EP, “I’m Up” (300/Atlantic). It is, like many of the videos he has a hand in conceptualizing, a fascinating dash of medium-fi, madhouse cinema.

headline: A Rough Ride for Tech Stocks, and It’s Not Over
text: It has been a rough year for tech stocks. Yes, even rougher than it has been for most everyone else on Wall Street (though a few energy companies might dispute that claim).

headline: Making Corrections in the Gmail Address Book
text: Q. When I’m sending a Gmail message in my web browser, I’ve noticed that the email addresses for certain people have completely wrong, outdated or unrelated names connected to them. How can I correct this?

headline: Sikh American Actor Flies Home to New York Wearing His Turban
text: A well-known Sikh American actor, Waris Ahluwalia, who was not allowed to board an airplane in Mexico City because he refused to remove his turban during a security check, flew home to the United States on Wednesday, ending a two-day standoff with Aeroméxico.

headline: By Hiring Lisa M. Borders, W.N.B.A. Gets a Leader Who Follows the Game
text: Lisa M. Borders, who was named the W.N.B.A. president Wednesday, describes herself as a “raving fan” of the Atlanta Dream, the franchise she helped attract when she was president of the local City Council.

headline: Bookshelf: Black History
text: New picture books tell both well-known and neglected stories from centuries of African-American life.

headline: Supreme Court’s Blow to Emissions Efforts May Imperil Paris Climate Accord
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court’s surprise decision Tuesday to halt the carrying out of President Obama’s climate change regulation could weaken or even imperil the international global warming accord reached with great ceremony in Paris less than two months ago, climate diplomats say.

headline: Deficit Threatens Stability of University of California, Berkeley, Official Says
text: The chancellor of the University of California, Berkeley, said Wednesday that the university had a “substantial and growing” deficit that could threaten its long-term stability and that it needed to reduce expenses and raise revenues to maintain its position as a premier public institution.

headline: Gov. Christie, Headed Home to New Jersey, Stalls Commute
text: The television at Gate B25 in Boston’s Logan Airport blared a CNN story on Wednesday: “Sources: Christie to meet with aides on future.” Then, “Sources expect Christie to formally suspend bid.”

headline: Newspaper Adviser Is Fired After Students’ Scoop Roils Maryland Campus
text: When student reporters at Mount St. Mary’s University, a small Catholic institution in Maryland, published an article in January that quoted the university’s president likening struggling freshmen to bunnies that should be drowned, they knew it might get a big reaction.

headline: Sofia Coppola to Make Opera Debut in Rome
text: In a coup for the struggling Rome Opera, the film director Sofia Coppola will make her operatic debut there, the company announced this week. Her staging of Verdi’s “La Traviata,” a collaboration with the fashion designer Valentino Garavani and his workshop, will open on May 24 and run through June 30.

headline: The Real Jobless Rate Is 42 Percent? Donald Trump Has a Point, Sort Of
text: Donald Trump seems quite certain that the real unemployment rate is higher than the 4.9 percent that the Bureau of Labor Statistics has reported it to be. A lot higher.

headline: In Italy, a Top Club Stands Alone in Supporting Women’s Soccer
text: FLORENCE, Italy — In England, many top soccer clubs, including Arsenal, Chelsea, Manchester City and Liverpool, operate a women’s team alongside their more famous men’s team. In Spain, teams like Barcelona, Athletic Bilbao, Atlético Madrid and Espanyol do the same. In France, the top-division clubs Paris St.-Germain, Lyon, Montpelier and St.-Étienne also field professional women’s teams while in Germany the group includes Bayern Munich, Wolfsburg, Bayer Leverkusen and Hoffenheim.

headline: With Storm Over, Some Humor on Anthem of the Seas
text: The voyage of Anthem of the Seas was cut short after sailing through a strong winter storm that produced hurricane-force winds. Here is Brett Michael Dykes’s original firsthand account.

headline: Take Two: Scarlett Johansson and Michèle Lamy
text: Scarlett Johansson and Michèle Lamy try some new products.

headline: Assisted Suicide Study Questions Its Use for Mentally Ill
text: A new study of doctor-assisted death for people with mental disorders raises questions about the practice, finding that in more than half of approved cases, people declined treatment that could have helped, and that many cited loneliness as an important reason for wanting to die. The study, of cases in the Netherlands, should raise concerns for other countries debating where to draw the line when it comes to people’s right to die, experts said.

headline: The Coolest Pins to Customize Your Denim
text: “We lack intimacy.”

headline: 1-Year-Old Girl Fatally Shot in Her Crib in Compton
text: A 1-year-old girl was resting in her crib, surrounded by family members inside a converted garage in Compton, Calif., when a bullet came through the garage door and struck her in the head, leaving her mortally wounded.

headline: Eiko Steps Away From One Dance Partner, to Take on Many More
text: For more than four decades, it was Eiko and Koma. But two years ago, after Koma injured his ankle, Eiko, the other half of the husband-and-wife dance duo — treasured for their stark, startlingly slow excavations of stillness and shape while time gradually passes — struck out on her own. The pair are likely to perform together in the future, but for now, Eiko is consumed with a solo project that has transformed her career.

headline: Brutal Romanian Prison Warden, 90, Loses Appeal of 20-Year Sentence
text: BUCHAREST, Romania — The highest court in Romania upheld a 20-year prison term on Wednesday for a 90-year-old former warden from the country’s repressive Communist past who had overseen brutal treatment of prisoners, including routine beatings and starvation.

headline: Traditionalists Rebuffed as Parliament Turns the Page on Parchment
text: LONDON — For centuries, acts of Parliament and other important documents have been inscribed on vellum, a parchment made from calfskin. Magna Carta, which King John signed 800 years ago last year, was written on vellum. So was the Domesday Book compiled in 1086, 20 years after William the Conqueror sailed across the English Channel.

headline: Deutsche Bank’s Opaque Balance Sheet Clouds Its Position
text: Deutsche Bank’s vast and opaque balance sheet is holding it back. Media reports that the German lender was considering buying back senior debt to strengthen its balance sheet sent its shares – and those of European peers – soaring on Wednesday. But Deutsche’s shares are still down 35 percent since early January.

headline: A Multifront Republican Battle in South Carolina
text: MOUNT PLEASANT, S.C. — Donald J. Trump’s rivals for the Republican presidential nomination dug in Wednesday for a hard fight in the South Carolina primary, where Mr. Trump will seek to gain a clear upper hand in the 2016 race after his smashing victory in New Hampshire.

headline: Big City Book Club
text: Matthew Thomas’s “We Are Not Ourselves,” a multi-generational saga of Irish immigrant life in New York, was the subject of an online discussion on Feb. 11, 2016.

headline: When Women Fire Back, Are They ‘Ferocious’? When Is a Critic a Scold?
text: Last week, The Times prominently displayed an analysis piece which explored the matter of sexist language and speech in the presidential campaign. Through interviews and other research, it showed how negative words such as “shrill” or “shouting” have been applied to Hillary Clinton, but not to her male rivals.

headline: Chris Christie Drops Out of Presidential Race After New Hampshire Flop
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, a once-commanding figure in the Republican Party who struggled to attract support for his presidential campaign but unsettled the race with his strident attacks on Senator Marco Rubio of Florida, ended his run for the White House on Wednesday.

headline: Coaching Stars to Avoid a ‘Racist Against Whites’ Moment
text: Earlier this awards season, at a ceremony for one of Hollywood’s guild prizes, a prominent filmmaker who does not have a dog in the fight mulled over whether to chat with the media. After seeking the advice of a friend, who replied, “Not unless you want to talk about diversity,” the filmmaker stood down.

headline: Department of Justice Sues Ferguson, Which Reversed Course on Agreement
text: WASHINGTON — The Department of Justice filed a civil rights lawsuit against Ferguson, Mo., on Wednesday, less than a day after the city rejected an agreement to overhaul its beleaguered criminal justice system and address allegations of widespread abuses by its police department.

headline: Ex-Los Angeles Sheriff, Lee Baca, Pleads Guilty to Lying in Corruption Inquiry
text: LOS ANGELES — Lee Baca, the former Los Angeles County sheriff who resigned in 2014 amid a growing corruption scandal in his department, pleaded guilty on Wednesday to making false statements to the federal authorities who were investigating the jail system he oversaw.

headline: Candy, Fit for a Valentine’s Day Sleepover
text: If anyone knows about gifting for Valentine’s Day, it’s the lingerie-designer-turned-candy-maker Maayan Zilberman. Her former fashion line, the Lake and Stars, blurred underwear with outerwear; her new project, Sweet Saba, delights in the mix-up between sculpture and candy. “It was a very seamless shift,” the sharply manicured Zilberman says of her new endeavor. “Candy, like lingerie, has its biggest market around Christmas and Valentine’s. I think if you have the same sensibility and the same customer, it’s just like saying you have a new dish on the menu.”

headline: What’s the Deal With Cruz and Kids?
text: Is there any limit to Senator Ted Cruz’s willingness to exploit small children – his own and now others – in embarrassing and peculiar ways to further his bid for the Republican presidential nomination? Based on his latest TV ad, “Playing Trump,” which features three kids playing with a Donald Trump doll and robotically mouthing Cruz campaign talking points, the answer is clearly “No.”

headline: Drug Traffickers Turn to New Type of Courier: Seniors
text: WASHINGTON — In what law enforcement officials describe as a new front in international smuggling, global traffickers and cartels are increasingly turning to a new source for couriers to smuggle drugs across international borders: vulnerable American older adults.

headline: False Convictions
text: To the Editor:

headline: Filters That Add a Dash of Dazzle to Smartphone Photos
text: When I learned about photography years ago, one of my favorite tricks with the camera was to use a filter — perhaps a color gel or a diffuser — to add a special effect to the final photograph.

headline: Autopsy Shows the N.H.L.’s Todd Ewen Did Not Have C.T.E.
text: When the former N.H.L. enforcer Todd Ewen died in September, reportedly of a self-inflicted gunshot, his brain was sent to researchers. Years of memory loss and undiagnosed depression led to speculation that Ewen, 49, had chronic traumatic encephalopathy, a degenerative brain disease caused by repeated blows to the head.

headline: Cruelty to Elephants
text: To the Editor:

headline: Marco Rubio Is Robotic, but Not Out of It
text: Don’t blame message discipline for Marco Rubio’s lightning-fast collapse from triumphant in Iowa to disappointed in New Hampshire. Even his opponents chalked up the I, Robot routine in Saturday’s debate to message discipline. But that’s a smear against one of the most effective tools any candidate has in his campaign arsenal. Mr. Rubio stumbled because he took the practice to an absurd extreme.

headline: Sales and Deals for Fashion Week and Valentine’s Day
text: Didn’t manage to score tickets to Yeezy Season 3? Cheer up: There are many more ways to take part in the fashion week festivities. On Thursday from 11 a.m. to 3 p.m., the e-commerce aggregator Lyst will team up with Uber on a giveaway celebrating the diversity of New York style. Enter the code FINDNYFW in the app for the chance to request a goody bag filled with items shoppable on Lyst (like, say, an oh-so-downtown Maiyet geometric block scarf) tailored to the neighborhood you’re in.

headline: The Landscape After New Hampshire
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Republican Mess
text: In 1996, Pat Buchanan — running as a populist, a protectionist, an outsider — won three of the first four Republican primary season contests, taking caucuses in Louisiana and Alaska, finishing a close second in Iowa, and then winning New Hampshire outright.

headline: An Exhibition That Proves Video Games Can Be Art
text: In April 2010, a brouhaha erupted in the gaming community that still reverberates today: The film critic Roger Ebert had opined that video games could never truly be counted as art. “Let me just say that no video gamer now living will survive long enough to experience the medium as an art form,” he wrote on his blog. But three months later, in an erudite follow-up titled “Okay, Kids, Play on My Lawn,” he recanted. Great works of art, he speculated, “could instruct me about life, love, disease and death, principles and morality, humor and tragedy.” Ebert admitted that he hadn’t spent enough time with video games to know if they could, indeed, evoke these feelings. “I don’t know if they can be inspired to transcend themselves,” he wrote. “Perhaps they can. How can I say?”

headline: Carly Fiorina Drops Out of Republican Presidential Race
text: Carly Fiorina, 61, the former chairwoman of Hewlett-Packard, suspended her presidential campaign Wednesday, announcing her decisions on social media after poor showings in the New Hampshire and Iowa nominating contests.

headline: A Rap Video With a Side of 3D-Printed Jewelry
text: In June 2014, the industrial designer Célia Elmasu and the multidisciplinary artist Nelly Zagury — longtime friends and intermittent collaborators — made a pact over Skype. “I said, ‘If I quit my day job, you quit yours. I quit; you quit,’” Elmasu, now 29, remembers. “Nelly said, ‘O.K., I’ll quit,’ and I asked, ‘You sure?’ And that started it all.” Zagury, 28, chimes in, “Our initial idea was two parts: a hip-hop musical and doing crazy props.” A year and a half later, the French-born, Brooklyn-based duo has created “the first 3D-printed music video.” Elmasu and Zagury’s jewelry brand, Holy Faya, regularly worn onstage by FKA twigs, is a fortuitous byproduct.

headline: G.M. Recalls Trucks Because of Brake Pedal Issue
text: General Motors is recalling about 478,000 trucks, including almost 427,000 in the United States, because the brake pedal could fall off, the automaker said on Wednesday.

headline: Experts Study Zika’s Path From First Outbreak in Pacific
text: HONG KONG — Yap Island, a speck of land in the Western Pacific best known for using huge stone discs as currency, was facing a medical mystery.

headline: Times Reporter: ‘I Would Never Cut a Deal Like That’
text: Here’s an ugly term: Transactional journalism — also known as a quid pro quo.

headline: Great Free Resources for Teaching Election 2016
text: Updated | Oct. 5, 2016

headline: Ojai Festival Names Future Directors
text: The Ojai Music Festival — the innovative California gathering that puts itself in the hands of a different music director each year — announced this week that it would have an eclectic group of stewards for the five seasons leading to its 75th anniversary in 2021.

headline: Natixis Acquires 51% Stake in Peter J. Solomon Co.
text: Buried in the latest quarterly earnings report from Natixis, the big French bank, was some surprising news: The firm has acquired a majority stake in one of the United States’ oldest boutique advisory shops.

headline: And Then There Were Four: Phone Booths Saved on Upper West Side Sidewalks
text: A work crew pulled up to the northwest corner of West End Avenue and 101st Street on Wednesday morning and approached an oblong glass box that looked so anachronistic that a passer-by might have wondered if it simply had dropped out of the sky.

headline: 5 New York Hotel Bars That Melt Away the Winter Blues
text: When the February air is biting and Manhattan’s avenues seem never-ending, few pleasures compare with ducking into a hotel bar and sinking into a club chair beside a fire.

headline: NATO to Expand Military Presence in Europe to Deter Russians
text: BRUSSELS — The defense ministers from all 28 NATO countries approved a plan on Wednesday to enhance the alliance’s military presence in Central and Eastern Europe, part of its expanding efforts to deter Russian aggression, according to NATO’s secretary general, Jens Stoltenberg.

headline: Marc Andreessen Apologizes After Facebook Disavows India Comments
text: Marc Andreessen, a Silicon Valley venture capitalist and board member of the social network Facebook, has long been one of its vocal supporters. On Wednesday, Facebook did not welcome that support.

headline: Google Car Exposes Regulatory Divide on Computers as Drivers
text: SAN FRANCISCO — It appears that Google has persuaded federal regulators that — in some situations at least — the Tin Man has a heart.

headline: Giants Cut Will Beatty and Geoff Schwartz, and Jon Beason Retires
text: Days after the Giants’ season ended, the owner John K. Mara declared the roster undertalented and soberly put the onus for rebuilding the team on General Manager Jerry Reese.

headline: A Fashion Crowd Celebrates Chinese New Year
text: Monkey masks are an unusual New York Fashion Week accessory. But they were de rigueur Monday night at Indochine, the French-Vietnamese hot spot in NoHo, where a Chinese New Year’s dinner was hosted by Dao-Yi Chow, the co-designer of Public School and DKNY.

headline: Tessa Thompson Is Just Like Us: She Discovers Designers on Instagram
text: Plus: much like the little black dress, the little black scarf is going everywhere; Carolina Herrera's latest capsule collection and art meets leather goods in the new Lizzie Fortunato bag collaboration with the painter Sally King Benedict.

headline: Mine Kills Civilians as Fighting Heats Up in Eastern Ukraine
text: DONETSK, Ukraine — Fighting that had been quiet for several months between Russia-backed insurgents and government forces has picked up in eastern Ukraine, punctuated by regular artillery shelling, the use of land mines and other tactics that have put civilians at risk.

headline: Twitter User Growth Stalls, and the Chief Pledges to Make Fixes
text: When Jack Dorsey returned last year as chief executive of Twitter, the social media company he co-founded, he had a mandate: Right a sinking ship.

headline: How a Junk-Food-Obsessed Instagram Chef Does Valentine’s Day
text: Everything about the Instagram celebrity chef Jacques La Merde is a little bit off. First, the faceless Instagrammer attracted thousands of followers (currently, 122,000), many of whom assumed La Merde was a man. But a recent episode of “Top Chef” revealed the account is run by the Toronto-based chef Christine Flynn. Many also assumed that La Merde was poking fun at the food world with an integration of Bugles and Drumsticks into daintily composed plates, mimicking complex dishes that might come out of Noma or Eleven Madison Park’s kitchens. In actuality, Flynn’s elaborate experiments in plating culture were exactly that — experiments. “I wasn’t allowed to eat junk food growing up,” she says.

headline: Streamlining the Universal Remote Device
text: IF you’re of a certain age, you may recall what you had to do to watch television: You turned the set on.

headline: The Portland of Portugal
text: In Portugal’s second most populous city, medieval townhouses stack up beside the Douro River like Legos, and churches wear their blue-and-white azulejo tiles outside as well as in. Settled by the Romans, and famous for its port wines, which became a favored export to England via the 1703 Methuen Treaty, Porto was a lucky beneficiary of its country’s vast, centuries-spanning empire — look to the Baroque, blinding-gilt interior of the Church of São Francisco for evidence. Its riverside location made it an important industrial center in the 1700s and 1800s.

headline: MetLife Makes Its Case Against ‘Too Big to Fail’ Label
text: WASHINGTON — The “too big to fail” label is finally having its day in court.

headline: Review: On ‘Those Who Can’t,’ Stalking the Halls of Lower Education
text: At this rate, by the end of the decade every comedy troupe in North America will have its own television series about misbehaving educators.

headline: At the Grammy Awards, a History of Old-Guard Resistance to Change
text: The slate of best new artist nominees at the 2011 Grammy Awards was the most stacked in recent memory: Justin Bieber, a teen heartthrob who would go on to become the only relevant solo male pop star of the 2010s so far; Drake, at the beginning of his quest to fully meld hip-hop and R&B; Mumford & Sons, a band that delivered roots rock with arena muscle; and Florence & the Machine, glam art-rock innovators.

headline: Review: A Cabinet of Curiosities at the Joyce
text: The choreographer Alwin Nikolais came to modern dance late after studying piano and working in scenic design, puppetry and acting. Looking back now, it makes sense. Nikolais, who died in 1993, was ahead of his time in his vision of theater as a place where sound, light and movement work in concert to give birth to jewel-like spectacles. He was long accused of dehumanizing dance; yes, there can be shapes instead of bodies and masks instead of faces, but there’s no denying the heart in his choreography, however peculiar, playful or grisly it is.

headline: Some Auto Insurance Premiums Penalize Home Renters, Study Finds
text: What does owning a home have to do with car insurance? Quite a bit, when it comes to the rates consumers pay for auto coverage, a new analysis finds.

headline: Versace Through the Years
text: Donatella Versace is the one designer who has consistently challenged the paradox of power and sex — and she’s done it with a laugh, a cigarette and a billion dollar business.

headline: Stakes in Nevada Rise for Hillary Clinton as Caucuses Near
text: LAS VEGAS — The Democratic presidential caucuses in Nevada were supposed to be an afterthought: lost in the shadows of high-profile battles in Iowa and New Hampshire, and fought in a state far off in the West where voters have a long, warm history with Bill and Hillary Clinton.

headline: Review: In ‘My Father, the Pornographer,’ Chris Offutt Opens Up
text: “Families,” a therapist once told me. “They keep us in business.”

headline: China Injects a Heavy Dose of Ideology Into New Year’s Eve Gala
text: BEIJING — “Too handsome! Aren’t they handsome,” the actor Ju Zhaojie cooed as dozens of soldiers, from an honor guard of the People’s Liberation Army, stamped off the stage, issuing earsplitting shouts.

headline: Mylan in $7.2 Billion Deal for Meda, a Swedish Drug Maker
text: After several attempts a few years ago to acquire Meda, a Swedish drug maker, Mylan finally found the price to solidify a deal: $7.2 billion.

headline: In the Pop-Up Kitchen With Albert Adrià
text: The Catalan chef brought T into the Domino kitchen, at the Café Royal hotel, to test recipes for his forthcoming 50 Days event.

headline: A Preview of Chef Albert Adrià’s Much-Anticipated London Pop-Up
text: This Friday, the beloved Catalan chef Albert Adrià (who is, of course, Ferran Adrià’s little brother) will cook in London for the first time with a pop-up at the Café Royal hotel. Unlike the five diverse restaurants he runs in Barcelona — which range from a perpetually sold-out avant-garde tapas bar called Tickets, to Hoja Santa, a modern Mexican table that was just awarded a star in the 2016 Michelin guide to Spain — the two-month-long pop-up will serve a prix fixe menu devised entirely by him.

headline: Fox News Draws 4.2 Million Viewers for New Hampshire Primary Coverage
text: Fox News drew 4.2 million viewers for Tuesday night’s coverage of the New Hampshire primary, the second-highest viewership for primary or caucus night coverage for any cable network dating to 2000. It was the highest rating for coverage of the New Hampshire primary for any cable network going back those 16 years.

headline: Better Call Roberto: Alagna Steps In to ‘Manon Lescaut’
text: The tenor Roberto Alagna was sleeping the morning after singing “Pagliacci” at the Metropolitan Opera last month when the company’s general manager, Peter Gelb, telephoned with a potential crisis on his hands. Jonas Kaufmann, one of the biggest stars in opera, had just withdrawn from a coming new production of Puccini’s “Manon Lescaut.” Would Mr. Alagna step in?

headline: Asahi’s Beer Buy: Trying to Escape Demographic Destiny
text: Anheuser-Busch InBev is getting the better of Asahi of Japan on three middling beer brands. While the $2.9 billion price tag is a bit lower than expected, the Japanese brewer’s acquisition of Peroni, Grolsch and Meantime clocks in at what may be some 25 times one measure of operating profit. The deal is only justifiable under the demographic logic of the buyer’s shrinking home country.

headline: AmfAR Gala to Honor Harvey Weinstein
text: The producer Harvey Weinstein is being honored Wednesday night at the annual amfAR gala, which serves as the unofficial kickoff to New York Fashion Week. Charli XCX and Icona Pop will perform — they collaborated on the 2012 hit “I Love It” — and a charity auction will take place during dinner. Last year, the event raised $2.25 million for AIDS research. Previous honorees include Bill Clinton, Elizabeth Taylor, Diane von Furstenberg and Elton John. More information can be found at amfar.org.

headline: Education May Cut Dementia Risk, Study Finds
text: The risk of developing dementia is decreasing for people with at least a high school education, according to an important new study that suggests that changes in lifestyle and improvements in physical health can help prevent or delay cognitive decline.

headline: Five Designers to Watch at New York Fashion Week
text: A handful of designers debuting — and a few to keep an eye on.

headline: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing: Donald Trump, Janet Yellen, Chris Christie
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Review: New York Philharmonic’s Chinese New Year, From Breezy to Languid
text: Hidden messages conveyed in an ancient, enigmatic language are the subject of Tan Dun’s “Nu Shu: The Secret Songs of Women,” which capped the New York Philharmonic’s Chinese New Year celebration at David Geffen Hall on Tuesday. This languid, melancholy work for solo harp, orchestra and what its composer calls “micro films” is the result of Mr. Tan’s own field research into a nearly extinct language and calligraphy used for 700 years by women from a village in his native Hunan province.

headline: The Boycott Before: Rap and Resentment at the 1989 Grammys
text: It can be said quite often: Hip-hop did it first.

headline: Kendall and Kylie Jenner Party for Their Fashion Brand
text: When young designers want to unveil their first collection, they may hold a fashion show, perhaps during fashion week. But not if you’re Kendall and Kylie Jenner.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Bulgaria and Elsewhere
text: Bulgaria and More — Photos of the Day

headline: Benjamin Millepied Opens Up on Leaving Paris Opera Ballet
text: PARIS — “No questions?” Stéphane Lissner, the general director of the Paris Opera, asked the 200 or so journalists assembled on Wednesday morning for the announcement of the Opera’s 2016-17 season. There was the briefest pause. “Well, thank you,” he said, leaving the podium immediately with the music director Philippe Jordan and the director of dance, Benjamin Millepied.

headline: Review: Bellini’s ‘La Sonnambula,’ Sung by Promising Young Voices
text: Over the last few years, the Juilliard School has become a hotbed for inventive opera productions. So it’s hard not to wish that the beautiful concert performance of Bellini’s “La Sonnambula” on Tuesday evening at the school’s Peter Jay Sharp Theater had been staged.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Feb. 10, 2016 — Photos of the Day
text: Photos from Bulgaria, Yemen, Afghanistan and Germany.

headline: U.S. and Europe Reach Agreement on Derivatives Regulation
text: An agreement between American and European regulators over the $553 trillion derivatives market could bring relief to banks and large clearinghouses, which had faced the threat of higher costs and disrupted trading.

headline: Three Ways to Quit a Campaign
text: This is the time when candidates who never had a shot at the Republican nomination but were hanging in through New Hampshire drop out of the race. Or as they say, “suspend” their campaigns – a term of art coined in the last few cycles so that they can go on raising money even though they are not actually running anymore.

headline: Orpheus Chamber Orchestra Announces Next Season
text: The Orpheus Chamber Orchestra announced Wednesday that its next season at Carnegie Hall would include a mix of classical works and new pieces, and feature performances with soloists including the pianists Christian Zacharias and Fazil Say, the violinist Vadim Gluzman and the cellist Alisa Weilerstein.

headline: Effort to Replace a Plaintiffs’ Lawyer in G.M. Case Is Rejected
text: The federal judge overseeing hundreds of claims against General Motors related to a defective ignition switch has rejected an effort to replace Robert C. Hilliard, one of the lead plaintiffs’ lawyers on the case.

headline: HBO Now Has 800,000 Paid Streaming Subscribers, Time Warner Says
text: HBO’s stand-alone video streaming service has attracted about 800,000 paying subscribers since starting last April, the premium cable network said Wednesday, the first time it has disclosed numbers for the service.

headline: Leslie Bassett, Pulitzer Prize-Winning Composer, Dies at 93
text: Leslie Bassett, a Pulitzer Prize-winning composer known for his lush sonorities and ecumenical instrumentation, died on Feb. 4 in Oakwood, Ga. He was 93.

headline: Senate Approves Penalties for Aiding North Korean Nuclear Program
text: WASHINGTON — In an effort to derail North Korea’s nuclear ambitions, the Senate on Wednesday unanimously approved strict sanctions intended to limit Pyongyang’s ability to finance warheads and missiles.

headline: Behind the Scenes With Vfiles’s 2016 Finalists
text: Six young designers from around the world will take part in tonight’s runway show.

headline: Behind the Scenes With Six of Fashion Week’s Emerging Designers
text: Earlier this week, six young designers from around the world convened in an empty retail space in SoHo to prepare their debut collections at New York Fashion Week. They were the winners of the sixth Vfiles Runway competition — which will be held tonight at Spring Studios — and have come from Italy, Switzerland, Ukraine, Holland and India. More than a few of them are in New York for the first time.

headline: SolarCity and Other Rooftop Providers Face a Cloudier Future
text: Just two years ago, SolarCity and other rooftop solar providers were Wall Street darlings, and prospects for growth were flying high, as enthusiasm for solar power was seemingly boundless.

headline: Young Bombers Kill 58 at Nigerian Camp for Those Fleeing Boko Haram
text: MAIDUGURI, Nigeria — When three girls showed up Monday at a camp for people who had fled the militant group Boko Haram, they were welcomed and offered a place to sleep.

headline: Stop Bernie-Splaining to Black Voters
text: Now that Iowa and New Hampshire are vanishing in the rearview mirror, the Democratic contests shift more West and South — beginning with Nevada and South Carolina, states that have significantly more Hispanic or black voters, respectively, who at this point disproportionately favor Hillary Clinton to Bernie Sanders.

headline: Yemen: Airstrike Kills Family in Capital
text: Two television journalists were killed late Tuesday, along with their three children, when an airstrike carried out by the military coalition led by Saudi Arabia hit their house in Sana, the capital, witnesses said. The journalists, Suaad Hujaira, 30, and her husband, Muneer Alhakami, 37, worked for Yemen TV, a state channel controlled by Yemen’s Houthi rebels and critical of the Saudis’ military intervention in Yemen. The coalition, which has been fighting the Houthis since March, has been accused of killing hundreds of civilians in airstrikes that are often indiscriminate, human rights groups say. Mr. Alhakami and Ms. Hujaira’s house was in a residential neighborhood in Sana, far from any obvious military target, residents said.

headline: Man Convicted of Killing 3 Brooklyn Merchants in 2012
text: A traveling clothing salesman was convicted on Wednesday of fatally shooting three merchants in Brooklyn, a series of apparently random attacks in 2012 that had shopkeepers on alert for months.

headline: Twitter, to Save Itself, Must Scale Back World-Swallowing Ambitions
text: Twitter is the world’s most important social network.

headline: Cuomo’s Proposal Seeks Confidentiality for Minors With H.I.V.
text: Among the recent patients at the Children’s Hospital at Montefiore in the Bronx was a 17-year-old with H.I.V. who put off his treatment until he turned 18, because he was worried his parents would kick him out and not pay for his medications if they found out about his status. At SUNY Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn, doctors wanted to prescribe Truvada, the preventive H.I.V. pill, to a 16-year-old girl who was dating a man who was H.I.V. positive. But she did not receive it because she could not qualify for state assistance to pay for it.

headline: Russian Intervention in Syrian War Has Sharply Reduced U.S. Options
text: MUNICH — For months now the United States has insisted there can be no military solution to the Syrian civil war, only a political accord between President Bashar al-Assad and the fractured, divided opposition groups that have been trying to topple him.

headline: Security Fears Hang Over African Marathons
text: DAKAR, Senegal — Samba Faye’s training for Sunday’s inaugural marathon here includes runs along Dakar’s scenic coastal road, where there has been a noticeable increase in armed security at upscale hotels and shopping areas after recent terrorist attacks in Burkina Faso and Mali.

headline: Where Campaigns Go to Die
text: The Iowa caucuses and the New Hampshire primaries are the first tests presidential hopefuls face every four years, and for a lot of candidates, it’s the beginning and the end.

headline: Technology Manager Gets 3 Years’ Probation in CityTime Scheme
text: It was one of the biggest frauds ever carried out against the City of New York, and a blot on former Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s reputation for managerial and technological savvy. On Wednesday, the criminal prosecutions spawned by the case, involving a computerized payroll system called CityTime, reached a quiet denouement when a federal judge in Manhattan sentenced a computer specialist at the center of the scheme to three years’ probation.

headline: Judge Refuses to Grant Mistrial in Akai Gurley Case
text: Lawyers defending a New York City police officer accused of killing an unarmed man inside a Brooklyn housing project sought on Wednesday to have the case declared a mistrial, arguing that a last-minute theory introduced by prosecutors was “inflammatory.”

headline: Canada: Another Human Foot Washes Ashore
text: The British Columbia Coroners Service said Wednesday that it had opened an investigation after a human foot washed up on the province’s shoreline, the 13th since 2007. Like most of the other cases, the current one involves a foot wearing a running shoe. It was found by a hiker on Vancouver Island’s Botanical Beach on Sunday. The coroner’s office said the foot became detached from the body because of “prolonged immersion in water.” The style of the running shoe that was found was first sold in North American stores in March 2013, indicating that the death occurred sometime after that date. The coroner’s office confirmed that 10 of the 12 feet in earlier cases came from seven people who have been identified. It said that foul play was not evident in the other cases.

headline: Pennsylvania to Start Impeachment Proceedings for Attorney General
text: HARRISBURG, Pa. — The Pennsylvania House voted overwhelmingly on Wednesday to begin impeachment proceedings against Attorney General Kathleen Kane, who survived a separate attempt by Senate Republicans to oust her using an arcane constitutional procedure not invoked here since 1891.

headline: Did the Supreme Court Just Kill the Paris Climate Deal? Maybe. We Explain.
text: Answers to questions about the court’s decision to temporarily block the Obama administration’s effort to regulate emissions from coal-fired power plants.

headline: Modern Love: The Podcast | The Plunge
text: Welcome to the fifth episode of Modern Love: The Podcast, brought to you by The New York Times and WBUR. This week, you’ll hear the actress Dakota Fanning read a 2013 Modern Love essay by Natalie Lindeman titled “Celebrating the Upside of an Emotional Plunge,” about a teenager who finds the silver lining (and love) after falling 100 feet into one the country’s steepest canyons.

headline: Dweller on the Upper Mississippi
text: THURSDAY PUZZLE — As a person who is fairly visual, I like to imagine that when I come across a particularly tough crossword clue, a question mark appears above my head until my brain deciphers the answer. As soon as I figure out the answer, that question mark is replaced by an energy-saving and eco-friendly light bulb. I should probably cut down on the video games.

headline: F.B.I. Agents Encircle Holdouts at Oregon Standoff
text: SEATTLE — F.B.I. agents moved in on Wednesday night to encircle the last four holdouts at a federal wildlife refuge in eastern Oregon that has been occupied since early January by armed antigovernment militants.

headline: Two Maryland Deputies Are Killed in Panera Bread Shooting
text: Two sheriff’s deputies were killed Wednesday in a shooting that started at a restaurant in a shopping center in Abingdon, Md., and ended near an apartment complex, the authorities said. The suspect was also killed in the exchange of gunfire.

headline: Police See Possible Hate Crime in Stabbing of Jewish Man in Brooklyn
text: A 25-year-old Jewish man dressed in Hasidic clothing was stabbed in the back on Wednesday as he walked along a street in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn, and his assailant was being sought in what the police were investigating as a possible hate crime, officials said.

headline: 캄보디아에서 만난 북한의 엘리트 예술 작품
text: 캄보디아, 시엠립 — 입구에서 관람객을 맞는 거대한 벽화 속 미소를 띤 석상은 캄보디아 앙코르 유적지 옆에 새로 문을 연 앙코르 파노라마 박물관 내부의 어마어마한 규모와 웅장함에 비하면 그저 맛보기에 불과하다.

headline: New York City to Review a Nuisance Law That Has Led to Evictions
text: The Police Department will review the circumstances under which it forces people from their homes using New York City’s nuisance-abatement law, a legal weapon that has been used for decades to shut down drug dens, brothels and other criminal operations, officials said on Wednesday.

headline: Donald Trump Takes Aim at Ted Cruz Again
text: Donald J. Trump released an ad Wednesday attacking Senator Ted Cruz of Texas as the two prepare to square off in South Carolina, after splitting the first two Republican nominating contests.

headline: Nets Look to Turn the Page on Misery. Maybe Next Week.
text: The Nets were 1.3 seconds away from their 40th loss of the season Monday when Joe Johnson banked in a 3-pointer as time expired to defeat the Denver Nuggets. The thrill of victory — a rare sight inside Barclays Center this season — sent the owner Mikhail D. Prokhorov (also a rarity inside the arena) out of his luxury-box seat, arms extended high in the air as he hollered and celebrated.

headline: Gov. Rick Snyder Asks Michigan Lawmakers for More Aid for Flint
text: Gov. Rick Snyder of Michigan asked state lawmakers on Wednesday to approve $195 million more in aid for Flint, where tainted water has caused health problems and prompted calls to rapidly fix the city’s crumbling infrastructure. But the governor’s request did not include funds to replace every lead service line in the city, as Flint’s mayor has insisted is necessary.

headline: Kanye West’s Yeezy Season 3 Extravaganza
text: Mr. West debuted his Yeezy Season 3 fashion collection and his new album, “The Life of Pablo,” at Madison Square Garden.

headline: El Chapo Could Be Tried in Brooklyn Court for Drug Trafficking, Official Says
text: If Mexico agrees to extradite the notorious drug trafficker known as El Chapo to the United States, he would be tried in federal court in Brooklyn, a law enforcement official said on Wednesday.

headline: Word of the Day + Quiz | panoramic
text: panoramic • \ˌpa-nə-ˈra-mik\ • adjective

headline: No Serious Injuries After Bus Carrying Argentine Soccer Team Crashes
text: Players from a top Argentine soccer team received emergency treatment after their bus crashed and overturned in Venezuela following a match in the Copa Libertadores, South America’s premier club tournament. Huracán, a team from Buenos Aires, defeated Caracas F.C. on Tuesday night to secure a berth in the Copa’s second round. But on the way back to the airport, the brakes on the team’s bus failed, club officials said. The bus flipped, and several players and members of the club’s staff were hurt, although none of the injuries appeared serious.

headline: Federal Grand Jury Begins Hearing Evidence in Eric Garner Case
text: Federal prosecutors began presenting evidence on Wednesday to a grand jury in Brooklyn in the death of Eric Garner, an unarmed black man who died after being placed in a chokehold by a white police officer in Staten Island in July 2014, according to a person briefed on the matter.

headline: What to Watch Thursday
text: César Award? Check. Oscar nomination? Alas, no. Kristen Stewart’s portrayal of a personal assistant to a French actress in “Clouds of Sils Maria” comes to cable. Shonda Rhimes’s tough cookies resume their lives midseason. And cast members of “The Walking Dead” talk zombies.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “Social media is the laxative of the fashion system. It makes everyone digest everything so much faster: trends, product discovery.”

headline: Corrections: February 11, 2016
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Firing Leads to Questions on California Coast’s Future
text: LOS ANGELES — The decision by the powerful commission that controls development along California’s coastline to fire its executive director threw the agency into turmoil Thursday, raising questions about why it acted and the future of the state’s 1,100 miles of coastal land.

headline: Berlin Film Festival Includes a Focus on Immigration and Refugees
text: BERLIN — The 66th annual Berlin International Film Festival opens Thursday with the European premiere of the Coen brothers’ latest caper, “Hail, Caesar.” But the Berlinale has always been the most engagé of the world’s film festivals and this year’s selection also reflects some of the weightier issues in Europe today: immigration and refugees.

headline: Robert Mapplethorpe: In Search of Perfection
text: A two-part show of Mapplethorpe’s work reveals an artist who pursued perfection from his models, subjects and even his prints.

headline: Yes, We Do Eat More Soup When We’re Sick
text: When two companies matched their data, they found the correlation.

headline: Robert Mapplethorpe: In Search of Perfection
text: How should we think about the work of Robert Mapplethorpe today — post-sadomasochism, beyond the culture wars and after the first wave of the AIDS epidemic? What does Robert Mapplethorpe have left for us?

headline: Outrage Over an Italian Student’s Murder in Egypt
text: Italy is in an uproar over the torture and murder in Egypt of Giulio Regeni, a 28-year-old Italian doctoral student at Cambridge University who disappeared in Cairo on Jan. 25 and whose half-naked, battered body was found in a ditch Feb. 3, hours after Italian officials appealed directly to President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt for help in locating the missing student.

headline: Hillary, Bernie and History
text: It’s a sad time for Hillary Clinton’s fans. Well, I guess that’s obvious, since she got clobbered in New Hampshire. But it’s the way she went down that was particularly painful. Bernie Sanders got more than half the women’s vote, mainly because younger women raced off to his corner in droves.

headline: All Praise the Women of Menopause
text: For some women, menopause is no big deal. Some say they barely notice it. My mother, long ago, described her menopause this way: “My periods just started gettin’ lighter and lighter, and my harmones  settled down, and then one day … pfft! It was over.”

headline: The G.O.P. Created Donald Trump
text: The betting markets now say that the most likely Republican nominee for president is a man who mocks women, insults Latinos, endorses war crimes like torture, denounces party icons and favors barring people from the United States based on their religion.

headline: The Court Blocks Efforts to Slow Climate Change
text: The Supreme Court’s extraordinary decision on Tuesday to temporarily block the Obama administration’s effort to combat global warming by regulating emissions from power plants was deeply disturbing on two fronts.

headline: Let’s End the Peril of a Nuclear Winter
text: IN the early 1980s, American and Russian scientists working together outlined a stark vision of the Cold War future. In a battle between the two superpowers, smoke from fires ignited by nuclear explosions would be so dense that it would block out the sun, turning the earth cold, dark and dry, killing plants and preventing agriculture for at least a year.

headline: What Lies Ahead for Donald Trump
text: As the campaign moves to larger states, and includes election days with multiple contests, how can Trump rise to the challenge?

headline: How Smartphones Are Killing Off the Fashion Show
text: The first big show of New York Fashion Week will not take place in a traditional space. It is not even on the traditional schedule, which lists roughly 150 shows stretching from Thursday morning to next Thursday night.

headline: What Bernie Sanders Needs to Carry His Success Into Other States
text: The Bernie Sanders coalition is starting to look interesting.

headline: Tracing the Bishops’ Culpability in the Child Abuse Scandal
text: Pope Francis’ commission on the clergy’s sexual violation of children had a timely private screening in Rome last week of “Spotlight,” the Oscar-nominated film about the pedophilia scandal in Boston. The film offers the Vatican, if it will listen, an emphatic lesson in accountability. It dramatizes the decision by The Boston Globe to do more than enumerate the scope of the scandal by reporting on cases involving scores of abusive priests. The scandal was tracked up the church hierarchy to Cardinal Bernard Law, who eventually had to resign his leadership when the news media, not the church, documented his role as a protector of abusive priests.

headline: News Q’s | Brazilians Shrug Off Zika Fears to Revel in Carnival Fun
text: The following lesson activities are based on the article “Brazilians Shrug Off Zika Fears to Revel in Carnival Fun.”

headline: Rachel McAdams’s Red Carpet Looks
text: The more avant-garde the outfit, the sharper Ms. McAdams looks.

headline: Rachel McAdams Tries Short Hair, Sheer Textures and Elie Saab
text: Rachel McAdams, 37, is perhaps best known for her lead roles in lighthearted films like “Mean Girls” and “The Notebook,” yet she’s tackled meatier fare recently: as a boxer’s doomed wife in “Southpaw” and a hard-hitting reporter in “Spotlight,” for which she has been nominated for her first Academy Award.

headline: Fashion Week: Happy Kanye West Day
text: Did you feel the slight tremble rippling through the cosmos this morning? Did you puzzle for an extra minute over which shirt to wear?

headline: Room for the Dog on the Upper East Side
text: After Emilie Gossiaux  graduated from  Cooper Union in 2014, she started interning at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on the Upper East Side.

headline: Student Question | How Much Do You Worry About Taking the SAT or ACT?
text: The SAT has gotten a major redesign, and many high school students are nervous.

headline: The Road to the Top of the World
text: In the Arctic, roads are magical. They appear in the fall and melt in the spring. Others, buckled by permafrost, undulate in the snow. Many are invisible to the naked eye — caribou migration routes that exist only by instinct. During the sunless, frigid winter, the Arctic Ocean becomes one vast road for polar bears and snowmobiles.

headline: In the Democratic Debate, Here’s What to Look For
text: Here’s our coverage of the sixth Democratic debate, and our live fact checks.

headline: Oaxaca’s Native Maize Embraced by Top Chefs in U.S. and Europe
text: SANTA ANA ZEGACHE, Mexico — In the birthplace of maize, nobody seemed to need Juan Velasco’s crop.

headline: Bernie Sanders Intrigues South Carolina Town That Loves Hillary Clinton
text: ORANGEBURG, S.C. — When Helen Duley was asked whom she would vote for in the South Carolina primary, she answered as if the very question were absurd.

headline: Britain, Better Off Out of Europe
text: Valentine’s Day is the traditional feast of love. But this February, Britons are more fixated on a political divorce.

headline: How the ‘Dirt Cure’ Can Make for Healthier Families
text: Dr. Maya Shetreat-Klein has a message for the parents of small children: Don’t be afraid of dirt.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know to start the day.

headline: A Doctor in the Neighborhood
text: One of the main premises of health care reform is that everybody needs to have a primary care doctor, ideally in the community. I happen to live right near my clinic, so I often see many of my patients on the street. This can be good or bad. There have been innumerable times when a meeting on the street has added an important element to medical care — reminders of missed visits, lost prescriptions, continuing issues that would not have otherwise made it to my office.
