text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall/Winter 2016 Fashion Week in New York.

headline: A Remedial Lesson in Republican History
text: When key Republicans refused earlier this month to schedule hearings with the White House budget director on the president’s new budget, the move was widely and correctly seen as churlish and childish.

headline: Adi Rukun, Neither Silent Nor Intimidated
text: There was a getaway car waiting outside. His family kept bags packed, ready to flee. And a fixer was on standby at the airport, waiting to book last-minute tickets if the need for escape should arise. Those precautions, among others, were taken by the filmmakers of the Oscar-nominated documentary “The Look of Silence” to ensure that its subject, Adi Rukun, remained safe during production.

headline: Harry Reid Says Alan Grayson Should Drop Senate Bid
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the Democratic leader, on Friday called for Representative Alan Grayson to drop his bid for the Senate, saying Mr. Grayson’s actions as a hedge fund manager “aren’t just disgraceful to the Democratic Party; they disgrace the halls of Congress.”

headline: Apple and Dr. Dre Are Said to Be Planning an Original TV Show
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple is working on an original television show with Dr. Dre, the co-founder of Beats Music and an Apple executive, according to a person with knowledge of the project.

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing: Hillary Clinton, Kanye West, Syria
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Republicans Fire Up Immigration Talk Heading Into South Carolina
text: MYRTLE BEACH, S.C. — The Republican presidential race has erupted in an incendiary new round of attacks over immigration, laying the groundwork in South Carolina for a monthslong fight that is likely to amplify hard-line talk about border security and migrants before a national audience.

headline: 36 Preguntas para enamorarse de cualquier persona
text: Hace más de 20 años, el psicólogo Arthur Aron logró que dos extraños se enamoraran en su laboratorio con estas 36 preguntas. ¿Te atreves?

headline: Slideshow: Off The Runway
text: Scenes from the fashion shows during day two of New York Fashion Week.

headline: Porn Star From a Pulled Ted Cruz Ad Is the Chatter at Bob Jones University
text: GREENVILLE, S.C. — In a corner of Bob Jones University, the evangelical institution where presidential candidates have long gathered to highlight their faith, Senator Ted Cruz stared into the cameras to answer the question that had almost certainly never been posed inside these halls.

headline: Prepare for ‘Guerrilla Warfare’ With Zika-Carrying Mosquitoes, Experts Warn
text: SAVANNAH, Ga. — It was standing room only at the annual conference of the American Mosquito Control Association this week.

headline: A Valentine’s Date Idea for Astronomy-Loving Early Birds
text: Those who are looking for an unusual Valentine’s Day activity may want to take advantage of the narrowing window of opportunity to see five planets align. This time-lapse video, captured on Jan. 28, gives a sense of what is possible for those who rise very early — or stay up very late.

headline: Meet the People Who Went to Kanye West’s Yeezy Season 3 Extravaganza
text: Fans of fashion and music discussed what they're wearing, how much they love Kanye and how they managed to get tickets.

headline: Maryland University Reinstates Two Faculty Members Amid Outcry
text: The president of Mount St. Mary’s University in Maryland has reinstated two professors who were fired this week for what the administration called disloyalty, after the dismissals were widely denounced by advocates of academic and journalistic freedom and led to a faculty vote demanding his resignation.

headline: Anxiety Rises in Mexico as the Peso Tumbles
text: MEXICO CITY — The voluble talk-show host Andrea Legarreta broke from her routine of celebrity chatter and household tips recently to give her television viewers an impromptu lesson in global economics and the Mexican peso.

headline: How Ute Lemper, German Chanteuse, Spends Her Sundays
text: With her sultry stage persona and “sharp vocal claws,” as a review in The New York Times put it, the German chanteuse Ute Lemper doesn’t project the vibe of an Upper West Side mom. But on Sundays — when she’s not presenting cabaret classics by Kurt Weill or her latest song cycle, “The 9 Secrets,” a setting of Paulo Coelho’s “Manuscripts Found in Accra” — she’s just that. “The rock-solid foundation of my life is my family, and I enjoy very much being with my kids and seeing them happy,” Ms. Lemper said, adding, “It’s only onstage that I am the glamorous lady.” Ms. Lemper, 52, lives in two apartments on different floors of a West 76th Street building with her husband, the percussionist and producer Todd Turkisher, 56; their children, Julian, 10, and Jonas, 4; and, when they are home from college, her two children from a previous marriage, Max, 21, and Stella, 19.

headline: Tommy Kelly, Who Played a Hollywood Tom Sawyer, Dies at 90
text: If you were a producer casting “The Adventures of Tom Sawyer,” that enduring study of small-town, Middle American life, where would you be least likely to look for your star?

headline: Fashion Week Today: Never Mind the Cold, It’s Always Sunny on Instagram
text: We’ll be bringing you highlights from the shows, from the extravaganzas to the scrappy upstarts.

headline: Friday Night Music: New Pornographers, Crash Years
text: I was thinking about the world economy, and realized this was running through my head:

headline: البؤس الجنسيّ في العالم العربيّ
text: حاضرٌ غائبٌ هو الجنس، لا بل حاضرٌ ومؤثّرٌ في كلّ ما لا يذكر. الجنس في كلّ مكان، حضوره طاغٍ، خاصّة بعد الموت.

headline: Strange Fascinations in a Kitsch Hideaway
text: A bar in Chinatown is a ramshackle retreat full of psychedelic charm.

headline: At a Chinatown Bar, Libations Sipped by the Light of Disco Balls
text: Trung Trang sat in his favorite booth at 169 Bar on East Broadway with his friend Allison Clark on a Saturday night last month. It was the night of the season’s first blizzard, and though Ms. Clark lived nearby, he had braved the trip to Chinatown from South Williamsburg, on foot. He was ready for a drink. A hodgepodge of disco balls, lasers and lanterns threw seizure-inducing hues of yellow, magenta and green onto their faces.

headline: Drew Lewis, Transportation Secretary During Air Controllers’ Strike, Dies at 84
text: Drew Lewis, who as transportation secretary under Ronald Reagan in the early 1980s led contract negotiations with the air traffic controllers’ union and, when many of its members went on strike, put together a temporary system to keep planes in the air, died on Wednesday in Prescott, Ariz. He was 84.

headline: Two-Thirds of the World Faces Severe Water Shortages
text: About four billion people, or two-thirds of the world’s population, face severe water shortages during at least one month every year, far more than was previously thought, according to Arjen Y. Hoekstra, a professor of water management at the University of Twente in the Netherlands.

headline: Recalling the Past Lives of an East Village Bathhouse
text: A recent article about the Russian and Turkish Baths, a 124-year-old bathhouse on East 10th Street that thrives despite competition from more luxurious spots like Spa Castle, examined the baths’ odd business arrangement: For more than two decades, the two owners have split the business, operating it on alternate weeks.

headline: Leading a 21st-Century ‘21’ Club
text: The venerable “21” Club on West 52nd Street is famous — notorious, even — for its speakeasy heritage and its history of well-known, well-lubricated regulars.

headline: Teatum Jones Wins the International Woolmark Prize
text: In 1954, two fashion world up-and-comers were honored by the International Wool Secretariat for their work in women’s wear. Karl Lagerfeld, 21 at the time, won a prize for coats, and Yves Saint Laurent, 18, was rewarded for dress design. The designers Hubert de Givenchy and Pierre Balmain were among the judges bestowing the honors.

headline: Take Me to the Pilot
text: There’s no mistaking the Intrepid Sea, Air and Space Museum among the recreational boats, yachts and water taxis anchored at the piers along the Hudson River’s Manhattan docks. It’s the aircraft carrier next to the space shuttle and the submarine.

headline: Cosby Appeal Filed to Prevent Sexual Assault Case Prosecution
text: Bill Cosby’s lawyers on Friday appealed a decision made by a judge in a Pennsylvania court last week that allowed prosecutors to proceed with a criminal sexual assault case against him.

headline: At Yonkers Brewing Company, Beer Steeped in Local Pride
text: Until about a year ago, the name most associated with beer in Yonkers was probably that of the notorious racketeer Dutch Schultz, whose criminal domain once included a brewery in the city.

headline: Jake Page, Editor Who Made Science Accessible, Dies at 80
text: Jake Page, an editor and columnist at Smithsonian magazine who brought the wonders of science to a general audience in dozens of books, and who channeled his interest in the Indians of the American Southwest into a series of popular mystery novels, died on Wednesday at his home in Lyons, Colo. He was 80.

headline: New Donald Trump Ad Highlights Father of Teenager Killed by Illegal Immigrant
text: Abandoning a plan to run strictly positive ads in South Carolina, Donald J. Trump’s campaign released one that focused on the 2008 murder of a black teenage athlete in Los Angeles by an illegal immigrant.

headline: Review: Beneath the Rafters of the Barn, Steak and Seafood
text: Entering a new restaurant, you react to certain details semiconsciously, décor features that skew your affections one way or another. The first thing I noticed at the Barn was the colored lights. Backlit areas glowed pink, yellow or green; a wooden lattice enclosed false marble panels that were lighted a luminous aqua from within. Wild, Gorgon-like chandeliers glimmered blue and yellow overhead. There was a vaguely disco-like quality to it all. Uh-oh, I thought.

headline: Georgia: State to Pay Transgender Inmate
text: The State Department of Corrections has agreed to pay a settlement of more than $250,000 to Ashley Diamond, the transgender woman who sued officials last year for failing to provide her necessary medical treatment and safekeeping during her incarceration. Ms. Diamond, a nonviolent offender who was housed in male prisons until her release in August, alleged that she was raped multiple times and that she was denied hormone therapy until the Department of Justice intervened in her case and The New York Times wrote about it. As result of her federal lawsuit, Georgia changed its approach to transgender inmates and dozens have started receiving hormones, the Southern Poverty Law Center said Friday.

headline: Review: The Stockton Inn, After a Revamp, Adopts a Modern Menu
text: After buying the business in 2012, the owner shut the banquet and hotel business to focus on the restaurant and tavern, following with a renovation.

headline: Michigan: Snyder Will Testify on Poisoned Water
text: Gov. Rick Snyder will testify before a congressional committee on the water crisis in Flint, he said on Friday. In a statement, Mr. Snyder, left, said that he had asked Representative Jason Chaffetz of Utah, chairman of the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee, for the “opportunity” to speak about the lead contamination that occurred in the Flint water supply in 2014 and 2015. Mr. Chaffetz has not set a date for the hearing, but said that six other witnesses were invited. They include Susan Hedman, a former regional administrator for the Environmental Protection Agency who resigned last week; Darnell Earley, a former emergency manager of Flint; Dayne Walling, a former mayor of Flint; and Gina McCarthy, the E.P.A. administrator. The witnesses “will shed light on many of our remaining questions and help us propose reforms to the authorizing committees,” Mr. Chaffetz said in a statement.

headline: Syria Truce Deal Makes Aid a Political Tool, Critics Say
text: UNITED NATIONS — Leaders of humanitarian aid organizations have, over the last few months, repeatedly implored the warring parties in Syria and their backers not to use the delivery of food and medicine as a bargaining chip in their negotiations about war and peace.

headline: Review: At ToA, a Family’s Latest Foray Into Asian Fusion
text: Last September, ToA Asian Fusion became one of the newest fusion restaurants — and there are many from which to choose — to open on Long Island. Located opposite the Paramount theater in Huntington, it is owned by members of the Chen family, who also own MoCA Asian Bistro in Woodbury, Hewlett and Forest Hills, Queens, and MoCA Express in Inwood.

headline: Brian Moynihan, Bank of America Chief, Got 23% Pay Raise in 2015
text: Bank of America gave its chief executive, Brian T. Moynihan, a pay package last year that was 23 percent larger than in 2014, as the big bank generated higher profits and put its mortgage problems squarely behind it.

headline: Art and Ceremony Intertwine at Hosftra University African Exhibit
text: While doing research for the exhibition “Africa: Sub-Saharan Diversity” at Hofstra University Museum, its curator, Karen T. Albert, wondered about the identification of one major object.

headline: Bill Richardson Aids Effort to Free Student Held in North Korea
text: Gov. John Kasich of Ohio has asked former Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico, a veteran diplomat and North Korea troubleshooter, to help in the effort to free an Ohioan arrested by the North Korean authorities six weeks ago, Mr. Kasich’s spokesman said Friday.

headline: While You Were Sleeping, They Made Art
text: It was 3 a.m. and Alexandra Rutsch Brock couldn’t sleep. She was scrolling through her Facebook news feed when she was struck by an image of an abstract painting posted by Julia Schwartz. “I fell in love with it,” Ms. Brock said.

headline: Review: In ‘Nureyev’s Eyes,’ a Bond Between a Painter and a Dancer
text: An unlikely but real friendship that developed between Rudolf Nureyev, the legendary Russian dancer, and Jamie Wyeth, the American realist painter, is imaginatively dramatized by David Rush in “Nureyev’s Eyes,” his two-character play at the George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick.

headline: Texas Panel Calls for an End to Criminal IDs via Bite Mark
text: An influential scientific commission in Texas called Friday for a halt in the use of bite-mark identifications in criminal trials, concluding that the validity of the technique has not been scientifically established.

headline: ‘The Moors’ at Yale Rep: Flights of Fancy and Tales of Deceit
text: A mastiff and a hen came to me in my sleep the other night, visitors from the play I had just seen in New Haven. I wonder if the writer Jen Silverman has had the same experience, because her inspired new play, “The Moors,” rolls out like the stuff of dreams, with telling passages heightened by surrealistic flights of fancy — including that mastiff and hen in an archetypally pleasing, you-really-ought-to-see-this parable.

headline: Stranded at the Border
text: For Syrians fleeing airstrikes in Aleppo Province and hoping to find refuge in Turkey, it remains to be seen what the recent cease-fire agreement means. Most of them are still stuck at the border.

headline: American Marathoners Can Reach the Olympics One Way: Going the Distance
text: LOS ANGELES — America’s top runners will gather on Saturday for the highest-stakes long-distance event in the nation: the Olympic marathon trials.

headline: Creations That Capture Our Imaginations
text: While today’s investment on infrastructure seems to prioritize repair, there are inspiring works to restore our faith in the power of great projects.

headline: Many Asians Express Dismay and Frustration After Liang Verdict
text: As the jury read the verdict — guilty — in the manslaughter trial of a New York City police officer whose gunshot into the stairwell of a public-housing building killed an unarmed man, the officer, Peter Liang, crumpled in his seat in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, his face falling into his hands.

headline: What Happened to the Great Urban Design Projects?
text: On any given day, painters are repainting some part of the [Golden Gate] bridge. They use 10,000 gallons of paint a year. It is crazy that people repaint a bridge all year … The Golden Gate Bridge, which is orange, is the best-known and best-loved bridge in the world. It is best known because it is bold and courageous and unusual and even strange. It is best loved because it is bold and courageous and unusual and even strange.

headline: In Little-Man Era, Four Big Men Will Test Their Skills
text: In the early days of the N.B.A., big men ruled the league. Giants with names like Mikan, Russell and Chamberlain dominated the paint, leaving smaller players to scrap for tougher shots outside.

headline: John Kasich Has Kinds Words for Chris Christie, but No Talk of Endorsement
text: COLUMBIA, S.C. — After winning over one of Gov. Chris Christie’s leading supporters, Gov. John Kasich of Ohio offered kind words for Mr. Christie on Friday, but said he had not asked him for an endorsement.

headline: Indie Bookstores Are Back, With a Passion
text: The decades of trauma suffered by independent neighborhood bookstores — damage from bargain megastores, the ascension of the e-book and Amazon’s flash delivery of cut-rate reading — hardly hindered Chris Doeblin’s search for the right place to open his fourth independent bookstore in Manhattan.

headline: With a Slur for Ted Cruz, Donald Trump Further Splits Voters
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. — Donald J. Trump has defied conservative orthodoxy on policy, shunned traditional politicking and even insulted prisoners of war and the disabled, sacrosanct constituencies that other candidates would no more slur than they would accept a bag of cash with cameras rolling.

headline: Another Season Gone Awry Hangs Over Carmelo Anthony, the All-Star
text: TORONTO — Carmelo Anthony, surrounded by many of his closest friends ahead of yet another appearance in the All-Star Game, said he was doing his best to forget about his full-time job, at least for a few fun-filled days.

headline: F.E.C. Tells Sanders Campaign That Some Donors May Have Given Too Much
text: The Federal Election Commission has asked the presidential campaign of Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont to re-examine contributions from more than a hundred donors who appear to have given more than the legally permissible amount.

headline: Republicans, Widows and Porn
text: You can’t possibly say it’s been a bad week when Ted Cruz has a problem with a soft-core porn actress.

headline: When Conditions Become Terrifying, an Elite Contest Can Proceed
text: HALF MOON BAY, Calif. — The veteran big-wave surfer Ken Collins thought he was going to drown. Safely alive a few minutes later, standing on a small dock with gauze stuffed into a left ear that had a ruptured drum, he was out of the Titans of Mavericks.

headline: Takata Discarded Evidence of Airbag Ruptures as Early as 2000
text: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — As the safety crisis surrounding Takata’s airbags that are prone to rupture has mushroomed, the Japanese auto supplier has insisted that the propellant in its airbags is safe.

headline: Sophie Theallet: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Ms. Theallet presents her fall collection.

headline: Last Militants Who Occupied Oregon Wildlife Refuge Appear in Federal Court
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — The standoff at a remote federal wildlife refuge that pitted armed militants against law enforcement officials began its next chapter in a federal courtroom here on Friday, a day after the final occupiers of the refuge surrendered. But the tough talk and the posturing about the government’s powers to oppress — the occupation group’s main ideological thread — continued in the street outside the courthouse, undiminished but now in a new setting.

headline: Prisoners Exonerated, Prosecutors Exposed
text: In 2015, 149 people convicted of crimes large and small — from capital murder to burglary — were exonerated. It is the highest yearly total since this grim form of record-keeping began, in 1989.

headline: Mrs. Clinton’s Mixed Immigration Message
text: In Thursday night’s Democratic debate, Hillary Clinton defended her past statements that Central American migrant children needed to be sent home from the border to “send a message” to other families: Don’t come.

headline: Glenwood Management, Developer Cited in Corruption Cases, Settles Disability Lawsuit
text: Glenwood Management, a politically influential developer of luxury high-rise apartment buildings in Manhattan that figured in two recent public corruption trials, has agreed to settle a civil rights lawsuit that claimed three of its residential complexes violated the Fair Housing Act’s requirements for people with disabilities.

headline: Monse: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Laura Kim and Fernando Garcia, alumni of Oscar de la Renta, present their second collection.

headline: Dealing With Space and Time
text: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This one by Peter Wentz was a fun solve and not terribly difficult, although I did jump around quite a bit to fill everything in.

headline: Earth, Wind & Fire’s Musical Reintegration
text: THIS past weekend, radio stations across the country honored Maurice White, a founder of, singer for and driving force behind the band Earth, Wind & Fire, who died on Feb. 4, by playing marathons of his music. On Sunday, Mr. White and his band will be awarded the Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award, joining musicians like Frank Sinatra, Ella Fitzgerald, Johnny Cash and the Beatles.

headline: U.S. Plans to Resume Commercial Flights to Cuba This Year
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Tuesday plans to complete an agreement with Cuba that will allow scheduled commercial flights to resume this year between the United States and the island nation for the first time in more than 50 years.

headline: Head of Sweden’s Karolinska Institute Quits Over Transplant Scandal
text: The top administrator of one of Europe’s leading medical universities resigned on Friday, becoming the latest casualty of a scandal involving a prominent surgeon in the field of regenerative medicine.

headline: Ah, Spring! What Could Go Wrong?
text: The best part of spring training, which opens for most teams by the end of this week, is the optimism. Every team’s best-case scenario is still in play. Whatever jersey a player wears, he can slip it on with pride and channel his inner Lloyd Christmas, the naïve dreamer from “Dumb and Dumber.”

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “In the wake of unfortunately so many deaths of unarmed black men, some cops gotta hang. The sentiment in the Asian community is: It’s easier to hang an Asian, because Asians, they don’t speak up.”

headline: Experts Discuss the Success Academy Video
text: A group of scholars shared their thoughts on effective teaching methods after watching a video of a teacher reacting to a student’s math mistake.

headline: Prostitute Found in Long Island Marsh in 2011 May Have Been Murdered, Pathologist Says
text: Shannan Gilbert had been missing for more than a year and a half when her remains were found in 2011 on Jones Beach Island, N.Y., in a marsh off an oceanside highway. Police officials in Suffolk County suspected at the time that Ms. Gilbert, 24, had drowned, and an autopsy by the county medical examiner left the cause of death undetermined.

headline: Syrian War Could Turn on the Battle for Aleppo
text: Russia is bombing rebel-held areas in Syria at a furious pace. That is giving the Syrian president, Bashar al-Assad, the upper hand. Meanwhile, critics accuse the United States of dithering.

headline: Readers Respond to Video of Success Academy Teacher’s Frustration With Student
text: “Didn’t Rutgers University fire its basketball coach for similar behavior?”

headline: On the Verge of Victory, the Rangers Let One Slip Away
text: A clash between the Rangers and the Los Angeles Kings stirs emotions for both squads.

headline: Yankees Settle With Closer Aroldis Chapman
text: The Yankees avoided arbitration with the newly acquired closer Aroldis Chapman and agreed to a one-year, $11.325 million contract. Chapman made $8.05 million last season, when he was 4-4 with 33 saves in 36 chances for the Cincinnati Reds.

headline: Corrections: February 13, 2016
text: THE ARTS

headline: What to Watch Saturday
text: The “Fast &” franchise goes airborne — and says farewell to Paul Walker — in “Furious 7.” “Meru” follows some fearless types up a stomach-turning blade of granite in the Himalayas. And Rebecca Hall and Jason Sudeikis spar alongside a couple of cute dogs in “Tumbledown.”

headline: North Korea Cancels Investigation Into Abductions of Japanese Citizens
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea has announced a halt to an investigation into the fate of Japanese citizens said to have been abducted by its agents decades ago, retaliating for sanctions Japan imposed this week after the North’s latest rocket launching.

headline: John Dickerson, Molded by News Legends, Hones His Skills at CBS
text: WASHINGTON — By the standards of Sunday morning news shows, the handoff of the anchor’s position on “Face the Nation” on CBS was really quite peaceful.

headline: Constant Tide of Migrants at Sea, and at Turkish Cemetery
text: IZMIR, Turkey — City workers shoveled dirt over the two coffins, one at a time, as an imam, in plaintive and meditative tones, sang prayers in Arabic.

headline: Gearing Up for the Cloud, AT&T Tells Its Workers: Adapt, or Else
text: DALLAS — Thirty-four years ago, Kevin Stephenson got his younger brother, Randall, a job with the telephone company.

headline: Layers a Ton, Loves Carolina Herrera
text: Name Kathleen Newman Bennetter

headline: Fashion Week: Saturday Is Church Day for Alexander Wang
text: Remember “Saturday”? That mythical day to sleep in, loll over coffee, maybe take in a movie? Try again next week. It’s New York Fashion Week, and the parade continues apace. Weekend or not, there’s a full day of shows ahead.

headline: The House D.J. of the Bernie Sanders Campaign
text: CONCORD, N.H. — Standing between a wall of retracted wooden bleachers and his turntables, Mel Sandico, a.k.a. Mel Cavaricci, a.k.a. D.J. Mel, looked up to survey the crowd filing into Senator Bernie Sanders’s New Hampshire victory party last Tuesday night.

headline: The New Celebrity Power Move: Keeping Secrets
text: The announcement of David Bowie’s death on Jan. 11 dealt a double blow. First was its finality. Then came the realization that barely anybody knew he had been sick, including an old ally like Brian Eno, with whom he had traded emails a week before.

headline: What Is Paul Rudnick Doing Writing Young Adult Fiction?
text: It didn’t take much to persuade Paul Rudnick to step inside P.S. 3 the other day to watch parents waiting to take their children home. After all, the gleefully transgressive humorist, who regularly launches little satirical missiles in The New Yorker, was about to publish his second young-adult novel. Observing a school pickup in his West Village neighborhood could be construed not so much as stalking as research, and also a good way to start this interview.

headline: Peggy Siegal Through the Years
text: Peggy Siegal, the omnipresent New York film publicist and event planner, remains Hollywood’s secret weapon in New York.

headline: Peggy Siegal, Best Hostess in a Supporting Role
text: Hunched over her saumon marine, Peggy Siegal, the omnipresent New York film publicist and event planner, was sitting between Oliver Stone and Anne Hearst at the Manhattan restaurant La Grenouille last October, talking about the night she tried to ascend to the throne of England.

headline: China’s Exodus of Capital
text: As the economy stumbles, individuals and companies are pulling money out of China en masse, leaving the government scrambling to limit the outflows.

headline: Chinese Start to Lose Confidence in Their Currency
text: HONG KONG — As the Chinese economy stumbles, wealthy families are increasingly trying to move large sums of money out of the country, worried that the value of the currency will fall and their savings will be worth less.

headline: Rescue Efforts End in Taiwanese City Struck by Quake
text: HONG KONG — Rescue efforts ended on Saturday at the site of a 17-story apartment complex in Tainan, in southwestern Taiwan that collapsed in an earthquake a week earlier, as search crews pulled the last of 114 bodies from the rubble.

headline: 1941: Germany Reported to Send Art to U.S. for Sale
text: LONDON — Fourteen world-famous paintings, having a total value of more than £2,000,000 ($8,000,000), are on their way from Germany to the United States by way of Siberia and the Pacific to be sold to bolster the Nazis’ dollar balances, the British Ministry of Economic Warfare said today [Feb. 12].

headline: The Week on Instagram
text: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took our followers from New Hampshire to San Pedro la Laguna in Guatemala.

headline: ‘Moonshot’ Metaphor on Cancer Is a Failure to Communicate
text: Can we agree to stop calling it the cancer moonshot?

headline: Royal Caribbean’s ‘Smartship’ Avoids a Titanic Situation
text: “It’s the most technologically advanced cruise ship in the world,” the Royal Caribbean sales agent told me over the phone when I booked a trip aboard the Anthem of the Seas, the cruise line’s flashy new megaship, reported to be the third-largest cruise vessel ever built. “It’s what we call a ‘smartship.’ ”

headline: A Little Variety
text: A LITTLE VARIETY PUZZLES — This week’s puzzles include:

headline: AT&T’s History of Invention and Breakups
text: AT&T, once known informally as Ma Bell, is a storied American brand that goes back under a succession of names to the late 19th century, after Alexander Graham Bell invented the telephone.

headline: Farhad and Mike’s Week in Tech: Rethinking Twitter, and a Hurdle for Facebook
text: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

headline: In Met’s ‘Manon Lescaut,’ Classic Love Story Gets Noir Twist
text: With courage, determination and a healthy measure of ambition, the tenor Roberto Alagna rescued the Metropolitan Opera’s new production of Puccini’s “Manon Lescaut,” which opened on Friday night. The production was thrown into crisis last month when Jonas Kaufmann, the most sought-after tenor in opera, withdrew from the entire run because of an illness he did not specify. Hoping to line up a star tenor replacement as des Grieux, the Met’s general manager Peter Gelb turned to Mr. Alagna, who had never sung the role. With just 16 days to prepare a major Puccini part for an important new production, Mr. Alagna, who had been appearing in “Pagliacci” at the Met, agreed to take it on.

headline: Falling Asleep to Grenades: Mexicans Tell Pope How They Live
text: A young mother living in one of Mexico’s most violent states said she had gone to sleep with the sound of grenades and guns outside her home. Another woman, in Mexico City, wrote that kidnappings had become so commonplace, they are spoken of like the weather. Many others complained about living under a corrupt government.

headline: Jason Wu Takes On Red Velvet
text: The designer’s fall/winter collection featured subtle plays on texture, from wool and lace to swingy beaded fringe.

headline: John Kasich Recalls Parents’ Death in Appeal to Religious Voters
text: ORANGEBURG, S.C. — About 15 minutes into his stump speech at a barbecue restaurant here on Friday, Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio turned to discuss “the glue that keeps us all together.”

headline: Dreams of Creating a Duplex
text: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: How to Watch the Republican Debate
text: Join us for our coverage of the Republican debate.

headline: At Chromat, a Powerful Cast in Electroluminescent Wares
text: The designer Becca McCharen presented athleticwear, lingerie and dresses — some of which lit up.

headline: Taliban, Using Humvees Stolen From Army, Attack Check Post
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — In an attack using a tactic long feared by Afghan officials, Taliban suicide bombers riding in two stolen Afghan Army Humvees clashed with security forces on Saturday in southern Helmand Province, killing six security personnel at a checkpoint, Afghan officials said.

headline: Even in Impersonations, Donald Trump Likes What He Sees of Himself
text: There is only one Donald J. Trump, and yet as he has continued his campaign for the Republican presidential nomination, there has been a groundswell of would-be Donald Trumps — who are imitating him for laughs.

headline: Francis Admonishes Bishops in Mexico to ‘Begin Anew’
text: MEXICO CITY — In a stinging rebuke to Mexico‘s church hierarchy, Pope Francis on Saturday told bishops that they had lost their way in “gossip” and “intrigue,” and challenged them to “begin anew” and tend to the church’s worshipers.

headline: After Stormy Royal Caribbean Cruise, Seeking Answers
text: Royal Caribbean’s Anthem of the Seas vessel returned earlier than scheduled to its port of origin, Cape Liberty, N.J., on Wednesday evening after facing 120 m.p.h. winds on Sunday off Cape Hatteras, N.C. The cruise ship departed last Saturday and was on its way to a port call in Port Canaveral, Fla., as part of a seven-day trip to the Bahamas when it ran into the storm.

headline: Your Daily Fashion Week Recap for Saturday, Feb. 13
text: 1. The Chromat show was lit — in the truest sense, with certain garments incorporating wirelessly triggered lights. “It’s all body-based,” said the designer Becca McCharen of her fall/winter 2016 collection. “We’re definitely interested in presenting the body in new juxtapositions.” For sportswear, dresses and underpinnings, she took inspiration from conceptual artists like Dan Flavin and Robert Irwin. See more scenes from Friday’s shows.

headline: Rihanna’s First Collection for Puma
text: Photos from the show.

headline: Roots of the Recent Violence Between Israelis and Palestinians
text: The geography of the issues surrounding the ongoing violence.

headline: Fired for Cursing on the Job, Testing the Limits of Labor Law
text: Little did the managers of a Hooters restaurant realize that a bikini contest they sponsored in 2013 would end up testing the limits of labor law.

headline: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — Solving a Puns and Anagrams puzzle feels, to me at least, kind of like cheating on a diet after a full week of eating only healthy food. It’s not that the daily crosswords aren’t fun, because they are. But PandAs feel more like the doughnuts of the puzzle world. They’re light, they’re entertaining and they sometimes have a sugary glaze and sprinkles on top. [Just … no. — Ed.]

headline: Rihanna on Her New See-Through, Stiletto-Heeled Puma Collection: ‘I Tried to Push the Envelope a Little Bit’
text: “I’m on cloud nine,” said Rihanna, the pop star turned brand ambassador and women’s creative director of Puma, after her first fashion show for the label. An hour earlier, her first full collection, a street-inspired, Japanophile departure from Puma’s usual sport-ready performance wear, had come down an L.E.D. runway to a crowd that included Naomi Campbell, Chris Rock, Travis Scott, Foxy Brown and Young Thug.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: A Tired View Of Newton And His Role

headline: Small Gifts to Bernie Sanders Challenge Hillary Clinton Fund-Raising Model
text: In the back of a Concord, N.H., school gymnasium, as Bernie Sanders gave a triumphant speech after winning the New Hampshire Democratic primary, Kenneth Pennington stood staring at his smartphone, watching the numbers climb. Mr. Pennington, 24, the campaign’s digital director, saw thousands of people cramming onto the Sanders website at once, frantically trying to donate to his campaign. In one minute alone, 2,689 people had donated an average of $34.

headline: Rihanna Brings Smoke, Mirrors and Transparent Tops to Wall Street For Her First Puma Collection
text: Trees, stark and faux in black and white, grew out of the floor and into a ceiling tiled with mirrors. At 23 Wall Street, the former House of Morgan had been converted into a forest from a digital-age fever dream — the Black Forest, one might almost say, since the stage had been set by Puma, the German sportswear behemoth, for the showing of its new collection designed by the pop idol Rihanna.

headline: Dividends, Wall Street’s Battered Status Symbol
text: Coca-Cola pays steady dividends. It has done so since 1920. In fact, it has increased dividends in each of the last 50 years.

headline: Mark Dunkerley: Where You Can See Airplanes and the Aloha Spirit
text: 1. Project runway

headline: Henry Kissinger: Sage or Pariah?
text: After Thursday's Hillary Clinton-Bernie Sanders debate, the former diplomat returns to the spotlight.

headline: A Monthly Gift That Keeps on Not Giving
text: The Haggler does not go camping, nor does he hike. He should probably claim that he is too busy protecting consumers to engage in an activity as frivolous as tromping through the woods and gaping at trees. But it is simpler than that. He doesn’t like the woods. He figures that his ancestors spent a lot of time in the woods wishing that they lived somewhere else. Like a city.

headline: AT&T’s Strategy Is One Part Innovation, One Part Inspiration
text: SAN FRANCISCO — AT&T is pulling out the stops to persuade people about futuristic plans for its network — and itself. Sometimes that means pushing new technology, and sometimes it means that executives show a little vulnerability, something rare in corporate America.

headline: Catholic Leaders Say Zika Doesn’t Change Ban on Contraception
text: As the Zika virus spreads in Latin America, Catholic leaders are warning women against using contraceptives or having abortions, even as health officials in some countries are advising women not to get pregnant because of the risk of birth defects.

headline: The Commute of the Future? Ford Is Working on It
text: On a brisk October day in Chicago, a few employees from the design firm Ideo left their office and headed to Knife & Tine, a restaurant about four miles away. The goal, besides lunch, was to complete the journey within 45 minutes, on a budget of just $10 for the whole group, all while carrying bulky shopping bags.

headline: Rebecca Minkoff: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Ms. Minkoff, the latest to adapt to the see now buy now experiment, presents her latest looks.

headline: At Rally in Rivals’ Home State, Donald Trump Boasts of Florida Jobs Record
text: TAMPA, Fla. — With Florida’s March 15 primary looming, Donald J. Trump drew another of his massive crowds Friday night in Tampa, where he boasted of his résumé as a developer and job creator in Florida.

headline: Scenes From Last Night’s Dazed x Calvin Klein Party
text: Last night, as polar gusts persisted outside, the Calvin Klein and Dazed party — a celebration for the magazine’s 100 pop culture disruptors — raged in Bushwick. Inside, projectors bathed two rooms in gray (one wall showed a triptych of black and white video footage featuring the Dazed 100 recipients; on another, their names flashed at a spastic clip).

headline: Inside the Dazed and Calvin Klein Party
text: Revelers braved harsh temperatures to attend the fashion week party in Bushwick.

headline: War, Disease and Scandals Test Soccer Chief in Sierra Leone
text: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone — For the last two and a half years, Isha Johansen has been throwing punches, both real and metaphorical, as the president of Sierra Leone’s soccer association, one of just a handful of women in the world to have ever held such a post.

headline: What to Look For in the Republican Debate
text: Join us for our coverage of the Republican debate.

headline: Suno: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Max Osterweis and Erin Beatty, the finalists in the 2012 Vogue/CFDA fund, present their fall designs.

headline: Facing Allies’ Doubt, John Kerry Voices Confidence in Syria Cease-Fire
text: MUNICH — Secretary of State John Kerry, facing both anger and skepticism from European allies about the willingness of the United States to intervene more deeply in the Syrian civil war, promised on Saturday to help close off the routes migrants were taking to Europe and warned Russia that its military effort to prop up President Bashar al-Assad of Syria would ultimately fail.

headline: Jets Will No Longer Get a Free Ride on Carbon Emissions
text: It has been almost 50 years since the federal government began setting standards for automobile emissions. It is also about a half-century since the introduction of wide-body jets set off a runaway expansion of the aviation industry. About 3.8 billion people are expected to fly this year, 50 times as many as 50 years ago — making planes the fastest-growing source of carbon dioxide emissions, although they have faced none of the limits set on cars or trucks. That is, until last week, when the International Civil Aviation Organization, a United Nations agency, finally proposed the first binding limits on aircraft emissions.

headline: The Orphaned ’90s
text: IN one theory of Hillary Clinton’s candidacy, before political reality intruded, she was going to have the best of two worlds.

headline: How We View Obesity
text: Readers discuss Americans’ obsession with weight and prejudices against “fat” people.

headline: Narcissism Is Increasing. So You’re Not So Special.
text: MY teenage son recently informed me that there is an Internet quiz to test oneself for narcissism. His friend had just taken it. “How did it turn out?” I asked. “He says he did great!” my son responded. “He got the maximum score!”

headline: When Hillary Clinton Killed Feminism
text: WASHINGTON — THE Clinton campaign is shellshocked over the wholesale rejection of Hillary by young women, younger versions of herself who do not relate to her.

headline: Are You a Toxic Waste Disposal Site?
text: EVEN if you’re not in Flint, Mich., there are toxic chemicals in your home. For that matter, in you.

headline: Fixing Our Broken Water Systems
text: Underneath America’s streets lies a network of pipes that is supposed to bring clean water into homes, schools and businesses. But the news of lead poisoning in Flint, Mich., and the emergence of similar problems in Sebring, Ohio, and other cities have revealed a shocking truth: Some of these systems are so old and poorly maintained that they have become a major hazard to human health.

headline: Time to Take North Korea Seriously
text: Since the first of the year, North Korea has conducted another nuclear weapons test and launched a satellite on a rocket. Both acts further advance North Korea’s quest to acquire the ability to fire a nuclear-armed missile against another country, while serving as a reminder of the world’s lamentable failure to shut the program down.

headline: Bill Cunningham | The Look
text: There’s an exhilaration to the opening of an international fashion season. The designer with the highest antennae will create, through clothes, the mirror image of our time. A look that defines a generation usually takes seven years to become visible. The rare exception: Christian Dior’s 1947 New Look, which arrived like a thunderclap. Shown here is the look that defined 2015: ankle boots, a long stretch of leg, a flowerlike blossom top and a fur pompom at the peak of knitted hats. Outside of this uniform, there were straws in the wind, above. Will shaping return to fashion through a cinched waist, a sculpted coat, a flared skirt? Or will it be an inflated silhouette, where the air between the cloth and the wearer creates the silhouette?

headline: Death, the Prosperity Gospel and Me
text: Durham, N.C. — ON a Thursday morning a few months ago, I got a call from my doctor’s assistant telling me that I have Stage 4 cancer. The stomach cramps I was suffering from were not caused by a faulty gallbladder, but by a massive tumor.

headline: Can Health Care Providers Afford to Be Ready for Disaster?
text: MORE than 200 people died in hospitals and nursing homes in Louisiana after Hurricane Katrina in 2005, leading to widespread agreement that health care preparedness in the United States needed dramatic improvement. One hospital, Memorial Medical Center, was so undone that two desperate doctors later said that they hastened the deaths of patients who had waited days in the heat for rescue.

headline: Amid Tension, Met and James Levine Mull Last Bow
text: The question of when and how to say farewell to a leader is one that bedevils all kinds of institutions, from Viacom, where the aging chairman Sumner M. Redstone recently stepped down under pressure, to the Denver Broncos, who will soon have to decide whether to ease out their quarterback, Peyton Manning, if he does not retire willingly.

headline: Not Their Mother’s Candidate
text: If, as we’ve all now heard, “there’s a special place in hell for women who don’t help each other,” then a room on the Upper East Side of Manhattan has long been a piece of feminist heaven. It’s the room that Gloria Steinem provided for years in her apartment as a residence for young women she mentored and encouraged and learned from.

headline: Nikki Silva
text: Nikki Silva is one half of the Peabody Award-winning Kitchen Sisters, creators of documentary-style programming for public radio and for podcasts.

headline: How New York Made Pre-K a Success
text: BORSCHT isn’t found on most prekindergarten menus, but it’s what the cooks were dishing up for the 35 children at Ira’s Daycare in Briarwood, Queens, on a recent school day. Many families in this neighborhood are Russian émigrés for whom borscht is a staple, but children from half a dozen countries, including a contingent from Bangladesh, are also enrolled here.

headline: The Love Story Primary
text: MY mom, Fran, is wise and warm and helpful in many ways, but she’s never been great at dispensing pithy nuggets of life wisdom. One year, for a Mother’s Day feature, a magazine editor asked me to tell her the best piece of advice my mother ever gave me. All I could come up with was, “Don’t pick it.”

headline: At U.S. Olympic Trials, Two Marathoners Use Teamwork to Become Teammates
text: LOS ANGELES — At the United States Olympic marathon trials on Saturday, the runners confirmed that women are far stronger when they stay in formation.

headline: Britain Aims to Strengthen North’s Cities
text: LIVERPOOL, England — London churns out so much wealth that its annual economic output is equal to Saudi Arabia’s. No other city in Britain comes close.

headline: The Strip
text: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: Hillary Clinton Emails Released by State Department
text: Three emails released by the State Department from Hillary Clinton’s private account were now considered “secret,” the government’s second-highest classification.

headline: More Hillary Clinton Emails Released, Including 3 Now ‘Secret’
text: WASHINGTON — The State Department released 551 more emails from the personal server of Hillary Clinton on Saturday, including 84 with some or all of the messages blocked out because they contained information that has now been deemed classified. Three of those are classified “secret.”

headline: Tibi: Fall 2016 RTW

text: Ms. Roche’s, a 2014 CFDA/Vogue fashion fund runner up, presents her latest looks.

headline: Mets’ Jenrry Mejia Is Said to Deny Doping Claims
text: Each time Mets pitcher Jenrry Mejia has tested positive for performance-enhancing drugs, he has declined to discuss the results or has maintained his innocence. Even after his third failed test in less than a year, which was announced Friday and resulted in a lifetime ban from Major League Baseball, Mejia appears to be sticking to the message that he has not used P.E.D.s.

headline: Bernie Sanders Tells Volunteers in Reno to Expect Victory in Nevada
text: RENO, Nev. — Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont told hundreds of volunteers gathered here on Saturday that his strong showings in Iowa and New Hampshire were not flukes.

headline: Man Arrested in Fatal Stabbing of Staten Island Woman and Her 2 Daughters
text: The suspect wanted in the stabbing at a Staten Island motel that left a homeless woman and two of her daughters dead was arrested and charged with murder on Saturday, the police said.

headline: Antonin Scalia, Justice on the Supreme Court, Dies at 79
text: Justice Antonin Scalia, whose transformative legal theories, vivid writing and outsize personality made him a leader of a conservative intellectual renaissance in his three decades on the Supreme Court, was found dead on Saturday at a resort in West Texas. He was 79.

headline: New Study Finds Persistent Peril from Urban Coal Soot in China and Indoor Smoke in India
text: The latest report on the “global burden of disease” finds air pollution caused the premature deaths of 5.5 million people in 2013, with China just ahead of India in deaths and the two countries together accounting for more than half the global total. The findings were released Friday by scientists at the University of British Columbia and discussed today at the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, in Washington.

headline: Caught Between Costly Alternatives, Ferguson Residents Worry About Its Fate
text: FERGUSON, Mo. — When the City Council took the defiant gamble last week of challenging parts of an agreement it had negotiated with the federal government to overhaul its Police Department and courts, it argued that the costs of the deal would drive the city into bankruptcy.

headline: The Death of Justice Scalia: Reactions and Analysis
text: Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia died on Saturday at a resort in Texas. His death quickly set off debate over a new nomination, with prominent Republicans calling for the next president to make a nomination. President Obama said he would nominate a new justice despite objections.

headline: All You Need
text: “Nothing you can know that isn’t knownNothing you can see that isn’t shownNowhere you can be that isn’t where you’re meant to beIt’s easy …” — The Beatles, “All You Need Is Love”

headline: A Tour of Rwanda, From Jungle to City
text: Rwanda, Jungle to City Gondwana Ecotours, founded by Jared Sternberg in 2013 when he was a law student at Tulane, has added Rwanda to its list of destinations. A highlight of the eight-day tour, departing from Kigali, is a trek into the jungle to view mountain gorillas, who live in a tropical rain forest in the Virunga Mountains. Guests also will have the chance to track chimpanzee and golden monkeys with a conservationist.

headline: Russian Orthodox Church Blocks Funeral for Last of Romanov Remains
text: MOSCOW — Ever since the remains of the last czar, Nicholas II, and most of his family were exhumed 25 years ago from a dirt road in the Urals, investigators, historians and surviving members of the Romanov dynasty have anticipated the day when all the murdered royals would be laid to rest.

headline: Erykah Badu’s Styling Debut
text: The R&B singer worked closely with the designer Kerby Jean-Raymond on his label Pyer Moss’s fall/winter show, which was presented this afternoon.

headline: At Pyer Moss, Erykah Badu Makes Her Styling Debut
text: For over a year, the men’s wear designer Kerby Jean-Raymond, of Pyer Moss, had his sights set on collaborating with the R&B singer Erykah Badu. She and Jean-Raymond eventually met through a mutual friend and embarked on a partnership that would mark a first for Badu: her styling debut. And this morning, when Badu arrived at his studio — wearing platform Teva sandals, an oversize denim tunic and a black chauffeur hat embellished with handmade pins reading “Acid” and “LSD” — she greeted Jean-Raymond like an old friend.

headline: Jordan Struggles Under a Wave of Syrian Refugees
text: AMMAN, Jordan — King Abdullah II made his people an extraordinary promise last week: For every job the government offered Syrian refugees, it would create five jobs for Jordanians.

headline: Justice Scalia’s Irreplaceable Views on CO2 and Climate

headline: University Student in New Delhi Arrested on Sedition Complaint
text: NEW DELHI — The police have arrested the president of a student union here on a complaint of sedition, a news agency reported, the latest controversy to hit one of the country’s highly politicized universities.

headline: How Scalia Compared With Other Justices
text: Justice Antonin Scalia was a leader of the Supreme Court’s conservative wing and the longest serving member of the current court.

headline: The Daily Bag: Alexander Wang
text: Punk-rock, mini bucket bags with grommets popped up at Alexander Wang — the ultimate cool girl accessory.

headline: At Alexander Wang, Blunt Bangs and Minimal Makeup
text: As a continuation of last season’s theme, the beauty looks at Alexander Wang’s fall/winter 2016 show honed in on model’s individuality. For makeup, Diane Kendal gave each one a minimal look inspired by youth culture’s adoption of high fashion. Youthful, but worn-in nonetheless — “like they’ve been up all night partying,” she said. (A similar theme to last season’s Marc Jacobs look, too.) The main focus was on eyes: Kendal filled lids in with chocolatey brown shadow (NARS Dark Angel Velvet Shadow Stick) up to the contour. She then diffused the shadow around the entire eye area with moisturizer, using just her fingers, and finished them off with a touch of lip balm for a subtle sheen.

headline: The Daily Shoe: Alexander Wang
text: Party shoes! Take it from someone who knows: Alex Wang.

headline: Highlights From Justice Antonin Scalia’s Opinions
text: The tenure of the conservative justice spans almost three decades, and includes a legacy of sharply written opinions.

headline: Battle Begins Over Naming Next Justice
text: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. — The death of Justice Antonin Scalia on Saturday set off an immediate partisan battle over a vacancy that could reshape the Supreme Court for years to come, as President Obama vowed to nominate a successor and Senate Republicans called on him to let the next president fill the seat.

headline: Kristaps Porzingis Quick to Make a Believer of Team World’s Coach
text: TORONTO — Ettore Messina, an assistant coach with the San Antonio Spurs, was only vaguely familiar with Kristaps Porzingis until this weekend. Messina, of course, had coached against Porzingis in two games this season, both wins for the Spurs. But Friday was their first meaty opportunity to get to know each other.

headline: Donald Trump Will Be G.O.P. Nominee, Students’ Mock Convention Says
text: LEXINGTON, Va. — A gymnasium full of college students here on Saturday did what a former Republican Party chairman, a former vice president and a former speaker of the House who addressed their mock convention would not: predict the Republican nominee for president.

headline: Adam Silver Aims to Reduce Excessive Fouling
text: TORONTO — Commissioner Adam Silver said Saturday that his personal views on the so-called Hack-a-Shaq tactic used by N.B.A. coaches had evolved.

headline: In Republican Debate, Jeb Bush Attacks Donald Trump
text: Former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida blasted Donald J. Trump for insulting the Bush family and ridiculed the idea that Mr. Trump could be commander in chief during a contentious and sometimes nasty Republican presidential debate in Greenville, S.C., on Saturday, a week before a crucial primary in the state.

headline: The Legendary Photographer Who Inspired a Fall Collection
text: The designer Carin Rodebjer has always preferred facts to fiction. “I love people and their stories, and I always find the most interesting stories in real life. Since I was a kid, I was reading biographies and watching documentaries,” she says. “I tend to navigate towards other artists who work with reality in some way.”

headline: Justice Antonin Scalia’s Supreme Court Legacy
text: Justice Antonin Scalia, who died on Saturday at the age of 79, served on the Supreme Court for 30 years and made as big a mark on the court and on American law and politics as some of the chief justices under whom he served. It took about 10 minutes after the announcement of his death for the right wing to start screaming that the Senate should not confirm a replacement while President Obama is in office.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “It has been 80 years since an election-year vacancy has been filled and the politics of the court has changed drastically since those days.”

headline: Obama to Nominate Scalia Replacement Over Republicans’ Objections
text: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. — President Obama said Saturday that he planned to submit a nominee to replace Justice Antonin Scalia on the Supreme Court, rebuffing Republicans who have called for him to leave the choice to the next president.

headline: Potential Supreme Court Nominees
text: Here is a list of potential Supreme Court nominees to replace Justice Antonin Scalia, who died on Saturday.

headline: Fire in Harlem Housing Project Critically Injures Woman and Boy
text: A woman and a boy were critically injured in a fire in an apartment at a public-housing project in Harlem, according to the Fire Department.

headline: Hillary Clinton Calls Mitch McConnell’s Stance on Supreme Court Nomination ‘Disappointing’
text: Hillary Clinton called Senator Mitch McConnell’s statement that the next president, not President Obama, should appoint a successor to Justice Scalia “disappointing” and “totally out of step with our history and our constitutional principle.”

headline: The Daily Jewel: Altuzarra
text: Altuzarra’s drop earrings, swinging with bells and pearls, were bohemian perfection. — MALINA JOSEPH GILCHRIST

headline: Bernie Sanders Relies on Supporters for Ad About Unity
text: After letting Simon and Garfunkel speak for him in one ad, Senator Bernie Sanders has turned over his latest to his supporters, several of whom created a 60-second spot titled “Together.”

headline: Antonin Scalia, Conservative Legal Giant
text: Antonin Scalia, dead unexpectedly this weekend at 79, was not the most politically powerful justice during his three decades on the Supreme Court. That distinction belonged to the court’s two swing votes, Sandra Day O’Connor and then Anthony M. Kennedy, respectively the philosopher queen and king of our fraying republican order.

headline: Hillary Clinton, Shifting Line of Attack, Paints Bernie Sanders as a One-Issue Candidate
text: HENDERSON, Nev. — Hillary Clinton set out on Saturday to blunt one of Bernie Sanders’s most potent arguments against her, attacking the Vermont senator as a one-note rival whose relentless focus on Wall Street excess and exorbitant political spending would do little to improve the lives of Americans.

headline: Texas Ranch Where Scalia Died Is Rugged Oasis for the Famous
text: HOUSTON — The closest community to the West Texas resort where Justice Antonin Scalia died is barely even a place anymore: It is a virtual ghost town where perhaps only a dozen people still live. And when a silver hearse drove across the rocks outside the Cibolo Creek Ranch on Saturday, it was from a funeral home at least an hour away.

headline: Scalia’s Supreme Court Seat and the Next Frontier in Political Hardball
text: It takes no feat of imagination to guess how the debate about replacing Justice Antonin Scalia, who died unexpectedly on Saturday, will take shape. Within a couple of hours of news of his death, Mitch McConnell, the Senate majority leader, joined by fellow Republicans like Ted Cruz, said that Justice Scalia’s seat on the United States Supreme Court should remain vacant until after the November presidential election.

headline: Altuzarra: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Mr. Altuzarra’s who is credited for reinventing the women’s coat in 2012, presents his fall looks.

headline: How Long Does It Take to Confirm a Supreme Court Nominee?
text: Republicans and Democrats are arguing over whether President Obama, whose term expires in 342 days, should try to fill Justice Antonin Scalia’s seat.

headline: Republican Candidates Unite Against Obama on Replacing Scalia
text: GREENVILLE, S.C. — The death of Justice Antonin Scalia on Saturday thrust the Supreme Court to the center of the already-volatile Republican presidential race, with the party’s candidates asserting that President Obama should not nominate a successor as they sought to court conservatives who have driven the party’s discourse in the current campaign.

headline: G.O.P. Candidates Call for ‘Delay’ in a Supreme Court Appointment
text: It came as no real surprise that all six Republican presidential candidates called for President Barack Obama to hold off on nominating a Supreme Court justice to replace Antonin Scalia, who died Saturday, portraying the appointment as a crucial opportunity to determine the direction of a raft of ideologically charged cases currently being considered by the high court.

headline: Richard Bettan, Gabriel Jaime
text: Richard Jason Bettan and Gabriel Jaime are to be married Feb. 14 at the Prince George Ballroom in New York. Jenna H. Ben-Yehuda, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, will officiate.

headline: William Benjamin, William Harper Jr.
text: William Allen Benjamin and William Claude Harper Jr. are to be married Feb. 14 at their apartment in Manhattan. The Rev. Elizabeth Gavin, who was ordained by the One Spirit Interfaith Seminary, is to officiate.

headline: Deva Estin, Samuel Guzik
text: Deborah Edith Estin, a daughter of Ann Laquer Estin and James D. Estin of Iowa City, is to be married Feb. 14 to Samuel Morris Guzik, a son of Dr. Robin J. Warshawsky and Dr. Howard J. Guzik of Roslyn, N.Y. Rabbi Deborah Bronstein is to officiate at the Rembrandt Yard Art Gallery and Event Center in Boulder, Colo.

headline: Tyndale Brickey, Andrew Bloom
text: Tyndale Anne Brickey, a daughter of Margaret Anne Brickey and Charles Lee Brickey of Cordova, Tenn., was married Feb. 13 to Andrew Jeremy Bloom, the son of Karen Silver Bloom and Ira W. Bloom of Westport, Conn. Kiley L. Bostick, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at the Marriott Harbor Beach Resort and Spa in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

headline: Margaret Havemann, Elliot Vice
text: Margaret Ruth Havemann, a daughter of Judy Havemann and Joel Havemann of Washington, was married Feb. 13 to Elliot David Vice, the son of Janet K. Vice and David W. Vice of Ladoga, Ind. Denise S. Feriozzi, who received temporary officiant status from the District of Columbia, officiated at the National Museum of Women in the Arts in Washington.

headline: Marisa Milton and Raymond Weaver II: On the Same Court at Last
text: Marisa Lorraine Milton and Raymond Lee Weaver II are to be married Feb. 14 in Washington. Dr. H. Philip Owens, a friend of the couple who received temporary officiant status from the District of Columbia Marriage Bureau, is to officiate at the Carnegie Institution for Science.

headline: Nicole McKown, Glenn Yarris Jr.
text: Dr. Nicole Diane McKown and Glenn Charles Yarris Jr. were married Feb. 13 at Sacred Heart Catholic Church in Tampa, Fla. The Rev. Bill Santhouse, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Bernie Sanders Says Obama Should Be Allowed to Nominate Supreme Court Justice
text: DENVER — Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont pointedly criticized Republican officials for recommending that President Obama hold off on nominating a successor for Justice Antonin Scalia of the Supreme Court, who died Saturday.

headline: Sadie Weiner and Zachary Wineburg: ‘The Tide Goes in, the Tide Goes Out’
text: Alissa Weiner and Zachary Riley Wineburg are to be married Feb. 14 at the Hickory Street Annex in Dallas. Rabbi Fred Guttman is to officiate.

headline: Jason Forbach, Joseph Spieldenner
text: Jason Forbach and Joseph Spieldenner, both actors in the ensemble of the Broadway revival of “Les Misérables,” were married Feb. 9 at Marc Forgione, a restaurant in New York. Cantor Shayna De Lowe officiated. On Feb. 19, Michael Kostroff, a friend of the couple, is to lead a ceremony with Jewish and Christian elements at Villa del Mar in Las Terrenas, Dominican Republic.

headline: Morgan Clifford, John Howell Jr.
text: Morgan Phillips Clifford, a daughter of Aelish S. Clifford and John P. Clifford Jr. of Avon, Conn., was married Feb. 13 to John Aubrey Howell Jr., a son of Regina D. Howell and Mr. Howell Sr. of Alexandria, Va. The Rev. Gregory Sutterlin, a Lutheran minister, officiated at the University Club in New York.

headline: Tyler Griffin, Valerie Katsorhis
text: Tyler Courtney Griffin and Valerie Katsorhis are to be married Feb. 14 by Chelsea Keegan, a friend of the couple and a Universal Life minister, at the Liberty Warehouse, an events space in Brooklyn.

headline: Lauren Boxer, Ari Ackerman
text: Lauren Sara Boxer and Ari Jack Ackerman are to be married Feb. 14 at the Mandarin Oriental in New York. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein is to lead the ceremony.

headline: Darsi Monaco, Jacob Mueser

Mueser of Boston. Monroe Robertson, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, will officiate at the Manhattan Penthouse, an events space in New York.

headline: Antonin Scalia (1936-2016)

headline: How Scalia Compared With Other Justices
text: The death of Justice Antonin Scalia will leave the Supreme Court with equal numbers of conservative and liberal justices. Justice Anthony M. Kennedy is likely to be the swing vote in most cases.

headline: Justice Antonin Scalia: His Life and Career
text: Justice Scalia, 79, was nominated to the Supreme Court in 1986. His theories, initially viewed as idiosyncratic, gradually took hold, and not only on the right and not only in the courts.

headline: What to Watch Sunday
text: Sex, drugs and — what else? — rock ’n’ roll: Martin Scorsese and Mick Jagger mine the 1970s New York music scene in “Vinyl.” A “Bachelor” couple dare to tie the knot. And Lily Tomlin shines as a lesbian poet with familial duties in “Grandma.”

headline: Fact Check: South Carolina G.O.P. Debate
text: The New York Times checks assertions from the Republican candidates during Saturday’s debate in Greenville, S.C.

headline: Free Spirit
text: Fashion seems a little like the Wild West right now. Perhaps in part thanks to ever-multiplying shows and the numerous collections designers must create to keep up with demand, there’s a sort of free and pioneering spirit blowing through the season. You can channel a prairie girl, a sister wife, a cyberpunk, a kooky intellectual. You can dress mannish, sexy or demure. Basically, if you wanted, you could wake up and put on a flowing floral dress or a futuristic short skirt or a tailored suit — in a solid, a floral, stripes, plaid or some clashing combo thereof — and in many places, at many kinds of jobs, head out to work. That freedom is exciting, and a form of power.

headline: Corrections: February 14, 2016
text: METROPOLITAN

headline: Republican Debate Takeaways: Saturday Night Fighting
text: GREENVILLE, S.C. — The Republican candidates debated on Saturday night as if it were one last chance to break through and take down their opponents — and for a few of them, it probably was.

headline: Who Won the Debate? Florida Candidates Bask in Sunny Reviews
text: The Republican primary debate on Saturday night was perhaps the most contentious face-off of the 2016 campaign, as the candidates shouted at, accused and insulted each other, while enduring frequent booing from the audience. Critics and commentators thought the night was won by Jeb Bush, a former governor of Florida, who delivered a strong performance just a week before the South Carolina primary, and Senator Marco Rubio of Florida, who bounced back from his flop at last week’s debate. As for the losers, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas was seen as flat at times under the heat of ad hominem attacks, while Donald J. Trump’s tirades appeared to be wearing thin. Here is a sampling of comments from the chattering class.

headline: Ece Sukan Loves Vintage, Givenchy and Plenty of Shearling
text: Name Ece Sukan

headline: Fashion Week: Shows to Share With Your Valentine
text: Envy the brunch crowd, Fashion Week faithful. For them is the 11 a.m. application of bacon, eggs over easy, café au lait. For you, a bracing, near-Arctic day of traversing Manhattan for shows. If there’s one thing Fashion Week lacks, it’s the proverbial day of rest.

headline: Creating a Computer Voice That People Like
text: When computers speak, how human should they sound?

headline: England, Seeking New Era, Is in the Six Nations Hunt
text: England’s new coach, Eddie Jones, had already talked a good game, and in the last half-hour of his second Six Nations match, his team played one.

headline: Fat Dad: Love in a Bowl of Soup
text: “Eat your soup. It’s good food,” my paternal grandmother, Bubbe Mary, would say.

headline: Five Big Questions After the Harshest G.O.P. Debate Yet
text: Do voters really care about Donald Trump’s conservative credentials?

headline: A Blended Family Survival Guide
text: Almost 20 years ago, when our five kids were all in elementary school, Rique and I blended our families. That’s the word the parenting industry uses. “Blend.” Talk about euphemism. There is no stress in the word “blend.” It’s one utterly pleasant syllable.

headline: 1891: General William Sherman Dies
text: NEW YORK — General Sherman died at ten minutes to two o’clock this afternoon [Feb. 14]. Death got the upper hand of the old warrior early in the morning, and at half-past five the change was so marked that messengers were hastily sent for Drs. Janeway and Green.

headline: Thumbing, Old and New
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Afghanistan Had Record Civilian Casualties in 2015, U.N. Says
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Taliban suicide attacks and a fierce battle for the northern city of Kunduz made 2015 the worst year for Afghan civilian casualties since the United Nations began tracking the data, officials said on Sunday, in a sobering reminder of the cost of the conflict at a time when the prospect of peace seems as distant as ever.

headline: Justice Antonin Scalia and the ‘Dead’ Constitution
text: WHETHER or not you agreed with the man, there is no question that Justice Antonin Scalia changed the United States Supreme Court, the way that the Constitution and laws are interpreted and the image of a Supreme Court justice far more than President Ronald Reagan could ever have foreseen when appointing him.

headline: 1941: U.S. Tells Citizens to Leave Far East
text: SHANGHAI — Apprehension was aroused in a large section of the American community here today [Feb. 13] when Consul General Frank P. Lockhart issued a circular to all Americans here reiterating the advice of the State Department that American women, children and men whose presence here is not essential withdraw to the United States in the interest both of their own safety and of national security.

headline: Three’s a Trend: Black Velvet
text: Silky, black velvet made several appearances on the runways in the first few days of New York Fashion Week. First, Adam Selman — a designer known for his use of color and print — showed a head-to-toe black velvet jumpsuit, in a relatively dark collection. Jason Wu interpreted the fabric into a puffer sweater with fur trim and a ladylike slit pencil skirt. And a few hours later, Fernando Garcia and Laura Kim of Monse showed their sophomore collection. It was filled with interesting evening wear — including a floor-length, drapey black velvet number that showed off hints of skin.

headline: Syrian Officer Gave a View of War. ISIS Came, and Silence Followed.
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Ours was an unusual, sometimes operatic, correspondence that unfolded over more than a year. Abu al-Majd, a Syrian police officer who was being deployed more and more often like a soldier, texted at all hours, sending news from the front lines and grumbling about boring, sunbaked patrols, his complaints sometimes punctuated by expressions of terror, pride or doubt.

headline: Key Questions and Answers About Antonin Scalia and His Legacy
text: Justice Antonin Scalia died on Saturday during a hunting trip in Texas. He was the longest serving member of the Supreme Court, appointed in 1986 by President Ronald Reagan. He leaves behind a substantial legal legacy and a host of questions. Here are answers to a few:

headline: A Crumbling Coney Island Landmark Is Getting a Makeover
text: In a parking lot a few hundred yards beyond Coney Island’s Parachute Jump, where customers floated toward the ground until the 1960s, lie pieces of the future: big white trusses. If they had come with an instruction manual, it would say, “Lots of assembly required.”

headline: Justice Antonin Scalia’s Death, and a Political Fight
text: To the Editor:
