text: The designer’s fall/winter collection, shown at St. Bartholomew’s on Park Avenue, mingled tweeds, streetwear and prison references.

headline: What to Cook This Week
text: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Tome: Fall 2016
text: Ryan Lobo and Ramon Martin, who waited 13 years to become designers, present their fall collection.

headline: Staying the Course in an Unnerving Presidential Race
text: As the results of the New Hampshire primary rolled in last week, a charter member of Washington’s Republican establishment received a one-word message from a colleague: “despair.” It’s a safe bet that there was a comparable Democratic exchange.

headline: Your Daily Fashion Week Recap for Sunday, Feb. 14
text: 1. Alexander Wang commented on “today’s youth culture and its various appropriations of high fashion,” wrote Laura Neilson, combining streetwear and tweeds in his fall/winter collection that walked at St. Bartholomew’s on Park Avenue. The beauty look(s) differed from woman to woman. The makeup artist Diane Kendal created a chocolatey-brown glossy eye, and the hairstylist Guido Palau didn’t hesitate to grab the scissors and hair dye, completely transforming the model Katie Moore.

headline: 1891: Oscar Wilde’s Valentine
text: In February 1891, the European edition of The New York Herald published the following letter from Oscar Wilde, responding to a review of his play, “Guido Ferranti.” The play is otherwise known as “The Duchess of Padua.” It ran for three weeks in January 1891 and has rarely been performed since.

headline: Review: ‘Better Call Saul,’ Quirky and Absorbing in Season Opener
text: Season 2 of “Better Call Saul” begins where Season 1 did: in purgatory, which happens to be a Cinnabon in Omaha. Saul Goodman (Bob Odenkirk), once Walter White’s skeevy lawyer, relocated there to save his skin after the bloody denouement of “Breaking Bad.” Like last year’s opening sequence, it’s a lovely, mournful short film, scored this time to the country standard “Funny How Time Slips Away.”

headline: Victoria Beckham: Fall 2016
text: Ms. Beckham, who grew her team from three people to 350 over the course of her career, presents her latest designs.

headline: Three’s a Trend: Extra-Warm Shearling
text: Winter has finally arrived on the East Coast — just in time for fashion week. But judging from the shows so far, anyone kicking themselves for not investing in a polar-vortex shearling will have something to look forward to next season. At Kanye West’s Yeezy show, there was a covetable butterscotch-colored cropped version; at Lacoste, creative director Felipe Oliveira Baptista showed a convertible, hooded navy coat with zips at the waist that can shorten or lengthen. And at Altuzarra, one jacket came with black and oxblood vertical stripes and oversize pockets. The message is clear: The shearling is the must-have coat of the season.

headline: Joe Jonas, Naomi Campbell and Adrien Brody Celebrate Diesel’s New Store
text: A new boutique on Madison Avenue is the occasion for three parties.

headline: Joe Jonas, Naomi Campbell and Adrian Brody Celebrate Diesel’s New Store
text: The brand Diesel had not one but three events on Saturday night. The night began at Diesel’s new Madison Avenue boutique, where Renzo Rosso, the president of OTB Group, Diesel’s parent company, posed with Naomi Campbell. Here are the photos.

headline: Public School: Fall 2016
text: Maxwell Osborne and Dao-Yi Chow’s fall collection.

headline: Syria Accord Looms Over Europe Security Meeting
text: MUNICH — The failure of world powers to quell the five-year conflict in Syria, the Russian military intervention there and the spread of Islamic terrorism overshadowed an annual security conference here, which came as Europe falters ahead of a new effort to cope with its refugee crisis.

headline: At Victoria Beckham, Slick Ponytails and a Soft Palette
text: “The overall aesthetic is a modern woman today,” the hairstylist Guido Palau said this morning of the beauty identity he’s helped to build in recent seasons at Victoria Beckham. “Almost kind of futuristic, but not in a fantastical way; in a very wearable way.” True to that ideal, for fall/winter 2016 he crafted an army of artful, slicked-back ponytails, tied at the nape of the neck with thin black string. The style was worn long, regardless of hair length — short-haired models were given extensions — and was shellacked in front with layers of Redken Triple Take Hairspray 32, sprayed at close range to create a hard “jewel-like” texture. Selectively curling the ponytails with a one-inch iron lent the hair a “loose movement — not curls, just bends,” as Palau said, and a softness to counter the hairline’s abundance of product.

headline: Taraji P. Henson on Alexander Wang, Cookie and the Oscars
text: There was an oddly somber feel to preshow proceedings at Alexander Wang this season, his usual downtown crowd muffled in big black coats under the cool cloistered ceilings of St Bartholomew’s Church on Park Avenue. The Wang Gang had shown up in their droves to support their friend on Saturday night, including Kylie Jenner and her rapper boyfriend Tyga, the singer Beth Ditto, Zoë Kravitz and Taraji P. Henson, the actress lately known for playing the ferocious matriarch Cookie Lyon in “Empire.” Head to toe in a black and studded Alexander Wang shift dress, Ms. Henson appeared delighted to be at the designer’s show for the very first time.

headline: Egyptian Appeals Court Orders New Trial for Officer Convicted of Manslaughter
text: CAIRO — An appeals court on Sunday overturned the manslaughter conviction of a police officer in the death of a poet and activist whose shooting during a protest march became a national scandal.

headline: Pregame Drills Lacked Flash, but Now They’re Jam-Packed
text: Brian Rohleder was perhaps the last player expected to have an impact on Kansas State’s opening game of the 2014 N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: After Antonin Scalia’s Death, Fierce Battle Lines Emerge
text: WASHINGTON — An epic Washington political battle took shape on Sunday after the death of Justice Antonin Scalia as Senate Republicans dug in and said they would refuse to act on any Supreme Court nomination by President Obama. But the White House vowed to select a nominee within weeks.

headline: At Fashion Week, Emily Ratajkowski Gets Political
text: At the Altuzarra show on Saturday night, the style and spirits of the assembled crowd were a little the worse for wear after temperatures had plunged to zero and many had been forced to stand outside at the Moncler show an hour earlier. Emily Ratajkowski, who shot to fame with the “Blurred Lines” music video in 2013, was in a sympathetic mood.

headline: Moncler Embraces Winter. The Crowd, Not So Much
text: It was around 6:45 on Saturday evening, and I was standing on the second-floor balcony of the David H. Koch Theater, overlooking the Lincoln Center Plaza — and I was freezing.

headline: Ranch Owner Recalls Finding Justice Antonin Scalia’s Body
text: HOUSTON — When Justice Antonin Scalia did not respond to a knock at the door of his suite at the Cibolo Creek Ranch at 8:30 a.m. on Saturday, John B. Poindexter, the property’s owner, was not alarmed.

headline: Donald Trump Holds Firm on Criticism of George W. Bush
text: The morning after the Republican presidential primary debate, Donald J. Trump said he had no regrets about saying that the George W. Bush administration “lied” in taking the nation to war in Iraq, despite the criticism Mr. Trump received.

headline: Vanessa Moody Transforms at Derek Lam
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall/Winter 2016 Fashion Week in New York.

headline: ‘Mourning Lincoln’ Wins Book Prize
text: “Mourning Lincoln,” the historian Martha Hodes’s account of how ordinary Americans lamented (or celebrated) the assassination of the Great Emancipator, has won the Gilder Lehrman Lincoln Prize, which is awarded annually by Gettysburg College and the Gilder Lehrman Institute of American History. The prize, for “the finest scholarly work in English on Abraham Lincoln, carries a $50,000 cash award.

headline: Estelle Parsons Takes Role in New Israel Horovitz Comedy
text: Estelle Parsons, the five-time Tony nominee who won an Oscar for “Bonnie and Clyde” and starred in the Israel Horovitz play “My Old Lady,” is reuniting with the playwright for “Out of the Mouths of Babes,” a new Off Broadway comedy.

text: The man accused of stabbing his girlfriend and two of her daughters to death at a Staten Island motel being used to house homeless people was arraigned on Sunday on three counts of murder and one count of attempted murder.

headline: Hood by Air: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Shayne Oliver who gets his inspiration from the street, presents his latest collection.

headline: Micklethwait’s Balancing Act, After a Year as Bloomberg Editor in Chief
text: In recent weeks, John Micklethwait, the editor in chief of Bloomberg, has sometimes felt, as he put it, like “a character in a Graham Greene novel. There’s an element of ‘there’s no perfect answer to it.’”

headline: ‘Deadpool’ Breaks Box Office Records for R-Rated Film
text: LOS ANGELES — Welcome to the A-list, Deadpool.

headline: ‘Super PAC’ Follows Jeb Bush in Taking Donald Trump to Task
text: Up until now, Right to Rise, the “super PAC” supporting Jeb Bush, had focused most of its negative advertising on Senator Marco Rubio and Gov. John Kasich. On Friday, the group altered course, running two negative ads against its candidate’s favorite debate foil: Donald J. Trump.

headline: Review: ‘La Sylphide’ Is City Ballet’s Bittersweet Valentine
text: Peter Martins isn’t one of those choreographers who loves love. He doesn’t get carried away by sentimentality. So it’s no surprise, but kind of refreshing, that he brought back his staging of “La Sylphide” — a ballet about a sylph who lures a young Scotsman away from his fiancée and, in the final heartbreaking moments, loses her wings, goes blind, keels over and dies — to New York City Ballet just in time for Valentine’s Day weekend. I hate cheap red hearts, too.

headline: Will Merkel Pay for Doing the Right Thing?
text: BERLIN — A former German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, recently called Angela Merkel’s decision to open the door to an unlimited number of refugees a “mistake” and offered this verdict: Merkel had a “heart, but no plan.”

headline: Trial of Chad’s Ex-President Is Punctuated by His Noncooperation
text: PARIS — Most mornings since September, the former president of the African nation of Chad was woken at dawn in his specially refurbished prison quarters for a trip he loathed.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Feb. 15
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Tuesday’s auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Wednesday.

headline: The Daily Shoe: Victoria Beckham
text: Victoria Beckham offered yet another great men’s wear-inspired flat at her fall/winter 2016 show this morning, but it’s this chunky-heeled boot with a buckle that stood out — especially for how good it will look with all the new midcalf skirts.

headline: The Daily Bag: Victoria Beckham
text: The luxurious fur bags at Victoria Beckham are so covetable the models don’t even want to let them go.

headline: Liberal Love for Antonin Scalia
text: Antonin Scalia was my hero. He was deeply conservative. He belittled lawyers. His opinions, especially in dissent, could be downright nasty. No justice in the Supreme Court’s history insulted his colleagues more, or more memorably. He was as aggressive and outspoken as I am reserved and cautious. He was a smoker. He was, in short, everything I am not. But I have looked up to him for years.

headline: For ‘Hangmen’ and ‘Escaped Alone,’ Connecting Threads in London
text: LONDON — Martin McDonagh has been sharpening his hooks. Not the kind that one of his homicidal characters might use to flay the flesh of an enemy (or relative), but the sort that a cunning dramatist plunges deep into a theatergoer’s attention and refuses to release until the final curtain.

headline: Review: Kanye West’s ‘The Life of Pablo,’ Songs of Praise and Self
text: It’s unlikely we’ll get a song as singular as Kanye West’s “Ultralight Beam” anytime soon, so best to linger on it, feel out its grooves and curves, allow it to seep into the pores.

headline: Brooks Brothers: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Looks from the Brooks Brothers Collection.

headline: In Grammy Race, the Band Highly Suspect Marvels at Its Surprising Double Shot
text: For a little-known band, one Grammy nomination might be explained away as a fluke. Scoring two simultaneous nominations is harder to comprehend, especially in mainstream categories like rock, which tend to favor household names. (Some recent winners: Beck, Foo Fighters, Green Day, Led Zeppelin.)

headline: Review: In Álvaro Enrigue’s ‘Sudden Death,’ a Farcical Duel With Topspin
text: Writing with his customary intensity about his favorite sport, David Foster Wallace described tennis as “chess on the run, beautiful and infinitely dense.” In his droll and erudite new novel, “Sudden Death,” Álvaro Enrigue provides his own distinct take on that chess-on-the-run notion and elevates it to an even more exalted level. Pitting two late Renaissance giants against each other, he transforms their match into a clash of ideologies, a contest that von Clausewitz might have described as a continuation of both war and politics by other means.

headline: Slideshow: Off the Runway
text: Scenes from the fourth day of New York Fashion Week.

headline: The Upmarket Tracksuit
text: The upmarket tracksuits, hoodies and other willfully subversive signifiers of survivalist chic have shown up on the New York Fashion Week runways. Here are some examples.

headline: The Tracksuit Reborn
text: It’s high time Seventh Avenue reclaimed ownership of a trend that European designers have been exploiting for a season or more. The upmarket tracksuits, hoodies and other willfully subversive signifiers of survivalist chic that were shown for spring at Vetements and Chloé, among others, have made their way stateside in force.

headline: The Lone Wolf at the Westminster Dog Show
text: Dr. Richard Meen fully grasps the monastic nature of his powers. On Tuesday night, just 30 minutes before the best-in-show competition at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show at Madison Square Garden, he will descend from his sequestered post in the Warwick Hotel in Manhattan to decide, alone, which of the animals is the purest of the purebreds.

headline: A Leisurely Return for the New York State Legislature
text: ALBANY — The scene in the State Capitol last week bore all the hallmarks of democracy at work: advocates and lobbyists pushing their causes, earnest interns scurrying about, and protesters making insistent pleas for funds for everything from housing to hepatitis C.

headline: An Unwanted Bill
text: MONDAY PUZZLE — They say it’s lonely at the top and I would dare say that no position is lonelier than that of the president of the United States, especially when it comes to making decisions that affect the rest of the free world. Today, we can almost literally see some of those past presidents on their ladder to success in David Kahn’s crossword.

headline: Sies Marjan: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Looks from Sies Marjan

headline: HomeAway, a Home Rental Service, Mocks the Competition
text: Guests cringe on a couch while a bathrobe-clad homeowner clips his toenails. A couple wakes to find that another homeowner has been watching them sleep. A woman at the bathroom sink gags when she spies a bar of soap riddled with strange hairs.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Baja East and Altuzarra in Pictures
text: A photo diary of the fall/winter 2016 collections that were presented yesterday.

headline: The Week in Kanye West
text: Kanye West debuted his new album, "The Life of Pablo," and his Yeezy Season 3 collection with Adidas during a loud, controversy-filled week.
