text: Mr. Simkhai’s, the 2015 CFDA/Vogue fashion winner presents his latest fall looks.

headline: Esperanza Aguirre, an Official in Spain’s Governing Party, Quits Amid Corruption Claims
text: MADRID — Esperanza Aguirre, the longstanding leader of the Popular Party in the Madrid region, resigned on Sunday amid investigations into mounting allegations of corruption within Spain’s governing party.

headline: New York Parking Alert: Alternate-Side Rules Suspended on Monday
text: Because of Washington’s Birthday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Monday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: The BAFTA Awards Red Carpet
text: The British Academy of Film and Television Arts (BAFTA) had its awards ceremony on Sunday, complete with its own red carpet (of course).

headline: Tombstone Survives on Spirit of the Wild West
text: Tourists come from all over the world to the small Arizona city to experience a taste of the past through guided tours and re-enactments.

headline: Guns Blazing, Tombstone Is Back to Its Past
text: TOMBSTONE, Ariz. — Ken Curtis felt a stinging pain beneath the double-stitched leather holster where his Mitchell Arms pistol rests when it is not in his hands, as it was that afternoon in October. He slid a finger inside his pants. Blood oozed from a hole in his lower abdomen. Mr. Curtis took a deep breath and slipped right back into character.

headline: Ted Cruz Attacks Donald Trump Over Planned Parenthood in New Ad
text: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas on Sunday released an advertisement attacking Donald J. Trump for his defense of Planned Parenthood — the most potent signal yet that Mr. Cruz views the issue as a chief vulnerability for his rival in South Carolina.

headline: Revolution Is Absent From Runways
text: Given all the talk about rule breaking and the appeal of extremes and the rejection of familiar codes of behavior (yadda, yadda, yadda) that has dominated the political and cultural conversation since the 2016 presidential campaign began, it wouldn’t be too outlandish to expect that some of it might find expression in fashion.

headline: Fashion Week Today: For Hood by Air, Pilgrimage on a Collision Course
text: We’ll be bringing you highlights from the shows, from the extravaganzas to the scrappy upstarts. Here is day 4.

headline: Severe Contraction and Falling Prices in Japan Signal Tough Test for Abenomics
text: Japan’s economy shrank in the final three months of 2015, the government said on Monday, undergoing a more severe contraction than experts had expected amid signs that global growth was stalling.

headline: Diane Von Furstenberg: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Ms. Furstenberg debuts her fall collection.

headline: Zika Virus Increases Concerns About Employee Safety
text: Early in her pregnancy, Whitney Peak traveled to Rio de Janeiro for her job with Leblon Cachaça, a liquor company based in Brazil. That was in October, before much was known about Zika, a mosquito-borne virus that has spread through South America and that scientists say may be linked to a birth defect and brain damage in babies.

headline: HSBC to Keep Headquarters in London Instead of Hong Kong
text: LONDON — HSBC said on Sunday that it would keep its headquarters in Britain after announcing plans last year to review whether to move its home.

headline: Brazil Pushes Public to Do Its Part in Fighting Zika Spread
text: SALVADOR, Brazil — Nearly a quarter of a million soldiers, sailors and other military personnel began fanning through Brazilian cities over the weekend as part of an ambitious campaign to combat the mosquitoes that are spreading Zika, the virus believed to be linked to a surge in infants born with severe brain damage.

headline: Movers on Bikes
text: The Cargo Bike Collective, a loose-knit group of people who own and ride the extra-long bikes, help move items in New York City.

headline: On the Move in New York, on Bicycles Built for More Than 2
text: The movers arrived at Barbara Ross’s apartment on the Lower East Side of Manhattan one Friday last month, grabbing bags of clothes and shoes, framed pictures and boxes of CDs. They carried the items downstairs and loaded them onto four long-framed cargo bicycles parked on Ridge Street.

headline: Edun: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Danielle Sherman presents her latest collection.

headline: How America Was Lost
text: Once upon a time, the death of a Supreme Court justice wouldn’t have brought America to the edge of constitutional crisis. But that was a different country, with a very different Republican Party. In today’s America, with today’s G.O.P., the passing of Antonin Scalia has opened the doors to chaos.

headline: Not Part of Video’s Script: An Arrest for Flying a Drone
text: Sean Riddle said the other inmates in the Manhattan holding cell that night were laughing — at him. Someone had overheard him talking to his court-appointed lawyer.

headline: New Report of U.S.-Made Cluster Bomb Use by Saudis in Yemen
text: Human Rights Watch released a report Sunday providing new indications that Saudi Arabia has fired American-made cluster munitions, banned by international treaty, in civilian areas of Yemen, and said their use may also violate United States law.

headline: Potential Nominees Obama May Consider to Fill Antonin Scalia’s Seat
text: The death of Justice Antonin Scalia in a presidential election year has set up a challenge for President Obama and his legal advisers. They must weigh the best person to put forward, knowing that Republican senators may block that nominee no matter who is chosen. At the same time, if a Democrat prevails in the presidential election, Mr. Obama’s nominee might be confirmed in the Senate’s lame-duck session or would be an obvious front-runner to be renominated by his successor in 2017. Here are six contenders being discussed by close observers of judicial politics.

headline: At United Pickle, Preserving the Standards of a Deli Staple
text: Not every cucumber has what it takes to be a pickle. As dozens of them tumbled from a steel hopper onto a conveyor belt in a Bronx factory, two workers enforced a strict pickle standard.

headline: The Cowboy Pilgrims of Mexico
text: More 3,000 people made this year’s three-day journey to a mountaintop statue of Jesus, keeping alive a tradition that began more than 60 years ago.

headline: Pilgrimage in Mexico Keeps a Cowboy Tradition Alive
text: SILAO, Mexico — Sheathed in colorful woolen ponchos and wearing crisp white hats, the cowboys rode their horses through green fields and blond meadows, holding banners of Christ the King and the Virgin of Guadalupe.

headline: In Queens, Antonin Scalia Took Pride in Melting Pot and Confrontation
text: Justice Antonin Scalia had a range that extended from in-your-face brash to an even-more-in-your-face pugnacious. He was self-aware, describing himself as “something of a shin kicker” and “something of a contrarian.” Sure, Justice Scalia was born in Trenton — predictably, New Jersey’s governor, Chris Christie, claimed him on Saturday, saying that the 79-year-old justice was “a native son of New Jersey.”

headline: In Mexican Slum, Pope Francis Laments Economic Gap
text: ECATEPEC, Mexico — Pope Francis stepped into the heartland of Mexican inequality on Sunday, presiding over an enormous outdoor Mass in the impoverished outskirts of the capital and urging the joyous crowd not to fall prey to the wealth, vanity and pride that can create “a society of the few, and for the few.”

headline: Kobe Bryant, in His Final Lap, Is Happy to Surrender the Midseason Stage
text: TORONTO — Before the N.B.A. All-Star Game on Sunday night, Stephen Curry told Kobe Bryant that he planned to accumulate a ton of assists by feeding the ball to Bryant as often as possible. Bryant, on the cusp of retirement with the Los Angeles Lakers, essentially advised Curry to pump the brakes.

headline: Trial Illuminates Porsches’ Rise to Power at Volkswagen
text: FRANKFURT — A criminal trial in Germany has shed new light on how a billionaire family acquired ultimate power at Volkswagen in the years leading up to the carmaker’s emissions-cheating crisis.

headline: Brits Off Broadway Festival Announces Lineup
text: New York theatergoers will have a chance to see a new production of the first professionally staged play by Richard Bean (“One Man, Two Guvnors”) when his 1999 play “Toast,” based on his experience working in a bread factory at age 18, is presented at 59E59 Theaters in April. The show comes to New York following a British tour, and is part of the annual Brits Off Broadway Festival, which will run April 19-July 3 and feature nine New York premieres.

headline: Questions for the E.C.B. Leader, Fed Minutes and Walmart Earnings
text: Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, is likely to face questions on Monday about his response to fears of a renewed banking crisis when he appears in Brussels at a hearing of the European Parliament’s Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs.

headline: Jenny Packham: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Ms. Packham, who is known for dressing Kate Middleton, presents her latest designs.

headline: Jeb Bush Adds a Weapon (His Brother) Despite Worries It Could Misfire
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. — The brother who was never expected to become president — but did — will be trotted out Monday as a lifeline to the brother who was always expected to become president, but now may not.

headline: The Supreme Court After Justice Scalia
text: When Antonin Scalia was named by President Ronald Reagan to fill a vacancy on the Supreme Court in 1986, the Senate considered the nomination for 85 days, then voted to confirm him. The tally was 98 to 0.

headline: Malawi Gets Its First Grammy Nomination, With Album by Prison Inmates
text: ZOMBA, Malawi — Old, overcrowded and unsanitary, the maximum-security Zomba prison holds murderers, robbers, rapists — and Grammy-nominated singers.

headline: Warren Manzi, Author of New York’s Longest-Running Play, Dies at 60
text: Warren Manzi, a playwright whose Off Broadway thriller, “Perfect Crime,” remains the longest-running play in New York theater history — nearly 29 years and counting — despite the fact that critics often did not like it and theatergoers often did not understand it, died on Thursday in Lawrence, Mass. He was 60.

headline: With Death of Antonin Scalia, an Already Volatile Campaign Erupts
text: In the hours after she learned about the death of Justice Antonin Scalia on Saturday, Hillary Clinton intended to confine her response to a 79-word statement extending thoughts and prayers to his family and praising his “energy and passion” on the bench.

headline: Parade in Chinatown Raises Spirits During a Record Plunge in Temperature
text: It was worth asking whether it was jubilation stirred up by the Lunar New Year Parade or an attempt to ward off hypothermia that had people dancing on the sidewalks of Chinatown in Manhattan on Sunday.

headline: Scalia’s Absence Is Likely to Alter Court’s Major Decisions This Term
text: WASHINGTON — Justice Antonin Scalia’s death will complicate the work of the Supreme Court’s eight remaining justices for the rest of the court’s term, probably change the outcomes of some major cases and, for the most part, amplify the power of its four-member liberal wing.

headline: Players Who Start March Like Lions Often Go Out Like Lambs
text: Spring training has existed in some form since the 19th century, but to this day no one really knows what to do with the statistics that are generated in that prelude to baseball’s regular season. The tendency of fans to get excited about good performances while writing off bad ones as meaningless has created an ambiguity that the sport seems unable to shake.

headline: Mitch McConnell’s Stance in Confirmation Fight Could Help and Hurt G.O.P.
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Mitch McConnell’s strategy to maintain the Republican majority has been clear: trying to prove that his party can govern. But by saying he will block a Supreme Court nominee who has not even been named, Mr. McConnell is headed toward partisan warfare instead.

headline: Major Donors to Hillary Clinton Include Napster Co-Founder
text: Sean Parker, the youthful billionaire and co-founder of the music-sharing service Napster, gave nearly $300,000 to a joint fund-raising committee for Hillary Clinton’s presidential campaign and dozens of state Democratic parties, federal filings show.

headline: New York Times Journalists Among Winners of 2015 Polk Awards
text: Seven New York Times journalists who investigated the hidden history of the Navy’s SEAL teams, and a 97-year-old reporter for Jet magazine were among the winners of the George Polk Awards in Journalism for 2015, which were announced on Sunday.

headline: ‘The Walking Dead’ Midseason Premiere: Carl’s Big Moment Arrives
text: I guess Carol was right.

headline: ‘Downton Abbey’ Season 6, Episode 7: Crash and Burn
text: This recap contains spoilers for Sunday’s episode of “Downton Abbey.”

headline: At Opening Ceremony, a Contemporary Vision of the Future
text: Syd Mead, 82, has been designing the future for more than a half-century. The Los Angeles-based visual futurist and illustrator is known for creating dazzling cityscapes, flying cars, solar sailors and light cycles for such films as “Blade Runner,” “Aliens” and “Tron,” as well as industrial designs for cars, yachts, wristwatches and more at Ford Motor Company, Phillips Electronics and U.S. Steel.

headline: Behind the Scenes at Opening Ceremony’s Futuristic Show
text: For the brand’s fall/winter 2016 collection, designers Humberto Leon and Carol Lim partnered with the sci-fi illustrator Syd Mead.

headline: Evening Hours | Chinese New Year
text: The New York Philharmonic and the China Institute celebrated the year of the monkey.

headline: How a Vacancy on the Supreme Court Affected Cases in the 2015-16 Term
text: The empty seat left by Justice Antonin Scalia’s death leaves the court with two basic options for cases left on the docket this term if the justices are deadlocked at 4 to 4.

headline: N.B.A. Game of the Week: Cavaliers at Thunder
text: Every week, The New York Times will choose one essential game to watch, highlighting hot teams, winning and losing streaks and statistical intrigue in the N.B.A.

headline: Prabal Gurung: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Mr. Gurung, who brought fashion to the aid of Nepal last year, presents his fall collection.

headline: ‘Billions’ Season 1, Episode 5: Citizen Axe
text: Coming off his dalliance last week with the lead singer of a Ratt cover band— surely its repertoire is more expansive, but it’s fun to imagine all-acoustic sets of songs like “Round and Round” and “Lay It Down” — Bobby (Damian Lewis) sits down for his first-ever viewing of “Citizen Kane.” (Quick side note: That he has a 35 mm projector in his house makes him heroic, and perhaps says something, too, about his love of tactile experiences, like biking out to collect the farm-fresh eggs he’s going to cook for breakfast.) It’s significant that Bobby never finishes the movie, taking one phone call before the opening credits and getting a visit from Wendy somewhere in the middle. But if he’d finished “Citizen Kane,” he would have learned the following:

headline: ‘Vinyl’ Series Premiere: A Golden Ear and a Silver Tongue
text: When Richie Finestra, the record-biz operator played by Bobby Cannavale, signs up his first client, they connect by name-checking favorite musical artists: Pinetop Perkins, Skip James, Kokomo Arnold. “Vinyl” does the same bonding ritual with its viewers, barraging them with beloved ’70s bands on the soundtrack, from Abba to Mott the Hoople, and mentioning everyone from Peter Frampton to David Geffen. Judging by its two-hour pilot, the show provides the thrill of nostalgia as effectively as “Mad Men” did: it remains to be seen whether it also has a story that’s worthy of its production values.

headline: Rangers Lead With Their Fists in a Much-Needed Victory Over the Flyers
text: Philadelphia Flyers forward Wayne Simmonds made sure to slow down before he passed the Rangers rookie defenseman Dylan McIlrath at center ice as they warmed up for Sunday’s game at Madison Square Garden. The two tough guys talked briefly, then went their separate ways.

headline: Opening Ceremony: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Carol Lim and Humberto Leon, who picked China as their inspiration for 2016, present their latest collection.

headline: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders Court Black Voters at Las Vegas Church
text: LAS VEGAS — Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont and Hillary Clinton took their increasingly contentious battle for the Democratic nomination to a predominantly black church in Las Vegas on Sunday morning.

headline: Corrections: February 15, 2016
text: THE ARTS

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “Given that the Senate is currently in recess, we don’t expect the president to rush this through this week, but instead will do so in due time once the Senate returns from their recess.”

headline: What to Watch Monday
text: The Grammy Awards remember those who the music industry has  recently lost. Seven newly recognized breeds join the top dogs at the Westminster Kennel Club show. And “11.22.63,” new to Hulu, has James Franco trying to prevent the assassination of President John F. Kennedy.

headline: Obama May Meet Zika Head On in Cuba
text: WASHINGTON — As the White House considers a historic visit by President Obama to Cuba this year, a concern beyond the political and diplomatic hurdles has arisen: the Zika virus.

headline: U.S. Aid for Abortions for Women With Zika
text: To the Editor:

headline: O Yeah, Canada: The Border Republicans Forgot
text: The Republican presidential candidates who battled for votes in New Hampshire last week, rousing the rabble with their usual talk of scary aliens at the border, were strangely silent about the closest international boundary. They did not warn of the Canadians who flood south by the millions each year to play and work, taking our Christmas-tree-selling jobs. They did not mention the Canadian scofflaws — nearly 100,000 in fiscal 2015 — who overstay their visas, the most of any nationality.

headline: Flaws in the New SAT
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Fire Meets the Wall
text: You don’t need a firewall unless there’s a fire, and a fire is precisely what the candidacy of Bernie Sanders has set off among disaffected Democrats.

headline: Keep Congress’s Portraits
text: To the Editor:

headline: Civility in Politics
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Bison Roundup the Government Wants to Hide
text: THE National Park Service is set to begin its annual roundup of wild bison in Yellowstone National Park today. A portion will be slaughtered to reduce the number of animals that migrate beyond the park’s borders.

headline: Is Humanity Getting Better?
text: I.

headline: Don’t Privatize Air Traffic Control
text: Some Republicans in the House have come up with a solution in search of a problem: privatizing air traffic control. Democrats, the Obama administration and sensible Republicans ought to oppose this measure, which would do nothing to improve the present, federally operated system and indeed could make it worse.

headline: The Learning Network Is Taking a Winter Break, but We’ll Be Back on Feb. 22
text: Because many schools around the nation are off this week, we’re taking a short break ourselves.

headline: Memorable Grammy Looks
text: A glimpse back at some noteworthy style moments: the good, the bad and the memorable.

headline: 爱因斯坦的望远镜
text: 爱因斯坦提出引力弯曲光的一个世纪后的今天，天文学家们使用星系甚至是星系团来放大远处的星星。

headline: ‘A Mother’s Reckoning,’ by Sue Klebold
text: [On this week’s Inside The New York Times Book Review podcast, Sue Klebold discusses “A Mother’s Reckoning.”]

headline: U.S. Rugby Sevens Team Emerges as Olympic Contender
text: WELLINGTON, New Zealand — The United States won a gold medal in rugby the last time the sport was played at the Olympics — in 1924.

headline: After Setbacks, Newark Alters a Program to Encourage Home Building
text: NEWARK — For the past week, on a block of North 13th Street just past the Morris & Essex Line tracks in this tumbledown city, the air has been full of diesel fuel and promise.

headline: Young Latinos Power Both Democrats in Nevada Caucus Campaign
text: LAS VEGAS — Liz Hernandez learned what deportation was at age 5, when immigration officers burst into her home and hauled away her father and four uncles. Five years later, she and her mother, younger sister and infant brother, after a brief return to Mexico in a failed attempt to start a family farm, crossed the desert headed north again in a sweltering van driven by smugglers.

headline: From Black-and-White Negatives, a Positive View of Harlem
text: In previously unseen photographs, the former Times photographer Don Hogan Charles Jr. reveals Harlem’s residents as fully rounded people, counter to the fearful perception reported in the 1960s.

headline: Ehud Olmert, Ex-Prime Minister of Israel, Begins Prison Sentence
text: JERUSALEM — Describing his fall as “painful and strange,” Ehud Olmert became on Monday the first former Israeli prime minister to enter prison, beginning a 19-month term for bribery and obstruction of justice.

headline: Support for Breast-Feeding, in a Multitude of Ways
text: In 2001, when Dr. Alison Stuebe was pregnant with her first child, breast-feeding was a personal challenge that soon morphed into a professional research interest. Her son Noah was 3 months old when she began her residency in maternal-fetal medicine at Brigham and Women’s Hospital in Boston. Determined to nurse him for a year, she arrived at the hospital carrying a breast pump and, through sheer determination, more than met her goal. Noah was 2½ before he was weaned.

headline: Doctor’s Orders: Stay in Bed and Do Nothing
text: It’s 3 in the morning when a lovely woman dressed in baby blue slips through a crack in the door to take my vital signs: temperature, blood pressure. She pings my knees with a rubber mallet, does a jerky massage on my feet to see if they’re swollen.

headline: In The Studio | Rag and Bone
text: David Neville and Marcus Wainwright, British school friends and co-CEOs of Rag & Bone, discuss how sitting side by side in their Meatpacking District office informs their creative process.

headline: Jessica Hart Gives Her Eyeglasses One Last Hurrah
text: Name Jessica Hart

headline: China’s Legal Professionals, Under Limits at Home, Note Scalia’s Death
text: BEIJING — The Stars and Stripes at half-staff at the United States Embassy in Beijing on Monday was not the only sign here of the death of Antonin Scalia, the American Supreme Court justice.

headline: Fashion Week: Tommy Hilfiger’s ‘Instapit’ and Jeremy Scott’s ‘Cowboys and Poodles’
text: New York Fashion Week is comfortable caroming into its second half on Presidents’ Day Monday. (You didn’t think anything so slight as a national holiday would interrupt fashion week, did you?) By Thursday, many of the gathered fashion tribe will be heading to London to continue the international jaunt. But before then, there’s lots to see.

headline: In the Studio with Rag & Bone
text: In episode one of season four of our In the Studio series, David Neville and Marcus Wainwright, British school friends and chief executives of Rag & Bone, discuss sharing an office, the problem with walls, and work/life balance. And that’s what didn’t make it into the video. (The interview has been edited and condensed.)

headline: ScienceTake | How the Stick Walks
text: The delightfully improbable stick insect uses two pairs of legs to walk and the front pair to check out what lies ahead.

headline: Stick Insect Helps Scientists Study How Animals Move
text: Stick insects, which look like walking twigs, are popular as pets and research subjects because they’re easy to keep, can’t fly away, and move at a pace that allows observation and study.

headline: SoftBank Announces Stock Buyback of About $4.4 Billion
text: HONG KONG — The multinational media and telecommunications conglomerate SoftBank said on Monday that it would buy back shares worth 500 billion yen, the biggest share repurchase it has ever made.

headline: From Black-and-White Negatives, a Positive View of Harlem
text: On Aug. 8, 1966, The New York Times ran an article about how many Harlem residents wished more white people would visit to see for themselves their community’s reality. The article, by McCandlish Phillips, detailed in an almost anthropological way the Harlem of 1966 to Times readers.

headline: Medical Residents, Misplaced Pride and Saner Hours
text: When one of my best friends in medical school returned from an interview for a surgical residency program, he told me how some of the surgeons there bragged that they were worked so hard that the divorce rate among their trainees was greater than 100 percent — some of them burned through two marriages.

headline: Opposition Candidate Briefly Held Before Uganda’s Presidential Vote
text: KAMPALA, Uganda — Uganda’s leading opposition figure was arrested on Monday, three days before the East African country’s presidential elections.

headline: Strong Dollar Blues
text: Gavyn Davies joins the chorus of those worried that the Fed is in denial about its interest-rate misstep:

headline: Past Grammy Looks: The Good, the Bad and the Memorable
text: The Grammy red carpet is usually on the more outrageous end of the fashion spectrum, with musicians showing off their personal style. Here is a look back at some noteworthy style moments: the good, the bad and the memorable.

headline: Nikita Kamayev, Ex-Head of Russian Antidoping Agency, Dies
text: MOSCOW — A former director of the disgraced Russian antidoping agency has died unexpectedly, a state news agency reported Monday, becoming the second former top official of the agency to die this month.

headline: Rising Yen Adds to Abe’s Challenges as Japan’s Economy Contracts
text: TOKYO — When Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan began a campaign three years ago to turn around his country’s economy, he took aim at areas as varied as taxes, trade and women in the workplace. The campaign, given the nickname Abenomics, relied heavily on one strategy: weakening the country’s currency.

headline: Republicans Risk Five Key Senate Races With Supreme Court Stance
text: The impending battle over replacing Antonin Scalia on the Supreme Court will undoubtedly loom over this year’s presidential contest. But it may have an even larger role in an often overlooked 2016 election contest: the fight for control of the Senate.

headline: Syrian Hospitals Hit as Battlefield Grows More Chaotic
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The prospect of a wider war loomed over an increasingly chaotic battlefield in northern Syria on Monday, as fast-moving clashes pitted United States allies against one another and tensions grew between two major powers, Russia and Turkey.

headline: Le procès Hissène Habré, un succès à ne pas répéter
text: DAKAR, Sénégal — La semaine dernière, les acteurs du procès de Hissène Habré se sont retrouvés ici pour leurs plaidoiries finales devant les Chambres africaines extraordinaires (CAE), un tribunal créé spécialement pour juger l’ancien président du Tchad. Habré, au pouvoir de juin 1982 à décembre 1990, est poursuivi, entre autres, pour de nombreux crimes de guerre et crimes contre l’humanité commis contre ses opposants politiques.

headline: Oxford’s Halley Professor on How the Climate Challenge Could Derail a Brilliant Human Destiny
text: Sustained large investments in fundamental science paid off in a big way last week, as Dennis Overbye so beautifully reported in The Times’s package on confirmation of Einstein’s 1916 conclusion that massive moving objects cause ripples in spacetime — gravitational waves.

headline: 1941: British Parachutists Invade Italy
text: LONDON — In a brief statement the British officially admitted today [Feb. 15] that they had dropped parachute troops by plane in southern Italy on Monday night and Tuesday morning.

headline: Zika Virus in Colombia Presents Complicated Choice About Abortion
text: CÚCUTA, Colombia — Margarita Rosa Barrios was six weeks pregnant when she began to feel the symptoms that every expecting mother here has come to dread: swollen eyes, aching joints, three days of fever. Just as she feared, she had the Zika virus.

headline: How Does One Dog Recognize Another as a Dog?
text: Q. How does one dog instantly recognize another as a dog, not some other animal?

headline: Donald Trump Escalates Rhetoric Before South Carolina Primary
text: Donald J. Trump, whose presidential campaign has doused the Republican Party with the verbal equivalent of napalm, has escalated his rhetoric to new levels of intensity before the crucial South Carolina primary this week. It is a vote that, if he wins, could erode the prospects of Republican leaders’ stopping his candidacy.

headline: Documentary on Migrants Wins Praise at Berlin Film Festival
text: BERLIN — As European leaders wrestle with a wave of migrants that is testing their commitment to open borders and their democracies, a documentary about the Italian island of Lampedusa — for years the first point of arrival in Europe for hundreds of thousands migrants from North Africa — has emerged as one of the strongest films at this year’s Berlin International Film Festival.

headline: Bluffer’s Guide to the Oscars: Best Actor
text: Everything you need to know about the contenders in one quick rundown.

headline: Silicon Valley Gives Ex-Convict a Familiar Feeling
text: SAN FRANCISCO — If you are, for whatever reasons, seeking a large number of young white men in plaid shirts who are partial to standing desks and seminars on “growth hacking” and “journey mapping,” look no further than San Francisco’s RocketSpace.

headline: Left-Leaning Economists Question Cost of Bernie Sanders’s Plans
text: WASHINGTON — With his expansive plans to increase the size and role of government, Senator Bernie Sanders has provoked a debate not only with his Democratic rival for president, Hillary Clinton, but also with liberal-leaning economists who share his goals but question his numbers and political realism.

headline: Bernie Sanders and a First for Jews
text: ON the night of his resounding victory in the New Hampshire primary, Bernie Sanders, the first Jew ever to win a presidential nominating contest in American history, got uncharacteristically personal in his victory speech. “I am the son of a Polish immigrant,” he told his frenzied crowd.

headline: Johnny Lattner, Heisman-Winning Halfback With Notre Dame, Dies at 83
text: Johnny Lattner, the versatile halfback who won the 1953 Heisman Trophy playing for an unbeaten Notre Dame team, died on Saturday at his home in Melrose Park, Ill., a suburb of Chicago. He was 83.

headline: Anti-Gay Actions in Indonesia Threaten a Fragile Population
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — First, a senior Indonesian government minister called for a ban on gay groups on university campuses. Another official pressured smartphone instant-messaging services to drop gay- and lesbian-themed emoji, prompting one company to comply.

headline: 1966: Russia Rejects Foreign Outcry
text: MOSCOW — The Soviet Union today [Feb. 15] rejected foreign criticism — including some from Western Communists — of the conviction here of writers Andrei D. Sinyavsky and Yuli M. Daniel. As the criticism poured in, Soviet officials appeared to be learning again, as they did in the Boris Pasternak case, of the power of the pen to stir international emotions. Mr. Sinyavsky and Mr. Daniel, both 40, were convicted yesterday of ‘‘anti-Soviet agitation and propaganda’’ after a four-day trial and were sentenced to a total of 12 years in a ‘‘strict regime’’ labor camp. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 16, 1966

headline: Benicio Del Toro and Laura Dern Join Cast of New ‘Star Wars’ Film
text: Hot on the heels of the record-setting “Star Wars: The Force Awakens,” the next installment of the franchise began filming in London on Monday, with Benicio Del Toro and Laura Dern joining the cast, the Walt Disney Company announced.

headline: Lionel Messi’s Foot Sends Penalty Kick Into Lore
text: Leave it to Lionel Messi to turn a straightforward penalty kick into a breathtaking moment.

headline: Woman Recalls Escape From Brooklyn Fire That Injured 4
text: She heard the screams in Polish coming from somewhere nearby — “Fire! Fire!” — and immediately thought of the two young women living next door, asleep on a frigid Sunday night.

headline: Silk Road Market Caters to Lovers of Acceleration, Handling and Plumage
text: KASHGAR, China — In many parts of the world, pigeons are an urban pest or, at best, a tasty meal. But here in this storied, ancient outpost near China’s border with Kyrgyzstan, they are much more: a hobby, an investment and, for some, an addiction.

headline: Honolulu Biennial in 2017 to Spotlight Local and International Contemporary Artists
text: Hawaii has a population of more than 1.4 million people but not a single museum is dedicated to contemporary art, said Isabella Ellaheh Hughes, a co-founder of the first Honolulu Biennial, which will open in spring 2017.

headline: 8 Recipes for the Week
text: “I work every morning, all morning, sometimes in the afternoons,” the novelist Jim Harrison told Esquire a few years ago. “Then sometimes I hunt in the afternoons — quail, doves, grouse up north — but just to stay alive, because writers die from their lifestyle but also from their lack of movement.”

headline: At Victoria Beckham, Casual Corsets Meet Men’s Wear
text: The designer showed a fall/winter 2016 collection that she says reveals her evolving personal style.

headline: Research Hints at Promise and Difficulty of Helping People With A.D.H.D. Learn
text: Over the past few decades, cognitive scientists have found that small alterations in how people study can accelerate and deepen learning, improving retention and comprehension in a range of subjects, including math, science and foreign languages.

headline: South Carolina Church Bridges Racial Gap, but Not Political Divide
text: GREENVILLE, S.C. — The members of Redemption church, a bracing blend of black and white with a smattering of Latinos, flowed into their arena-size sanctuary on one of the last Sundays before the South Carolina primaries. They prayed side by side in the glow of the animations streaming across a million-dollar video wall. They sang together, arms raised, to carefully calibrated worship music that fused strummy, sentimental rock with melismatic soul. They mingled afterward in the church’s Higher Grounds Café & Coffee Bar, standing in line for chicken-wing lunches.

headline: Slideshow: Off the Runway
text: Scenes from the fashion shows during day three of New York Fashion Week.

headline: Americans and Dutch Train Senegal Commandos as Fears of Terrorism Grow
text: ST.-LOUIS, Senegal — On a hazy afternoon last week, about two dozen Senegalese commandos dressed in dark green camouflage uniforms landed their black Zodiac boats on a sandy beach and clambered ashore, their M-16 rifles at the ready.

headline: An Anti-Corruption Charade in Honduras
text: WASHINGTON — Last spring and summer, huge protests set off by corruption scandals engulfed two Central American nations. In Guatemala, an investigation led by a United Nations-sponsored International Commission Against Impunity exposed a far-reaching customs corruption ring and uncovered evidence that its leader was none other than the country’s president, Otto Pérez Molina. Protests in Guatemala City grew, and in September, Mr. Pérez Molina resigned and was sent to jail to await trial.

headline: Hood by Air’s Shayne Oliver Returns to His American Roots
text: Inspired by the past year and a half spent in Italy — and our country’s founding fathers — the designer introduced a fresh yet nostalgic take on his signature streetwear.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Diane von Furstenberg and Prabal Gurung in Pictures
text: A photo diary of the fall/winter 2016 collections that were presented yesterday.

headline: Scalia’s Supreme Court Seat Has Been Vacant For More Than 400 Days
text: Since 1900, the Senate has voted on eight Supreme Court nominees during an election year. Six were confirmed.

headline: The St. Petersburg Lottery
text: This week’s challenge was suggested by Adam Kucharski, a lecturer in mathematical modeling at the London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine, where he studies the dynamics of infectious diseases, particularly emerging infections. Adam is also an award-winning writer, and author of “The Perfect Bet: How Science and Math Are Taking the Luck Out of Gambling,” the story of the mathematicians who make millions by doing the impossible: cracking the code of gambling.

headline: Bard Music Festival Tackles the Puccini Paradox
text: This summer’s Bard Music Festival will focus on Puccini — whose works will be performed alongside those of his predecessors, contemporaries and successors — to explore the paradox of how he became one of the most successful opera composers of all time despite often being critically underrated.

headline: Life Insurance Made Easy
text: As soon as somebody depends on you financially, you need life insurance.

headline: Carolina Herrera: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Ms. Herrera’s latest designs.

headline: How the Bafta Winners Do (and Don’t) Foretell the Oscars
text: Huge surprises out of the British Academy of Film and Television Arts awards Sunday: Leonardo DiCaprio kissed Maggie Smith for the Valentine’s Day kiss cam, but Michael Fassbender would not kiss his girlfriend, Alicia Vikander, creating a moment so awkward that BBC cut it!

headline: Deal on Aviation Emissions Sets Can’t-Miss Goals
text: If the global goals laid out at the recent Paris climate conference are to be met, curbing aviation emissions is critical. But don’t expect last week’s agreement to set the first standards for airplanes to make a big dent. In fact, it will do little to reduce the rise in emissions from airlines, the fastest-growing source of greenhouse gases responsible for climate change.

headline: Uptown — but Natural — Beauty at Carolina Herrera
text: “It’s not about ‘she woke up like this,’ or that she did it herself,” said the hairstylist Orlando Pita, referring to the uptown, well-bred beauty persona behind Carolina Herrera’s fall/winter 2016 show. That idea was translated into impeccable blowouts and polished curls with slightly off-center parts. Using Tresemmé Beauty Full Volume Mousse throughout the hair, Pita spread volume evenly for a natural — rather than ‘Dynasty’ — effect. Pita and his team diffused natural frizz out of curly hair — and flatironed straight locks slightly to create a glasslike finish.

headline: Verbatim: John Kasich Suggests Changing Your College Major
text: — Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio, at Grand Valley State University in Allendale, Mich., on Monday, relating the story of a discussion with a political science major — he told the student he knew of lots of available jobs in such studies, eventually, like, at Nordstrom.

headline: 1952 | Scalia, 16, Attacks the Democrats
text: It was a presidential election year and Antonin Scalia figured in it — in a very small way.

headline: U.S.-Owned Plane Carrying Corpse and Cash Is Impounded in Zimbabwe
text: It was supposed to be a routine refueling stop in Zimbabwe by an American-owned cargo plane, traveling to South Africa from Germany. Then airport officials noticed blood spattered on the fuselage and found a corpse and a small fortune in South African cash inside.

headline: New Jersey Mayor’s One-Man Mission to Help Cuban Migrants Draws Scrutiny
text: Felix Roque was impatient. At the end of December, Dr. Roque, a pain specialist and the mayor of West New York, N.J., canceled his appointments and got on a plane to Costa Rica.

headline: Hedge Fund Managers Spot an Opportunity Amid Market Volatility
text: Stock markets are plunging. The price of oil is in turmoil. And hedge funds just came off their worst year since the peak of the financial crisis in 2008.

headline: Wild Tomatoes Repel Whiteflies, Study Finds
text: Whiteflies are the scourge of many farms, damaging tomatoes, peppers, eggplants and other crops. Now, researchers in Britain report that a species of wild tomato is more resistant to the pest than its commercial counterparts.

headline: Tasked With Combating Opium, Afghan Officials Profit From It
text: GARMSIR, Afghanistan — The United States spent more than $7 billion in the past 14 years to fight the runaway poppy production that has made Afghan opium the world’s biggest brand. Tens of billions more went to governance programs to stem corruption and train a credible police force. Countless more dollars and thousands of lives were lost on the main thrust of the war: to put the Afghan government in charge of district centers and to instill rule of law.

headline: Misha Nonoo and Opening Ceremony Party on Valentine’s Day
text: Karolina Kurkova and Caroline Vreeland at Valentine’s Day cocktails; Rosario Dawson and Chinese dragons at Opening Ceremony’s after-party.

headline: Misha Nonoo and Opening Ceremony Party on Valentine’s Day
text: Misha Nonoo and Alexander Gilkes hosted a Valentine’s party at their Greenwich Village home Sunday night. The Brazilian model Lais Ribeiro and her mom posed in the heart-shaped photo booth.

headline: Ted Cruz Ad Goes After Donald Trump’s Stance on Planned Parenthood
text: Ted Cruz’s campaign has opened a new line of criticism against Donald J. Trump, running an ad called “Currency” for Mr. Trump’s positions in favor of Planned Parenthood.

headline: Your Daily Fashion Week Recap for Monday, Feb. 15
text: 1. Hood by Air’s Shayne Oliver brought a hodgepodge of materials to the runway — including fur, leather (regular and patent), plastic wrap, rubber and bag tags — for the brand’s fall/winter 2016 show, titled “Pilgrimage.” “I’ve been trying to create new silhouettes that bring HBA more into a fashion context,” the designer said. See more photos from the show.

headline: Q. and A.: Steps Toward Settling Puerto Rico’s Debt
text: How much of Puerto Rico’s overall debt is because of the Puerto Rico Electric Power Authority?

headline: Pro-Jeb Bush Group Cancels Some Advertising in Super Tuesday States
text: Right to Rise, the “super PAC” supporting Jeb Bush that has dominated the ad-spending battle so far, has canceled up to a third of its ad reservations in March 1 primary states, according to media buying sources.

headline: At Puerto Rico’s Power Company, a Recipe for Toxic Air, and Debt
text: As a lab director at Puerto Rico’s power authority, Abraham Ortiz uncovered what he suspected was a pattern of lawlessness in the authority’s purchasing department, a secretive place where officials controlled contracts to buy billions of dollars’ worth of oil.

headline: Meet Dôen — a Breezy, Bohemian New Brand
text: The direct-to-consumer, contemporary line stocks casual staples inspired by the founders’ Santa Barbara upbringing.

headline: Ted Cruz Calls Donald Trump’s Sister, a Judge, an ‘Extremist’
text: AIKEN, S.C. — Senator Ted Cruz took aim on Monday at the judicial record of Donald J. Trump’s sister, calling her a “radical pro-abortion extremist” unfit for the Supreme Court.

headline: A New, Bohemian Line — with Empowerment Built In
text: When both Margaret Kleveland and her sister Katherine had children within the space of just over a year, it quickly became clear to them that their corporate jobs in fashion weren’t going to cut it any longer. “We had always talked about starting a label together, but it was always one of those things we thought would happen down the road,” says Katherine, who formerly served as the Executive Vice President of Design at Joie. It wasn’t until Margaret, who worked in design and development at B&B footwear design, had a son in the summer of 2015 that the two women decided to finally launch their brand. “We had a phone conversation and we were just like, ‘It’s time, let’s do it.’”

headline: The Author Pat Conroy Announces He Has Pancreatic Cancer
text: The lyrical Southern novelist Pat Conroy, whose books include “The Prince of Tides” and “The Great Santini,” announced Monday that he had pancreatic cancer.

headline: What Would Scalia Want in His Successor? A Dissent Offers Clues
text: WASHINGTON — What sort of person would Justice Antonin Scalia have wanted President Obama to name as his successor? We know more than you might think.

headline: Colorado Planned Parenthood Clinic Reopens After Deadly Attack
text: COLORADO SPRINGS — The Planned Parenthood clinic attacked in November by a gunman professing anti-abortion views reopened on Monday with a packed schedule of patients and no end to the pressures on it: Two protesters stood nearby, holding signs and accusing the organization of harming women and killing babies.

headline: The Corset Comeback
text: At New York Fashion Week, a telling handful of designers are romancing the corse. Here are some examples.

headline: The Corset: Back in Form
text: Victoria Beckham slashed and sliced it; Rihanna laced it up like a high-top sneaker at Fenty x Puma; Laura Vassar and Kristopher Brock of the Brock Collection rendered their version in courtly brocade.

headline: Our Brains Remember the Good Stuff
text: The human brain is attracted to things that were once pleasing even if they no longer are, researchers report. Study participants were asked to find red and green objects on a computer screen filled with different colored objects. They received small rewards for finding the objects: $1.50 for the red ones and 25 cents for the green ones.

headline: Tommy Hilfiger: Fall 2016
text: Mr. Hilfiger’s latest fall looks.

headline: Grammys 2016: Highlights and Analysis
text: Taylor Swift’s “1989” won album of the year, and Mark Ronson and Bruno Mars took home the prize for record of the year. Kendrick Lamar swept the rap categories.

headline: Future Earns His Third Straight No. 1 With ‘EVOL’
text: For the third time in less than seven months, Future is on top.

headline: Opening Ceremony Sees the Future. And It Hovers.
text: Trend proposals come flying down the runway during New York Fashion Week at incredible speed, but even among that melee, “hydroponic space agriculture” is bound to stand out.

headline: Three’s a Trend: Reimagined Check
text: As we hit the halfway point of New York Fashion Week, a few trends have begun to emerge: Several runways have featured playful check prints — recast every which way. At Suno, a beautiful jacket and pleated skirt came in muted tartan; at Victoria Beckham, where many looks included woven jackets, a checkered dress with cutouts was a standout. Jason Wu, meanwhile, showed a navy coat that recalled parochial school — but elevated with yellow and gray stripes.

headline: Congress Girds for What It Loves Most: A Battle Royal Over Supreme Court Pick
text: WASHINGTON — The outbreak of political conflict over whether the Senate should even consider President Obama’s choice to replace Justice Antonin Scalia on the Supreme Court jolted awake a capital that was settling in for a sleepy, humdrum year in the shadow of the raucous and unpredictable presidential campaign.

headline: Review: Cleveland Orchestra Plays Mozart, and to Its Strengths
text: Less than a month after bringing an astonishing, hair-trigger program to Carnegie Hall — a wintry new vocal cycle by Hans Abrahamsen and a sensitive yet turbocharged Shostakovich performance — the Cleveland Orchestra returned on Sunday with something completely different.

headline: Grand Central Terminal Goes Dark After Power Failure
text: It could have been a set from a zombie movie, hulking forms emerging from shrouded subway stairs, wandering aimlessly into the light. Hungry and confused.

headline: Letters From Pope John Paul II Show Deep Friendship With Woman
text: WARSAW — The future Pope John Paul II, Karol Wojtyla, began a friendship with a Polish-American philosopher in 1973 that lasted the rest of his life. She hosted him when he visited New England and translated a book of his, and they stayed in touch, off and on, until his death in 2005.

headline: Donald Trump Calls Ted Cruz ‘Unstable’ and ‘Dishonest’
text: Liar. Liar. Nuts. Unstable. Liar.

headline: Starting Windows 10 Without a Password
text: Q. Can I change the settings on my Windows 10 laptop so that I don’t have to enter a password every time I start the computer?

headline: More Republicans Say They’ll Block Supreme Court Nominee
text: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans on Monday began to close ranks behind a vow by Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, to block consideration of any nominee to replace Justice Antonin Scalia, who died over the weekend, for the remainder of President Obama’s term.

headline: Verbatim: Donald Trump on Dreamers
text: — Donald J. Trump, referring to the children of undocumented immigrants at a news conference in South Carolina.

headline: Ads From Pro-Cruz Group Attacking Marco Rubio Are Pulled in South Carolina
text: Television stations in South Carolina have pulled an ad from Stand for Truth, the “super PAC” supporting Senator Ted Cruz, after a legal review.

headline: No Comment Necessary: Mitch McConnell on the Supreme Court, Then and Now
text: Mitch McConnell, Feb. 13, 2016: “The American people should have a voice in the selection of their next Supreme Court justice. Therefore, this vacancy should not be filled until we have a new president.”

headline: By Phone, James Dobson Tells South Carolinians Ted Cruz Is Only Alternative to Donald Trump
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. – In a recorded phone message made to South Carolina voters on Sunday night, James C. Dobson, the evangelical leader, called on Republicans to support Senator Ted Cruz for president as the only real alternative to Donald J. Trump.

headline: A New Culprit in Lyme Disease
text: Mosquitoes may be receiving all the attention amid the Zika virus epidemic, but they are hardly the only disease vectors to worry about. Researchers at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., have discovered a new species of tick-borne bacteria that causes Lyme disease.

headline: 40 Trillion Bacteria on and in Us? Fewer Than We Thought.
text: There are a lot of bacteria on us and in us — our microbiome, it is called. Calculating exactly how many microbes each of us carries is hard, and the most common number cited, both in popular and scientific literature, is almost certainly wrong.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: Sies Marjan, New York Fashion Week’s Most Buzzed-About Debut, Turns Its Back on Black
text: It takes a certain amount of élan to make a goatskin coat, a double duchesse satin blouse, capri-length cargo pants and stamped-croc slip-ons in a yellow so bright it could make the sun blush.

headline: Emmy Rossum is So Happy to Be Home, Despite the Dirt Floor
text: It was snowing Monday morning, but inside the Frick, where Carolina Herrera presented her fall 2016 collection that morning, a flurry of starlets were sporting barely-there clothes for far warmer climes. Emmy Rossum, for one, wore a sleeveless floral-print tea dress in pale pink from Mrs. Herrera’s spring 2016 collection, and answered some questions.

headline: Cornell’s Plan to Merge Hotel School Gets an Icy Reception
text: ITHACA, N.Y. — They call themselves “hotelies”: students and alumni of the Cornell University School of Hotel Administration, the world’s oldest undergraduate program devoted to the hospitality industry and, many say, the best.

headline: ‘A Doubter’s Almanac,’ Ethan Canin’s Latest Novel, Has Real-Life Parallels
text: Ethan Canin was shopping at a grocery store in Iowa City recently, when he paused to marvel at a neatly stacked pyramid of oranges. To Mr. Canin, the pile of fruit perfectly illustrated the Kepler conjecture, a 17th-century mathematical premise about the most efficient way to stack spherical objects. Mathematicians have wrestled with the conjecture for centuries, but the store clerk had solved the problem intuitively.

headline: Getting People to Exercise Requires the Right Incentive
text: People will exercise more if you give them money — but only if they are paid in the right way.

headline: Yolanda Foster: Watching Her Daughter Gigi Hadid From the Front Row
text: Yolanda Foster, the mother of Gigi Hadid and a former model herself, was at the Park Avenue Armory on Monday, watching from the front row as her daughter walked in the Tommy Hilfiger show.

headline: The Daily Jewel: Tommy Hilfiger
text: Tommy Hilfiger’s paste and pearl drop earrings look as precious as a family heirloom — but are a whole lot more fun. — MALINA JOSEPH GILCHRIST

headline: North Korea Leader Should Be Told He Could Face Trial, U.N. Official Says
text: GENEVA — A United Nations human rights investigator said in a report released Monday that the organization should officially notify North Korea’s top leader, Kim Jong-un, that he and subordinates could face trial for heinous crimes. The investigator also recommended the creation of an expert panel to identify ways of prosecuting them.

headline: Steven Stucky, Composer Who Won a Pulitzer, Dies at 66
text: Steven Stucky, a Pulitzer Prize-winning American composer whose work was widely commissioned by major orchestras around the world and who earned respect as a conductor, teacher and author, died on Sunday at his home in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 66.

headline: Review: Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane’s ‘Body Against Body,’ Through a Fresh Lens
text: “Isn’t it true,” a woman seated behind me asked after a performance by the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company, “that the definition of dance is moving to music?” That’s a question you’re unlikely to hear at New York Live Arts, where the Jones/Zane troupe has its home, but the company was on tour — at Queens Theater, in Corona — a destination easily reached from Manhattan and yet distant enough from downtown to shift your perspective on “Body Against Body,” a program of duets created 20 to 30 years ago.

headline: Champions League Returns With Teams Shifting Priorities Up a Notch
text: Paris St.-Germain has played 38 games in various competitions this season. But its current campaign shifts into a new stage — some would argue its most important stage — with the start of the Champions League knockout rounds on Tuesday.

headline: Review: Art and Nature Blend in a Concert by Contemporaneous
text: A bitter wind off the harbor on Thursday evening kept making creaking and popping sounds emerge from the garage door that defines one wall of Pioneer Works, the Red Hook, Brooklyn, warehouse converted into a sprawling art space in 2012.

headline: Unusual Molecules Shine Light on New Applications
text: Ben Zhong Tang was stumped. A chemist at the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology, he was looking at a powder that glowed bright green under ultraviolet light. But when the powder was dissolved in a clear solution, the glow disappeared.

headline: Recalling Scalia, a Literary Stylist Who Scorned ‘Jiggery-Pokery’
text: The legal opinions of Justice Antonin Scalia, who died on Saturday after nearly 30 years on the Supreme Court, have long received attention as much for their elegant, learned and often scathing style as for their staunchly conservative substance.

headline: Review: In ‘Funny Girl,’ Sheridan Smith Does the Heavy Lifting
text: LONDON — “When you’re gifted, then you’re gifted,” sings Fanny Brice in the hit revival of “Funny Girl,” currently enjoying a sold-out run at the small but mighty Menier Chocolate Factory before transferring to the West End in April. Since Fanny is portrayed by Sheridan Smith in Michael Mayer’s dutiful production of this 1964 biomusical, no one is likely to challenge such a self-assessment.

headline: Review: Maxwell’s Sensual R&B Makes a Big Room Intimate
text: From the stage of Barclays Center on Sunday night — Valentine’s Day — Maxwell urged, “I want all of the couples who came tonight to procreate this evening,” answered by cheers and laughter. Seven years after releasing his latest album and five years after his previous New York City concert, Maxwell was ready to resume his career as one of R&B’s most elegant accessories to seduction.

headline: ‘Embrace of the Serpent,’ Ciro Guerra’s Searching Tale About Invaded Amazon Cultures
text: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — In 1979 the German director Werner Herzog set out into the Peruvian Amazon to begin filming “Fitzcarraldo,” the quixotic tale of an Irish rubber baron’s quest to build an opera house in the jungle.

headline: Jeremy Scott: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Mr. Scott’s latest collection.

headline: Shoppers Recall Their First Barneys Purchases
text: As Barneys returns to its downtown Manhattan roots, notable shoppers reminisce about their first big purchase at the store.

headline: Off the Runway: Feb. 15
text: Scenes from the fifth day of New York Fashion Week.

headline: Slide Show: Grammys Red Carpet
text: The looks — and the stars who wore them — from the music industry’s big night.

headline: Review: ‘The Right Kind of Crazy,’ on the Team That Landed the Mars Rover Curiosity
text: When the Mars rover Curiosity stuck its landing on the red planet on Aug. 6, 2012, it not only opened a new era of space exploration and a bright new door to NASA’s future, but it also signified a triumph of human ingenuity over staggering odds.

headline: Romee Strijd Transforms at Jeremy Scott
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall/Winter 2016 Fashion Week in New York.

headline: Low Oil Prices Claim New Victim, an Offshore Drilling Company From Texas
text: Yet another oil company has filed for bankruptcy, as the energy industry and its lenders brace for a prolonged slump.

headline: Grammy Winners 2016
text: Read our full report on the Grammys | A critic’s notebook on the show

headline: No Mention of ‘Birther’ Debate as Donald Trump Woos Blacks in South Carolina
text: Donald J. Trump, looking to amass as many votes as possible in the South Carolina primary, is increasingly trying to appeal to the state’s black voters. In doing so, he appears to hope that any memory of his 2011 demand to see the birth certificate of the nation’s first black president is a distant one.

headline: The Row: Fall 2016 RTW
text: The Olsen twins are back in New York to present their latest fall collection.

headline: 3.1 Phillip Lim: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Mr. Lim who just celebrated his 10th anniversary, presents his fall collection.

headline: Slide Show: Grammys Red Carpet
text: Check out some of the show’s most glittering outfits, including many that will be cited by the fashion police in the days to come.

headline: Bernie Sanders Meets With Residents of Flint Before Campaign Rally in Michigan
text: YPSILANTI, Mich. — Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont held a boisterous campaign event at Eastern Michigan University here on Monday with about 9,400 supporters cheering along to his hour-long speech.

headline: Rush Limbaugh Sees Strategy Behind Donald Trump’s ‘They Lied’ Claim
text: As Donald J. Trump on Monday avoided repeating his recent debate claim that the George W. Bush administration had “lied” in the buildup to the invasion of Iraq in 2003, the conservative radio host Rush Limbaugh said that Mr. Trump had used the language of Democrats to attack the former president.

headline: Review: Vox Luminis Explores Bach’s Family Tree
text: That Bach came from hardy compositional stock is well known. But the actual music of his forebears remains obscure.

headline: Police Investigating Claim Eliot Spitzer Choked Woman in Plaza Hotel
text: Eliot Spitzer, who resigned as governor of New York in 2008 amid reports that he was a client of a high-priced prostitution ring, is now at the center of a new criminal investigation, according to officials, after a 26-year-old woman said he choked her when they were alone in a room at the Plaza Hotel.

headline: Group Backing Ted Cruz Makes $573,000 Ad Buy in Nevada
text: The most prominent “super PAC” supporting Ted Cruz said on Monday that it was placing a $573,000 ad buy in Nevada and boosting its field operations in the state.

headline: Review: In ‘Drunken With What,’ a Streamlined ‘Mourning Becomes Electra’
text: Eugene O’Neill had some difficulty settling on a form and a style for the trilogy of plays that would constitute “Mourning Becomes Electra,” his 1931 adaptation of Aeschylus’ “The Oresteia.” He tried verse, he tried masks; he tried abandoning the play entirely and writing a life of Aeschylus instead. The script ultimately blended Greek tragedy with Yankee mythos, Freudian theory with melodrama. Hailed as a masterpiece in its day, it is a lot less popular now.

headline: R.N.C. Disputes Donald Trump’s Claim on Debate Being Stacked With Donors
text: The Republican National Committee is pushing back against Donald J. Trump’s claim that the jeers that serenaded him during the presidential debate on Saturday were from an audience stacked with big money donors.

headline: In Supreme Court Vacancy, Ted Cruz Senses an Opening
text: AIKEN, S.C. — A conservative titan. A judicial morass. A Senate showdown with President Obama.

headline: U.S. Closing a Loophole on Products Tied to Slaves
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama will sign legislation this week that effectively bans American imports of fish caught by forced labor in Southeast Asia, part of a flurry of recent actions by the White House, federal agencies, international trade unions and foreign governments to address lawlessness at sea and to better protect offshore workers and the marine environment.

headline: What Planners of Brooklyn-Queens Streetcar Line Can Learn in New Jersey
text: HOBOKEN, N.J. — With Mayor Bill de Blasio proposing a streetcar line from Brooklyn to Queens, city planners do not have to search far for an example of a similar system to help guide them.

headline: Yemen: Embattled City at Risk of Famine, United Nations Warns
text: Residents of Taiz, a city that has come under siege in the nearly year-old Yemen conflict, are one step away from famine because combatants have prevented aid groups from delivering emergency supplies, the United Nations said on Monday. The World Food Program, the organization’s anti-hunger agency, said it had managed to send some aid into Taiz over the weekend, but described the shipment as a “one-off delivery” that would feed only 3,000 families for a month. Taiz residents are now among roughly 7.6 million people in Yemen who are classified as “severely food insecure” — a condition in the five-point Integrated Food Security Phase Classification scale just above famine level.

headline: Bahrain: 4 Journalists Detained
text: Press freedom advocates protested to Bahrain on Monday over the arrest of four American journalists who had been reporting on the fifth anniversary of the political opposition uprising in the Gulf monarchy, an ally of the United States. The Bahrain authorities, who seized the four on Sunday, did not identify them by name, but the family of one identified her as Anna Therese Day, a freelance journalist and Fulbright Fellow who has reported for The Huffington Post and other media outlets. The Bahrain police website said the four were suspected of having entered Bahrain illegally and “participating in an unlawful gathering.” The Committee to Protect Journalists in New York called for their immediate release.

headline: Israel: Ex-Prime Minister Begins Prison Term for Bribery Conviction
text: Describing his fall as “painful and strange,” Ehud Olmert became on Monday the first former Israeli prime minister to enter prison, beginning a 19-month term for bribery and obstruction of justice. In a video released by his office shortly before the armored car carrying him swept through the prison gates, Mr. Olmert, 70, who was convicted in 2014, acknowledged that he had “made mistakes,” but he insisted that he had done nothing criminal. Looking somber and fatigued, Mr. Olmert remarked: “I accept the sentence with a very heavy heart. Nobody stands above the law.”

headline: Lincoln Memorial to Get Major Renovation
text: WASHINGTON — The Lincoln Memorial will undergo some of its most extensive renovations to date, the National Park Service said on Monday, including efforts to wash away dirt and debris, repair damage sustained during a 2011 earthquake, and build a substantial space for educational programs under the memorial.

headline: Zero + Maria Cornejo: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Ms. Cornejo’s latest looks.

headline: Thom Browne: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Mr. Browne presents his latest designs.

headline: Leo Van Munching Jr., Empire Builder for Heineken, Dies at 89
text: Leo Van Munching Jr., whose stewardship of the importing company started by his father made the Dutch-brewed beer Heineken and its low-calorie sibling, Amstel Light, familiar brand names in the United States, died on Sunday at his home in Darien, Conn. He was 89.

headline: An Asia Summit Meeting Is Overshadowed by Scalia
text: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. — President Obama welcomed the leaders of 10 Southeast Asian countries to this desert oasis for a summit meeting on Monday, giving him another chance to shine a spotlight on one of his most ambitious geopolitical projects: the “pivot” to Asia.

headline: In Queens, Broadcasting Banter From a Bar in a Garage
text: It was Friday night again, and the men trickled in — Brian, Ryan, Pat and Tommy — and joined their friend John at a bar lined with ashtrays, shot glasses and bottles of Irish whiskey.

headline: At Mass, Pope Francis Embraces ‘Misunderstood’ of Mexico
text: SAN CRISTÓBAL DE LAS CASAS, Mexico — Pope Francis came to the highlands of Mexico’s southern frontier on Monday to offer a pastoral embrace to the region’s impoverished indigenous people, expressing shame over discrimination and exploitation and honoring the legacy of a beloved local bishop who once clashed with the Mexican government — and the Vatican.

headline: Saying Farewell to David Frei, Westminster’s Nuzzling Voice
text: David Frei’s voice has become as familiar as the woof of a beloved family pet during his 26 years as the lead commentator of the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show. Clad in a tuxedo, he re-enters the lives of dog enthusiasts each February for two nights of prime-time canine analysis and storytelling.

headline: ‘The X-Files’ Season 10, Episode 5: Mulder’s Magic Mushrooms
text: “The X-Files” took inspiration from a variety of sources this week in a slow-starting episode that ended up being quite enjoyable and ultimately a little heartbreaking. We saw Mulder dancing shirtless and communicating with the near dead and Scully mentoring a younger agent who bore more than a passing resemblance to Mulder.

headline: ‘A Crisis Every Day’ for the Mayor Trying to Rescue Atlantic City
text: ATLANTIC CITY — Even a short list of the troubles that have befallen this fading seaside resort since Donald Guardian was elected mayor would make anyone wonder why he got himself into this mess.

headline: Kendrick Lamar Sweeps Rap Field at Grammys; Taylor Swift Wins Best Album
text: LOS ANGELES — The 58th annual Grammy Awards on Monday celebrated a young generation of chart-dominating pop stars, with Taylor Swift winning album of the year for “1989” and Kendrick Lamar sweeping the rap categories, even as the show devoted much of its airtime to lionizing musical heroes of decades past.

headline: ‘Real Clothes on Real Girls’: Diane von Furstenberg’s Immersive Experience
text: “Real clothes on real girls.” That was how Diane von Furstenberg described the idea behind her fall … well, call it an immersive experience: the fashion equivalent of the theatrical trend embodied by “Then She Fell” and “Sleep No More.”

headline: Jeb Bush, With Assist From George, Goes After Donald Trump
text: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C. — The Bush family, a dynasty that defined Republicanism for decades, clashed on Monday with the new and irreverent face of the party, Donald J. Trump, in one of the most vivid and powerful confrontations in the presidential primary campaign so far.

headline: A New Season for the Mets’ Matt Harvey, but One Pitch Is Hard to Shake Off
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Matt Harvey had a quiet off-season, for the most part. He took some time to rest, attended a bunch of Knicks and Rangers games and began working out at Scott Boras’s training facility in California, trying to make sure his right arm would be strong and durable as he heads into his second full season following Tommy John surgery.

headline: Dispute With New York City Threatens Success Academy’s Pre-K
text: A critical deadline passed on Monday in a dispute between Success Academy charter schools and the de Blasio administration over the charter school network’s prekindergarten program, leaving its fate in doubt.

headline: How to Bring the Supreme Court Back Down to Earth
text: Seven of the eight justices on the Supreme Court today all come from the federal appeals courts. (So did Justice Antonin Scalia, who died Saturday.) Only Justice Anthony M. Kennedy, who was a judge in California, served outside the East Coast cities of Boston, New York, Philadelphia and Washington. All eight attended law school at Harvard or Yale. None ever held elected office. Today’s court is “in some ways the most insulated and homogenous in American history,” as Adam Liptak wrote in 2009.

headline: Before Scalia’s Death, a Clash Between G.O.P. and Obama Over Appellate Judges
text: WASHINGTON — The vow by Senate Republicans to block whomever President Obama nominates to fill the sudden vacancy on the Supreme Court presages a prolonged election year struggle, but the clash is less a new front against the White House than an escalation of a battle that had begun at the appeals court level before Justice Antonin Scalia died.

headline: No Corrections: February 16, 2016
text: No corrections appeared in print.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “This fight has been fought by both sides for decades.”

headline: Carved Decoration on a Ship’s Prow
text: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Some of you out there are beginning solvers, and I will be talking directly to you today. Those of you who are veteran solvers will no doubt find this fairly easy, but if you are a beginner who is just challenging yourself to push past Monday solving, it’s helpful to learn how to recognize different types of themes.

headline: Organic Meat and Milk Higher in Healthful Fatty Acids
text: Organic meat and milk differ markedly from their conventionally produced counterparts in measures of certain nutrients, a review of scientific studies reported on Tuesday.

headline: Zac Posen: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Mr. Posen presents his fall collection.

headline: Rag & Bone Menswear: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Mr. Wainwright and Mr. Neville present their latest designs in men’s wear.

headline: November's Referendum on Justice
text: If the Senate Republican leaders refuse to consider a Supreme Court nomination from President Obama, what effect could that have on the November elections?

headline: Man Waving Gun Is Shot by Officers in the Bronx, Police Say
text: A man who had been seen waving a gun and pointing it at people was shot and wounded by police officers outside a playground in the South Bronx on Monday afternoon, the authorities said.

headline: Rag & Bone: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Mr. Wainwright and Mr. Neville who met at a british boarding school, present their latest designs.

headline: ‘Better Call Saul’ Season 2 Premiere: No Seriously, Call Saul
text: The debut episode of Season 2 of “Better Call Saul” ends with Jimmy McGill warily checking out his swish new office at the Santa Fe law firm of Davis & Main. Near a window, Jimmy finds a light switch with a stern warning: “Always leave ON!!! Do NOT turn OFF!”

headline: Opera Philadelphia Will Mount ‘Breaking the Waves’ Adaptation
text: “Breaking the Waves,” a new chamber opera by Missy Mazzoli with a libretto by Royce Vavrek that is based on the psychosexual 1996 Lars von Trier film of the same name, will be given its world premiere in September by Opera Philadelphia, the company announced Tuesday.

headline: Borzoi, Bulldog, German Shepherd and Shih Tzu Are Group Winners
text: The first night of judging at the 140th Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show produced winners in four groups Monday at Madison Square Garden. A borzoi named Lucy was first among the hounds; Panda, a Shih Tzu, was named the top toy; Annabelle, a serene bulldog, was selected as the best in the nonsporting group; and Rumor, a German shepherd who was the top dog heading into the show, won the herding group.

headline: A Good Hair Day, at Least for the Nonhumans
text: It was snowy and windy in Manhattan, but the competitors were perfectly primped for judging at the 140th annual Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show.

headline: At the Grammys, Big Voices, Pretty Faces and Bitter Truths
text: To belt, to dance, to rap or to mourn? The 58th annual Grammy Awards cycled through those modes on Monday night in its live broadcast from the Staples Center.

headline: What to Watch Tuesday
text: No time to read? Catch up on The New Yorker with a new series drawn from its pages. Meanwhile, on “American Crime Story,” Robert Shapiro assembles the Dream Team. And Gonzaga University’s men’s basketball players hustle toward March Madness.

headline: 2016 Grammy Awards
text: At this year’s biggest music award ceremony, performers were honored, stars paid tribute to legends and artists spoke out about social injustices.

headline: A Frequent Flyer’s Photos of Air Travel
text: For the past ten years, Mindaugas Kavaliauskas has been zipping through airports, traveling extensively to produce photography events. He eventually slowed down, capturing the beauty in moments of familiarity. The following captions for the slideshow were provided by the photographer.

headline: E-Commerce: Convenience Built on a Mountain of Cardboard
text: Ruchit Garg, a Silicon Valley entrepreneur, says that he worries that something isn’t right with his Internet shopping habit. With each new delivery to his doorstep — sometimes several in a day — he faces the source of his guilt and frustration: another cardboard box.

headline: Transgender Patients Face Challenges at the Hospital
text: After a skiing accident in January left him with a smashed knee, Beck Bailey, a transgender man in Greenfield, Mass., spent 15 days in a Vermont hospital undergoing a handful of surgeries. As part of his normal routine, Mr. Bailey gives himself regular shots of testosterone. But the endocrinologist on duty in Vermont told him that patients should not take testosterone post surgery.

headline: A Frequent Flyer’s Photos of Air Travel
text: Mindaugas Kavaliauskas grew up in Lithuania when it was still a part of the Soviet Union and he remembers flying as a teenager to Moscow to see his grandmother in the 1980s. Air travel seemed “a matter of privilege, luxury.” And now? Well, he has used the word “bus” more than once.

text: To the Editor:

headline: The Chirp Heard Across the Universe
text: The faint chirp detected by what must be two of the largest and most sensitive microphones ever made — a brief, rising tone from gravitational waves generated by an immeasurably powerful collision of two black holes a billion years ago — has engendered a number of articles about why we should concern ourselves, and by extension dedicate so many resources, to exploring an event so distant in time and space. Various justifications have been offered, from lists of the practical benefits of past discoveries that seemed useless when they were made, to the metaphysical notion that the better we understand our universe, the better we understand ourselves.

headline: In Election Years, a History of Confirming Court Nominees
text: MEMPHIS — “THE American people should have a voice in the selection of their next Supreme Court justice,” Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the Republican majority leader, announced after news of Justice Antonin Scalia’s death. “Therefore, this vacancy should not be filled until we have a new president.” Many of the Republican presidential contenders have heartily endorsed this argument.

headline: How the Coal Industry Flattened the Mountains of Appalachia
text: As the destructive coal mining process known as mountaintop removal ebbs in Appalachia, it is leaving behind what amounts to its own grim field of tombstones: A grossly disfigured landscape pocked with decapitated mountains standing flat as mesas and inhospitable to forest restoration.

headline: Let Ohio Vote First
text: We, as voters and election-obsessed bystanders, made it past the first two contests in this eons-long presidential primary, but seven candidates weren’t so lucky.

headline: A College Education for Prisoners
text: States are finally backing away from the draconian sentencing policies that swept the country at the end of the last century, driving up prison costs and sending too many people to jail for too long, often for nonviolent offenses. Many are now trying to turn around the prison juggernaut by steering drug addicts into treatment instead of jail and retooling parole systems that once sent people back to prison for technical violations.

headline: A Hidden Cost to Giving Kids Their Vegetables
text: WHY do poor children have poor diets?

headline: Medicines to Keep Addiction Away
text: Second of two articles

headline: 인간 자폐증 연구를 위해 자폐증 행동을 보이는 원숭이를 만들다
text: 유전자 이식을 통해 자폐증과 유사한 행동을 하는 원숭이가 만들어졌다. 원숭이는 인간과 매우 유사하므로 이 원숭이를 대상으로 여러 치료법을 시도해 봄으로써 자폐증에 대한 더 많은 정보를 얻을 수 있을 것으로 보인다.

headline: Denise Matthews, Pop Singer Known as Vanity, Dies at 57
text: Denise Matthews, the singer, model and actress known as Vanity, who toured with Prince in the 1980s before eschewing her wild persona for life as a minister, died on Monday in Fremont, Calif. She was 57.

headline: John Slaney Has a New Shot at Glory, 25 Years After His Moment
text: The calls came to John Slaney for more than two decades, typically right before Christmas. Canadian sports media outlets would request interviews, asking Slaney to wax nostalgic about what remains the highlight of his hockey career: his dramatic goal against the Soviet Union on Jan. 4, 1991, which earned Canada a gold medal at the world junior hockey championships.

headline: New York Schools Wonder: How White Is Too White?
text: How white is too white? At the Academy of Arts and Letters, a small K-8 school in Brooklyn founded in 2006 to educate a community of “diverse individuals,” that question is being put to the test.

headline: How a Reporter’s Quest for Online Bargains Led to a Network of Syrian Contacts
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — As the Syrian war erupted in 2011, Hwaida Saad, a Lebanese journalist in The New York Times’s Beirut bureau, rummaged through her contacts, looking for phone numbers.

headline: Fashion Week: Eveningwear, With a Chance of Showers
text: Don’t rain on my parade? Don’t ask for the impossible. The forecast for today calls for two things: Showers and runway shows. Skip the suede boots and pack the umbrellas. Through inclement weather, New York Fashion Week soldiers on.

text: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.

text: STOCK MARKETS SPRING BACK | Asian and European stocks extended their gains on Tuesday, bouncing back from last week’s rout, Reuters reports.
