headline: Why Poland Needs American Support
text: WARSAW — SITTING next to Barack Obama at a luncheon during the United Nations General Assembly session in 2009, President Lech Kaczynski of Poland gave his counterpart a copy of “The Peasant Prince,” a biography of Thaddeus Kosciuszko, the Polish military commander who joined George Washington’s army in 1776 and drew up the strategy for the Battles of Saratoga, the turning point of the American Revolution.

headline: Democrats See Chance to Bolster Enthusiasm in G.O.P. Pledge to Block Scalia Replacement
text: Republican senators who are thought most susceptible to a political backlash for blocking any new Supreme Court nominee appear to be shaking off concern and joining the call to wait for the next president to fill the vacancy caused by Antonin Scalia’s death. And that is just fine with some Democrats.

headline: New York Today: The Great Indoors
text: Updated, 7:43 a.m.

headline: Review: Premiere of Wheeldon’s ‘Strapless’ at the Royal Ballet
text: LONDON — A new ballet by the British choreographer Christopher Wheeldon is an event, and one with a score by Mark Anthony Turnage (“Anna Nicole”) even more so. On Friday night, the great and the good had turned out at the Royal Opera House here to see the premiere of “Strapless,” part of a Royal Ballet all-Wheeldon bill that included “After the Rain,” created for New York City Ballet in 2005, and “Within the Golden Hour” ( San Francisco Ballet, 2008).

headline: Bernie Sanders, Seeking to Court Black Voters, Will Visit South Carolina and Georgia
text: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont will head south on Tuesday to court voters in South Carolina, where a recent poll shows him trailing Hillary Clinton, and to host a rally in Georgia as part of his campaign’s tour of black colleges and universities.

headline: Fat Cats on a Diet: Will They Still Love You?
text: Maya has had a tough time slimming down. After 16 months of dieting, she’s dropped 10 pounds and 6 ounces.

headline: Belgian Police Charge 3 in Investigation of ISIS Network
text: PARIS — The Belgian police raided nine homes and arrested 10 people in Brussels as part of an investigation into an Islamic State recruitment network, a spokesman for the federal prosecutor’s office said on Tuesday.

headline: A Fight in the Trenches, From South Carolina to Nevada
text: As the race for the South Carolina Republican primary winds down to the final five days, it has become a fight for the soul of the party — between Donald J. Trump and the party’s last president, George W. Bush. The fight for votes, however, is between Mr. Trump and Senator Ted Cruz of Texas, with Jeb Bush, Senator Marco Rubio of Florida and Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio right behind them.

headline: Republicans and Hispanics: The Extent of the Damage Done
text: The Republican Party has ended up someplace where many of its leaders didn’t want it to be — divided about how much it cares about Hispanic voters.

headline: The Quietly Subversive Fictions of Dana Spiotta
text: When Dana Spiotta was working on her fourth novel, ‘‘Innocents and Others,’’ she sat beneath a huge bulletin board pinned with her sticky notes and research materials: lists of relevant words (passion, transformation, intimacy) and ‘‘seeing’’ devices (zoetrope, stereoscope, camera obscura), and photographs of Orson Welles, Jean-Luc Godard and the Maysles brothers. ‘‘It’s like walking into the book,’’ Spiotta told me. ‘‘You feel it all around you.’’

headline: Xinjiang Region of China Bans Glacier Tourism, Citing Risk to Ecosystem
text: BEIJING — Glaciologists in China and elsewhere have said for years that climate change is the main cause of glacier erosion, which threatens the water sources of much of humanity.

headline: Israeli Officers Briefly Detain Two Journalists
text: JERUSALEM — Israeli authorities issued statements of regret on Tuesday after police officers briefly detained The Washington Post’s bureau chief in Jerusalem and a colleague while they were conducting interviews at the Damascus Gate into the Old City, a site of frequent attacks by Palestinians against Israeli Jews in recent months.

headline: At the Grammys, a Muted Night for Fashion
text: Maybe designers just hit overload. Maybe with the current fashion season, the coming Oscars and the British Academy of Film and Television Arts awards last Sunday, they just thought: We can’t handle another awards show. Maybe the musicians attending thought: Enough with the fashion credits; we want the focus to be on us and our art. Leave the crazy clothes to the MTV Video Music Awards; make this about the music.

headline: Chinese Writer Says He’s Forbidden From Traveling to U.S. for Harvard Prize
text: HONG KONG — The author of a landmark book documenting the millions of deaths from China’s Great Famine said on Tuesday that his former employer, the official Xinhua News Agency, had forbidden him from traveling to Harvard University next month to receive an award honoring his courage and integrity.

headline: Oil Output Freeze Has a Catch: Attracting OPEC Unity
text: MOSCOW — As prices have dropped ever lower, smaller oil producing nations on precarious financial ground have regularly pushed their bigger brethren to stop pumping at record levels and help calm the markets.

headline: Want Viagra? Proposed Kentucky Law Would Require Note From Spouse
text: A Kentucky state representative believed that a new law requiring women to have a medical consultation 24 hours before having an abortion smacked of sexism.

headline: Table for One: Pulling Up a Chair for Solo Diners
text: Table for one? Done.

headline: Gefilte Fish and Gumbo in Buenos Aires
text: On a recent Friday night, a small group stood outside Mishiguene in Buenos Aires, chatting and sipping digestifs after an opulent 12-course tasting menu. Not five minutes had passed when a fellow diner opened the door and bellowed: “Come back in, you have to see this!” The restaurant’s chef, Tomás Kalika, had momentarily stopped dinner service to introduce an accordionist and a clarinetist who began to play joyous klezmer songs, eventually bringing patrons to their feet.

headline: ADT in $6.9 Billion Deal to Sell Itself to Apollo Buyout Firm
text: The ADT Corporation, which provides home and business security systems for 6.5 million customers, is being acquired by the private equity firm Apollo Global Management for $6.9 billion in the largest leveraged buyout so far this year.

headline: U.N. Rights Official Urges China to Release Detained Lawyers
text: GENEVA — The United Nations’ top human rights official called on China on Tuesday to immediately and unconditionally release a group of lawyers detained starting last summer, and he expressed concern over a “very worrying pattern” of arrests and disappearances.

headline: 1916: Oath Binds Allies to Belgium
text: HAVRE — Great Britain, France and Russia, the guarantors of the independence of Belgium, which Germany, another guarantor, has so ruthlessly violated, have entered into a solemn pact that they will not lay down the sword until the integrity of King Albert’s Kingdom has been re-established, its political and economic independence have been restored and generous compensation has been paid for the wrongs which it has suffered. Italy and Japan, although these Powers were not signatories to the original treaty, have associated themselves in the undertaking of the Triple Entente, their Ally. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Feb. 17, 1916

headline: Rubio Tax Cut Got Bigger and Bigger
text: If you want an insight into what Senator Marco Rubio’s instincts on policy are, just look at what happened when he got his hands on another senator’s tax cut plan: It became about three times larger, and way more tilted toward the rich.

headline: Why Angela Merkel Could Lead the U.N.
text: LONDON — Filed away at the back of an office at United Nations headquarters in Turtle Bay, in New York, is a small collection of yellowing letters, containing appeals from the organization’s first secretary general, a former Norwegian minister named Trygve Lie, to be allowed to relinquish his post. To this day, his motive is unclear: Was he desperate to escape the burdens of high office? Or did he believe in his own indispensability and wish to evoke pleas from member states for him to remain?

text: Dear Diary:

headline: Eagles of Death Metal Return to Paris for Concert
text: PARIS — The sold-out concert by Eagles of Death Metal here Tuesday night was at once a tribute to those who died in the November terrorist attacks during a performance by the band and a celebration of those who survived.

headline: Uganda’s Least Equal Voters: The L.G.B.T.I.
text: SAN FRANCISCO — As an attorney and Uganda human rights activist, America’s elections thrill me. It is breathtaking to witness democracy in full roar, as candidates vie for the nation’s highest office.

headline: Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton to Meet Civil Rights Leaders
text: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont will meet with the heads of several civil rights organizations in Washington on Thursday morning, an effort that comes as he continues to court black voters ahead of Saturday’s Democratic caucuses in Nevada and the party’s Feb. 27 South Carolina primary.

headline: Moving Music Between iPads
text: Q. How do I transfer music from my old iPad to my new one?

headline: After 25 Years of U.S. Role in Iraq, Scars Are Too Stubborn to Fade
text: BAGHDAD — It was once a well-kept memorial for hundreds of Iraqi civilians who were killed by American bombs while they slept, a powerful symbol of suffering embraced by a dictator’s propaganda machine.

headline: 1941: British Mine Singapore Coast
text: LONDON — The laying of a new mine field off Singapore, already one of the most strongly fortified naval and air bases in the world, was announced today [Feb. 16] by the British government. Any vessel wishing to pass through the area off the east coast of the Malay Peninsula must apply to British naval authorities at Singapore for a route, the announcement said, while any ship disregarding these instructions would do so at its own peril. The announcement made clear that Great Britain fully realized the gravity of the Far Eastern situation and was preparing for any eventualities. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 17, 1941

headline: Taking Creepiness Out of Computer Voices
text: As machine learning and the use of artificial intelligence spread, technologists are running into questions over when A.I. can get too real — and too creepy.

headline: A Warning on the Federal Reserve’s Limits
text: Inside the hurricane-force partisanship swirling around the capital, Washington has retained a singular bulwark for mainstream consensus: Federal Reserve stewardship of economic policy.

headline: A Possible Preview of Next Year’s Oscar Race
text: Too early to talk about next year’s Oscar race? Never!

headline: My Unicorn Problem
text: It has been an interesting few months on the progressive side of the political debate, and I mean that in the worst way. A significant number of progressives are very, very excited by the unexpected support for Bernie Sanders, and are shocked and horrified to find many — I think most — liberal policy wonks rather skeptical. For me this is somewhat familiar territory: I was skeptical about Barack Obama’s promises of transcendence back in 2008, too. And then as now a fair number of enthusiasts took no time at all to declare that I was a corrupt villain, a tool of the oligarchs, desperate for a job with Hillary etc.. OK, this too shall pass. But I thought it might be worth saying a bit more about where people like me find ourselves.

headline: Dispatcher in Deadly German Train Crash Faces Investigation
text: BERLIN — A dispatcher is under investigation for involuntary manslaughter following the deaths of 11 people after the German authorities concluded human error led two trains to collide in Bavaria last week, prosecutors said on Tuesday.

headline: The War After Scalia
text: In the wake of Antonin Scalia’s death, two lines of critique are circulating concerning Senate Republicans’ immediate declaration that they won’t approve any replacement before the next president is elected and inaugurated. The first, offered by David Frum, Chris Cillizza and others, holds that Mitch McConnell and Co. would have been better served politically by pretending to consider an Obama nominee and then simply using a sixty-vote threshold to avoid approval, rather than coming across as baldly intransigent from day one. The second one, offered by Slate’s Mark Joseph Stern (who wrote one of the more generous liberal eulogies for Scalia), goes further and argues that Senate Republicans are gambling significantly by declining to approve a moderate-liberal nominee, since if they lose the Senate and the White House this fall they could end up with a more radical, precedent-overturning liberal on the court instead of a compromise choice. Here’s Stern:

headline: Pact on U.S.-Cuba Flights Reopens Battle for Seized Property
text: MIAMI — The Obama administration’s top transportation officials joined Cuban dignitaries at the Hotel Nacional in Havana on Tuesday to sign an agreement that will restore commercial airline service between the two countries for the first time in more than 50 years.

headline: Pittsburgh Exchanges Macy’s for Mixed-Use Giant
text: PITTSBURGH — A plan to convert Pittsburgh’s 12-story landmark Macy’s department store into a one-million-square-foot mixed-used behemoth has become one of the latest votes of confidence in the decade-long resurgence of the city’s downtown.

headline: France Weighs Limits of Liberty, Equality and Citizenship
text: How proposed changes to France’s Constitution to fight terrorism compare with laws in other countries.

headline: Boutros Boutros-Ghali, Former U.N. Secretary General, Dies at 93
text: Boutros Boutros-Ghali, an Egyptian diplomat who led the United Nations in a chaotic 1990s tenure that began with hopes for peace after the Cold War, but failed to cope with genocide in Rwanda and Bosnia and ended in angry recriminations with Washington, died on Tuesday in an Egyptian hospital. He was 93.

text: Ms. Burch’s fall collection.

text: A photo diary of the fall/winter 2016 collections that were presented yesterday.

headline: The Best and Worst of the Grammys
text: Kendrick Lamar’s marquee performance, Lady Gaga’s tribute to David Bowie — and other Grammy moments that had us cheering and cringing.

headline: Catherine Opie in Conversation With Rodarte
text: The photographer Catherine Opie is the focus of several new shows on both coasts. A current exhibition at Lehmann Maupin in New York, split between the gallery’s Chelsea and Lower East Side locations, showcases a wide assortment of her work — including landscapes, portraits and pieces from her “700 Nimes Road” series, photographs of Elizabeth Taylor’s belongings.She is also currently the subject of three shows in Los Angeles — at LACMA, MOCA’s Pacific Design Center and the Hammer. She spoke to the Rodarte designers Laura and Kate Mulleavy, her frequent collaborators who will show their fall/winter 2016 collection today, for T.

headline: Pizza Moto @ John Grace Bakery
text: A mobile pizzaiolo sets up permanent shop on the border of Carroll Gardens and Red Hook.

headline: Pizza Moto Comes to Rest in Brooklyn
text: David Sclarow built his first wood-burning pizza oven so he could feed guests at the wedding of two cheesemakers. They were getting married some distance from Brooklyn, where he lived, so he layered the bricks and concrete on top of a flatbed trailer that he could hitch to the back of his Volkswagen Doka. The next time he took his mobile pizza oven for a spin, it collapsed, but by that point, he liked it so much that he rebuilt it.

headline: New York Police Still Struggle to Follow Street-Stop Rules, Report Finds
text: A review of hundreds of street stops by the New York Police Department last year found that in over one-quarter, officers failed to document the suspicion that prompted them to stop someone for questioning. In most instances, sergeants signed off on the stop-and-frisk paperwork even when the forms filled out by officers omitted required information.

headline: N.H.L. This Week: Blackhawks Visit Rangers, Then Go Outdoors
text: Every Tuesday, The New York Times will look at the week ahead in the N.H.L., highlighting hot — or not so hot — teams and players. (All times Eastern.)

headline: The Daily Bag: The Row
text: Only The Row could make a piece of lustrous chartreuse satin without straps or hardware the most simple-yet-desirable handbag we’ve seen yet. — MALINA JOSEPH GILCHIRST

headline: James Truman, Condé Nast Alumnus, Is Now Editing Restaurants
text: It would be an understatement to say that James Truman has given some thought to how his new restaurant, Nix, will look.

headline: University of Arizona Students Hurl Insults, and Litter, at Mosque in Tucson
text: TUCSON — Rania Kanawati, a Syrian immigrant, was walking to her car after Friday Prayer last month at the Islamic Center of Tucson when a beer can landed right behind her, then another one fell by her side.

headline: At Thom Browne, Revisiting New York City’s Not-so-Roaring ’20s
text: A misty Washington Square Park set the scene for the designer’s fall/winter 2016 show, inspired by the melancholy of the Depression.

headline: Facts & Figures: South Carolina Trump Supporters on the Civil War
text: Thirty-eight percent of Donald Trump supporters in South Carolina wish the South had won the Civil War, according to a new poll by Public Policy Polling. Another 38 percent are undecided, and 24 percent are glad the North won.

headline: Two Poems by J.R.R. Tolkien Found in School Publication in England
text: “Grim was the world and grey last night/The moon and stars were fled.” So begins “Noel,” one of two previously unseen poems by J. R. R. Tolkien, discovered in a 1936 school annual in England. Stephen Oliver, the headmaster of Our Lady’s School in Abingdon, Oxfordshire, found the poems after being contacted by Wayne Hammond, a Tolkien scholar, who had discovered a note by the author mentioning their publication.

headline: What I Learned From Justice Scalia
text: When I first met Antonin Scalia, I was a small child with one brown ponytail atop my head. Which is odd, because I was a full-grown woman and my hair was short and blond. Still, sitting on the black leather sofa in his chambers, I remember shrinking. Overpowered by his intellect and his enormous personality, I felt that my feet no longer touched the floor. I had become Lily Tomlin’s iconic character, Edith Ann, in that great big rocking chair. And now I had to convince this giant of a man to hire me as his law clerk.

headline: Fed’s Neel Kashkari Says Banks Are ‘Still Too Big to Fail’
text: WASHINGTON — During the 2008 financial crisis, Neel Kashkari worked tirelessly to save the nation’s largest banks. As a senior Treasury Department official in the George W. Bush and Obama administrations, he helped those banks grow larger than ever.

headline: 3 Americans Kidnapped in Baghdad Are Released
text: BAGHDAD — Three Americans who were kidnapped from a Baghdad apartment by Shiite militiamen last month were released unharmed on Tuesday after the Iraqi authorities negotiated their freedom, State Department officials confirmed. After showers, medical checkups and a meal at the American Embassy, they were quickly put on a plane out of the country.

headline: Italian Lawmakers’ Vote on Same-Sex Civil Unions Stalls
text: ROME — The Italian Senate began voting Tuesday afternoon on a contentious bill that for the first time would allow civil unions for same-sex couples.

headline: Rag & Bone Marches to Its Own (Two) Drummers
text: The best way to appreciate Rag & Bone’s fall show, held Monday night in a cavernous open-plan studio over truffled popcorn and designer chocolate, was to shut one eye, then the other.

headline: Where Do You Draw the Line Between Commercial and Literary Fiction?
text: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, James Parker and Rivka Galchen on where they draw the boundary — if they do — between commercial and literary fiction.

headline: In N.F.L.’s Trying 2014, Roger Goodell Earned $34.1 Million
text: Roger Goodell, the commissioner of the N.F.L., was paid $34.1 million in 2014, a year in which the league was tarnished by how it handled domestic violence cases involving several of its star players.

headline: Playing the Game at Tory Burch
text: Demonstrating her firm belief in the future of athleisure, and the fact that women are increasingly inclined to wear their gym clothes to lunch (and work, and play, and what have you), Tory Burch mixed her main line and her new Tory Sport line in a 1970s-inflected show on Tuesday morning to relatively seamless effect.

headline: U.N. Says Aid Delivery Near in Syria for 5 Towns
text: UNITED NATIONS — Five days after world powers announced that aid would soon reach starving Syrians trapped behind front lines, the United Nations was still negotiating with the government in Damascus on Tuesday over lifting blockades to humanitarian convoys, announcing by day’s end that it hoped to start sending 80 trucks to deliver food and lifesaving medicines on Wednesday.

headline: ‘Come From Away,’ a Sept. 11 Musical, Is Coming to Broadway
text: The events of Sept. 11, 2001, do not seem to be the most obvious fodder for a Broadway musical. But after successful runs at La Jolla Playhouse and Seattle Repertory Theater, “Come From Away” – tracing how the residents of Gander, Newfoundland, took in thousands of diverted airline passengers that terrible day – will come to New York in the spring of 2017.

headline: South Street Seaport Museum Ready for First Exhibition Since Hurricane Sandy
text: The South Street Seaport Museum is set to open its first exhibition since 2012, when Hurricane Sandy destroyed its electrical system and computer network, left oily residue on the premises and created yet another hurdle for an institution that had experienced years of difficulties.

headline: Ted Cruz Outlines Plan to Strengthen Military
text: MOUNT PLEASANT, S.C. — Senator Ted Cruz of Texas outlined his plans to strengthen the military in an address aboard the U.S.S. Yorktown on Tuesday, advocating what he called a “more tooth, less tail” approach.

headline: Review: In ‘Please Continue,’ Human Nature Gets a Lab Test
text: The first time I heard about the Milgram experiments, back in Sociology 101, I was stunned. The results seemed to prove that humans were inherently bad. The subjects’ behavior explained Nazi Germany.

headline: Kosher Fish Sauce From Vietnam
text: An Orthodox rabbi from Vietnam was there to certify it, so Red Boat’s new fish sauce (nuoc mam) is kosher. It is clear amber, properly funky, richly anchovied and without additives or preservatives. It would lend umami to gefilte fish or chopped liver. It’s also kosher for Passover: Red Boat Kosher Fish Sauce, $14.99 for 8.45 ounces at Kalustyan’s, 123 Lexington Avenue (East 29th Street), 212-685-3451, kalustyans.com.

headline: Nicholas Kristof: Three Decades of Covering the World
text: Welcome to Times Insider Events — live programming for Times Insiders and their guests.

headline: Vera Wang: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Ms. Wang presents her fall collection.

headline: Hungary Assails Human Rights Advocates in the Country, U.N. Expert Says
text: LONDON — A United Nations expert warned on Tuesday that human rights advocates in Hungary faced threats and political pressure, citing “attempts to silence dissenting voices” in a country that has taken a sharp right-wing turn since 2010.

headline: Plan by Institute in Princeton Clashes With a Park’s Revolutionary War Past
text: PRINCETON, N.J. — The Battle of Princeton, which some historians say changed the course of the Revolutionary War, unfolded on Jan. 3, 1777, when Gen. George Washington rallied his troops to defeat the British Redcoats. The battle was fought in difficult conditions, and though it was fierce, the fighting ended quickly.

headline: President Raises Stakes in Supreme Court Nominee Battle
text: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. — President Obama on Tuesday challenged Republicans to offer a plausible rationale for refusing to consider a Supreme Court candidate to replace Justice Antonin Scalia, and he pledged to nominate someone with an “outstanding legal mind” who cares about democracy and the rule of law.

headline: Hillary Clinton, Seeking to Solidify Blacks’ Support, Meets With Civil Rights Leaders
text: Hillary Clinton met with the National Urban League on Tuesday in New York, where she thanked the group for “the extraordinary advice that they have given” to her campaign as both she and Senator Bernie Sanders seek to shore up support among blacks as the Democratic battlefield heads to South Carolina.

headline: Coming at the Graduate Center
text: At 6:30 this Thursday; will be streamed at this link.

headline: Second Sedition Arrest in India as Former Lecturer Is Held

text: Details about a memorial and funeral for Justice Antonin Scalia — and the Supreme Court’s week ahead — began to surface Tuesday, three days after Justice Scalia, a lifelong Roman Catholic, was found dead in his room at a Texas ranch.

headline: Atlanta Restaurants Rise Up
text: As the nation’s infatuation with Southern food matures, Atlanta is coming into its own.

headline: Atlanta Pulls a Chair to the Table for Culinary Greats
text: ATLANTA — Atlanta has long been considered the capital of the New South. It boasts the world’s busiest airport and 16 Fortune 500 companies. It is a black entertainment mecca. So many movies are shot here that people call it Y’allywood.

headline: Young Saudis See Cushy Jobs Vanish Along With Nation’s Oil Wealth
text: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — In pressed white robes and clutching crisp résumés, young Saudi men packed a massive hall at a university in the capital city this month to wait in long lines to pitch themselves to employers.

headline: Prosecutors Have Deal With Second Dewey & LeBoeuf Figure
text: The criminal case arising from the collapse of the once-prominent law firm Dewey & LeBoeuf has been cut in half, with Manhattan prosecutors agreeing to a deferred prosecution agreement with another of the four original defendants.

headline: Next Supreme Court Justice Will Be Crucial to Climate Change
text: The United States sure knows how to throw cold water on international harmony.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Candidacy Reveals Generational Schism Among Women
text: STATE COLLEGE, Pa. — In the sun-drenched student center on the Pennsylvania State University campus here, a few days after Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont trounced Hillary Clinton in the New Hampshire Democratic primary last week, Renee Tillman, Melanie Suarez and Kamryn Sandidge were picking at their lunchtime salads when they were asked if they considered themselves feminists.

headline: Nigerian Women Freed From Boko Haram Face Rejection at Home
text: DAKAR, Senegal — A new crisis is emerging as the Nigerian military liberates droves of women and girls from their Boko Haram captors: Many of the newly freed are being rejected when they return to their communities, according to a report released Tuesday.

headline: U.S. Had Cyberattack Plan if Iran Nuclear Dispute Led to Conflict
text: BERLIN — In the early years of the Obama administration, the United States developed an elaborate plan for a cyberattack on Iran in case the diplomatic effort to limit its nuclear program failed and led to a military conflict, according to a coming documentary film and interviews with military and intelligence officials involved in the effort.

headline: Bedford & Co. Fires Up a Wood Grill
text: Bedford & Co. The latest decorative statement in New York restaurants is a woodpile. Increasingly, chefs are installing wood-fired grills and ovens and, like John DeLucie in this new venture, putting stacks of split logs on display. And not just for show. “I saw this grill in Argentina,” he said of the wood-fueled contraption in his open kitchen. “I knew I had to have one.” He features wood-grilled dishes like oysters, lamb ribs, artichokes, beets and whole fish. This restaurant represents a fresh start for Mr. DeLucie, who the last few years has closed all his others, including Crown, the Lion and Bill’s Food & Drink, which he owned with partners. Bedford & Co., done in dark browns and olive green, is on two levels in the new Renwick hotel: (Opens Wednesday): 118 East 40th Street, 212-634-4040, bedfordandco.com.

headline: We Asked, You Answered: Is It Important to Elect a Female President?
text: The Times asked readers for their opinions, and thousands responded. Here is a sampling of the replies.

headline: Purple Magazine and Jeremy Scott Keep the Fashion Party Going
text: Olivier Zahm, Hari Nef and Zachary Quinto gather at Narcissa; Jeremy Scott celebrates his new collection at Flash Factory.

headline: Purple Magazine and Jeremy Scott Keep the Fashion Party Going
text: Purple magazine held its annual fashion week party at Narcissa in the Standard, East Village hotel, where diners were treated to a throwback party favor: disposable cameras. The famed photographer Ellen von Unwerth takes a selfie.

headline: How Mansur Gavriel Turned a White Box Into a Cozy Home
text: A sometimes overlooked part of fashion week (by showgoers, at least) are sets, but designers can spend months transforming a space for their collection. For their fall/winter 2016 presentation, Rachel Mansur and Floriana Gavriel of the New York City-based accessories brand Mansur Gavriel enlisted a handful of collaborators to turn the Swiss Institute in Soho into a domestic scene. The final result displayed their pieces amid a cozy living room and kitchenette — complete with fresh food. “As designers, we think in terms of a world,” Mansur says. “Although we’ve only been able to express shoes and bags, so far, we’re always thinking about the emotional aspect — and not product-driven — and that’s what we want to roll out.” Scroll over the images above and below to go inside the presentation.

headline: Music by Fashion’s Most In-Demand Sound Director — for Chloë Sevigny
text: This season, the French sound illustrator Michel Gaubert is scoring New York Fashion Week shows for Lacoste, Adam Selman, Proenza Schouler, Diane Von Furstenberg, Rodarte, Michael Kors, Jeremy Scott and Tory Burch. But on Sunday afternoon, he traded the runway for an East Village furniture store, to celebrate a different kind of creative collaboration: “Prayer to Saint Thérèse” — an original audio work spoken by Chloë Sevigny, and turned into song. “I’ve been a fan of Chloë for a long time,” said Gaubert. Part of Régime des Fleurs’ Artefacts program, which pairs exquisite old objects with original artistic works, the song honors the patron saint of flowers — a fitting ode to the fragrance brand’s handmade perfumes, which are heavily inspired by art history.

headline: ‘Indentured,’ by Joe Nocera and Ben Strauss
text: The N.C.A.A., the nonprofit organization that once governed college athletics and now more closely resembles a sprawling sales team for high-end workout gear, was, like so many despots before it, meant to be a force for good. Its first executive director, a former sportswriter named Walter Byers, built the organization as a buffer against creeping capitalism and shady gambling interests — a way to protect ­student-athletes from the rampaging hordes of greed charging in from the sidelines. It was meant to be a place of purity.

headline: The Right Sauces for Whole Wheat Pasta
text: Whole wheat pasta just doesn’t work with all sauces. Its nutty, somewhat assertive flavor can overpower a subtle sauce, and its texture, which can be granular, doesn’t work with others.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
text: $3.275 million

headline: Apollo Builds In Safeguards for Its ADT Deal
text: Leon D. Black is giving new meaning to secured loans. Apollo Global, the private equity firm he helps run, has agreed to buy the home safety and fire protection company ADT for about $7 billion. It’s a buyout of alarming size given the fear coursing through credit markets, but the deal comes with plenty of safeguards.

headline: ‘West of Eden,’ by Jean Stein
text: Oral history looks all too easy. When the Belarussian writer Svetlana Alexievich won the 2015 Nobel Prize in Literature for her oral histories of humanitarian crises, it seemed an overdue confirmation of the genre’s literary nature — not just its capacity to tell sweeping, timeless human stories, but also the craft and cunning involved in its artful assemblage of specific, individual voices. In this country the form has proved to be both a serious vehicle for popular history and a reliable producer of best sellers, beginning with Studs Terkel’s “Working” in 1974. But it was Jean Stein’s 1982 book “Edie: American Girl,” edited with George Plimpton, that gave oral history the particular shimmer that comes when lofty literary aims happen to coincide with sheer entertainment value. “Edie” conjured the tragic life of Edith Sedgwick, who was born into a patrician New England family, grew up with seven siblings on isolated ­ranches near Santa Barbara under the yoke of a semi-deranged father, came east and after a stint in a mental hospital became Andy Warhol’s arm candy and a figure in New York counterculture, before being cast out by him and dying at 28 of an overdose. In many ways Stein’s new book, “West of Eden,” continues the larger project she began in “Edie”: chronicling a trickster promise embedded in our national consciousness — something shining and elusive and at its center not just ugly but quite often deadly.

headline: Conspiracy Theories About Zika Spread Through Brazil With the Virus
text: SALVADOR, Brazil — The Zika virus, some Brazilians are convinced, is the inadvertent creation of a British biotech company that has been releasing genetically modified mosquitoes to combat dengue fever in Brazil. Others here and elsewhere see it as a plot by global elites to depopulate the earth and install a “one-world government.”

headline: New York Fashion Week: Street Style
text: Street style scenes in New York City during New York Fashion Week.

headline: Mets’ Bullpen Will Be Deep. The Question Is When.
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — One sweltering day last August, Jerry Blevins remembered he had left his iPad in his car outside his hotel. The Mets were beginning to pick up steam, but he was stuck here, rehabilitating a broken forearm.

headline: Penetrating Every Stage of Afghan Opium Chain, Taliban Become a Cartel
text: ZARANJ, Afghanistan — Shortly after sunrise, an Afghan special operations helicopter descended on two vehicles racing through the empty deserts of southern Afghanistan, traversing what has become a superhighway for smugglers and insurgents.

headline: As Marijuana Sales Grow, Start-Ups Step In for Wary Banks
text: When Lamine Zarrad was not at his job as a federal banking regulator in recent months, he was spending a lot of time at Denver’s marijuana dispensaries.

headline: Vice Bets on an Unlikely Food Star: Action Bronson
text: The mountainous rapper Action Bronson was hanging around in the lounge at the Manhattan offices of Goliath Artists, a hip-hop-focused talent management company, lovingly describing his Albanian grandmother’s culinary specialties, like flija, a multilayered pancake. “Very intricate peasant dishes,” he said as he rolled a very, very large joint.

headline: NATO and Europe’s Refugee Crisis
text: The announcement last Thursday that NATO would send ships to patrol the Aegean in an effort to break up the smuggling rings ferrying desperate refugees and migrants from Turkey to Greece is, at this point, more a symbolic show of solidarity than anything else. Even so, it reflects a heightened sense of urgency about the refugee crisis and sends a strong signal that the Western alliance stands ready to help Europe cope with it.

headline: Bernie Sanders Pledges to Focus on the Plight of Disenfranchised Blacks
text: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Senator Bernie Sanders spent Tuesday courting black voters in South Carolina with promises that he would combat institutional racism, reform police departments across the country, and make getting an education and a well-paying job easier.

headline: Woman Arrested After Stabbing Death at a Brooklyn Restaurant
text: A 35-year-old woman has been arrested in the stabbing death of a man after an argument in a Chinese restaurant in Brooklyn, the authorities said on Tuesday.

headline: Grammys Ratings Hold Steady as Awards Move to a New Night
text: The Grammys on CBS drew 25 million people on Monday night, roughly in line with last year’s show, when 25.3 million people tuned in.

headline: 2 More Top Executives to Step Down at A.I.G.
text: After joining the American International Group nearly two decades ago, Brian Schreiber became a major executive in building the insurance giant up — and then, after the financial crisis, in helping it shrink.

text: Rio Uribe’s latest looks.

headline: Manny Pacquiao Apologizes for Calling Gays ‘Worse Than Animals’
text: Manny Pacquiao, the Filipino world champion boxer turned politician, apologized Tuesday after calling people in gay relationships “worse than animals” during an interview with a local broadcaster, setting off a torrent of criticism.

headline: Donald Trump Is a Conundrum for Political Comedy
text: In all of political comedy, there may be one person who truly understands Donald J. Trump. And that person is a dog.

headline: Review: A Look Into the Life of Henry James, in His Own Unsimple Words
text: “I hate American simplicity,” Henry James (1843-1916) said to his niece Peggy, who had the sense to write his comment down. “I glory in the piling up of complications of every sort. If I could pronounce the name James in any different or more elaborate way I should be in favor of doing it.”

headline: Review: So Percussion, Glenn Kotche and Shara Worden Join in Making a Joyful Noise
text: It’s a good thing the sirens that wailed through Zankel Hall on Friday didn’t signal an emergency: The auditorium was so densely packed at the start of So Percussion’s late-evening concert that it would have taken a while to evacuate. But there was no danger mistaking these piercing sounds, produced on hand-cranked sirens by the ensemble’s members, Eric Cha-Beach, Josh Quillen, Adam Sliwinski and Jason Treuting, for anything other than the opening fanfare of a performance that would prove entertaining, virtuosic, occasionally lyrical, but most often joyfully loud.

headline: Review: ‘Climate Control,’ Where Hot and Cold Mix It Up in a Pas de Deux
text: They come from different tribes. She, in her fur-trimmed hood, could be a Native American of the far north, though her pointe shoes are puzzling. He, with his chest bare above what looks like a grass skirt, might be Polynesian, though the skirt is made of silvery tinsel and his crown suggests ice. She wields a small electric fan; he, a flashlight. But this woman and man join together in a traditional ballet pas de deux.

text: “I want to protect these men from themselves.”

headline: After a Rocky Start, Ted Cruz Had Success Before Supreme Court
text: WASHINGTON — On the first Monday in October 2003, as the Supreme Court began a new term, a 32-year-old lawyer who then called himself R. Edward Cruz made his first appearance before the justices. It did not go well.

headline: They Held Power. They Stole Millions.
text: The Justice Department has led an effort to recover assets that it says were stolen by foreign officials — dictators, politicians and ruling elites – and laundered in the United States. Here is a look at some of the cases it is pursuing:

headline: Wanted by U.S.: The Stolen Millions of Despots and Crooked Elites
text: It’s hard to imagine a public official with more toys than Teodoro Nguema Obiang Mangue, who spent $300 million on Ferraris, a Gulfstream jet, a California mansion and even Michael Jackson’s “Thriller” jacket. The buying spree is all the more remarkable since this scion of the ruling family of Equatorial Guinea, one of Africa’s smallest countries, bought all this while on an official salary of $100,000 a year.

headline: Michael Moore Says No, Donald Trump Is Not Like Him
text: Donald J. Trump’s rivals are trying to tar him as a “Michael Moore Republican” after his lampooning of George W. Bush as a president who lied to America and failed to keep the country safe. But Mr. Moore, the liberal filmmaker, does not see much similarity between himself and Mr. Trump.

headline: German Police Raid Property of Group Linked to ISIS
text: BERLIN — More than 200 police officers and intelligence agents raided an office and 12 homes in the northern German city-state of Bremen on Tuesday to enforce a ban on a Salafist group linked to a previously outlawed group that sent at least 15 people to join the Islamic State in Syria, the authorities said.

headline: The Art and Fashion of Lynn Wyatt’s Paddle8 Auction
text: The auction site will sell pieces of couture owned by the Texas socialite and her friends.

headline: A Famous Texan Socialite on Feeling Comfortable in Couture
text: The legendary Houston socialite Lynn Wyatt likes to describe her couture gowns as “old friends.” The sentiment refers to her penchant for re-wearing the same custom outfits on multiple occasions — and the fact that many of the dresses were designed by close friends. This week, Wyatt, 80, will auction off 17 of her most iconic couture outfits from the ’70s, ’80s, and ’90s — including designs by Chanel, Valentino, Yves Saint Laurent and Givenchy — on Paddle8. A portion of the proceeds will go to benefit the Rothko Chapel in Houston.

headline: Kirsten Dunst and Jennifer Jason Leigh Bask in Rodarte’s Spell
text: On the damp, drizzly afternoon of Rodarte’s show, Kirsten Dunst, a longtime friend of the designers, was seated front row in a sheer, feathered Rodarte dress. It was hardly the thing for inclement weather, though Ms. Dunst cut through all questions of pragmatism and practicality with the plain-spoken truth about doing fashion week as a celebrity: “In a car, out of a car,” she said.

headline: John J. Riccardo, Former Chairman of Chrysler, Dies at 91
text: John J. Riccardo, who as chairman and chief executive of Chrysler recruited Lee Iacocca before stepping aside as the automaker neared bankruptcy, died on Saturday in Ann Arbor, Mich. He was 91.

headline: Prado Museum Rescinds Loan of Downgraded Hieronymus Bosch Works
text: AMSTERDAM — The Prado museum in Madrid has rescinded the loan of two works to a major retrospective of Hieronymus Bosch after researchers downgraded the attribution of the paintings to Bosch’s workshop or followers rather than to the 16th-century Dutch master himself.

headline: Apple Plans $12 Billion Bond Sale for Buybacks and Dividends
text: Apple announced plans on Tuesday to sell up to $12 billion in bonds to pay for share buybacks and dividends, as blue-chip companies test investors’ appetite for debt after two weeks of turbulent markets.

headline: In Speech on Ending Racism, Hillary Clinton Offers $125 Billion Plan to Help Poor Minorities
text: In a wide-ranging speech on “ending systemic racism,” Hillary Clinton presented a $125 billion plan to assist poor and minority communities with job training, education and re-entering society after incarceration, part of an effort to speak directly to African-American voters as the Democratic primary contest heads to South Carolina.

headline: A Tenacious Team of Two in the Cosby Case
text: NORRISTOWN, Pa. — Of the dozens of women who have said Bill Cosby sexually assaulted them, Andrea Constand is the only one whose complaint has led to criminal sexual assault charges. And Kevin Steele is the prosecutor who is now bringing her case to trial.

headline: Accessories Designers Grab Some Fashion Week Heat
text: With the cameras trained mostly on the catwalks, it is easy to forget that the accessories designers who show during fashion week also have the power to turn heads.

headline: Review: ‘Embrace of the Serpent,’ Where Majesty Meets Monstrosity
text: “The horror! The horror!” The terminal valediction of Kurtz in Joseph Conrad’s “Heart of Darkness” is deconstructed with a raging eloquence in the Colombian director Ciro Guerra’s majestic, spellbinding film, “Embrace of the Serpent.” Is the unspeakable savagery evoked by his dying words really beyond the reach of the civilized imagination? I doubt it.

headline: Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton Easily Top New Poll in South Carolina
text: Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton hold commanding leads in South Carolina ahead of the primary election there, according to a poll released Tuesday.

headline: Virtual Reality Companies Look to Science Fiction for Their Next Play
text: Tech companies have spent years developing better, cheaper devices to immerse people in digital worlds. Yet they are still figuring out how to make virtual reality the kind of technology that people cannot live without.

headline: A Patient Shot in His Hospital Room? Evolution of a Times Story
text: A student I know at the Icahn School of Medicine got in touch to say that a young man with bipolar disorder had been shot in a Houston hospital room by off-duty police officers moonlighting on the security staff. I was skeptical.

headline: The Daily Jewel: Rodarte
text: A cuff of climbing silver calla lilies clipped to the upper arms of models at Rodarte’s romantic show made for the chicest of corsages. — MALINA JOSEPH GILCHRIST

headline: John Kasich Hopes for Another Success Story in Michigan
text: LIVONIA, Mich. — Four days before the South Carolina primary, Gov. John Kasich stepped off his campaign bus into a crowded Republican Party office near Detroit on Tuesday morning and marveled at how many people had shown up to see him.

headline: Ukraine’s Prime Minister, Arseniy Yatsenyuk, Survives No-Confidence Vote
text: MOSCOW — The pro-Western government that took power in Ukraine after street protests two years ago barely survived a no-confidence vote in Parliament on Tuesday amid infighting and widespread disappointment over its failure to deliver on promises to root out corruption.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: A Conversation With Brian Ezra
text: Mr. Ezra, 34, is a founding principal of Avery Hall Investments, a residential developer focused on Brooklyn. The company, which was started in 2013, is working on several projects, including residential and mixed-use developments in Boerum Hill, Cobble Hill and Park Slope. Mr. Ezra grew up in Park Slope.

headline: At Film Comment Selects, Period Pieces Lead the Way
text: Even when it looks backward, Film Comment Selects is not a festival that you would ever accuse of dwelling in the past. The editors of Film Comment, the magazine of the Film Society of Lincoln Center, have programmed their annual February showcase with a combination of under-the-radar art house entries and idiosyncratic revivals that reliably deliver an atmosphere of cutting-edge eclecticism.

headline: Review of New York Police Department's Street Stops
text: A review of hundreds of street stops by the New York Police Department last year found that in over one-quarter, officers failed to document the suspicion that prompted them to stop someone for questioning.

text: Scenes from the sixth day of New York Fashion Week.

headline: Deconstructing the Westminster Dog Show
text: Sharing the jokes, observations and reactions of three New York Times reporters assigned to cover the Best in Show competition at the Westminster Dog Show.

headline: Off the Runway: Fashion Week, Day 6
text: Kate Bosworth, front row at Tory Burch, talks about her latest film; A.P.C’s first New York show; Gypsy Sport’s finale, complete with a model and her 6-week-old daughter, Rain, clutched to her chest; and more from the sixth day of New York Fashion Week.

headline: Coach: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Stuart Vever’s presents his fall collection as Coach celebrates its 75th anniversary.

headline: Rodarte’s Fall Show
text: Rodarte’s new collection included a heady mix of frilled leather and sheer lace.

headline: Rosie Assoulin Sees the Light
text: If the varicolored candles lighting the way to Rosie Assoulin’s presentation in the meatpacking district on Monday posed a fire hazard, no one seemed to mind. Most visitors milling around the otherwise austere space on Gansevoort Street were far too busy taking in Ms. Assoulin’s romantically inclined collection of floor-length coats, dresses and jumpsuits, some effusively ruffled, others pointedly underadorned.

headline: Puerto Rico’s House of Representatives Passes Bill to Restructure $9 Billion in Debt
text: A plan to restructure about $9 billion of Puerto Rico’s debt, hailed as a model for the rest of the island’s debt-laden government, moved toward the desk of Gov. Alejandro García Padilla to be signed into law on Tuesday, after winning approval by Puerto Rico’s House of Representatives.

headline: Bill Clinton Makes Case for Hillary Clinton’s Candidacy in South Carolina
text: GREENVILLE, S.C. — Former President Bill Clinton stumped for his wife, Hillary, on Tuesday at community center packed with a diverse crowd of some 1,000 undecided voters, supporters and even a few conservatives.

headline: A Fight Over Argentina’s Debt Produces No Winners
text: The battle over Argentina’s debt is at the end stage, as the hedge funds and the country enter into negotiations to resolve the dispute.

headline: Review: Bolaño’s Mysterious ‘2666,’ Distilled to 5½ Hours by the Goodman Theater
text: CHICAGO — The obvious challenge in adapting a novel to the stage is how to make a story lying flat on the page leap to three-dimensional life. The task is particularly confounding in the case of “2666,” Roberto Bolaño’s magnum opus, published after his death at 50 in 2003. The book spans two continents, nearly a century, two converging story lines — each dangling digressions like an overtrimmed Christmas tree — and runs to around 900 pages of dense prose.

headline: A Fluffy White Dark Horse at Westminster
text: In the bleachers behind Ring 6 of the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show at Pier 94 on Tuesday, Janice Lynch and Brenda Mantz of Falls Church, Va., were taking turns chatting up their Samoyeds while waiting for judging in the breed to begin. More important, the two dozen Samoyeds were biding their time until the Doberman pinschers got out of the ring.

headline: Former U.N. Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali
text: Boutros Boutros-Ghali served as the United Nations secretary general during the chaotic 1990s.

headline: President Obama Criticizes G.O.P. Field, Particularly Donald Trump
text: President Obama on Tuesday offered an extended critique of the Republicans running to replace him, describing them as “troubling” to people around the world and singling out Donald J. Trump as someone who would not be a serious president.

headline: Viral Student Loan Nightmare Is Not What It Seems, Authorities Say
text: In a country where 40 million people owe upward of $1.2 trillion on their student loans, it’s not hard to imagine why a tale about armed federal agents’ showing up at the door of a Texas man to arrest him over unpaid student loans set the Internet abuzz.

headline: Behind the Scenes at the Dog Show
text: The Westminster dog show, which had 199 breeds and varieties in competition, concluded Tuesday night. C. J., a German shorthaired pointer, was named best in show.

headline: Suitor on Tinder App Is Accused of Theft From 2 Women
text: The women liked the way the man looked in his picture on the dating app Tinder, so they swiped right to indicate interest in getting together. He said that his name was Tristan Acocella, that he was in finance and that his sister had cancer.

headline: Jerome Weinrib, ABC Carpet’s Old-School Proprietor, Dies at 86
text: Jerome Weinrib, an old-school rug merchant who helped build ABC Carpet into one of New York’s most successful home furnishing brands, died on Saturday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 86.

headline: Embattled Pennsylvania Attorney General Says That She Will Not Seek Re-election
text: Attorney General Kathleen G. Kane of Pennsylvania said on Tuesday that she will not seek re-election this fall, the latest twist in a political potboiler that has shamed a succession of state officials, destroyed several careers and left Ms. Kane facing felony charges and impeachment.

headline: Alabama: Spill Recovery Money Won’t Go to Hotel
text: A federal judge in Mobile, Ala., on Tuesday blocked the use of more than $58 million of BP oil spill recovery money for construction of a hotel and conference center along the Gulf of Mexico. Senior Judge Charles R. Butler Jr. said government officials had not appropriately determined whether there were “reasonable restoration alternatives” to the project, which supporters have called crucial to attracting visitors after the spill in 2010. The project’s executive director, Cooper Shattuck, said that “there are other funds available for the continued work on the lodge that do not include taxpayer dollars.” Robert Wiygul, a lawyer for the Gulf Restoration Network, which challenged the plan, praised the decision.

headline: Zimbabwe: Owner of Impounded Jet Says Body on Board Was a Stowaway
text: The American corporate owner of the cargo jet impounded in Zimbabwe after the bloodied body of a man was discovered aboard during a refueling stop confirmed on Tuesday that man was a stowaway found in a compartment adjacent to the nose landing gear. The owner, Western Global Airlines of Estero, Fla., also said that it was working with the Zimbabwean authorities to investigate the matter. The MD11 aircraft, en route on Sunday to Durban, South Africa, from Munich, Germany, was carrying a “diplomatic shipment” for the South African Reserve Bank, the company said. Officials quoted in Zimbabwe news accounts said the shipment was a large amount of South African currency. Western Global Airlines, which specializes in cargo flights to Africa, said that the identity of the body had yet to be established but that there was “no indication that his presence is related to the company or this specific cargo shipment.”

headline: Pope Francis Entreats Mexico’s Youth to Resist Call of Drug Cartels
text: MORELIA, Mexico — Pope Francis delivered his most searing indictment of the Mexican underworld Tuesday, encouraging the nation’s youth to value themselves and resist the temptation to join forces with “criminal organizations that sow terror.”

headline: Long After Bergdahl’s Release, His Hometown Is Still Under Siege
text: HAILEY, Idaho — It was the third text message from the unfamiliar number — the one that made direct reference to Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl — that frightened Sherry Horton. It was written in nearly unintelligible gibberish, but its tone was unmistakably menacing.

headline: F.D.A. Issues Zika Virus Guidelines for Blood Supply
text: The Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday issued new guidelines for blood banks intended to help prevent the contamination of the nation’s blood supply with the Zika virus.

headline: Spaniard to Face U.S. Trial in Art Scandal
text: MADRID — The national court on Tuesday ordered the extradition to the United States of a Spanish businessman accused in a major art market scandal that involved the sale of nearly $70 million in forged paintings through Knoedler & Company, once New York’s oldest gallery.

headline: George Gaynes, a Versatile Character Actor, Dies at 98
text: George Gaynes, who played a grouchy foster parent on the 1980s sitcom “Punky Brewster,” the beleaguered commandant in seven “Police Academy” films and a soap opera star with a crush on Dustin Hoffman in drag in the Hollywood hit “Tootsie,” died on Monday at his daughter’s home in North Bend, Wash. He was 98.

headline: At Oscar de la Renta, an Innocent, Idyllic Beauty Look
text: The beauty look at Oscar de la Renta’s fall/winter 2016 show today was evocative of Edwardian beauties — with a touch of coquettishness. Hair was a soft, romantic bun achieved by separating manes into three portions. A bottom layer was left slightly limp at the neck, the hairline loose, lending a pastoral, lived-in quality. The choice to leave knots in a hairnet, noted the hairstylist Guido Palau, “nods to another time and is very contained and proper,” but still very easy, with softness around the face. Nails were also reminiscent of another era. Inspired by 18th-century manicures, which entailed buffing nails to a shine, models’ were given a coating of sheer pink polish, followed with Essie Matte About You topcoat for a satin finish.

headline: Eyeing South Carolina, Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders Vie for Crucial Voters
text: Scrambling for the support of black voters as a crucial primary in South Carolina nears, Hillary Clinton and Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont made appeals on Tuesday to corral their backing. Mrs. Clinton used an address in Harlem to propose $125 billion in new spending to reinvigorate poor and minority communities, and Mr. Sanders barnstormed the South, pledging to combat institutional racism and reform police departments nationwide.

headline: Now Is the Winter of Odd Mets Content
text: When last seen, the Mets’ magic had come undone. The second baseman with the golden bat turned fumble-fingered; the staff ace became hittable in his moment of redemptive glory; the alchemist manager mixed the wrong potions and mistimed the summoning of relievers.

headline: Oscar de la Renta: Fall 2016 RW
text: Peter Copping’s last ready-to-wear collection as creative director.

headline: Giants’ Coaching Changes Start and Nearly End at Top
text: Fans of the Giants might have been hoping for some kind of leadership overhaul under the new head coach Ben McAdoo, but the team announced Tuesday that 12 assistant coaches from the former coach Tom Coughlin’s staff had been retained.

headline: Sarah Parcak to Use TED Prize Money for Crowdsourcing on Archaeological Sites
text: If someone gave you $1 million to fulfill a dream, what would it be?

headline: Christie Calls for End to Partisan Politics in State Budget Address
text: After spending much of the past year engaged in partisan politics as he campaigned for the Republican presidential nomination, Gov. Chris Christie asked New Jersey lawmakers on Tuesday to put aside their petty political differences as they worked to solve some of the state’s most pressing problems.

headline: Obama’s Options for a Supreme Court Nominee, and the Potential Fallout
text: The death of Justice Antonin Scalia immediately prompted lofty-sounding pronouncements from leaders of both parties. But behind the public statements, the two parties are engaged in raw political calculations about how to best leverage the vacancy, underscoring the country’s deep polarization and the reality of how elections are waged nowadays.

headline: N.S.A. Discloses Inspector General Reports on Surveillance Program
text: In response to a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit by the New York Times, the N.S.A. has partly declassified and disclosed these inspector general reports. They primarily relate to its warrantless surveillance program under the FISA Amendments Act.

headline: N.S.A. Gets Less Web Data Than Believed, Report Suggests
text: WASHINGTON — A newly declassified report by the National Security Agency’s inspector general suggests that the government is receiving far less data from Americans’ international Internet communications than privacy advocates have long suspected.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “It’s nice that science fiction exists because these are really creative people figuring out what the ultimate use of any technology might be. They come up with a lot of incredible ideas.”

headline: Mexico’s Kingpin Strategy Against the Drug Cartels
text: A look at the Mexican government’s decade-long effort to break up drug cartels by targeting their leaders.

headline: Who I Am Inside
text: Administrivial Will Shortz “Ask Me Anything” Alert! Have a question about the New York Times crossword … or editor Will Shortz … or anything about puzzles? Will is taping an “Inside The Times” podcast next Tuesday, Feb. 23. If you have a question for him, you can leave it here. Will will answer as many questions as he can during 30 minutes. A further announcement will be made when the podcast is ready, which should be soon after Feb. 23.

headline: Nicolas Sarkozy Placed Under Investigation on 2012 French Election Charges
text: PARIS — Former President Nicolas Sarkozy was placed under formal investigation by French judges on Tuesday on preliminary charges of illegal overspending during his failed 2012 bid for re-election.

headline: Paris St.-Germain Wins but Rues What Might Have Been
text: PARIS — Zlatan Ibrahimovic waved his hands in the air. Ángel Di María fell to his knees and swiped at the ground in frustration. Laurent Blanc shook his head.

headline: De Blasio Says Idea of Closing Rikers Jail Complex Is Unrealistic
text: It began as a “dream” on Thursday, in a speech by the New York City Council speaker: closing the Rikers Island jail complex.

headline: An Underground Brook, Gallons of Sewage and a Century-Old Problem
text: One day, Steve Duncan dropped about eight feet down into an arched brick tunnel that runs below Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx, and waded into icy cold water in a culvert.

headline: C. J., a German Shorthaired Pointer, Wins Best in Show at Westminster
text: As each of the seven competitors for best in show at the 140th Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show on Tuesday approached Richard Meen, the judge, he told them, “Relax.” But you wonder if any one of the four-legged champions, let alone their handlers, could heed the advice, even if they were aware that his non-canine work is psychiatry.

headline: ‘The People v. O.J. Simpson’ Episode 3: The Dream Team Assembles
text: O.J. Simpson appears in this week’s episode for maybe five minutes. The rest of it focuses on his lawyers and the stage they are setting for one of the most spectacular public trials of the modern era.

headline: Judge Tells Apple to Help Unlock iPhone Used by San Bernardino Gunman
text: WASHINGTON — A judge in California on Tuesday ordered Apple to help the F.B.I. unlock an iPhone used by one of the attackers in the assault in San Bernardino that killed 14 people in December.

headline: Political Backlash Grows in Washington to Chinese Takeovers
text: HONG KONG — As Chinese companies try to snap up American tech businesses, they are setting off ripples of unease in the Obama administration and in Congress, inciting a backlash that has stopped the latest acquisition attempt.

headline: Hong Kong Students Who Protested Government Now Seek to Take Part in It
text: HONG KONG — A group of young students seeking greater autonomy for Hong Kong is forming a political party to participate in local elections this year, a move that is likely to unsettle a Chinese leadership fighting multiple separatist movements within its borders.

headline: China Deployed Missiles on Disputed Island, U.S. Says
text: HONG KONG — The Pentagon has evidence that the Chinese military has deployed surface-to-air missiles on a disputed island in the South China Sea, a United States official has said.

text: The latest designs from Mr. Rodriguez, who recently dressed Michelle Obama.

text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Looking Beyond the Scripts of the Campaign Trail
text: Six Times photographers have blanketed the early presidential campaign states for the last three weeks, challenged by carefully constructed stagecraft.

headline: Killer Mike Defends Himself After ‘Uterus’ Comment at Sanders Rally
text: Killer Mike, a rapper and much-used surrogate for Bernie Sanders, ignited a controversy on Tuesday after he said that “a uterus doesn’t qualify you to be president” during an event hosted by the Vermont senator at Morehouse College in Atlanta.

headline: Veto Likely to Block Renaming of China Embassy’s Street After Liu Xiaobo
text: HONG KONG — The Chinese Embassy’s stationery seems safe for now.

headline: Six Photographers’ View of the Campaign Trail
text: Photographing presidential campaigns takes patience and endurance: 18-hour days are the norm, and getting beyond the carefully constructed stagecraft and tightly scripted events can be a challenge.

headline: Love Scandal May Doom Bolivian Leader’s Push for a Fourth Term
text: LA PAZ, Bolivia — Shortly after President Evo Morales of Bolivia quashed rumors last month that he had shelled out $200 for haircuts, a more serious allegation has transfixed the country, one of the poorest in South America, and now threatens his bid for a fourth term.

headline: Who Are We?
text: I find this election bizarre for many reasons but none more than this: If I were given a blank sheet of paper and told to write down America’s three greatest sources of strength, they would be “a culture of entrepreneurship,” “an ethic of pluralism” and the “quality of our governing institutions.” And yet I look at the campaign so far and I hear leading candidates trashing all of them.

headline: A Tale of Horror at the United Nations
text: The United Nations is failing some of the most vulnerable children it is supposed to protect. A decade ago, the organization acknowledged that some of the peacekeepers sent to international conflict zones were sexually abusing local women and children, and it promised corrective action. The scourge continues, prompting one senior United Nations official to recoil at what he called the “constant horror story of allegations” against the peacekeepers.

headline: The Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Trump
text: Donald Trump has been recognized for his mastery of the media, his fascination with gilt and his bold advocacy for baffling hair.

headline: Hillary Clinton Should Just Say Yes to a $15 Minimum Wage
text: On the campaign trail, Hillary Clinton has eloquently defined workers’ rights as human rights. She could assert both more forcefully by championing a stronger federal minimum wage of $15 an hour.

headline: Donald Trump’s Secret? Channeling Andrew Jackson
text: SINCE Donald J. Trump shot to the top of Republican polls last fall, pundits have tried to make sense of his popularity. He has been described as a modern-day product of reality-TV narcissism, or the second coming of European fascism. But as he cruises into the South Carolina primary after beating his rivals by double digits in New Hampshire, it’s clear that neither idea quite explains his strength.

text: BEIJING — More than 9,000 Chinese villagers are leaving their homes to make way for aliens — or for the possible echoes of them, at least.

text: The end is nigh. New York Fashion Week has rounded the proverbial bend and is careening toward its seasonal close. Don’t worry — London, Milan and Paris still await. And before that, two more days of shows.

headline: Airlines to Offer Cheaper Flights, but Are They Worth the Savings?

headline: The Consequences of Our Consequence-Free Society
text: Lately I’ve been thinking about the notion of false courage. It was introduced to me by an unlikely philosopher king: the Dallas Cowboys’ owner, Jerry Jones, whom I interviewed for an article on the N.F.L. that ran in the Feb. 7 issue of the magazine. We were talking about proposals on how to improve player safety in football. Jones mentioned to me a counterintuitive idea that Lamar Hunt, the founding owner of the Kansas City Chiefs, once suggested.

headline: The More Donald Trump Defies His Party, the More His Supporters Cheer
text: NORTH AUGUSTA, S.C. — Mark Jebens, a veteran of 22 years in the Marine Corps, found no fault with Donald J. Trump’s scathing criticism that President George W. Bush “lied” about weapons of mass destruction while leading the United States into war in Iraq.

text: PARIS — Depending on who is telling the story, Daoud Muradyan, a blind 21-year-old, is either a potential terrorist or a harmless immigrant who embodies everything that is wrong with France’s broad new antiterrorism powers.

text: This changing neighborhood, known for its vintage townhouses, is also seeing large-scale development.

headline: Prospect Heights, Where Historic Meets Brand New
text: Rebecca Saltman, 41, an instructor at Teachers College, Columbia University, and her husband, Benjamin, 39, a doctor, were enthusiastic about the sense of community and the cultural amenities of Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, when they bought their townhouse there in 2010 for just over $1 million, with help from Ms. Saltman’s parents, who live in the garden apartment.

headline: Apple Fights Order to Unlock San Bernardino Gunman’s iPhone
text: WASHINGTON — Last month, some of President Obama’s top intelligence advisers met in Silicon Valley with Apple’s chief, Timothy D. Cook, and other technology leaders in what seemed to be a public rapprochement in their long-running dispute over the encryption safeguards built into their devices.

headline: ‘Ginny Gall,’ by Charlie Smith
text: When Delvin Walker, the protagonist of Charlie Smith’s novel “Ginny Gall,” is deep into his prison sentence for a crime he did not commit, a fellow inmate introduces him to the work of Zora Neale Hurston. The inmate quotes a line memorized from Hurston’s essay “How It Feels to Be Colored Me”: “I do not belong to that sobbing school of Negrohood who hold that nature has somehow given them a lowdown dirty deal.” Delvin lets out a low whistle of disbelief in response. “Well, no wonder I never heard of that woman,” he says, and the inmate posits that, unlike them, Hurston must be “somebody who’s found a way out of the general disrespectfulness.”

headline: ‘The Queen of the Night,’ by Alexander Chee
text: In opera, voice is everything. The narrator of “The Queen of the Night,” Lilliet Berne, is a star of the Paris Opera. She possesses a rare and delicate Falcon soprano range, named for ­Marie-Cornélie Falcon, whose voice famously shattered in the middle of a performance and never recovered. Lilliet’s world is one of silence and sound, of risk and fragility, and the balance between vocal power and expression.

headline: Instead of Democracy, Uganda Moves Toward Dictatorship Light
text: KALUNGU, Uganda — For eight hours, under a beating sun, thousands of people stood in an open field, waiting patiently.

headline: Which Type of Exercise Is Best for the Brain?
text: Some forms of exercise may be much more effective than others at bulking up the brain, according to a remarkable new study in rats. For the first time, scientists compared head-to-head the neurological impacts of different types of exercise: running, weight training and high-intensity interval training. The surprising results suggest that going hard may not be the best option for long-term brain health.

headline: Morning Agenda: Fed’s Neel Kashkari Says Banks Still Too Big to Fail
text: FED’S NEEL KASHKARI SAYS BANKS STILL TOO BIG TO FAIL | Neel Kashkari, the new president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis, worked tirelessly to save the nation’s banks during the 2008 financial crisis. But now he thinks it is time to consider breaking them up,
