headline: National Poll Shows Donald Trump With Big Lead and Democrats in Virtual Tie
text: Donald J. Trump‘s popularity continues to rise nationally, according to a new Quinnipiac University poll that shows him with more than double the support of his closest Republican contender.

headline: Pope Francis Wades Into U.S. Immigration Morass With Border Trip
text: CIUDAD JUÁREZ, Mexico — Stepping to the concrete edge of the Rio Grande, Pope Francis on Wednesday went to a militarized divide of the United States-Mexican border and prayed for compassion toward immigrants. He never set foot in the United States, but he did step directly, and deliberately, into the acrimonious American debate over immigration.

headline: New York Today: A Dog Has His Day
text: Updated, 10:07 a.m.

headline: In Battle Over Scalia Replacement, Obama Takes Advantage of Far-Flung Senate
text: President Obama is back in Washington, but the Senate remains out of town on the President’s Day holiday recess — and that has its benefits and disadvantages as the Supreme Court fight heats up.

headline: Palau vs. the Poachers
text: Late on a January 2015 evening in Shepherdstown, W.Va., a data analyst named Bjorn Bergman, surrounded by whiteboards scribbled with computer code, was orchestrating a high-stakes marine police chase halfway around the world. Staring at his laptop in a cramped ground-floor office, he drank from his sixth cup of coffee and typed another in a long series of emails: ‘‘Try and cut them off rather than making for the last known position.’’ Nearly 9,000 miles away, the Remeliik, a police patrol ship from the tiny island nation Palau, was pursuing a 10-man Taiwanese pirate ship, the Shin Jyi Chyuu 33, through Palauan waters. Bergman, working for a nonprofit research organization called SkyTruth, had mastered the use of satellite data to chart a ship’s most likely course. Instead of pointing the police to where the pirate ship was, he would tell them where it was about to be. He took another sip of coffee, studied his screen, then typed again: ‘‘It may be advisable for the Remeliik to turn southeast.’’

headline: Do Women Need Legislative ‘Protection’?
text: In September 1905, a laundress named Emma Gotcher reported Curt Muller, the owner of Portland Grand Laundry, for making her work more than 10 hours — the state’s legal limit for women — on, of all days, Labor Day. Gotcher was a labor activist, married to a leader of the Shirtwaist and Laundry Workers’ Union. The court found Muller guilty of violating Oregon law and fined him $10. He refused to pay, and on appeal to the Supreme Court, his lawyer drew national attention by making a feminist argument: Limits on women’s work hours actually discriminate against them. Two years earlier, in the well-known case Lochner v. New York, the Supreme Court struck down a state law that restricted bakers, most of them men, to the same 10-hour day. The bakers were ‘‘in no sense wards of the state,’’ the court said. Why, Muller’s lawyer asked, should women be treated differently?

headline: Jon Taffer Sees Shakespeare in Reality TV
text: On your reality show ‘‘Bar Rescue,’’ you do speedy overhauls of failing bars. Do you ever worry that moving so quickly sort of undermines the owners? There’s an independent website called Bar Rescue Updates that we have nothing to do with, and they track us. According to them, we have a 70 percent success rate — the highest in all of transformation television.

headline: Are We Doomed to Slow Growth?
text: One day in 1980, when I was 10, I sat in my great-grandmother’s living room and poured out questions about what life was like for her as a girl in Belarus. At 90, she was still sharp and could answer my questions. But she didn’t betray any of the emotion I hoped for. Born in 1890, in a tiny village powered by horses and the sun in a manner hardly changed from the time of ancient Rome, she grew up to witness the invention of the airplane and the adoption of electricity and the telephone. I wanted her to join me in marveling at this series of world-changing transformations, which I knew were beyond anything her girlhood self could have imagined. She just answered my questions calmly, politely. ‘‘No, I don’t remember the first airplane I saw.’’ ‘‘No, I don’t remember the first person I called on a telephone.’’

headline: Reinvention in Walla Walla’s Wine Country
text: There are only so many occasions on which a responsible adult can justify consuming alcohol and food nonstop for an entire week. Turning 40 is one of them.

headline: Leaving ‘Full House’ Was His Biggest Regret. So He Rebuilt It.
text: In one of the valleys between the peaks of his career, Jeff Franklin had an idea for a TV series. Called “House of Comics,” it would follow three aspiring stand-ups living together in Los Angeles. “It was three single guys trying to cause trouble, and then turning it into material for their act,” Mr. Franklin explained. “That was the show I wanted to do.”

headline: Judge John Hodgman on a Home Cellphone Ban
text: Denise writes: We are expecting our first baby, and I want her to grow up in a home where people still pay attention to one another. I’d like to put a friendly sign on our door that asks guests to use phones in our home only in the event of an emergency. My husband cringes at the thought.

headline: Should I Speak Up for a Pet Pig?
text: I am in a profession where I often go to people’s houses to work with their children. I have one client whom I like very much and who has requested my services a number of times, but whenever I leave that client’s house, I find myself troubled. This family has a teacup pig, which lives with them in a medium-size apartment. I consider myself an animal lover, and it so happens that I have looked into the fad of teacup pigs. I know that they are really piglets of a larger variety, the potbellied pig, which are unintentionally underfed by owners who have been led by dishonest sellers to believe that the pigs need to eat less than they really do. Right now the pig is small, perhaps 10 to 15 pounds, but I know it will keep growing and that the lowest healthy weight for a full-grown ‘‘teacup pig’’ is about 60 pounds; a potbellied pig can easily grow to more than 100 pounds. I asked the family how big the pig would get, thinking perhaps they knew the facts and had some plan. They told me that they expect it to remain the size it is now. The worst part? They often remark that the pig is acting hungry; I imagine they feed him the too-small amount they were directed to by the seller. I believe that this family loves their pig very much and that I am witnessing an unintentional act of animal cruelty, but I am in a quandary: Should I tell them that they are unwittingly mistreating their beloved pet? I worry that I would be overstepping my professional bounds. People can be very touchy when it comes to their pets, and I want to maintain cordial relations with them for the sake of my continued employment. Do I have an ethical obligation to tell them the truth about teacup pigs? Name Withheld

headline: Clinton, Sanders and the Underrated Power of the Black Voter
text: If you were asked to assess African-American voting power, you might think about the long history of disenfranchisement that still lingers today, in troubles in Ferguson, Mo.; in efforts to roll back the Voting Rights Act; or in recent moves to limit voting access around the country.

headline: Final Days Before Crucial Votes Offer Viewers a Full Television Lineup
text: The 2016 presidential campaign has played out largely on television, whether in the form of ads or news conferences or the reams of Donald J. Trump coverage. So it’s only fitting that the final days of the Republican primary in South Carolina and the Democratic caucuses in Nevada will play out in televised town-hall-style meetings.

headline: Where the Senate Stands on Nominating Scalia’s Supreme Court Successor
text: Should the Senate vote on a nominee from President Obama to fill the Supreme Court vacancy left by the death of Justice Antonin Scalia, or should the next president decide? We’re asking each senator his or her position.

headline: Bombardier to Cut 7,000 Jobs as New Airliner Struggles to Draw Buyers
text: OTTAWA — Bombardier, the Canadian transportation company, said on Wednesday that it would lay off about 7,000 employees over the next two years, as it struggles to find buyers for a new series of planes that for the first time put it in direct competition with the aviation giants Boeing and Airbus.

headline: Arguing Before Justice Scalia
text: A few years back, during oral argument, Justice Antonin Scalia asked me when I thought “the bad old days” — when the Supreme Court routinely looked beyond the text of statutes — had ended?

headline: Boutros-Ghali: Outspoken Diplomat
text: Boutros Boutros-Ghali, the former U.N. secretary general, died at the age of 93. His tenure was defined by tragedies in Somalia, Rwanda and the former Yugoslavia as well as friction with the Clinton administration.

headline: Three’s a Trend: Edgy Sequins
text: What do we associate with sequins? Glamour — even gaudiness? This season, three designers used them in new, unexpectedly edgy ways. First, Joseph Altuzarra closed his show with a floor-length boho gown that was toughened up with sequins. Derek Lam showed a beaded black V-neck paired with an armor-like metallic skirt. And yesterday on the dreamy Rodarte runway, Kate and Laura Mulleavy added a sparkly touch to their signature, intricate gowns.

headline: ‘Hamilton’ Tops Box Office Again With Nearly $1.8 Million
text: The juggernaut that is “Hamilton,” the hip-hop-flavored musical about the founding fathers, shows no signs of slowing down, once again winning the weekly Broadway box-office derby. And given the prime showcase for the musical’s opening number on the Grammys broadcast on Monday night, that dominating run could continue for quite a while.

headline: A Young Sneaker Brand Enlists an Octogenarian South African Artist
text: When the Swedish sneaker and accessories brand Eytys approached the South African artist and teacher Esther Mahlangu about a partnership, she had a full schedule. “I was working on a major exhibition at the UCT Irma Stern Museum at the time,” she says, referring to the University of Cape Town institution, “as well as celebrating my 80th birthday.” But perhaps drawn in by the lack of specific direction or by the promise of a different material (in her decades-spanning career, she has painted on surfaces like clay pots, museum walls, skate decks, a BMW and her own house), she agreed.

headline: 1916: Germany’s Defensive Guns
text: WASHINGTON — Just when a merchant ship is armed for defence and not for offence must be explained to the German Government by the United States before assurances are given that the first-named class will not be regarded as ‘‘warships’’ and sunk without warning by submarines. This request was handed to Mr. Robert Lansing, Secretary of State, by Count von Bernstorff to-day [Feb. 17], following the protest at Germany’s Memorandum that after March 1 its submersibles would begin the new campaign. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Feb. 18, 1916

headline: Noah Haidle’s ‘Smokefall’ Comes to New York
text: Arriving on the winds of great notices in Chicago, where it received two productions from the Goodman Theater, Noah Haidle’s “Smokefall” makes its New York premiere this month. Mr. Haidle’s previous plays have toyed with fantasy and form, and “Smokefall” is no exception. Although it nominally tells of four generations of a Michigan family, the play has elements of surrealism: a character named Beauty, for instance, never speaks and prefers subsisting on dirt and paint to regular food. A novel diet, certainly, if not the most sensible.

text: The sons of two of America’s most influential evangelical figures are establishing their own identities, and often take different approaches to faith and politics.

headline: Diane Lane to Honor Elizabeth Swados With a Grant for Arts Educators
text: The actress Diane Lane is funding a grant for arts educators to honor the composer, writer and director Elizabeth Swados, who died in January. The grant is being created in partnership with the Ziegfeld Club and will award $5,000 to an influential female educator in New York.

headline: U.S. Women’s Path to Rio Has but One Hurdle Left
text: What do you call a soccer team that wins three games out of three by a total score of 16-0?

headline: Worried Wonks

text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall/Winter 2016 Fashion Week in New York.

headline: 1941: Turkey Signs Bulgaria Pact
text: SOFIA — Nazi diplomacy scored a notable triumph today [Feb. 17] when the governments of Bulgaria and Turkey issued a joint declaration pledging themselves to mutual friendship and good-neighborly relations and affirming their will to refrain from aggression.

headline: Q. and A.: Martyna Majok, Putting Immigrant Lives on Center Stage
text: On paper, Martyna Majok looks like so many other young playwrights, with a master’s degree from the Yale School of Drama.

headline: Boy Howdy That’s Delicious
text: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Rodarte and Coach in Pictures
text: A photo diary of the fall/winter 2016 collections that were presented yesterday.

headline: The Daily Shoe: Oscar de la Renta
text: Unapologetically ladylike and elegant, these black Oscar de la Renta heels look simple — except they’re not. True to form, Peter Copping added a delicate twist: a platform and a tiny cluster of jewels on the heel, almost like a little wink as the model walked by.

headline: ‘Over-Scheduled Andrew,’ by Ashley Spires
text: There are some picture books that reach for timelessness, offering no details that give away exactly when the story is taking place, or when it was written. And there are some that speak directly to their moment. “Over-Scheduled Andrew” is (you guessed it) firmly in the latter camp, taking aim at the current vogue for jam-packing children’s days with adult-run activities. This book represents the backlash against the frantic pursuit of what’s often known as “enrichment,” a term that can seem most apropos for the wallets of the adults who teach and coach all these after-school classes, teams and activities. Spires’s message is not subtle: She writes as an unapologetic champion of the idea that, rather than pushing elementary-schoolers into organized, goal-oriented pursuits, we would enrich their lives more by offering them, say, a couple of unstructured hours with a giant cardboard box, some scissors, packing tape and markers, and no grown-ups chirping directions at them.

headline: Jeb Bush, Going for Broke in South Carolina, Embraces Legacy
text: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C. — In his early days as a presidential candidate, Jeb Bush appeared to campaign in a defensive stance: Sensitive about his political patrimony, he insisted he was his “own man” and struggled to address the conduct of the Iraq war under his brother, President George W. Bush.

headline: When Harry Truman Nearly Doubled the Minimum Wage
text: One of the arguments against raising the federal minimum wage from $7.25 an hour today to $15 an hour over five years is that the United States has never had an increase that large. There is solid research to show that modest increases in the minimum help low-wage workers without harming low-wage employers. But there is no similarly rigorous research on the effects of large increases.

headline: Zenefits Scandal Highlights Perils of Hypergrowth at Start-Ups
text: If you’ve never heard of the human-resources start-up Zenefits, get ready to never forget it.

headline: Why America Turned Off Al Jazeera
text: WASHINGTON — The closing of Al Jazeera America, expected in April, is a sad conclusion to a project that was by turns uplifting and inspiring as well as troubling and depressing. Its demise offers a lesson in both the limitations of public diplomacy and the obstacles to providing high-quality television journalism.

headline: Italian Senate Puts Off Vote on Civil Unions Bill
text: ROME — The Italian Senate has postponed a vote on a contentious bill that would recognize civil unions for same-sex couples, after a boisterous discussion that risked defeating the law.

headline: Jeb Bush Pushes Back At Marco Rubio on Foreign Policy Experience
text: BEAUFORT, S.C. — Jeb Bush has largely refrained from attacking Senator Marco Rubio of Florida by name on the campaign trail. But fighting for his political life ahead of the primary Saturday in South Carolina, a state with a large population of active military members and veterans, Mr. Bush took issue with comments Mr. Rubio made questioning his foreign policy experience.

headline: Marin Mazzie to Return to Broadway in ‘The King and I’
text: Back in December, when Marin Mazzie went to see “The King and I” with her mother, she was just there for fun, not to scope it out as a job prospect. For one thing, she had no idea Kelli O’Hara would be leaving the show.

headline: Florida Teenager Is Accused of Posing as a Doctor. Again.
text: A teenager in South Florida who was advertising his health care services had certifications in holistic healthcare. He had lab coats and a stethoscope. He even had a medical office.

headline: At Oscar de la Renta, Berry Shades and Romantic Silhouettes
text: Creative director Peter Copping’s fall/winter 2016 collection — his third for the label — included mostly dresses and skirts, and minimal accessories.

headline: For Pentagon Equity in Parental Leave
text: To the Editor:

headline: Vegas on the Cheap? Get Off the Strip
text: Things were in full swing when I arrived at the Fremont Street Experience, a covered outdoor street fair that functions as the throbbing party vein of downtown Las Vegas. Occasional screams emanated from above as kids whizzed by on a zip line that runs the length of the street 12 stories up. I grabbed a draft beer at one of the casino bars and walked by an Elvis impersonator and his backing band blasting through a solid rendition of “Hound Dog.”

headline: Should Obama Pick Nominee? Your Answer May Depend on How Much History You Know
text: The Senate is preparing for a no-holds-barred battle over whether it should even consider President Obama’s choice to replace Antonin Scalia on the Supreme Court. Not surprisingly, Americans are divided by political party about whether Mr. Obama should be the one to nominate the replacement, a new online poll shows. But there is also a fascinating wrinkle.

headline: For Brandon Maxwell, Cocktail Hour Takes On New Drama
text: The designer showed his second collection at Monkey Bar last night, to a crowd of fans that included Lady Gaga.

headline: Met to Stage Its First Opera by a Woman Since 1903
text: An opera composed by a woman will appear at the Metropolitan Opera for the first time in more than a century next season, when the house presents the Finnish composer Kaija Saariaho’s ethereal “L’Amour de Loin,” one of the most acclaimed operas of the 2000s.

headline: Missiles Deployed on Disputed South China Sea Island, Officials Say
text: HONG KONG — China has apparently deployed surface-to-air missiles on a disputed island in the South China Sea, escalating regional tensions with China’s neighbors and the United States.

headline: Free Tools to Keep Those Creepy Online Ads From Watching You
text: SAY you’re doing a web search on something like the flu. The next thing you know, an ad for a flu remedy pops up on your web browser, or your video streaming service starts playing a commercial for Tylenol.

headline: Bill Simmons Names His New Website the Ringer
text: The sports personality Bill Simmons’s much anticipated new website has a name: the Ringer.

headline: Should the Authorities Be Able to Access Your iPhone?
text: WASHINGTON — As a legal matter, the showdown between the Obama administration and Apple touched off Tuesday by the ruling of a federal magistrate judge in California turns on an 18th century law. More practically, though, it boils down to this question: Should you be able to lock your phone so securely that even the F.B.I. cannot open it?

headline: Afghanistan’s Crippled Power Grid Exposes Vulnerability of Besieged Capital
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — When saboteurs crippled the Afghan capital’s power supply last month, the tailors in Najeebullah’s clothing shop had to abandon their electric sewing machines for hand-cranked models. Their output fell by half.

headline: Prado Explains Decision to Withhold Works from Bosch Show
text: AMSTERDAM — The Prado museum in Madrid on Wednesday made public its reasons for revoking its loan of two paintings to a major Hieronymus Bosch retrospective in the artist’s hometown, ’s-Hertogenbosch, the Netherlands.

headline: What Has the Wonks Worried
text: The open letter to Sanders and Friedman by former CEA chairs didn’t get into specifics, and I’m already hearing from Bernie supporters accusing them of arrogance, or high-handedness, or something. But here’s what Friedman has said, in what the campaign’s policy director calls “outstanding work”:

headline: Donald Trump Says Paul Ryan Cost Republicans the 2012 Election
text: Donald J. Trump on Wednesday blamed Mitt Romney’s selection of Paul Ryan as his running mate for costing Republicans the 2012 presidential election.

headline: Taliban Used Child Soldiers in Kunduz Battle, Rights Group Says
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Child soldiers recruited by the Taliban were used in the battle to overrun the northern city of Kunduz last year, a prominent human rights organization said on Wednesday.

headline: Car Bomb Strikes Military Convoy in Ankara, Killing 28, Officials Say
text: ISTANBUL — Turkey reeled on Wednesday from a deadly bombing of a military convoy in the capital, plunging its leaders deeper into crisis mode and underscoring the country’s vulnerability to the Syrian war and revitalized Kurdish insurgency.

headline: Hillary Clinton Donors Hear Concerns About Nevada Outcome
text: Hillary Clinton’s campaign manager briefed some of her most loyal and active fund-raisers this morning about the upcoming Nevada caucuses and responded to frustrations among some of her donors that the campaign needed to do a better job of demonstrating its successful mobilization of grassroots activists and small donors.

headline: Liberal Economists Raise More Red Flags on Bernie Sanders’s Spending Plans
text: A group of leading liberal economists who served in the Obama and Clinton administrations have assessed the proposals of Bernie Sanders and concluded that the Vermont senator’s rosy economic projections do not add up.

headline: In Neanderthals’ DNA, Ancient Humans May Have Left Genetic Mark
text: In 1997, scientists found the first scrap of Neanderthal DNA in a fossil. Since then, they have recovered genetic material, even entire genomes, from a number of Neanderthal bones, and their investigations have yielded a remarkable surprise: Today, 1 to 2 percent of the DNA in non-African people comes from Neanderthals.

headline: Donald Trump Stays Away From Nevada as Caucuses Near
text: Donald J. Trump is not going this week to Nevada, where Republicans will hold their caucuses on Tuesday. While there’s a dearth of reliable polling there, Mr. Trump is not worried about his prospects in the state.

text: A new study provides more evidence that eating high-cholesterol food does not increase the risk for heart disease.

headline: Infighting Dilutes Push in Britain to Leave E.U.
text: LONDON — Old-fashioned, upper class and with a habit of spouting Latin quotations, the British lawmaker and European Union critic Jacob Rees-Mogg is affectionately known in Parliament as the “honorable member for the early 20th century.”

text: The ghosts of past failures haunt China’s new mergers and acquisitions players.

headline: Where to See Ballet and Puppet Theater in Yogyakarta
text: As covered in a recent article, Yogyakarta in Indonesia has become a vibrant center of art, dance and puppet theater. Here is how to get the most out of a visit.

text: Yes, some owners resemble their dog. The annual dog show revealed emotional similarities as well.

headline: Uncanny Moments from the Westminster Dog Show
text: Sure, it’s deeply amusing when owners look like their dogs, and try to complement them with their attire in the show ring. (Liberace must have been gazing down fondly on the 140th Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show this year, what with its abundance of gold lamé, silver filigree and suits that sparkled.)

headline: Channing Dungey to Succeed Paul Lee as Chief of ABC Entertainment
text: LOS ANGELES — A long-running internal battle among ABC executives over creative control and future strategy led to the ouster on Wednesday of the network’s entertainment president and the elevation of a pair of his lieutenants.

headline: Supreme Court Vacancy Has Left and Right Ready to Pounce
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s senior adviser and his top lawyer were blunt with liberal activists on a strategy call as they jumped into what political professionals in Washington expect to be one of the hardest-fought Supreme Court battles in a generation.

headline: F.D.A. Deals Setback to Catalyst in Race for Drug Approval
text: WASHINGTON — A Florida company involved in an unusual race for approval of a drug that treats a rare neuromuscular condition had a setback on Wednesday, after federal regulators said they needed more information before deciding whether to approve it.

headline: Xuly Bet: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Lamine Kouyaté presents his fall collection.

headline: ‘International Pop’: The Usual Suspects and More
text: “International Pop,” which opens Wednesday, Feb. 24, at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, lays waste to the idea of Pop Art as a mostly American — or even American-British-German — phenomenon. Beginning with one of Jasper Johns’s 1958 “Flag” paintings, this revisionist show, which originated at the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis, includes the usual suspects from either side of the Atlantic. But it encompasses many more unusual artists who responded to the rise of consumer culture, popular media and various forms of imperialism while also experimenting with new art forms during the turbulent 1960s and ’70s.

headline: A Marathon Evening of Prokofiev Piano Concertos at BAM
text: It’s not often that Prokofiev fans have a chance to hear all five of his Piano Concertos in one evening. On Wednesday, Feb. 24, Valery Gergiev conducts the Mariinsky Orchestra in a marathon performance featuring five pianists, beginning with George Li playing the single-movement Concerto No. 1. Alexander Toradze will perform the fiendishly difficult, fascinating second concerto, dedicated to a close friend of Prokofiev’s who committed suicide. The pianist Sviatoslav Richter described the “Intermezzo” of the brooding work, which has a huge, roiling cadenza, as evoking “a dragon devouring its young.”

headline: Fed Officials, at Meeting, Found Economic Outlook Cloudy
text: WASHINGTON — Federal Reserve officials threw up their hands in January, deciding that they could not decide whether market turmoil would impede domestic economic growth.

headline: Sendak’s ‘Wild Things,’ Via Spike Jonze
text: It wasn’t easy for Spike Jonze to create his 2009 adaptation of Maurice Sendak’s 1963 classic, “Where the Wild Things Are,” about a lonely boy’s escape to a fantastical island populated by fearsome if benign monsters. His original conception for the film — which ends the Nitehawk Cinema’s Little Bookworms series on Feb. 27 and 28 (Saturday and Sunday) — was too dark for Warner Bros., and the giant supporting characters, offspring of Jim Henson’s Creature Shop, had animatronic issues. But the director persisted, and the movie, written by Mr. Jonze and Dave Eggers and offering gentle songs by Karen O of the Yeah Yeah Yeahs, became a classic of its own. The newcomer Max Records plays the hero, Max, but it’s the ensemble behind the beasts (including Forest Whitaker, Lauren Ambrose, Catherine O’Hara and Chris Cooper) who sparkle. As Max’s buddy Carol, James Gandolfini (Tony Soprano himself) had perhaps the most tender role of his career. Ages 6 and up. (136 Metropolitan Avenue, Williamsburg, Brooklyn; nitehawkcinema.com.)

headline: ‘Girls’? Aren’t They Women Yet?
text: When last we saw our “Girls,” they were growing up. Marnie (Allison Williams), having been abandoned at their showcase by Desi (Ebon Moss-Bachrach), stepped onstage to find her voice. Jessa (Jemima Kirke), after witnessing the agony of birth, decided to become a therapist. Shoshanna (Zosia Mamet), faced with the option of moving in with Scott (Jason Ritter), chose to take a job in Japan. And Hannah (Lena Dunham) — after tearfully rebuffing Adam (Adam Driver) in his plea to get back together — was seen, six months later, kissing a new guy, Fran (Jake Lacy), in the snow.

headline: At Michael Kors, ‘I Woke Up Like This’ Beauty Sticks
text: Michael Kors’s models are known to have a healthy, sun-kissed glow. But this season, the show’s makeup artist, Dick Page, traded consistently bronzed complexions for a leftover-from-the-night-before look. Inspired by what off-duty models might look like in real life, Page didn’t remove any of their existing eye makeup — at times leftover from previous shows — before getting to work. He then closely lined lids with either a black, brown or navy hue before smudging it with his fingers.

headline: Makeover Set for Police Building at Heart of a Sleeker Times Square
text: The identical mosaic tile maps of New York City on the sides of the police substation in Times Square hark back to a different era. Some of the Monopoly-like symbols among the tiles that once helped tourists locate landmarks are gone. So, too, are a number of those landmarks, like the old Metropolitan Opera House.

headline: Blackhawks Rally Past Rangers in Ryan McDonagh’s Return
text: A day before visiting the White House to mark their third Stanley Cup victory in six seasons, the Chicago Blackhawks stopped by Madison Square Garden on Wednesday.

headline: Celebrating When Hip-Hop Had Its Crossover
text: First, the hairsplitting: “I Love the 90s” is an excellent concept for a tour of came-and-went hip-hop-meets-pop dynamos, but in this lineup, which comes to New York and New Jersey this week, the Technicolor end of the late 1980s is the real touchstone. That’s when the croaky-voiced Tone Loc was at his peak, when Kid ‘n Play and Salt-N-Pepa were perfecting their dance moves, when Rob Base was fine-tuning his chants.

headline: Lady Gaga Applauds Brandon Maxwell, and Kirsten Dunst Dances With Rodarte
text: Brandon Maxwell hosts a show and after-party at the Monkey Bar on the Upper East Side, while the Rodarte sisters, Kate and Laura Mulleavy, hold an after-party at Berlin in East Village.

headline: Mari Giudicelli’s Debut Shoe Collection
text: The model launches her eponymous brand of loafers and mules this week.

headline: Blake Lively Talks About Michael Kors
text: Michael Kors has made a fortune from perfecting a certain look that is all his own. Camel coats, deep tans and a glossy blowout? So Michael Kors. Tan leather bag and shoes? Very, very Michael Kors. Bare legs in winter because you have a car waiting for you in the snow outside? The definition of Michael Kors.

headline: Lady Gaga Applauds Brandon Maxwell, and Kirsten Dunst Dances With Rodarte
text: Brandon Maxwell held a party immediately following his runway show at the Monkey Bar on the Upper East Side. Lady Gaga attended, giving her former stylist and friend a standing ovation as the models streamed out for the finale. And at the Berlin bar in the East Village, the Rodarte designers gathered their friends, including Kirsten Dunst and Tavi Gevinson, to celebrate their collection and Kate Mulleavy’s birthday.

headline: Find Out What’s New in Smartphones at Mobile World Congress
text: EVERY year, the smartphone world gathers in Spain for a giant trade show called Mobile World Congress, M.W.C. for short. Thousands of exhibitors show off their current and coming wares, including smartphones, wearable technology and new apps.

headline: Spanish Unit of China’s ICBC Raided in Money Laundering Case
text: The Spanish police raided the Madrid subsidiary of one of China’s largest banks on Wednesday and arrested five of its directors as part of a broad investigation into money laundering.

headline: Russia Sues Ukraine in London Court Over Unpaid Debt Claim
text: MOSCOW — Russia filed a lawsuit against Ukraine in the London High Court on Wednesday over $3 billion in unpaid loans, escalating a legal battle that is adding to the geopolitical tensions between the two countries.

headline: Nikki Haley Endorses Marco Rubio as South Carolina Prepares to Vote
text: CHAPIN, S.C. — Senator Marco Rubio received the endorsement Wednesday of South Carolina’s governor, Nikki R. Haley, a stamp of approval that could prove significant as his campaign tries to break out ahead in the state’s primary on Saturday.

headline: Argentina Battles Major Outbreak of Dengue as Mosquito Population Swells
text: BUENOS AIRES — Argentina is grappling with its worst outbreak of dengue in seven years as the population of Aedes aegypti mosquitoes, which also transmit the Zika virus, expands in the subtropical northeast of the country.

headline: 73-Story Tower Would Be Brooklyn’s Tallest by Far
text: Scrutiny is about to begin of a proposal for the tallest tower in Brooklyn, one that would be impossible to ignore.

headline: A New Shoe Brand Focuses on the Classics
text: The model Mari Giudicelli is best known for her work for brands such as Maryam Nassir Zadeh, Ulla Johnson and Eckhaus Latta — she’s appeared in countless runway shows, magazine editorials and ad campaigns. But now, she’s becoming a designer in her own right: on Friday, she will debut her eponymous shoe line — a selection of classic, simple loafers and flats in suede and exotic skins.

headline: Once No. 4, Juan Martín del Potro Starts Over Again at 1,041st
text: DELRAY BEACH, Fla. — Eleven months was long enough for Juan Martín del Potro to ponder whether he wanted to attempt another comeback from wrist surgery. One match into his return from his fourth wrist operation, he appeared satisfied with his decision.

headline: Ted Cruz Rebuffs Donald Trump Ad Lawsuit Threat
text: SENECA, S.C. — He read aloud from a cease-and-desist letter. He presented the video evidence. He said he looked forward to deposing his chief rival for the Republican nomination.

headline: Police Seek Suspect After Fatal Brooklyn Shooting
text: The police on Wednesday were searching for an assailant who fatally shot a Brooklyn man during an argument outside an apartment building that has a history of drug activity.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Sandy Alderson, Feeling Better, Is Focused on Health of Pitchers and Wright
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — A few days after the Mets clinched the National League East in September and General Manager Sandy Alderson was doused with champagne, looking happier than he had in years, he was told he had cancer. He dealt with the news quietly as he fine-tuned his roster and had two more champagne baths in the Mets’ run to the World Series.

headline: Seeking a More Humane Way to Die
text: To the Editor:

headline: Heartburn Drugs Tied to Dementia Risk
text: The popular heartburn drugs known as proton pump inhibitors have been linked to a range of ills: bone fractures, kidney problems, infections and more. Now a large new study has found that they are associated with an increased risk for dementia as well.

headline: Aid Deliveries Begin to 5 Besieged Syrian Towns
text: GENEVA — More than 100 trucks laden with emergency food and medicine began deliveries on Wednesday to tens of thousands of desperate Syrians in five locations besieged for months by the civil war, United Nations officials and relief workers reported.

headline: Mile 13 in the Deployment Marathon
text: The hardest part of the journey is the first step, right? Respectfully, I disagree; I think it’s the steps in the middle. We’ve just passed the halfway point in my Navy husband’s seven-month deployment (preceded by over a year of constant in-and-out travel for training, called “work-ups”), and instead of sprinting to a finish line, it feels like my 5-year-old daughter, 3-year-old son and I are crawling along a never-ending trail.

headline: Ex-Eurythmic Dave Stewart, the Zelig of Pop
text: We all know Six Degrees of Kevin Bacon: How many steps does it take to connect any famous person to the ubiquitous character actor?

headline: A Powerful ‘Elektra,’ Sheep at the Armory and Other Spring Classical Highlights
text: Speculation swirls around any new production at the Metropolitan Opera. But the company’s staging of Strauss’s “Elektra,” opening on April 14, has been awaited with particular eagerness, and has already been deemed a milestone in the career of its director, Patrice Chéreau.

headline: Ratmansky and Lil Buck on the Spring Dance Calendar
text: Some kinds of climate change are good. The eight-week repertory announced by American Ballet Theater for its annual spring season at the Metropolitan Opera House is the best news for this company in more than 25 years. More than that, it refreshes the whole New York dance environment. Instead of relying chiefly on fare choreographed over a century ago in inadequate productions (as it once did), the company is giving extensive time to important 20th- and 21st-century ballets.

headline: A Former Tween Idol, Reborn Off Broadway
text: Nat Wolff arrives at Joe Allen, the Midtown restaurant that’s served as a hangout for off-duty actors for over 50 years, with a gash on his finger. The 21-year-old is currently starring in a revival of Sam Shepard’s 1978 Pulitzer Prize-winning play “Buried Child” at the Alice Griffin Jewel Box Theatre, and at the previous night’s performance — during a scene in which his character, Vince, violently hurls glass bottles against a wall — he looked down to find a pool of blood at his feet. To many, Wolff is best known for his roles as a teenager blinded by cancer in “The Fault in Our Stars” and as the lead opposite Cara Delevingne in last summer’s “Paper Towns,” both adaptations of John Green novels. By contrast, Shepard’s drama, about three generations of a Midwestern family coming to grips with an economic depression and personal tragedy, marks a step up in intensity. “I insisted when we started that we use real glass in the play,” Wolff says, examining his hand. “But now I’m not so sure.”

headline: Cliffside Home Will Go to Los Angeles County Museum of Art
text: LOS ANGELES — Soon after Michael Govan took his job as the director of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art in 2006, he began talking about acquiring “a major work of architecture” for the museum to oversee, preserve and open up to visitors. Now, almost 10 years into his job, he has managed to make his first acquisition: The Sheats-Goldstein residence, an angular glass-walled home designed by John Lautner that comes complete with a nightclub, tennis court and a “skyspace” installation by the artist James Turrell in its backyard.

headline: No Flower is Getting More Love This Season Than the Daisy
text: Expect a floral explosion as spring looks start to arrive in stores.

headline: Be Cautious When Choosing a Tax Preparer
text: Consumers looking for someone to handle their income tax returns may not know that many paid tax preparers aren’t required to have special training or pass a test to prove their expertise. So it’s important to do some research before handing over your financial information.

headline: Photos of the Day: Turkey and Elsewhere
text: Turkey and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Paris Doesn’t Get Sweatpants, Yet. So A.P.C. Brought Its Own to New York.
text: Jean Touitou of A.P.C. is as close as contemporary fashion comes to a saloniste. The outspoken founder of the label, whose stores reliably dot the cool neighborhoods of the globe, declines runways and shows his collections in group presentations that he narrates, microphone in hand, often pausing to quote from Proust or digress into discussions of his late cousin’s genius unpublished novel. They are not without incident (as when he stumbled into a fiasco of race relations and political correctness by quoting his friend and collaborator Kanye West), and they are never without interest.

headline: Feb. 17, 2016 — Photos of the Day
text: Photos from Turkey, Uganda, Russia and Germany.

headline: Naian González Norvind Reaches for High Notes in ‘Her Requiem’
text: Lately, the Fauré Requiem has weighed heavily on Naian González Norvind’s mind. So have the requiems of Mozart, Dvorak and Verdi.

headline: University of Texas Sets Parameters for Concealed Handguns on Austin Campus
text: Despite his own reservations, and those of much of his staff and student body, the president of the University of Texas at Austin on Wednesday announced rules that will allow concealed handguns to be carried on campus, including in classrooms.

headline: Sarah Charles Lewis Bids for Posterity in ‘Tuck Everlasting’
text: Sarah Charles Lewis is only 11, but already she has a position on immortality: If offered a liquid that would allow her to live forever, but keep her always at her current age, she would decline.

headline: 2016-02-15-Report
text: A policy governing concealed carry on campus was developed to comply with a new state law.

headline: UT Austin s Campus Carry Policies Office of the President the University of Texas at Austin
text: In an open letter, Gregory L. Fenves, president of the University of Texas at Austin, announces a policy that will generally allow concealed carry, which has been prohibited on the campus.

headline: Why Teenage Girls Roll Their Eyes
text: Many people can roll their eyes, but adolescent girls have practically monopolized the ocular gesture as a form of communication. Adults on the receiving end of an eye roll are often offended, and sometimes that’s just what the girl had in mind. But frequently, it’s not. Eye-rolling serves a variety of purposes, and the meanings behind the mannerism tell us a lot about what it’s like to be a teenager.

headline: Zainab Jah, ‘Eclipsed’ Star, Is Ready for Battle
text: In “Eclipsed,” which begins previews Feb. 23 at the Golden Theater, Zainab Jah plays Maima, an AK-47-toting soldier who has given herself the name Disgruntled. But one evening at a South Brooklyn bistro, plates of oysters arrayed before her, Ms. Jah seemed content. “I’m greedy,” she said, with enthusiasm and without apology.

headline: For Director Lileana Blain-Cruz Things Are Going Swimmingly
text: The director Lileana Blain-Cruz didn’t so much stand up as pop out of a chair in New York Theater Workshop’s rehearsal studio. She then danced across the floor toward the actors Alex Breaux and Lucas Caleb Rooney. “I’m going to switch something up for you,” she nearly sang, suggesting a change in the fight scene they were rehearsing for “Red Speedo,” now in previews at the theater.

headline: Open Letter from the University of Texas at Austin
text: In an open letter, Gregory L. Fenves, president of the University of Texas at Austin, announces a policy that will generally allow concealed carry, which has been prohibited on the campus.

headline: 2016-02-15-Report
text: A policy governing concealed carry on University of Texas campuses was developed to comply with a new state law.

headline: Review: Herlin Riley Commands Attention on ‘New Direction’
text: “New Direction”

headline: Pope Francis Visits U.S. – Mexico Border
text: Pope Francis stepped directly into the angry American political debate about immigration on Wednesday when he visited Ciudad Juárez, Mexico, at the border with the United States. He celebrated Mass at a fairground barely 300 feet from the Rio Grande, calling forced migration “a human tragedy.”

headline: Review: Michael Pollan and Pangs of Guilt, Not Hunger
text: Michael Pollan is food-shaming us again, this time in a four-part Netflix docu-series. It’s a gentle sort of shaming, and informative, but unless you’ve previously been converted to Pollanology through his books (“The Omnivore’s Dilemma”) or his other screen appearances (“Food, Inc.”), you’ll come away feeling mighty guilty about what you eat.

headline: Review: In ‘Every Song Ever,’ Ben Ratliff Helps the Listener Discern
text: Complaining that there’s too much good art and entertainment being made at the moment seems churlish — how could that be a problem? Yet it’s undeniable that there is something curiously oppressive about the current bounty, something paralyzing about our ease of access to it. Television is one field where what ought to be a boon feels increasingly like a bane: With scores of new shows each season, keeping up with what’s good gets to seem like a chore. If anything, the overload in music feels even more unmanageable.

headline: Acel Moore, Founder of Black Journalists’ Organization, Dies at 75
text: Acel Moore, a Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist who co-founded the National Association of Black Journalists and awakened his white colleagues and their readers to everyday life in black communities, died on Friday at his home in Wyncote, Pa., near Philadelphia. He was 75.

headline: Channing Tatum Gives ‘Hail, Caesar!’ a Tap-Dancing Kick
text: What turned into one of the most memorable dances on film in recent years started modestly with this description, said its choreographer, Christopher Gattelli: “Burt Gurney does a number on a ship with a mop.”

headline: The Look: Anna Sui’s Frothy Baby-Doll
text: In the early 1980s, Anna Sui was a young fashion hopeful toiling, mostly unsung, on Seventh Avenue, her look largely influenced by the style and the music of the London youth quake. Flash forward a decade, and a chain of lucky circumstances introduced the Chinese-American designer to her first brush with fame.

headline: At Narciso Rodriguez, Sculpture-Adorned Earlobes
text: “Narciso and I have a similar aesthetic and we look at women in the same way,” says the jewelry designer Ana Khouri, referring to her friend and collaborator Narciso Rodriguez. Given her formal training as a sculptor, Khouri views her pieces as “not only dressing the body, but making a connection with the body.” She adds that Rodriguez, too, “is very conscious of lines and forms.”

headline: Lela Rose: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Looks from the Lela Rose Collection.

headline: Facts & Figures: January’s Record-Breaking Heat
text: Last month was the warmest January worldwide since recording began in 1880. What’s more, the temperature anomaly for January — a measure of how much the temperature differed from an average of past temperatures for the month — was also the largest ever calculated.

headline: Ted Cruz in Virtual Tie With Donald Trump in New National Poll
text: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas has erased Donald J. Trump’s lead in a new national poll that could signal a significant shift in the race for the Republican nomination with primary election season in full swing.

headline: Testosterone Gel Has Modest Benefits for Men, Study Says
text: More than a million men have smeared testosterone gels on their bodies in recent years, hoping it would rejuvenate them, energize them, and increase their libido. But until now, there has never been a rigorous study asking if there were any real benefits to testosterone therapy for healthy men with so-called low T.

headline: Boss Women: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Jason Wu, the Taiwanese-born designer, presents his fall women’s collection.

headline: DKNY: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Maxwell Osborne and Dao-Yi Chow’s second collection for DKNY.

headline: The Thinking Woman’s Runway
text: It was snowing outside, speckling the stiletto boots and soaking the tights of the fashion folk, and inside, snow lay lightly on the ground for Thom Browne’s show, deep in the bowels of a Chelsea art gallery where Mr. Browne had recreated Washington Square circa the Henry James years.

headline: Every Minute Counts on the Way to Opening Night
text: On one recent Tuesday, we spent an hour each with a dozen upcoming Broadway shows as they worked under looming deadlines. From the costume shop to the first curtain call, here's how the steps and stories, the stitches and salesmanship come together.

headline: Review: ‘Twelfth Night’ by Filter Theater, Set at the Frat
text: Who needs cakes and ale when you have pizza and lager? In the best bits of “Twelfth Night,” presented at the Skirball Center for the Performing Arts in association with the Royal Shakespeare Company, the British troupe Filter Theater reimagines Shakespeare’s comedy as a frat bacchanal. There’s even an improvement on beer pong.

headline: Review: Denes Varjon, a Hungarian Pianist, at Zankel Hall
text: A sparsely attended concert at Zankel Hall on Tuesday evening by the Hungarian pianist Denes Varjon demonstrated the difficulty of marketing an artist who may be admired by musicians and industry professionals but is not well known among a broader audience in this country.

headline: Ex-Deutsche Bank Analyst to Pay $100,000 Over Ratings
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission on Wednesday settled with a former stock analyst over accusations that he had failed to tell investors what he really believed about the value of a company’s shares he was promoting.

headline: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing: Donald Trump, iPhone, Hillary Clinton
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Review: ‘Join or Die With Craig Ferguson’ — Historic Errors
text: The informational side of television has its standard documentary programming and its standard talk shows, but lately it has also sprouted a sort of mumblecore hybrid of the two. People with varying qualifications prattle about a subject in a way that’s supposed to be entertaining, occasionally bumping into an illuminating fact or idea while doing so.

headline: As Demographics in Cambodia Shift, Youth Seek Political Change
text: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — Thy Sovantha, Cambodia’s youngest political star, is still seething.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Review: Jack Garratt Chops, Croons and Wobbles
text: “Phase”

headline: Review: BJ the Chicago Kid Waxes Reflective on ‘In My Mind’
text: “In My Mind”

headline: Yahoo Closes Online Magazines, a Costly Experiment by Marissa Mayer
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Marissa Mayer, the embattled chief executive of Yahoo, is gutting one of her signature projects: A cluster of digital magazines devoted to topics like food, autos, real estate, travel and technology.

headline: Review: Dave Holland Trio in a Bracingly Uncorked Evening at the Village Vanguard
text: Opening night of a newly incorporated jazz group’s residency can be a crapshoot. Conventional wisdom holds that as time progresses, the music will only get better. But there are provisos and exceptions, most of which were manifest in the Dave Holland Trio’s jubilant, blazingly exploratory first set at the Village Vanguard on Tuesday night.

headline: Bill Cosby Sued Accuser’s Lawyers on Eve of His Criminal Hearing
text: On the eve of a critical hearing in his criminal case earlier this month, Bill Cosby sued the two lawyers for the woman who accused him of drugging and sexually assaulting her, according to court records.

headline: John Kasich Turns His Sights on New England
text: BLUFFTON, S.C. — Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio, who has competed in South Carolina while also looking ahead to more hospitable primary states, is not planning to stay here on Saturday when Republican voters go to the polls.

headline: Harper Beckham, the 4-Year-Old Street-Style Star
text: The newest street-style fashion star has been photographed dining at Balthazar and Nobu, shopping at Barneys, vacationing in Marrakesh and the Napa Valley and going to the ballet in London. She favors Chloé, Marc Jacobs and Zara, and seems to have an occasional fondness for the color pink.

headline: Long-Shot Nominees and Their Oscars Fatigue
text: Shortly after the curtain fell on the 2010 Academy Awards, Michael Barker, the co-president of Sony Pictures Classics, bumped into the French director Jacques Audiard, and was startled to find him grinning from ear to ear. Mr. Audiard’s film, “A Prophet,” had just lost the best foreign-language film Oscar to “A Secret in Their Eyes,” and yet the filmmaker, Mr. Barker said, could not have looked more pleased.

headline: Off the Runway: Feb. 17
text: What you need to know from the seventh day of New York Fashion Week.

headline: Pope’s Presence Crosses Border Into U.S., Even if He Doesn’t
text: EL PASO, Tex. — In Mexico, Ciudad Juárez was naturally consumed with the visit by Pope Francis on Wednesday. But across the border here in West Texas, its sister city, El Paso, was equally swept up.

headline: Law Center Finds Surge in Extremist Groups in U.S. Last Year
text: Extremist groups thrived in the United States last year as the divisive rhetoric of national political leaders fueled America’s anxieties over the country’s shifting demographics, according to a report by the Southern Poverty Law Center.

headline: A Designer Pop-Up and Brandon Maxwell at Bergdorf Goodman
text: On Thursday, be sure to check out the Bergdorf Goodman pop-up of Beau Souci, a line founded by Paola Russo, owner of the Los Angeles concept boutique Just One Eye. Designed by Aurélie Larrousse, who graduated from Studio Berçot in Paris, it marries French chic with SoCal cool in looks like a gold and silver watersnake leather skirt ($2,750) paired with a plain white tee ($140).

headline: Erykah Badu, Debut Fashion Week Stylist
text: At the Pyer Moss show at Milk Studios on Saturday, a quintet played classical music in hospital gowns, a jacket had the message “You don’t have any friends in LA” written across the breastplate, and the final model held a sign that said: “My demons won today. I’m sorry.”

headline: The Olsen Twins Expand Their Empire With New Eyewear
text: Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen rolled into the Oliver Peoples Madison Avenue boutique on Tuesday night for a party celebrating their first eyewear collaboration. Perhaps not surprisingly, given the reluctance of The Row designers to engage much with the public or the press, they have cheekily named a pair of $340 oversize tortoise sunglasses “Don’t Bother Me.”

headline: The Blowout Parties of New York Fashion Week
text: Blame it on the arctic blast, on awards season, on fashion week’s very influence hanging in the balance.

headline: Off the Runway: Fashion Week, Day 7
text: Above, Jennifer Hudson snaps a photo from the front row of the Michael Kors show. Click on the slide show above for more images from the seventh day of New York Fashion Week.

headline: A Novel Plan for Health Care: Cutting Costs, Not Raising Them
text: As employees know all too well, health insurance companies have one surefire way to lower costs: Ask their customers to pay more.

headline: Mayor de Blasio’s America: A Pastrami Sandwich From Carnegie Deli
text: For Mayor Bill de Blasio, happiness is a warm pastrami sandwich.

headline: Three’s a Trend: Plastic and Rubber
text: Streetwear has officially embraced the weird for fall/winter 2016, with runways dominated by oversize silhouettes, tough boots and pieces wrought in nylon and rubber that appear to be made of plastic bags. At Hood by Air (center), arguably the season’s most talked-about show so far, a duffle coat was matched with rubber bottoms and rubber boots. Last night, the minimalist Narciso Rodriguez (right) added a refreshing edge to his show with a silk and wool trench coat that boasted a plasticky sheen. And today, Maxwell Osbourne and Dao-Yi Chow’s second collection for DKNY (left) was filled with tomboyish pieces like a nylon anorak with matching pants.

headline: Voters in South Carolina Give Jeb Bush Some Campaign Advice
text: SUMMERVILLE, S.C. — Jeb Bush has reached the point in his floundering presidential campaign where voters are offering him unsolicited advice.

headline: That time when they said...
text: Reviewing past statements by lawmakers on judicial nominations reveals how easily they alternate positions based on control of Congress or the White House.

headline: Marchesa: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Keren Craig and Georgina Chapman present their latest looks.

headline: Senators Limber Up for a Dexterous Flip on Judicial Nominees
text: WASHINGTON — The long-serving senator professed outrage. How dare the opposition refuse a vote on a high-level presidential judicial nominee.

headline: Early Behavior Therapy Found to Aid Children With A.D.H.D.
text: Children with attention-deficit problems improve faster when the first treatment they receive is behavioral — like instruction in basic social skills — than when they start immediately on medication, a new study has found. Beginning with behavioral therapy is also a less expensive option over time, according to a related analysis.

headline: Accusation at Indiana University Triggers Review of Sexual Misconduct Cases
text: Indiana University Bloomington will review the handling of 18 sexual misconduct cases after the associate dean who led hearings on the cases was publicly accused of sexually assaulting a woman.

headline: Chinese Missiles in South China Sea Underscore a Growing Conflict Risk
text: WASHINGTON — China’s deployment of surface-to-air missiles on a disputed island in the South China Sea, at the very moment that President Obama is trying to buttress American influence in the region, underscores the growing risk of conflict among the Chinese, their neighbors and the United States.

headline: Apple’s Stance Highlights a More Confrontational Tech Industry
text: The battle between Apple and law enforcement officials over unlocking a terrorist’s smartphone is the culmination of a slow turning of the tables between the technology industry and the United States government.

headline: Three Former New Jersey Governors Ask the State to Reopen the Sheridan Case
text: In the 11 months since a county prosecutor in New Jersey ruled the violent deaths of John and Joyce Sheridan a murder-suicide, their disbelieving family has been waging a determined effort to have the case reopened. On Wednesday, friends of the family released a letter supporting their cause that was signed by some 200 people — including three former governors, a former state Supreme Court justice and several former high-ranking prosecutors.

headline: Pope Francis at the Border
text: Pope Francis’ trip to Mexico ended on Wednesday in Ciudad Juárez, a city once made hellish by drug violence and still gripped by poverty and crime. He did not seem afraid, and brought with him only smiles and hugs, and words of solace and encouragement.

headline: Manhattan Prosecutor Asks to Be Recused From Spitzer Inquiry
text: The Manhattan district attorney has moved to recuse himself from the criminal investigation into an allegation that former Gov. Eliot Spitzer assaulted a 26-year-old woman at the Plaza Hotel, saying the close ties between his office and Mr. Spitzer had created an apparent conflict of interest.

headline: Delta, in Alliance With Danny Meyer, Aims to Elevate Airline Food
text: It is no secret that airlines are waging an increasingly pitched battle for the biggest-spending passengers who fly in premium classes: The carriers have deployed amenities like fluffy feather duvets and spa treatments.

headline: Legal Heavyweights Enter Round 3 in New Jersey Gambling Case
text: PHILADELPHIA — Before the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit began the important business on Wednesday of deciding whether New Jersey could offer legal wagering on sports, Judge Thomas L. Ambro offered a tribute to Justice Antonin Scalia, listing his many contributions to the law.

headline: Audit Faults New York City for Not Using Vacant Lots for Affordable Housing
text: New York City’s scarcity of inexpensive land is often cited as an impediment to building more affordable housing, but the comptroller’s office has identified more than 1,000 city-owned vacant lots across the boroughs that have been sitting idle, most for more than 30 years.

headline: Jordan Spieth and Rory McIlroy Resume Fight for Top Spot
text: LOS ANGELES — A 12-year-old Jordan Spieth sat glued to the television for the 2006 Rose Bowl, between No. 2 Texas and top-ranked Southern California. The game had the requisite star power and drama for a marquee event in this entertainment capital of the world.

headline: Nikki Haley Endorses Marco Rubio, Aiming to Project Vibrant New G.O.P.
text: CHAPIN, S.C. — Senator Marco Rubio of Florida on Wednesday won the coveted backing of South Carolina’s governor, Nikki R. Haley, bringing together two of the youngest Republican rising stars at a moment when their party is facing difficult questions about whether instead to look to its past or to political outsiders for leadership.

headline: Andrzej Zulawski, Rebellious Film Director, Dies at 75
text: Andrzej Zulawski, a Polish director who blended surrealism, horror and psychic excess in the emotionally savage films “The Important Thing Is to Love,” “Possession” and “My Nights Are More Beautiful Than Your Days,” died on Wednesday in Warsaw. He was 75.

headline: Blacks See Bias in Delay on a Scalia Successor
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. — As he left Martha Lou’s Kitchen, a soul food institution here on Wednesday, Edward Gadsden expressed irritation about the Republican determination to block President Obama from selecting Justice Antonin Scalia’s replacement on the Supreme Court.

headline: Albany Again Has Stony Brook’s Number as Winning Streak Ends at 18
text: ALBANY — As the wins pile up for Stony Brook again this season, the Seawolves remain haunted by the question that has troubled them for five agonizing years, beginning with when they first reached the cusp of the N.C.A.A. tournament: Can they finally win when it matters?

headline: William H. Tankersley, Watchdog for CBS Taste Standards, Dies at 98
text: William H. Tankersley, who defined broadcast standards for CBS during a volatile period of change in mores on television and in American society, doing celebrated battle with envelope pushers like Norman Lear and the Smothers Brothers, died on Feb. 5 in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 98.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “One could say that Daesh has won because its goal has been to sow trouble, and they have succeeded.”

headline: With Much Unsettled for Nets, Brooklyn Complex Is a New Center of Gravity
text: Mikhail D. Prokhorov smirked as guests were served an array of refreshments at a ceremony Wednesday for the opening of the Nets’ new practice site in the Sunset Park neighborhood of Brooklyn.

headline: Rikers Guard Charged With Lying in Inmate’s Death Pleads Guilty
text: A New York City correction officer on duty at Rikers Island when a homeless veteran overheated before dying in his cell pleaded guilty on Wednesday to a felony charge that she lied about checking on inmates that night, the authorities said.

headline: Trial Starts in Attack at Exhibit of Anti-Islam Cartoons
text: PHOENIX — Federal prosecutors opened their case here on Wednesday against a man accused of being the mastermind behind a thwarted attack last year at an anti-Islam cartoon exhibit in Texas that left two gunmen dead in a shootout.

headline: Modern Love: The Podcast | Magically Interrupted
text: In this week’s episode of Modern Love: The Podcast (the sixth so far), the actor Michael Shannon (“Boardwalk Empire,” “Take Shelter,” “Revolutionary Road”) reads “A Memory Magically Interrupted” by Robert Leleux.

headline: Review: In Shepard’s ‘Buried Child,’ a Father and Family Dissolve Into Darkness
text: So you’ve come back, have you? And it’s exactly as you remember, and like nothing you can recall. Yes, honey, you’re home. Wherever that happens to be, it’s the place you can never return to and never escape from.

headline: So THAT’S the Trick Here
text: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Interesting-looking grid today, Isn’t It?

headline: CUNY Schools to Lure Foreign Entrepreneurs With New Visa Program
text: The next Elon Musk may soon be working at a City University of New York campus in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, perhaps joined by the next Sergey Brin in Flushing, Queens. And they could be creating hundreds of jobs.

headline: Are You a Recent Migrant to Germany? We Want to Hear From You
text: Germany’s decision to throw open its borders last summer to an unprecedented flow of migrants inspired admiration and condemnation at home, in Europe and around the world.

headline: Knicks Shrug Off Losses and Trade Rumors as They Try to Refocus
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Eight days removed from their most recent game and winless in February, the Knicks reconvened for practice Wednesday afternoon after an extended All-Star break.

headline: Proenza Schouler: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez, who are exploring the see now buy now technique, present their latest collection.

headline: Donald Trump Wants to Hold to Middle Ground on Mideast, for Now
text: Donald J. Trump declined to say on Wednesday night which side deserves blame for the violent clashes between Israelis and Palestinians, adding he wants to remain “neutral” heading into a potential presidency so he can be best positioned to negotiate a deal between the two sides

headline: Marco Rubio and Ted Cruz Clash, Yet Find Common Ground
text: GREENVILLE, S.C. – Senator Marco Rubio of Florida shared his concerns about safety in football, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas sang a few bars, and Ben Carson opened up about why he left the medical field.

headline: Charges Dismissed Against 6 Ex-Employees of Rentboy.com
text: Federal authorities have dismissed charges against six former employees of the website Rentboy.com, while continuing to move forward with a case against the chief executive on counts of money laundering and promoting prostitution, according to court documents posted on Wednesday.

headline: What to Watch Thursday
text: Admit it: You’ve missed Craig Ferguson. But now he’s back, examining the historical foibles of his adopted country in “Join or Die.” “Mom” tackles addiction with the help of the surgeon general. And the Republican and Democratic presidential candidates answer questions at town hall meetings.

headline: Apple Letter on iPhone Security Draws Muted Tech Industry Response
text: After a federal court ordered Apple to help unlock an iPhone used by an attacker in a December mass shooting in San Bernardino, Calif., the company’s chief executive, Timothy D. Cook, penned a passionate letter warning of far-reaching implications beyond the case.

headline: Corrections: February 18, 2016
text: NEW YORK

headline: Toyota Recalls Nearly 3 Million RAV4s Over Seatbelt Separation
text: TOKYO — Toyota recalled nearly three million RAV4 sport utility vehicles worldwide on Thursday, saying their rear seatbelts could be severed in a crash, leaving passengers unprotected.

headline: Ingram Micro Sold to Chinese Company for $6 Billion
text: HONG KONG — Tianjin Tianhai, a Chinese shipping group, will buy the technology distributor Ingram Micro for $6 billion in the latest mega-deal involving a Chinese company.

headline: Racial Gerrymandering in North Carolina
text: The North Carolina legislature is hurriedly redrawing the lines of two congressional districts that had been gerrymandered along racial lines and ruled unconstitutional by a Federal District Court. Unless the Supreme Court steps in, the Republican-controlled legislature must draw new maps by Friday, in time for the March 15 state primary, under an order from the district court.

headline: Republicans See How Long They Can Hold Their Breath
text: Maybe we’d better refrain from having any new opinions until after the election.

headline: Politics: All in My Family
text: One of the more interesting features of the Democratic primary process is the generational divide among support for candidates — older Democratic voters generally prefer Hillary Clinton, and younger ones overwhelmingly prefer Bernie Sanders.

headline: How to Break a Party
text: Beginning with the Tea Party wave and continuing through the not-Romney musical chairs of the 2012 Republican primary and the battles over debt limits and fiscal cliffs, most coverage of the Republican Party’s internal divisions during the Obama era fell into an easy groove: There was the establishment, and there was the base.

headline: America’s Stacked Deck
text: It’s a little bizarre this political season to see wealthy candidates in both parties denouncing our political system for representing mostly the interests of, well, wealthy people.

headline: China’s Missile Provocation
text: China’s decision to station surface-to-air missiles on a disputed island in the South China Sea is the latest in a series of provocative acts that is fueling regional tensions. This unwise move raises new doubts about President Xi Jinping’s pledge not to “pursue militarization” in a vital waterway and passage for $5 trillion in annual trade.

headline: Resetting the Post-Scalia Supreme Court
text: In the days since Justice Antonin Scalia’s death, there has been plenty of talk about the substantial impact his absence will have on the Supreme Court’s docket. I’d like to shift the focus to the Roberts court itself.

headline: Crimes, iPhones and Encryption
text: Should companies, like Apple, have to unlock encrypted communication in the case of a crime?

headline: Mainstream G.O.P. Field of Three Faces Brutal Delegate Math
text: If the Republican Party remains divided for much longer, it will start getting more difficult for a mainstream candidate to win the nomination.

headline: How to Win an Election
text: Every election cycle, we’re asked to make monumental decisions about which people and policies should control our country, and we have to sort through a barrage of information to arrive at our selections. Often, we pick the candidate who breaks through the noise with a message that resonates with us. The politicians that prevail politicians are excellent storytellers.

headline: Shedding a House to Buy an Upper East Side Apartment
text: Shortly after they married in 1983, Morgan and Susan Snyder moved to Westchester County to be near Mr. Snyder’s job. “We discovered the city once we got to Westchester,” Mrs. Snyder said.

headline: Scuba Diving in Thailand: A Balancing Act
text: Last spring, when my 22-year-old son Forrister and I pulled on wet suits and shouldered scuba tanks for our first night dive, we’d been aboard the Chinese junk in the Indian Ocean off Thailand for all of 24 hours. As our launch shuttled us out to smooth granite rocks just peeking above the surface near Island No. 9 in the Similan archipelago, I wondered whether I’d made a terrible mistake. Even including that day’s three dives, the sum total of Forrister’s diving experience amounted to only seven.

headline: A Supreme Court With Merrick Garland Would Be the Most Liberal in Decades
text: It should be no surprise that Justice Antonin Scalia’s death has led to a political fight. His replacement on the court could lead to a historic change in the court’s balance of power.

headline: Chase Elliott, a Hall of Famer’s Son, Gains Respect Quickly
text: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. — Years ago, in a perhaps prescient moment, a family friend decided that the name William Clyde Elliott II did not fit a young boy. So he nicknamed the lad Chase, and the moniker stuck.

headline: Deadlocks and Rearguments: What’s Ahead for the Supreme Court
text: What lies ahead for the Supreme Court when it returns to the bench on Monday, a week after the death of Justice Antonin Scalia?

headline: Fashion Week: We Hardly Knew Ye
text: It went by in the blink of an eye, as it always does: There went Kanye West, there went Rihanna, there went Alexander Wang, all the best and buzziest of New York Fashion Week. They have deposited us here, on its final day. But not before the biggest names — they for whom first names alone suffice — come out.

headline: Nigeria’s Booming Film Industry Redefines African Life
text: ASABA, Nigeria — Sitting on a blue plastic stool in the sweltering heat, Ugezu J. Ugezu, one of Nigeria’s top filmmakers, was furiously rewriting his script as the cameras prepared to roll. “Cut!” he shouted after wrapping up a key scene, a confrontation between the two leading characters. Then, under his breath, he added, “Good as it gets.”

headline: A Bronx Precinct Where Killings Persist
text: The strangers slept no more than a dozen steps apart in a housing project in the South Bronx — she on a cot pushed up against the wall in the living room of her ailing mother’s apartment, and he in a narrow, airless hallway of the building, on the threshold of his family’s door.

headline: Long Sleeves and Bug Spray in São Paulo
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Last December, I suddenly found myself in possession of two bottles of the most precious liquid in town: Exposis Extrême, an extra-strong insect repellent. It’s deemed the best protection against the Aedes aegypti mosquito, which transmits dengue, chikungunya and, now, the Zika virus. Its active ingredient is icaridin, which also repels ticks and the mosquitoes that carry malaria. I’d bought the bottles earlier in the year, during an outbreak of dengue fever, in the hope that a high-quality bug spray would keep me safe from the virus. (It didn’t. I came down with dengue, anyway.)

headline: Syria's White Rose
text: BERLIN — At the end of Bertolt Brecht’s “Life of Galileo,” there is a sharp exchange. Andrea Sarti, a student of the astronomer, says, “Unhappy is the land that breeds no hero.” To which Galileo shoots back: “No, Andrea. Unhappy is the land that needs a hero.”

headline: The World’s Best News Photos
text: An update regarding two winning photographers using pseudonyms for their entry names has been added below.

headline: The World’s Best News Photos for 2015
text: The World Press Photo contest winners were announced, with a moody black-and-white image depicting the hardship of the Syrian migration crisis winning photo of the year.

headline: Proenza Schouler’s Arty Processes
text: When you’re spending hundreds of thousands of dollars to stage a fashion show, the fine points matter — not just the clothes, but the when, the where and the how, too. So it was hardly a coincidence that Proenza Schouler’s fall show happened to be at the Whitney Museum of American Art on Gansevoort Street.

headline: Turkey Blames Kurdish Militia for Ankara Attack, Challenging U.S.
text: BAGHDAD — In blaming a Syrian Kurdish militia supported by the United States for a deadly car bombing in Ankara, Turkey added new urgency on Thursday to a question its president recently posed to the Obama administration: Are you on the side of a NATO ally — Turkey — or its enemies?

headline: How Meditation Changes the Brain and Body
text: Editors’ note: Be mindful that this article is from early 2016, but know that your mindfulness helps your mind and body.
