At her graduation show at Central Saint Martins in 2014, the designer showed giant dresses embellished with clusters of florals made from Swarovski crystals and pearls. “The skirts were so huge that they had to redesign the catwalk,” Robertson says, laughing. “That scarred me a bit, and after that I decided to make couture-like pieces that are more casual and wearable.”

headline: What to Cook This Week
text: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Simone Rocha, J.W. Anderson and Gareth Pugh in Pictures
text: A photo diary of the fall/winter 2016 collections that were presented at London Fashion Week yesterday.

headline: Ticket Sellers Promise Marquee Names, but the Comics Rarely Show
text: Paige Kaden, who is new to town, stood on a frigid block in Times Square on Thursday afternoon, looking for a man named John. She was angry.

headline: Trump Targets Free Trade, and G.O.P. Follows Suit
text: Any doubts that Donald J. Trump has had a huge (as he might say) influence on the Republican Party were dispelled this month when Senator Rob Portman came out against the Trans-Pacific Partnership.

headline: Review: In ‘The Woodsman,’ a Love Lost in Oz Under a Witch’s Spell
text: The moment you step through the door, enchantment envelops you. Flocks of Mason jars hang suspended, glowing with amber light. Bare branches sprout from walls in the orchestra or reach scraggy arms across the ceiling, almost into the balcony. Thunder rumbles under birdsong.

headline: Liv Tyler’s Final Touches for Belstaff
text: LONDON — Celebrity collaborations with luxury brands are a dime a dozen these days, and most of the time it’s a marriage of convenience where neither party knows nor particularly cares about the other.

headline: Mulberry: Fall 2016
text: Johnny Coca’s debuts his first collection for Mulberry.

headline: Samsung Announces Gear 360, a New Virtual Reality Camera
text: With competition continuing to heat up in the handset market, Samsung Electronics is relying heavily on virtual reality to help distinguish its smartphones.

headline: After South Carolina, Cruz and Rubio Vie to Become Top Rival to Trump
text: Mainstream Republicans grappled on Sunday with Donald J. Trump’s sweeping victory in South Carolina as if cycling through stages of grief, with some refusing to accept that he could be the party’s eventual nominee and others searching for ways to prevent his insurgent candidacy from becoming unstoppable.

headline: Belstaff: Fall 2016
text: Delphine Ninous’s latest collection.

headline: No, the Polling Doesn’t Prove Bernie Sanders Won the Hispanic Vote in Nevada
text: One of Saturday’s biggest election surprises was the entrance and exit polling measuring Hispanic voters in the Nevada caucus. It found that Bernie Sanders defeated Hillary Clinton by eight percentage points among Hispanic voters, overturning months of conventional wisdom about Mrs. Clinton’s strength among nonwhites.

headline: Ted Cruz and Donald Trump Head Toward Super Tuesday With G.O.P.’s Deepest Pockets
text: A seven-month, $220 million surge of spending on behalf of mainstream Republican candidates has yielded a primary battle dominated by Donald J. Trump and Senator Ted Cruz of Texas, two candidates reviled by most of the party’s leading donors.

headline: What to Watch Sunday
text: Are our “Girls” about to become women? Check out the Season 5 premiere. Cast members of “Cheers,” “Friends,” “Frasier” and “Taxi” pay tribute to the director James Burrows. And step into the ring with Sylvester Stallone and Michael B. Jordan in “Creed.”

headline: Huishan Zhang: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Mr. Zhang presents his fall collection.

headline: Welsh Town Leads a British Revolt Against the Tax System and Corporations
text: CRICKHOWELL, Wales — Fifty small businesses line the cobbled streets of Crickhowell. There is a bookstore and a bakery, a salmon smokery and a pub.

headline: Paul Smith: Fall 2016
text: Mr. Smith, who recently collapsed his diffusion lines, presents his latest collection.

headline: American Sleep Patterns Vary by Age, Race and Place, Study Finds
text: One out of three Americans do not get enough sleep, according to a new study from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which found that sleep schedules varied by race, age and geography.

headline: Tim Etchells Wins Award in Honor of Spalding Gray
text: This year’s Spalding Gray Award, named for the prolific monologuist who died in 2004, has been awarded to Tim Etchells, the British interdisciplinary artist and artistic director of the theater troupe Forced Entertainment.

headline: Kerry Says U.S. and Russia Near Syria Truce Deal as 100 Die in Attacks
text: JERUSALEM — Secretary of State John Kerry announced on Sunday an agreement with Russia for an imminent, if “provisional,” partial truce in Syria, saying it largely awaited a conversation between President Obama and President Vladimir V. Putin to work out final details.

headline: Review: In ‘Evicted,’ Home Is an Elusive Goal for America’s Poor
text: One of the most heartbreaking moments in Matthew Desmond’s “Evicted: Poverty and Profit in the American City”— and there’s a shameful assortment to choose from — is when 13-year-old Ruby Hinkston takes refuge in the public library. She’s come to use the computer. It turns out that she’s been slowly building her dream house with a free online game, and she wants to visit it again.

headline: Donald Trump Struggles to Explain Comments on Persian Gulf War From 2002
text: Donald J. Trump said on Sunday that he wasn’t precisely sure what he meant in 2002 when he told the radio host Howard Stern that he wished the Persian Gulf war in 1991 had been “done correctly.”

headline: Temperley London: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Alice Temperley presents her latest collection.

headline: Celebrating the Many Changes of David Bowie, the Thin White Duke
text: Mr. Bowie’s music was performed all weekend by the Loser’s Lounge at Joe’s Pub in the East Village.

headline: Alexander McQueen: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Sarah Burton presents her fall collection.

headline: Caution Rebuffed, Unicorns and Other Start-Ups Fixate on Rainbows
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Technology stocks are gyrating. Valuations for once-vaunted private companies have been slashed and some start-ups have shut down. Even Apple’s chief executive, Timothy D. Cook, recently said he was “seeing extreme conditions unlike anything we have ever experienced.”

headline: ‘Deadpool’ Holds Top Spot at Box Office
text: LOS ANGELES – Three new niche films generated O.K. audience interest over the weekend, as “Deadpool” remained the mainstream movie of the moment.

headline: Yale Banishes Demons. Next Are Tigers and Lions.
text: PHILADELPHIA — Yale may always be, as its fictional alumnus C. Montgomery Burns once put it on “The Simpsons,” first in gentlemanly club life, but in Ivy League men’s basketball, it has not finished alone in first since 1962.

headline: London Mayor Joins Chorus Demanding Exit From E.U.
text: LONDON — Prime Minister David Cameron faced another jarring reminder of the country’s deep divisions over whether Britain should stay in the European Union on Sunday when Mayor Boris Johnson of London, a fellow Conservative and one of the party’s most popular figures, announced that he would join the forces campaigning to exit the bloc.

headline: Yoenis Cespedes Appears Early; the Mets Appear Pleased
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The position players were not required to report to spring training for another three days, so the Mets’ complex was relatively quiet Sunday when Yoenis Cespedes made his entrance with his new wheels: a custom pickup that looked ready for a monster truck rally.

headline: Denny Hamlin Wins Daytona 500 With Late Surge
text: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. — With a margin of victory that was both historic and microscopic, Denny Hamlin claimed the 58th running of the Daytona 500 by barely the nose of his racecar.

headline: Rebellious Youth-Inspired Beauty at Topshop Unique
text: “We’ve been thinking about the mishmash of styles and sounds floating around Soho in the late 1980s. There was still a hangover from punk, but the New Romantic thing was happening and people were starting to go to raves,” said Topshop Unique’s creative director Kate Phelan backstage at today’s show. The label’s fall/winter 2016 collection explored, once again, British youth culture. “This is not an army of replica girls,” Phelan added. “It’s about having your own individual attitude.”

headline: The Letters From Harper Lee to Berkeley Breathed
text: The letters written to the cartoonist Berkeley Breathed from Harper Lee, with notes.

headline: Truce Unravels as Fighting Picks Up in Ukraine
text: MARYINKA, Ukraine — Though overshadowed by the war in Syria, fighting in eastern Ukraine has picked up sharply in recent weeks, residents along the front line, commanders and European monitors say.

headline: The European Dream: A Requiem
text: Paris — Jihadist attacks, a migrant flood, Greek debt, surging nationalism: Across the European Union, anxiety and division are brewing in a way not seen since the 1940s.

headline: Election of a Female President Opens a New Era for a Former Boys Club
text: One evening last month, after the traditional cocktails and black-tie meal, the members of the Century Association gathered in the reading room of their Renaissance-style clubhouse on West 43rd Street and, with little fanfare, made a bit of literary history.

headline: When Harper Lee, of ‘Mockingbird,’ Corresponded With Opus the Penguin’s Creator
text: Generations of admiring readers knew Harper Lee as the reclusive author of the classic novel “To Kill a Mockingbird.” But a relative few were given a glimpse of another side of Ms. Lee: that of a witty, impish and loyal pen pal.

headline: 5G Is a New Frontier for Mobile Carriers and Tech Companies
text: GUILDFORD, England — On the outskirts of this sleepy commuter town just south of London, plans are underway to build the fastest cellphone network in the world.

headline: When Peacekeepers Come Home
text: Over decades, several truths have emerged about United Nations peacekeeping forces. They can do immense good by separating combatants and pacifying civilian areas. They are, on occasion, guilty of sexual violence and financial corruption in the societies they have been sent to help. And increasingly, the troops are drawn from less wealthy countries, rather than the rich nations that finance the operations.

headline: Art in San Bernardino
text: Images documented by a poet and a photographer in the California city.

headline: Young Voters, Motivated Again
text: In one of the more pleasant surprises of this presidential campaign, young Americans are voting in big numbers, contributing to some unexpected results so far.

headline: A Bruised San Bernardino Shows Cultural Stirrings
text: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif. — When Juan Delgado, a poet and professor here, thinks about his beloved and beleaguered city, he often turns to the image of a dandelion, the much-maligned flower known for its deep roots and its ability to thrive under adverse circumstances. “The dandelion is not easily uprooted,” he observes. “Its beauty is persistence.”

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Feb. 22
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Quick but Efficient
text: MONDAY PUZZLE — The vast majority of crossword puzzles are not washable, but it would be nice if this one by Ed Sessa could at least be wiped down. It’s literally dripping with DIRTY stuff.

headline: Refugee Influx in Germany Sets Off a Brooding Cultural Debate
text: BERLIN — The 66th annual Berlin International Film Festival wrapped up over the weekend. But perhaps more gripping than any drama onscreen is the one playing out in Germany itself, where the arrival of more than one million asylum-seekers in the past year — 80,000 of them in Berlin — has been challenging the country’s ideas about itself.

headline: Spinning Tunes in Ghana, With the World on His Mind
text: Marathon D.J. sets are a staple of electronic music culture. From Berlin clubs to Bushwick loft parties, headlining D.J.s sometimes spend three, six or even eight hours behind the decks. But these feats of song-selecting endurance pale compared with the typical weekly schedule of D.J. Katapila, a musician in Accra, the capital of Ghana, in West Africa.

headline: Reporting on Life, Death and Corruption in Southeast Asia
text: BANGKOK — The protesters built what looked like medieval ramparts topped with sharpened wooden stakes in the heart of Bangkok. The military was preparing to sweep them out.

headline: Review: ‘Suspects,’ Britain’s Unscripted Relative of ‘Law & Order’
text: When “Suspects” had its premiere in Britain in 2014, it was called innovative and revolutionary. If you were a detective, you might have asked: Hasn’t anyone seen the American or British versions of “Law & Order,” let alone classic British series like “The Bill” or “Taggart”?

headline: A Lingerie Brand Offers Real Women as (Role) Models
text: Attempts to move away from airbrushing in advertising have ebbed and flowed over the last decade, but at a time when even Barbie now comes in petite, tall and curvy, more retailers are turning to authentic-looking women to market their products.

headline: Muted Response to Bernie Sanders at South Carolina Church
text: WEST COLUMBIA, S.C. — The problem began as soon as Bernie Sanders walked into the dining room of the revered, and predominantly black, Brookland Baptist Church. Instead of flocking to him, as people do at his large college rallies, many of church’s 780 members looked up for a moment, then quietly went back to eating their Sunday feast — unmoved as Mr. Sanders, the Democratic senator from Vermont, tried to work the room.

headline: Review: ‘Madama Butterfly’ Showcases Ana María Martínez
text: Half an hour of intermission separates the first and second acts of Puccini’s “Madama Butterfly” at the Metropolitan Opera. But in the libretto that gap covers three years of suffering for the title character, a betrayed young geisha waiting in vain for the return of her American husband.

headline: Oscars Pin Hopes on Chris Rock for Ratings
text: LOS ANGELES — The last time Chris Rock hosted the Oscars, he was judged by many to be a bust.

headline: Bernie Sanders Hits a Roadblock
text: Bernie Sanders’s loss in the Nevada caucuses, 47 percent to 53 percent, reveals a very real weakness of his insurgent challenge to Hillary Clinton.

headline: After Bush v. Gore
text: The dramatic controversy surrounding the 2000 presidential election led to sweeping voting reforms, but opened the door to a new set of problems that continue to impact elections today.

headline: 16 Years After Bush v. Gore, Still Wrestling With Ballot-Box Rules
text: Reflecting on baseball attendance, the philosopher Yogi Berra observed that “if people don’t want to come to the ballpark, how are you going to stop them?” He could have said much the same thing about the American electorate. If voters don’t want to go to the polls, what is going to stop them, too? Often enough, nothing has.

headline: Review: Limón Dance Company Reconstructs Its Founder’s ‘Dialogues’
text: In the golden age of modern dance, works were choreographed and performed and either kept alive through performance or not performed and thus most likely forgotten. In rare cases, a work might have been filmed, leaving a record for posterity. Recently, when Carla Maxwell, artistic director of the Limón Dance Company, was made aware of a film of “Dialogues,” a lost work that José Limón created in 1951, she set out to bring the piece back to life.

headline: Chats That Led to ‘Becoming Mike Nichols’ on HBO
text: A few years ago, the stage director Jack O’Brien had a long, late lunch with Mike Nichols. He returned home, “exhilarated and sort of drained and exhausted and stimulated,” he said. “There was nothing like talking to Mike.”

headline: Review: George London Foundation Singing Competition Offers Arias to Please a Crowd
text: However you may feel about classical music competitions (and there are reasons to love some and loathe others), it is hard not to become caught up in the final judgments, to see how audience favorites and your own have fared in the judges’ eyes and ears. In the case of the George London Foundation Awards Competition for young American and Canadian opera singers (one of the more lovable affairs), which held the final round of its 45th annual contest on Friday, at the Morgan Library & Museum, the odds were good that at least some of the choices would please everyone.

headline: Like the Last President to Visit Cuba, Obama Seeks a Change
text: WASHINGTON — Imagine an American president in his final year in office, making a historic and carefully choreographed trip to Cuba to extend a hand of friendship to an island neighbor after decades of hostility and mistrust.

headline: Bubba Watson Outplays Strong Field at Northern Trust Open
text: LOS ANGELES — The Northern Trust Open trophy belonged to Bubba Watson, but for the 31st year, Riviera Country Club came out on top. Led by Watson, the deepest field of 2016, as determined by the Official World Golf Rankings, could not challenge the tournament record, 20 under par.

headline: U.S. Scrambles to Contain Growing ISIS Threat in Libya
text: THIES, Senegal — The Islamic State’s branch in Libya is deepening its reach across a wide area of Africa, attracting new recruits from countries like Senegal that had been largely immune to the jihadist propaganda — and forcing the African authorities and their Western allies to increase efforts to combat the fast-moving threat.

headline: Newly Elected Central African Republic Leader Faces Hard Realities
text: BANGUI, Central African Republic — A former prime minister, Faustin Archange Touadéra, has won election as president of the Central African Republic, according to preliminary results, setting the stage for the first elected government in three years for a poverty-stricken country that is just emerging from a devastating civil war.

headline: Allergan Earnings, the Mobile World Congress and Durable Goods Data
text: Here’s what to look for this week.

headline: Maple Syrup Makers in New York Savor Aftertaste of a Mild Winter
text: SALEM, N.Y. — Snowmobile sales have sputtered, ski resorts are struggling and some bait shops, which rely heavily on ice fishing, can barely afford to keep their lights on.

headline: College Student Missing After Plane Lands in a Long Island Harbor
text: SETAUKET, N.Y. — The police searched on Sunday for a 23-year-old City College student from Queens who was aboard a small plane that made a forced landing in the frigid waters of Setauket Harbor off the North Shore of Long Island after its engine malfunctioned, the authorities said.

headline: When a State Balks at a City’s Minimum Wage
text: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. — Veronica Roscoe, who earns $7.75 an hour working at a Burger King here, thought last August that she had won: This city had become the first in the South to approve a local minimum wage.

headline: Stanley Druckenmiller, a Billionaire Financier, Backs John Kasich
text: The billionaire financier Stanley F. Druckenmiller has signed on to support Gov. John Kasich presidential bid, the Kasich campaign said on Sunday.

headline: Clinton Campaign Rebuffs Sanders on Latino Vote in Nevada
text: LAS VEGAS — Hillary Clinton’s campaign had one of its polling firms that specializes in the Latino vote assess the Nevada caucus results in an effort to rebut the claim by Senator Bernie Sanders that, though he lost over all, he won among Hispanics, a demographic that is crucial to the success of both candidates.

headline: Wellness App Aims to Improve Workplace Nutrition
text: A growing number of companies are offering their employees digital tools to help improve their eating habits in hopes of increasing productivity, reducing sick days and cutting health care costs.

headline: Olympic Duties Leave UConn’s Geno Auriemma Right at Home
text: STORRS, Conn. — Geno Auriemma spent a couple of hours at the University of Connecticut’s practice center on Sunday overseeing drills, teaching halfcourt sets, encouraging players and pointing out mistakes. He was in his element. At one point during a scrimmage, he noticed a defensive error.

headline: Supreme Court Fight Is New Front in Partisan Warfare
text: WASHINGTON — The prospect of the Supreme Court’s sitting for a year or even longer at less than full strength means the partisan warfare that has overtaken Washington could produce a whole new kind of government shutdown — one limiting the court’s ability to fully function.

headline: Iran’s Thwarted Reformers Set Careful Goals for Coming Vote
text: TEHRAN — They clapped and cheered, and many shouted for the release of their political leaders under house arrest for the past five years. Some held up pictures of a popular former president, Mohammad Khatami. Pictures of his hands, to be exact, because displaying his portrait is illegal.

headline: A Rising Call to Promote STEM Education and Cut Liberal Arts Funding
text: When the Kentucky governor, Matt Bevin, suggested last month that students majoring in French literature should not receive state funding for their college education, he joined a growing number of elected officials who want to nudge students away from the humanities and toward more job-friendly subjects like electrical engineering.

headline: Teaching Bronx Students the Language of Computers
text: The website allows users to post videos of police abuses, track them on an interactive map and even play a game in which the goal is to avoid gunfire from police officers.

headline: What 5G Will Mean for You
text: You may soon start hearing a lot about 5G, or the fifth generation of wireless technology. This technology is expected to leap ahead of current wireless technology, known as 4G, by offering mobile Internet speeds that will let people download entire movies within seconds, and it may pave the way for new types of mobile applications.

headline: No Corrections: February 22, 2016
text: No corrections appeared in print.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “ISIS is spreading even to here. If we do not have a multinational effort, ISIS will spread even more.”

headline: Wild Muster a Show of Strength in Their Long-Awaited Outdoor Game
text: MINNEAPOLIS — Not that he was anxious or anything, but the Minnesota Wild owner Craig Leipold said he had started monitoring the weather about a month ago for his team’s Stadium Series outdoor game with the Chicago Blackhawks. A week before the game, he started checking the forecast twice a day.

headline: Yankees Hope New Workout Area Puts Them on Upward Trajectory
text: TAMPA, Fla. — When pitcher James Kaprielian rolled up to Steinbrenner Field several weeks ago, he had to blink, rub his eyes and do a double take. As he glanced toward left field, there was an incongruous sight on one of the practice diamonds, something he had never seen on a baseball field — an enormous grass mound, 10 feet tall with a 30-yard incline.

headline: As a Species, the Knuckleball Flutters but Survives
text: PORT CHARLOTTE, Fla. — Phil Niekro was a 21-year-old pitcher in Class A when his manager, Red Murff, gave him a compliment that propelled him to the Hall of Fame. If Niekro could control his knuckleball just a little better, Murff said, he would pitch in the big leagues.

headline: Jimmer Fredette, a Basketball Prodigy, Now Plays Catch-Up
text: WHITE PLAINS — A high-profile spectator found a spot along the baseline Sunday afternoon to watch Jimmer Fredette play his final game (for now, at least) with the Westchester Knicks of the N.B.A. Development League.

headline: Delegate Count Leaving Bernie Sanders With Steep Climb
text: Senator Bernie Sanders vowed on Sunday to fight on after losing the Nevada caucuses, predicting that he would pull off a historic political upset by this summer’s party convention.

headline: Review: In ‘The Good Girl,’ a Sexbot Gets Weepy
text: Programmed to please, the sexbot has lately developed a peculiar tic: a postcoital tendency toward tears.

headline: In a Black Church in South Carolina, Bernie Sanders Struggles to Get an ‘Amen’
text: WEST COLUMBIA, S.C. — The problem began as soon as Bernie Sanders walked into the dining room of the revered and predominantly black Brookland Baptist Church here. Instead of flocking to him, as supporters do at his large college rallies, many of the church’s 780 members present looked up for a moment, then quietly went back to eating their Sunday feast — unmoved as Mr. Sanders, the senator from Vermont, tried to work the room.

headline: Poll Watch: Donald Trump’s Curiously Strong Support Among Evangelicals
text: So far, evangelical voters in three states have weighed in on their preference in the race for the Republican presidential nomination. In both Iowa and New Hampshire, evangelical voters were less likely than non-evangelical voters to support Donald Trump — by 7 and 11 points, respectively.

headline: Governors Devise Bipartisan Effort to Reduce Opioid Abuse
text: WASHINGTON — Alarmed at an epidemic of drug overdose deaths, the National Governors Association decided over the weekend to devise treatment protocols to reduce the use of opioid painkillers.

headline: ‘Vinyl’ Season 1, Episode 2: Mugged by God
text: The record company president Richie Finestra has been transforming his rage into self-loathing, but beating a man to death (in last week’s pilot) marked a turning point: He’s directing his anger outward, and everything he encounters is in danger, whether that’s an employee who gets fired for talking back or a Jethro Tull LP that gets snapped in half for being insufficiently rocking.

headline: Review: ‘Nice Fish,’ Mark Rylance and Louis Jenkins’s Quirky Ice Fishing Tale
text: For a certain slice of New Yorkers — you know who you are — Mark Rylance is the cultural deity that Beyoncé is to, well, a different slice of New Yorkers. At a recent performance of “Nice Fish,” a quirky charmer of a play written by Mr. Rylance and Louis Jenkins, the audience greeted every stuttered utterance of Mr. Rylance’s with delighted laughter and murmurs of pleasure, as if sampling the world’s most ravishing tasting menu.

headline: Escape From Bushworld
text: LAS VEGAS — The Bushes always bristled at the “d” word. And now they don’t have to worry about it anymore.

headline: ‘The Walking Dead’ Season 6, Episode 10: Rick Finds Love, Jesus
text: That noise you heard Sunday night was the sound of “Walking Dead” nation rejoicing — or the romantically obsessed quadrant, at least. For that was when “Richonne” moved from fan fiction sites and Tumblrs into the actual world of the show, as Rick and Michonne’s friendly joshing about hard days and dental health finally escalated into considerably more. (Cough called it cough… )

headline: Senators Returning to Square Off Head to Head Over Replacing Scalia
text: WASHINGTON — Members of Congress will return to work on Monday, convening for the first time since the death of Justice Antonin Scalia  in what is expected to be a protracted fight over any nominee offered by President Obama to replace the justice on the Supreme Court.

headline: ‘Billions’ Season 1, Episode 6: A Weird Couple of Days
text: There was reason to suspect, when “Billions” was announced, that Showtime was offering a prestige series about Wall Street, featuring two highly respected actors, Paul Giamatti and Damian Lewis, and a co-creator credit for a New York Times editor.

headline: Rosario Ferré, Writer Who Examined Puerto Rican Identity, Dies at 77
text: Rosario Ferré, a formidable figure in Puerto Rican letters who wrote novels in both Spanish and English, and who was a finalist for the National Book Award in 1995 for the family epic “A House on the Lagoon,” which she translated herself from the original Spanish, died on Thursday at her home in San Juan, P.R. She was 77.

headline: Douglas L. Inman, Coastal Science Pioneer, Dies at 95
text: When Douglas L. Inman began his career as a coastal scientist in the 1950s, little was known about the coastal region where water, land and air come together, which geologists call the nearshore. It was obvious that beaches differed from place to place, but geologists struggled to do much more than classify them according to their shapes. Little was known about the direct relationships among waves, currents and the movement of coastal sediments like sand.

headline: N.B.A. Game of the Week: Warriors at Thunder
text: Every week, The New York Times chooses one essential game to watch, highlighting hot teams, winning and losing streaks and statistical intrigue in the N.B.A.

headline: A Monthlong Celebration of Albert Camus in New York
text: “I loved New York, with that powerful love that at times leaves you full of uncertainty and abhorrence,” Albert Camus wrote in 1947, a year after making his only trip to the United States. Now, New York will be paying him a less ambivalent tribute, with a nearly monthlong series of events commemorating the 70th anniversary of his visit to the city.

headline: HPV Sharply Reduced in Teenage Girls Following Vaccine, Study Says
text: A vaccine introduced a decade ago to combat the sexually transmitted virus that causes cervical cancer has already reduced the virus’s prevalence in teenage girls by almost two-thirds, federal researchers said Monday.

headline: Unions Say a Majority of Their Members Support Hillary Clinton
text: In an effort to dispute what they say is a false narrative that union voters are closely split between Hillary Clinton and Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, a group of more than 20 unions representing more than 10 million workers released a statement on Monday reaffirming support for Mrs. Clinton.

headline: What to Watch Monday
text: Do you thrill to the sound of humming presses and rumbling trucks? Then check out “Spotlight,” the best-picture Oscar nominee that A. O. Scott of The New York Times says gets the gray areas of newspaper journalism right. “The X-Files” return comes to a close with Chris Carter, the show’s creator, at the helm. And Mike Nichols reminisces about his early career.

headline: London Fashion Week: Burberry, Christopher Kane and Erdem
text: LONDON — And so to Monday, the fourth day of the London schedule, which begins with shows from two outsiders who have managed to make the city — and its fashion scene — their own. The Serbian-born Roksanda Ilincic shows her Roksanda collection at 10 a.m., followed an hour later by the Canadian designer Erdem Moralioglu, whose Erdem brand is celebrating its 10th anniversary this year.

headline: Facebook Open Sources Wireless Gear
text: Facebook created a global computing system faster than any of its peers by working with crowds of outside engineers, patent-free. Now it wants to do the same thing with the world’s wireless communications technology.

headline: Lee Friedlander’s Overlooked Civil Rights’ Photos
text: A new book shows how before Lee Friedlander became known as the quintessential street photographer, he chronicled an important — if sometimes overlooked — moment in civil rights history.

headline: Lee Friedlander’s Overlooked Civil Rights Photos
text: The photographs in Lee Friedlander’s book “Prayer Pilgrimage for Freedom” are of a subject not usually associated with him: the civil rights movement. Among his earliest and least typical images — the photographer was only 22 when he made them — they document a historic, if lesser known, event in the struggle for racial equality and justice.

headline: HSBC Posts 4th-Quarter Loss and Comes Under S.E.C. Scrutiny
text: LONDON — HSBC said on Monday that it lost money in the fourth quarter and warned that it was being investigated for hiring candidates with ties to government officials in the Asia-Pacific region.

headline: Cranks on Top
text: If prediction markets (and most hardheaded analysis) are to be believed, Hillary Clinton, having demonstrated her staying power, is the overwhelming favorite for the Democratic nomination. The Republican race, by contrast, has seen a lot of consolidation — it’s pretty much down to a two-man race — but the outcome is still up for grabs.

headline: Housing Solutions for New York City, Deep in the Weeds
text: One of the mysteries of life in New York is the persistence of vacant lots. How a city of skyscraping land prices and a million matchbox apartments could also be home to properties that sit behind chain-link fences for years, even decades, as habitat for weeds and broken bottles, seems the definition of inexplicability.

headline: Getting Rid of Big Currency Notes Could Help Fight Crime
text: Few Europeans use the 500-euro note, and most Americans rarely encounter the $100 bill. Yet hundreds of millions of these notes are in circulation around the world, where they are often used by drug cartels, corrupt politicians, terrorists and tax cheats to evade law enforcement. That’s why officials in Europe and elsewhere are proposing to end the printing of high-denomination bills.

headline: Why Are White Death Rates Rising?
text: IT’S disturbing and puzzling news: Death rates are rising for white, less-educated Americans. The economists Anne Case and Angus Deaton reported in December that rates have been climbing since 1999 for non-Hispanic whites age 45 to 54, with the largest increase occurring among the least educated. An analysis of death certificates by The New York Times found similar trends and showed that the rise may extend to white women.

headline: Is There Action the U.S. Should Take in Syria?
text: Can America do anything to keep Assad from decimating his opponents and widen the fight against ISIS?

headline: EFG International Agrees to Buy BTG Pactual’s Swiss Business
text: LONDON — The private banking and asset management firm EFG International said on Monday that it had agreed to acquire BSI, the Swiss private-banking arm of the Brazilian investment bank BTG Pactual, for 1.33 billion Swiss francs, or about $1.34 billion.

headline: Renewed Efforts to Stop Subway Sex Crimes
text: Fanning out along the platform at the City Hall subway station in Manhattan, the plainclothes police officers blended in with the morning commuters. As they prepared to board a northbound train, they watched closely, their eyes darting from rider to rider.

headline: Student Question | Is Apple Right in Refusing to Unlock the iPhone of One of the San Bernardino Killers?
text: Last week, a judge in California ordered Apple to help the F.B.I. unlock an iPhone used by one of the attackers in the assault in San Bernardino that killed 14 people in December. The following day, Timothy D. Cook, the chief executive of Apple, responded with a letter to Apple customers, warning of the “chilling” breach of privacy posed by the government’s demands.

headline: Staying Healthy While Traveling the Globe
text: On a recent trip to Tanzania with four grandsons, my most important task (beside protecting them from the jaws of a lion or leopard) was to keep them, and myself, in good health. It would not have been much fun to be stuck in a tent next to the commode or flattened on a cot while the rest of the gang viewed a dazzling array of wild animals from the safety of a Land Rover.

headline: Smartphone Era Politics
text: The time has come for a painful confession: I have spent my life with words, yet I am illiterate. I can ape the vocabulary of my times but it is not mine. Certain things I cannot say, only mouth.

headline: A Sri Lankan Lesson in Free Speech
text: London — I gave a talk last month at the Galle Literary Festival in Jaffna, Sri Lanka. This festival, whose home is in the southern city of Galle, has become over the past decade one of the brightest lights in Sri Lanka’s cultural firmament. This year, it established “outreach” festivals in Kandy, in Sri Lanka’s hill country, and in Jaffna in the North.

headline: Morning Agenda: HSBC’s Fourth-Quarter Losses
text: HSBC’S FOURTH-QUARTER LOSSES | HSBC, Britain’s largest bank by assets, posted a loss of $1.33 billion for the three months ending Dec. 31,Chad Bray reports in DealBook. It had posted a profit of $511 million in the fourth quarter of 2014. Before taxes, the bank posted a loss of $858 million.

headline: Jazz at Lincoln Center Announces Lineup for 2016-17 Season
text: Jazz at Lincoln Center’s 2016-17 season will celebrate a clutch of jazz centenaries and welcome an array of familiar collaborators, often in new configurations. The season, running from September through next June, has no official theme but could be seen as a homecoming: this will be Jazz at Lincoln Center’s first full slate of programming since the reopening of Frederick P. Rose Hall, after renovations to create the Mica and Ahmet Ertegun Atrium last year.

headline: ScienceTake | Flight of the Sea Snail
text: A tiny marine mollusk no bigger than a peppercorn flies through the water with the same wing motion as a fruit fly.

headline: A Sea Snail That Moves Like a Flying Insect
text: Most of the tiny creatures in the sea, collectively called zooplankton, move themselves along by using their limbs to paddle. But the sea butterfly, a marine snail the size of a peppercorn, has long appeared to use winglike appendages to fly through the water.

headline: Scientists Ponder the Prospect of Contagious Cancer
text: For all its peculiar horror, cancer comes with a saving grace. If nothing else can stop a tumor’s mad evolution, the cancer ultimately dies with its host. Everything the malignant cells have learned about outwitting the patient’s defenses — and those of the oncologists — is erased. The next case of cancer, in another victim, must start anew.

headline: Cameron’s Referendum Gamble
text: Britain’s prime minister, David Cameron, is facing the biggest challenge of his career. The referendum expected this June on whether the country should stay in the European Union will define his legacy.

headline: Narrow Focus May Aid F.B.I. in Apple Case

headline: How to Make the Most of Drugs We Already Have
text: Though you may not have realized it, there’s a good chance that a doctor has prescribed you a medication for a use other than what it was approved for. This off-label use is perfectly legal, but isn’t as safe as it might be, in part because incentives to invest in costly clinical trials to test such uses are weak.

headline: ‘Easy Money’ Isn’t Cheap: Hong Kong License Plate Sells for $2.3 Million
text: HONG KONG — A vehicle license plate in Hong Kong sold at auction for 18.1 million Hong Kong dollars on Sunday, or $2.3 million, the highest price ever paid in the city. The plate carries the number 28, which in Cantonese sounds similar to a phrase for “easy money.”

headline: Haryana State in India Proposes New Caste Status in Bid to Quell Protests
text: NEW DELHI — A state government in India promised to introduce a bill to grant coveted “backward” status to a relatively prosperous caste group, officials said Monday, in an effort to quell protests that have raged for the past four days.

headline: China’s Excess Production Has Intensified Slowdown, Business Group Says
text: BEIJING — The failure of Chinese leaders to tackle the problem of excess industrial production has intensified an economic slowdown in the country and threatens to wreak havoc on global markets, a prominent European business association said in a new report on Monday.

headline: Beijing to Raise Threshold on Red Alerts for Smog
text: BEIJING — The first red alert over air pollution in the Chinese capital almost brought this city to a standstill in December, with schools shut, construction halted and driving restricted. Now, in a swift policy shift, Beijing plans to issue a red alert based on higher thresholds, despite government pledges to better address the toxic air.

Trump to meet with her after a speech in which he spoke approvingly of killing Islamic terrorists with bullets dipped in the blood of pigs.

text: Sysco said on Monday that it had agreed to acquire the Brakes Group, a European food distributor, for $3.1 billion.

text: A government watchdog group filed a formal complaint with New York City officials on Monday against Mayor Bill de Blasio and the outside political groups tied to him, requesting an investigation into whether their fund-raising and spending violated the law.

headline: China Moves to Halt ‘Weird’ Architecture
text: BEIJING — China is home to at least 10 White Houses, three Arcs de Triomphe and one Eiffel Tower. But 2016 might signal the end for China’s more grandiose architecture.

headline: 1941: Mines in Part of Mediterranean
text: LONDON — The British Admiralty, in a move to isolate Italy from Tripolitania and Tunisia and to hamper the Italian fleet in its operations off the southern Italian coast, announced today [Feb. 22] that an area of some 150,000 square miles in the central Mediterranean, with Malta as its focus, was dangerous to shipping, indicating that the area was spotted with mines laid by the British Navy. The danger area runs from Bengasi, in Libya, to Cape Santa Maria di Leuca, the tip of the heel of Italy, then along the Italian coast around the toe, and northward to Point Paolo Fuora. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 23, 1941

headline: Construction Begins on the 5G Wireless Dream
text: Most people think that trying to download an entire movie to a mobile device is the act of a madman. Or the act of someone with plenty of time and money to burn.

headline: Clearing Clutter From the YouTube Video Screen
text: Q. Is there a way to turn off those onscreen text boxes that cover up part of the video while it’s playing on YouTube?

headline: An Island, a Focal Point for a Healthy Marine Ecosystem
text: Islands play a crucial role in sustaining marine ecosystems in the Pacific Ocean, according to a new study. The waters surrounding islands are rich in phytoplankton, microscopic organisms that inhabit the upper layers of the oceans and serve as an important food source for larger animals. After studying 35 coral reef islands using satellite imagery and ship-based surveys, researchers concluded that the biomass of phytoplankton around islands was up to 86 percent greater than what is found in other parts of the ocean. The findings appear in the journal Nature Communications.

headline: Michael Jaharis, Pharmaceutical Executive and Philanthropist, Dies at 87
text: Michael Jaharis, whose business expertise in the pharmaceutical industry made him a fortune estimated at more than $2.2 billion, and who gave major gifts to cultural institutions like the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Art Institute of Chicago and the Metropolitan Opera, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 87.

headline: Margaret Sullivan, New York Times Public Editor, Joining Washington Post
text: Margaret Sullivan, the public editor of The New York Times, is leaving to join The Washington Post as its media columnist, the two newspapers announced on Monday.

text: All of us want to be normal, yet none of us want to be average.

headline: Sylvester Stallone on the Weakest Link in ‘Creed’: Himself
text: It’s too easy to surmise, given Sylvester Stallone’s slightly slurred and deliberate manner of speaking (the result of facial nerve damage caused by rough forceps at birth), as well as his most enduring screen roles — “Rocky” and “Rambo” — that the man might not be a mental giant. But such assumptions could not be farther from the truth.

headline: Bangladesh Arrests Three Men in Priest’s Beheading
text: DHAKA, Bangladesh — Three men were arrested on Monday in connection with the beheading of the highest-ranking priest of a Hindu temple in northern Bangladesh, officials said.

headline: The Playful, Cartoonish Designs of a Furniture Wunderkind
text: Plastic bits and blobs dangle from the ceiling and just about every other surface of the 26-year-old designer Misha Kahn’s studio in Brooklyn, which he shares with fellow designer Katie Stout (who just opened a show with Bjarne Melgaard at Karma gallery). A kind of clubhouse for outlandish furniture, their studio is something of a Willy Wonka wonderland. Kahn’s material irreverence and cheeky sense of humor have already amassed him a following, with commissions from luxury clients like Dior. His work has also been shown at the collection of New York’s Museum of Art and Design. Kahn’s creations, which range from inflated chandeliers to slouching concrete side tables, bring to mind the playfully haphazard aesthetic of ’90s Nickelodeon cartoons like “The Ren and Stimpy Show” — an analogy Kahn welcomes with a laugh, pointing out one of his latest pieces, a fluorescent, amoeba-shaped mirror, as a ready example.

headline: Can You ‘Suntan’ Through a Window?
text: Q. On these cold yet sunny winter days, can a person absorb vitamin D by sitting inside next to a sunny window?

headline: Anthony Davis’s 59-Point Night Gives Pelicans Limited Hope
text: Anthony Davis earned several entries in the record books with his 59-point, 20-rebound explosion at Detroit on Sunday. But was it a sign of improvement for the struggling New Orleans Pelicans, or a single memorable moment in a lost season?

headline: A Turning Point for Syrian War, and U.S. Credibility
text: PARIS — In case anyone missed it, Laurent Fabius, who was the French foreign minister as recently as two weeks ago, accused President Obama of letting down not just Syria but the whole world in 2013.

headline: Uganda Opposition Candidate Kizza Besigye Taken From Home

headline: A Black Hole That Has Stopped Swallowing Stars
text: The brightest orb in the center of this photograph captured by the Hubble Space Telescope is a galaxy some 300 million light-years away called NGC 4889.

headline: No Shortcuts in Evaluating Your Investment Risk
text: Early in my career, I worked for a big brokerage firm. Back then, I made a habit of seeking out the veteran stockbrokers and quizzing them about their careers. One day, I had a pretty extensive conversation about risk with one of those grizzled Wall Street guys.

headline: Marco Rubio Bets on Nevada, a State That Shaped His Childhood
text: LAS VEGAS — The neighborhoods of squat cinder-block bungalows on this city’s north end do not usually produce a lot of Republicans.

text: Christopher Kane’s outsize talent has propelled him from design stints at Donatella Versace Atelier and Topshop to collaborations with pop luminaries like Kylie Minogue and Beth Ditto.

text: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: A Do-It-Yourself Revolution in Diabetes Care
text: John Costik got the call at the office in 2012. It was his wife, Laura, with terrible news: Their 4-year-old son, Evan, was headed into the emergency room.

headline: Eric Brown, Record-Breaking British Aviator and World War II Combat Pilot, Dies at 97
text: Eric Melrose Brown, a renowned British Navy test pilot who shattered records and made history with exploits that advanced Allied fighter power in World War II and quests for jet propulsion and supersonic speeds in postwar aviation, died on Sunday in southern England. He was 97.

headline: 1966: France Finished With NATO
text: PARIS — President Charles de Gaulle regards the North Atlantic Treaty Organization as finished as far as France is concerned, French government sources said today [Feb. 22]. He is willing to open talks on the future status of American bases in France, they said. But he has no intention of quitting the Atlantic alliance as such, which he regards as different than NATO, they added. The sources said he definitely will pull France out of NATO and its entire integrated command structure by the deadline of April 4, 1969, which he set in his news conference yesterday. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 23, 1966

headline: The Day My Megabus Caught Fire
text: Yesterday was my first time taking Megabus, a discount intercity bus service that began in 2006 and quickly gained notoriety for advertising fares as low as $1 each way. Yesterday was also the first time I had to evacuate a bus as it was catching fire.

headline: Univision Aims to Make Hispanic Voting Bloc Even More Formidable
text: About 11 million Hispanics voted in the 2012 presidential election, fewer than half of those who were eligible. Activists in both major political parties have been trying to increase that number, through voter registration drives and appeals over issues like immigration and wage stagnation on the left, and economic freedom on the right.

headline: It’s Possible to Grow a 3-D Printed Ear on a Mouse’s Back
text: This unattached ear bathed in pink goo may look like a freaky find from Frankenstein’s laboratory, but it’s actually the product of a decade worth of medical research with 3-D printing.

headline: U.S. Soccer Keeping Silent on FIFA Presidential Vote, for Now
text: Nine months ago, just before the last election for FIFA president, the United States Soccer Federation publicly endorsed Prince Ali bin al-Hussein of Jordan in his race against Sepp Blatter, the longtime and much-maligned incumbent who went on to win re-election easily. At the time, U.S. Soccer’s endorsement was seen as a bold show of protest against the status quo within the scandal-plagued governing body.

headline: The Daily Bag: Mulberry
text: Mulberry got a new creative director — and a whole new crop of handbags. This one in particular, a mostly python carry-all with a touch of punk, was pure perfection.

headline: Searing Grapefruit for a Juicy, Refreshing Breakfast
text: At this time of year, there is a dearth of fruit in many parts of the country, but grapefruit from Texas, Florida and Southern California is still very much in season.

headline: U.N. Finds ‘Deliberate’ Destruction of Hospitals in Syria
text: UNITED NATIONS — First, the government soldiers made sure no food could get into rebel-held towns. Then, government planes bombed what health centers remained in those towns, making sure that those who got sick from hunger had no medical care to save them.

headline: Writer Apologizes for SB Nation Article on Convicted Rapist
text: The author of a deleted SB Nation article on Daniel Holtzclaw, a former police officer and convicted rapist, that was criticized as being overly sympathetic  apologized on Monday, saying that he had produced a piece with “massive shortcomings” but that at least four editors had cleared it before publication.

headline: Tribeca Film Festival Opening With Look at Met’s Costume Show
text: For the opening night of this year’s Tribeca Film Festival, the event is getting fashionable. Organizers announced Monday that it will open with the documentary “The First Monday in May,” about the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s popular fashion exhibition from last year,  “China: Through the Looking Glass.”  Organized by the curator Andrew Bolton, that show, from the museum’s Costume Institute, drew more than 800,000 visitors and explored the influence of Chinese culture on Western fashion.

headline: Not Every Drop of a Person’s Blood Is the Same, a Study Says
text: As diagnostic tests rely on ever-tinier amounts of blood, some scientists are striking a note of caution. As it turns out, not all drops of blood are identical.

headline: Kevin McCarthy, G.O.P. House Leader, Says He Could Work With Donald Trump
text: Representative Kevin McCarthy, a Republican from California and the House majority leader, said on Monday that he would be able to work with Donald J. Trump as the party’s presidential nominee, the latest signal of acceptance from national figures of the billionaire real estate developer.

headline: Adam Kucharski: The Perfect Bet
text: For this week’s challenge we continue with Adam Kucharski, the award-winning author of “The Perfect Bet: How Science and Math Are Taking the Luck Out of Gambling.” We met Dr. Kucharski last week with the St. Petersburg Lottery, in which we were playing directly against a house with infinite resources.

headline: The Daily Shoe: Alexander McQueen
text: The classic velvet smoking slipper gets the McQueen treatment with embroidered patches in the shape of horses, eyes and lips. — MALINA JOSEPH GILCHRIST

headline: Multitools Make the Man
text: The art of equipping yourself for the battle of the everyday.

headline: ‘The Life of Elves,’ by Muriel Barbery
text: Muriel Barbery’s previous novels, “The Elegance of the Hedgehog” and “Gourmet Rhapsody,” took place in the same Paris apartment building. Her latest departs from both that locale and the quotidian world. Set in Burgundy, Italy and a magical place called the Pavilion of the Mists, “The Life of Elves” follows two girls of otherworldly provenance — Clara, the daughter of a human and her elfin lover, and Maria, an elf child who fully resembles a human being — born just as an evil leader is about to unleash his destructive powers.

headline: As 2 Famed Businesses Reopen, Tenants Above Them Remain Without Gas
text: Last week, while Mayor Bill de Blasio was downstairs tucking into a pastrami sandwich at the newly reopened Carnegie Deli, Elsie and Pasquale Forino sat in their sky-blue kitchen one floor above having their own breakfast of toast and fruit. When Mr. Forino pressed down the lever on the toaster, the lights dimmed.

headline: ‘A Doubter’s Almanac,’ by Ethan Canin
text: It’s hard to create a great literary monster. The character’s behavior has to evoke repulsion in the readers, meanwhile engaging their sympathy for the suffering soul beneath. In Ethan Canin’s new novel, “A Doubter’s Almanac,” the mathematician Milo Andret is certainly despicable enough. With relish and malice, he manipulates the lives of his family members. He humiliates his wife, curses his daughter and bedevils his son. He uses women. He demeans his colleagues. He is a raging, nasty drunk. Twice, he nearly commits murder. In the face of all this, can Canin also portray him as a tragic figure worthy of pity? The novel’s success hinges upon the answer.

headline: Yahoo’s Decision to Explore a Sale Exposes a Weak Board
text: It’s hard to believe, but after all these years, the Yahoo board is still a contender for America’s worst corporate board.

headline: Inside Fashion Week
text: Glittering rats, organza shirt-dresses and Supreme Court vacancies: Vanessa Friedman, the Times’ chief fashion critic, makes sense of New York Fashion Week.

headline: Burberry, J.W. Anderson and Simone Rocha: Reflections on a Fashion System
text: LONDON — In the streets and cafes here, there is a lot of talk about the possibility of a Brexit — Britain’s leaving the European Union, to be decided June 23 in a national referendum — with Prime Minister David Cameron pleading to stay and the London mayor, Boris Johnson, announcing on Sunday that he’s for leaving.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Wet Look Trend
text: Lacquered fabrics slick enough to skate on were the last word this week at any number of shows.

headline: How Jeb Bush Spent $130 Million Running for President With Nothing to Show for It
text: When Jeb Bush formally entered the presidential campaign in June, there was already more money behind him than every other Republican candidate combined. When he suspended his campaign on Saturday night in South Carolina, Mr. Bush had burned through the vast majority of that cash without winning a single state. It may go down as one of the least successful campaign spending binges in history. Here is Mr. Bush’s story, as told by his ledger:

headline: Pouring on the Wet Looks
text: Lacquered fabrics slick enough to skate on were the last word this week at any number of shows. The look, trotted out in high gloss, demi-gloss and lipstick-tinted variations, lent unaccustomed luster to the coats, trousers and calf-clutching fetish boots in the collections of Hood by Air, Lacoste, Proenza Schouler and Calvin Klein, to name but a handful.

headline: While HSBC Stays Upbeat, Investors Worry About Rates and China
text: HSBC shares are being weighed down by fear of the future. The global lender thinks it can bolster returns even as its balance sheet shrinks. That is why it increased the dividend despite a 7 percent drop in underlying pretax profit in 2015. But investors remain more worried about negative interest rates, China’s slowdown and cheap oil.

headline: Christopher Kane: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Mr. Kane, who just launched his first campaign, presents his latest collection.

headline: Review: Les Ballets de Monte Carlo’s Rendition of ‘Cinderella’
text: Why leave a fairy tale just the way it is? The French choreographer Jean-Christophe Maillot is fond of skewing tradition, preferring to delve into the psychological underpinnings of his characters. In his rendition of “Cinderella,” he focuses on the heroine’s deceased mother, who has returned to her daughter’s life as the Fairy. He also rids the story of the usual Cinderella trappings: the fireplace, a pumpkin and glass slippers. Her bare feet are dipped in gold glitter. Of the many confusing and random turns in Mr. Maillot’s high-strung, unfulfilling production, one point is clear: Our Prince has a foot fetish.

headline: Coddled Eggs in Elegant Glass Vessels
text: It’s an indulgence, but if coddled eggs are your solo breakfast luxury, you will need just one of these elegant Jenaer Glas vessels based on a 1930s Bauhaus design by Wilhelm Wagenfeld. Butter the inside, crack in an egg, seal the top and place it in a water bath in a 275-degree oven or on the stovetop for about eight minutes. Include a little cream, some meltable cheese or herbs, and bits of bacon. The instructions (in 10 languages, yet somehow rather inadequate) suggest you also use the coddler for soufflés, pâtés and gratins, but I would keep it for breakfast: Egg coddler, $22, MoMA Design Store, momastore.org.

headline: A Slow Unveiling for Tourette’s Disease
text: Tourette’s disease was named in 1885, but The New York Times did not mention it until 90 years later.

headline: U.S. Economy Still on the Rise, White House Report Finds
text: WASHINGTON — The United States economy continued a strong rebound last year, with unemployment falling by half since the depths of the 2008 recession, wages growing and consumer confidence at its highest point in a dozen years, the White House said on Monday. But a slowdown overseas and persistent income inequality at home threaten to sap some of those gains in the years to come.

headline: Bernie Sanders Opens A New Front In His War on Hillary Clinton’s Big Money
text: The Democratic National Committee has quietly reversed the ban on accepting lobbyist donations that Barack Obama insisted on as a good government reform when he was running for the White House eight years ago. Hailed back then as a step to rein in the power of special interest money, the ban was dropped at some point in recent months by the D.N.C. without public notice. But the reversal was confirmed this month by The Washington Post and immediately became a factor in the party’s contest for the presidential nomination, with Senator Bernie Sanders pressing Hillary Clinton to join his call to instantly restore the Obama ban.

headline: Why Pertussis Is Making a Comeback
text: Whooping cough, a potentially life-threatening childhood illness, all but disappeared in the 1940s after a vaccine was developed. Why is it making a comeback now, when most children are vaccinated?

headline: At Burberry: The Starriest Front Row in Town
text: LONDON — As sure as showers will fall during London Fashion Week (there were plenty over the last four days), Burberry will provide the starriest front row of the schedule.

headline: Hill and Friends: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Emma Hill and Georgia Fendley, who were formerly at Mulberry, present their latest collection for their new line.

headline: Podcast: Inside Fashion Week
text: New York Fashion Week ended on Friday with a Marc Jacobs show during which “glittering rats chased their tails around Victorian coats.”

headline: Coercion May Make People Feel Less Responsible for Actions
text: Some people feel responsible for their actions even if they are forced to take them. But many do not, a new study suggests, finding in coercion a freedom from blame.

headline: Paul Simon Returning to Forest Hills Stadium After 46 Years
text: Paul Simon spent his formative years at Forest Hills High School, playing music with a Forest Hills native named Arthur Garfunkel. So it’s only fitting that he will end his 2016 summer tour at Forest Hills Stadium on June 30 — his first appearance there in 46 years.

headline: In Nevada, the Marco Rubio Entourage Is Lacking in Diversity
text: ELKO, Nev. — The diversity of Marco Rubio’s political team in South Carolina was so striking that his campaign boasted they were the face of the new conservative movement. Mr. Rubio, a Cuban-American, Gov. Nikki Haley, an Indian-American, and Senator Tim Scott, who is black, were like a Republican Benetton ad, as Ms. Haley joked at every event.

headline: Watchdog Group Wants Investigation Into Groups’ Fund-Raising Efforts
text: Common Cause New York requested that the city’s Campaign Finance Board and its Conflicts of Interest Board look into nonprofit groups, run by close allies of Mayor Bill de Blasio, that have helped advocate for his policies.

headline: Income Inequality: ‘The Rules of the Game Are Fixed’
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Case for Rubio-Kasich
text: Saturday’s Republican primary in South Carolina was not quite the train wreck for the not-Trump portion of the party that seemed likely after New Hampshire’s multi-candidate pileup. Boosted by Nikki Haley’s endorsement, Marco Rubio basically saved his campaign with a second-place finish, while Jeb Bush finished far enough back that dropping out became the only honorable option. That consolidation meant that notwithstanding Donald Trump’s victory, it wasn’t nearly as good a night for him as New Hampshire: The field narrowed, the party’s leadership accelerated its rally around Rubio, and the emerging three-way battle between Trump, Rubio and Ted Cruz, while still better for the Donald than a two-man race, isn’t the pure gift to him that the old Christie-Jeb-Rubio-Kasich combination offered.

headline: Kalamazoo Shooting Suspect Charged, but Motive Remains Mystery
text: KALAMAZOO, Mich. — An Uber driver admitted his involvement in a Saturday night shooting rampage that left six people dead and two others injured, the county prosecutor said on Monday as the driver was formally charged with murder. But the motive of the man, who had no criminal history, remained a mystery.

headline: Life After Scalia
text: Arthur Brooks: Hi, Gail. Lots to discuss this week. First the crazy primaries, and then I hope we can talk about Justice Scalia.

headline: Maggie Siff on ‘Billions’: ‘I Might Leave Marks’
text: When first we meet Maggie Siff on Showtime’s “Billions,” she’s in a black leather get-up and stiletto boots, standing over a bound and gagged Paul Giamatti.

headline: Criminal Complaint in Kalamazoo Shooting
text: Prosecutors on Monday charged Jason Dalton with six counts of murder in the shooting spree in Kalamazoo, Mich.

headline: John Kasich Credits 1978 Victory to ‘Women Who Left Their Kitchens’
text: FAIRFAX, Va. — Recalling his earliest days in politics on Monday, Gov. John Kasich of Ohio said that he first won election to the State Legislature thanks in large part to “women who left their kitchens” to campaign for him.

headline: Lech Walesa Files Made Public Despite Forgery Claims
text: WARSAW — A Polish national archive released portions of decades-old files on Monday that indicate former President Lech Walesa, the leader of the Solidarity movement and a Nobel Peace Prize recipient, was a Communist informer in the 1970s, even though Mr. Walesa has asserted that the documents are forged.

headline: Bridging a Digital Divide That Leaves Schoolchildren Behind
text: McALLEN, Tex. — At 7 p.m. on a recent Wednesday, Isabella and Tony Ruiz were standing in their usual homework spot, on a crumbling sidewalk across the street from the elementary school nearest to their home.

headline: Cereal, a Taste of Nostalgia, Looks for Its Next Chapter
text: King Vitaman and I were tight when I was young. Sweetened cereals were a rarity in my house, so beating my siblings to breakfast was the only way to make sure the king and I would have some time together.

headline: Apple Showdown Heightens Challenge of Encrypted Data
text: The clash between the Justice Department and Apple over the court order requiring the company to weaken the security functions on the iPhone of one of the attackers in the San Bernardino, Calif., shootings is only the latest instance of the government’s effort to deal with encrypted data.

headline: At Burberry, Three Eclectic Beauty Looks for Fall
text: Backstage at Burberry’s fall/winter 2016 show, the makeup artist Wendy Rowe mirrored the “earthy opulence” of Christopher Bailey’s clothes with a trio of beauty looks: the nude (“some girls just look best completely natural, so we said let’s keep it like that”), the disheveled (essentially a dark eye, lined with Burberry’s Eye Colour Cream in charcoal with a glint of glittery sparkle — “as though they’ve tried to wipe it off”) and the all-out glitter-bombed.

headline: 래리 페이지의 집착, 구글을 움직이는 원동력
text: 3년 전, 무기 회사 록히드 마틴의 핵융합 프로그램을 관장하던 엔지니어 찰스 체이스는 구글이 주최한 “세상의 문제를 해결하자”는 뜻의 솔브포엑스(Solve for X) 콘퍼런스에서 하얀 가죽 소파에 앉아 있었다. 그때 전에 만난 적이 없었던 남자가 다가와 무릎까지 굽히고 앉으며 그에게 말을 걸었다.

headline: Mark Zuckerberg Backs Apple in Its Refusal to Unlock iPhone
text: BARCELONA, Spain — Mark Zuckerberg on Monday threw his support behind Apple in its bitter battle with the United States government over attempts to gain access to information protected by the company’s sophisticated encryption technology.

text: The Jets gave cornerback Antonio Cromartie four years. He lasted one.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: Letters to the editor should only be sent to The Times, and not to other publications. We do not publish open letters or third-party letters.

headline: The Making of an Alinea (Pop-Up) Dish
text: “We wanted to pay homage to the South American influence in Miami’s gastronomic culture,” said chef Grant Achatz, who is currently installed in the newly opened Faena Hotel Miami Beach for a three-week residency. The pop-up series, aptly named “Alinea In Residence,” brings Achatz and a staff of approximately 50 to Miami from Madrid (where the team had recently completed a similar short-term series), to execute an original multicourse menu in the Modernist style of his award-winning Chicago restaurant.

headline: Men’s Shorts Go Long (and Short) for Spring
text: This season, consider shorts in varying lengths.

headline: Seas Are Rising at Fastest Rate in Last 28 Centuries
text: The worsening of tidal flooding in American coastal communities is largely a consequence of greenhouse gases from human activity, and the problem will grow far worse in coming decades, scientists reported Monday.

headline: Death Valley Is Experiencing a Colorful ‘Superbloom’
text: Death Valley, one of the hottest places on Earth, is now a riot of color: More than 20 kinds of desert wildflowers are in bloom after record rain last October.

headline: 6 Trends From the Fall 2016 Runways
text: Sumptuous velvet; twisted variations on the 1980s power suit; steamy corsetry and lacing; athletic looks; and high-sheen finishes set the tone for a week of New York Fashion Week collections as novel as they were provocative.

headline: Review: ‘The Secret Garden,’ a Concert Revival in Which Sadness Morphs Into Joy
text: The 1991 Broadway musical adaptation of Frances Hodgson Burnett’s classic children’s novel “The Secret Garden” is held by many in such esteem that the audience for its robust concert revival at David Geffen Hall arrived with rapturous expectations on Sunday evening. The performance, which was repeated on Monday, is the fourth installment in a series of such musical revivals by Manhattan Concert Productions.

headline: U.S.-Russia Deal on a Partial Truce in Syria Raises More Doubt Than Optimism
text: WASHINGTON — The United States and Russia announced an agreement on Monday for a partial truce in Syria, though the caveats and cautious words on all sides underscored the obstacles in the way of the latest diplomatic effort to end the five-year-old civil war.

headline: Adele Is Back on Top, but Kanye West’s Album Doesn’t Make Chart
text: Adele’s performance at the Grammy Awards may have been plagued by audio problems, but her fans apparently did not mind much, sending Adele’s album “25” back to the top of the chart for a ninth time. (The fact that Valentine’s Day fell during the sales week also helped.)

headline: Lynn Nottage Wins Blackburn Prize for ‘Sweat’
text: The Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright Lynn Nottage will need to make room on her shelf for another prestigious award: She is the 2016 winner of the Susan Smith Blackburn Prize for “Sweat,” her acclaimed drama about deindustrialization in a working-class city in Pennsylvania.

headline: Pentagon to Send Congress Plan for Closing Guantánamo
text: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon is expected to send Congress a plan on Tuesday for the closing of the wartime prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, which President Obama wants to complete before he leaves office.

headline: Review: Nicolas Altstaedt and Alexander Lonquich, in a Stirring Concert at the Frick
text: Late in his life, while battling rectal cancer, Debussy began a series of six sonatas for various instruments, starting with the Sonata for Cello and Piano in 1915. He ended up finishing only three before his death in 1918. Coming from such a pioneering composer, this sonata project seemed a throwback, a nod to the Neo-Classicism coming into vogue in Paris at the time.

headline: Two Mary Katrantzou Skirts — From Sketchbook to Runway
text: T visited the designer in the weeks before her fall/winter 2016 collection — and then again on the day of the show.

headline: How Democratic Superdelegates Can Overrule the Voters’ Will

headline: The Making of Mary Katrantzou’s Elaborate Tulle Skirts
text: Less than two weeks before London Fashion Week, Mary Katrantzou was feeling good. “I like the collection so far,” the designer said, referring to her fall/winter 2016 offering, which was presented yesterday — though she acknowledged that she was preparing for an emotional roller coaster. “Now you like it, because you’re excited because a lot of the ideas are going to launch. Then you get stressed before the show, because the ideas haven’t come back launched and ready, so you’re just a bit concerned. And then you feel sick, because you don’t know how it will all feel when it comes together.” She continued, laughing: “So at the moment, you’re coming in just before the storm. Everything’s good now, and in seven days it won’t be.”

headline: Review: Inon Barnatan Soldiers Through Hallowed Works at 92nd Street Y
text: The fine Israeli pianist Inon Barnatan has served New York assiduously and well in recent years, especially through collaborative efforts with the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center and as the New York Philharmonic’s first artist-in-association. On Saturday evening he took the stage at the 92nd Street Y for a fascinating and rewarding solo recital.

headline: Steps Taken Toward Cease-Fire in Syria
text: The White House press secretary, Josh Earnest, confirmed that President Obama and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia discussed a cease-fire plan in Syria. A spokesman for the United Nations secretary general urged its implementation.

headline: Explaining E.T.F.s and How They Gained Their Allure
text: Exchange-traded funds, or E.T.F.s, give investors access to a vast array of investment notions, from the obvious (stocks, bonds and commodities) to the less so (derivatives and opportunities to sell short just about anything).

headline: A New Breed of Trader on Wall Street: Coders With a Ph.D.
text: HOLLYWOOD, Fla. — The mood in the markets may be getting grimmer, but in the booming world of exchange-traded funds, people just want to party.

headline: Waris Ahluwalia, Back in New York, Turban in Place
text: Waris Ahluwalia was standing in the middle of Park Avenue Armory last Thursday night, waiting for the Marc Jacobs fashion show to begin, while a series of famous well-wishers came up to greet him.

headline: Trevor Nunn, British Shakespeare Master, Tries Something New: Directing Americans
text: For more than half a century, Trevor Nunn has directed Elizabethan tragedies and contemporary comedies, heady literary adaptations and at least one roller-skating fantasia. He was the youngest-ever artistic director of the Royal Shakespeare Company and later ran London’s National Theater. He wrote the lyrics to “On My Own” from “Les Misérables.” He was integral in shaping “Cats.”

headline: Vaginal Ring With Drug Lowers H.I.V. Rates in African Women
text: A flexible and inexpensive ring that is inserted into the vagina, where it slowly releases an antiviral drug, helped protect African women against contracting H.I.V. from their sexual partners, researchers said Monday in reports on two major studies that included more than 4,500 women.

headline: For Mark Willenbring, Substance Abuse Treatment Begins With Research
text: On the rainy fall morning of their first appointment, Dr. Mark Willenbring, a psychiatrist, welcomed a young web designer into his spacious office with a firm handshake and motioned for him to sit. The slender 29-year-old patient, dressed in a plaid shirt, jeans and a baseball cap, slouched into his chair and began pouring out a story of woe stretching back a dozen years.

headline: Bluffer’s Guide to the Oscars: Best Director
text: Everything you need to know about the contenders in one quick rundown.

text: FAIRFAX, Va. — Gov. John Kasich of Ohio responded forcefully on Monday to a claim by Senator Marco Rubio’s campaign that Mr. Kasich had no realistic way to win the Republican presidential nomination.

headline: At Funeral Mass for ‘Big Ang,’ the Sacred and the Irreverent Mingle
text: A woman from Staten Island was eulogized in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, on Monday, a cable television star who had a distinctive nickname and a distinctive voice and spoke in a distinctive New York patois; who bought a bigger house to have space for her 500 pairs of shoes and 300 pocketbooks; and who owned a bar that she said had “become, like, a tourist trap.”

headline: In Gaza, Bicycles Are a Battleground for Women Who Dare to Ride
text: SALAHUDDIN ROAD, Gaza Strip — The four women pedaling bicycles with jammed gears and wobbly chains up Salahuddin Road, Gaza’s bumpy main highway, on a recent morning caused quite a stir.

text: One of the longest streaks in women’s college basketball has ended.

headline: Xi Jinping’s News Alert: Chinese Media Must Serve the Party
text: BEIJING — The Chinese news media covered President Xi Jinping’s most recent public appearances with adulation befitting a demigod.

headline: Street Style: London
text: The stylish set on the streets of London during fashion week.

headline: Tensions Over New York’s Homeless Shelters Explode After Disputed Rape Accusation
text: The missives began in earnest late last month after the killing of a former teacher at a Harlem shelter: 11 letters between state and city officials over conditions and violence in New York City’s homeless shelter system.

headline: Rudy Giuliani, Although Friends With Donald Trump, Is Not Ready to Endorse Yet
text: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former mayor of New York, is an admirer of Donald J. Trump and has been friends with him for decades. His endorsement could be useful to Mr. Trump, both as an affirmation in national security terms and an appeal to transplanted New Yorkers in Florida and elsewhere.

headline: At New York City Ballet, Works That Tell Stories and Don’t
text: The ballets of Justin Peck usually grow on renewed acquaintance. This hasn’t happened yet with his latest work, “The Most Incredible Thing,” which had its premiere at New York City Ballet on Feb. 2. After three viewings and two casts, I like it no better than before. On Saturday afternoon, though, the company revived Mr. Peck’s “Paz de la Jolla” (2014), a work not seen onstage since its initial season but the subject of the documentary “Ballet 422.” It looked fresher, deeper, more poetic than before.

headline: Hollywood’s Inclusion Problem Extends Beyond the Oscars, Study Says
text: Men far outnumber women as directors, writers and industry executives. Minorities are drastically underrepresented in acting roles. Lesbian, gay and transgender characters are almost nonexistent. This is the portrait of an “epidemic of invisibility” in Hollywood described by researchers in a study released on Monday of more than 400 movies and scripted television series from 2014 and 2015.

headline: Joe Biden Argued for Delaying Supreme Court Picks in 1992
text: WASHINGTON — As a senator more than two decades ago, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. argued that President George Bush should delay filling a Supreme Court vacancy, should one arise, until the presidential election was over, and that it was “essential” that the Senate refuse to confirm a nominee to the court until then.

headline: Bernie Sanders Accuses Hillary Clinton of Copying His Message
text: BOSTON — Bernie Sanders, eager to bounce back from his loss Saturday in the Nevada caucuses, pointedly attacked Hillary Clinton on Monday, arguing that she was copying his message and that she might be improperly influenced by Wall Street donations to her candidacy.

headline: Iran’s Hard-Line Press Adds to Bounty on Salman Rushdie
text: TEHRAN — A group of hard-line Iranian news media organizations says it has raised $600,000 to add to a bounty for the killing of the British novelist Salman Rushdie.

headline: Five Women From ‘Black Lives Matter’ Campaign for Hillary Clinton in S. Carolina
text: SUMTER, S.C. – Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders are seeking to appeal to their core constituencies — she to women and he to young people — as they seek votes from African-Americans in South Carolina.

headline: At New York Fashion Week, Exaggerated Beauty Looks
text: Exaggerated or colored, a number of memorable beauty looks at New York Fashion Week focused on the eyes. At Hood by Air, eyebrows were graphically painted with black acrylic paint. Here are the looks.
