text: Photos from Macedonia, Greece, Syria and Italy.

headline: Crossing Borders, Confronting Boundaries
text: There are different ways to cover a story about migrants. Sometimes you interview people about their experiences and talk to officials, then stitch together an article with composite perspectives and experiences told secondhand.

headline: Mitt Romney Says Donald Trump Should Release His Tax Data
text: Mitt Romney emerged from political hibernation on Wednesday and issued a challenge to Donald J. Trump: Show us your taxes.

headline: Credit Unions Turn Borrowers Into Savers
text: Saving money by taking out a loan may sound counterintuitive, but a program offered by some credit unions is aimed at having consumers do just that.

headline: Senate Republicans and the Supreme Court: Where Is This Headed Exactly?
text: Hi, John,

headline: Escape to California in Style
text: Luckily, laid-back Cali-vibes can be secured without ever setting foot on a plane — not that any of the items here wouldn’t be best enjoyed if you did.

headline: Review: BalletBoyz Get Ready to Rumble
text: Few dance troupes are named more informatively than BalletBoyz. When the Royal Ballet principal dancers Michael Nunn and William Trevitt founded the company in 2000, they called it George Piper Dances, but the distinctive appeal indicated by the nickname they eventually adopted was already evident. They prefaced their performances with short, demystifying films in which they appeared as ordinary blokes with cheeky senses of humor. Then they danced with gorgeous, far-from-ordinary technique.

headline: Review: Animal Collective, in Joyful Pursuit of Sensory Overload
text: Build it up, take it apart. Fatten it up, slim it down. A long-running band develops a history and reacts against it — especially a band as self-conscious about sound as Animal Collective, which has just released its 11th full-length album since it emerged in 2000, “Painting With” (Domino).

headline: The Might-Have-Beens of Marijuana
text: Former Attorney General Eric Holder, in a newly released interview conducted after he left office, said he was in favor of reclassifying marijuana as something less than a Schedule I controlled substance comparable to heroin. This was hailed as encouraging news by marijuana enthusiasts who immediately asked why Mr. Holder didn’t push for this change when he was running the Justice Department.

headline: Review: ‘Pandemic’ Explains How to Host the Perfect Pathogen Party
text: Sometimes, the best approach to a book about deadly pathogens is to read it in a slightly dissociated state — it allows you to marvel at the cunning adaptability of microbial life, rather than contemplate the far creepier possibility of your own doom. In her introduction to “Pandemic: Tracking Contagions, From Cholera to Ebola and Beyond,” Sonia Shah, a science writer whose previous books include “The Fever” and “The Body Hunters,” does not seek shelter in euphemisms or shy away from scary numbers. Instead, she cites a study in which 90 percent of epidemiologists say they believe a global pandemic will sicken one billion and kill up to 165 million within the next two generations.

headline: How Mario Batali Does Breakfast
text: Depending on who you ask, Chelsea’s Maritime Hotel could be seen as proof of the architect Albert C. Ledner’s inspired vision — or a monolithic monument to 1960s kitsch. Originally designed as a hiring hall for the National Maritime Union, the 11-story, porthole-adorned tower has since served as a shelter for runaways and as housing for the New York Service Center for Chinese Study Fellows, before opening as a fashionable hotel in 2003.

headline: Roberto Cavalli: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Peter Dundas shows his fall collection for Roberto Cavalli.

headline: Review: Mariinsky Ballet in ‘Raymonda,’ Searching About for a Perfect Suitor
text: WASHINGTON — Is the Mariinsky Ballet of St. Petersburg breaking records this week? I hope so. Between Monday and this coming Sunday, it is to perform eight programs in four theaters, in three cities on both sides of the Atlantic.

headline: Mr. Purple, a Trendy Hotel Bar on the Lower East Side
text: Follow any trend to its exhausted end, and you may end up at Mr. Purple, a lounge on the 15th floor of the Hotel Indigo on the Lower East Side. It’s the kind of place where buzzwords like “reclaimed wood,” “small-batch spirits” and “regionally brewed craft beer” feel like PowerPoint concepts introduced in a focus group.

headline: Carla Hayden Nominated to Head Library of Congress
text: WASHINGTON — Carla D. Hayden, the longtime head of Baltimore’s library system and an advocate for the privacy rights of library users, was nominated by President Obama on Wednesday to lead the Library of Congress.

headline: Governors Unite in the War Against Opioids
text: State governments are at the front lines of the country’s epidemic of drug overdose deaths. That’s why it is important that the National Governors Association says it will come up with  protocols for dispensing prescription painkillers that are among the biggest sources of addiction and abuse in the country.

headline: Macklemore & Ryan Lewis Return to the Hip-Hop Fray
text: To be Macklemore & Ryan Lewis is to be scrutinized ceaselessly. The most consequential white hip-hop act since Eminem, this Seattle duo became a pop sensation, hip-hop curio and sociocultural lightning rod in 2012 on the back of the quirky breakthrough “Thrift Shop.” The boisterous and off-kilter track turned out to be the first in a string of four Billboard top 15 hits, two of which went to No. 1.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Labor Unrest Stirs in Russia as an Economic Chill Sets In
text: NIZHNY TAGIL, Russia — Workers in this city that calls itself the “birthplace of the trains” gained fame some years back for helping birth something far different: President Vladimir V. Putin’s drive to crush and marginalize a budding democracy movement. Recently, after a year with little or no work in the city’s giant train factory, they staged a protest of their own, aimed straight at Mr. Putin and his wealthy cronies in the industrial sector.

headline: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing: Donald Trump, Republican Party, iPhone
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Q. and A.: Timothy Olyphant, a Tough Lawman, Goes Country Onstage
text: Countless words have been spilled on the subject of Timothy Olyphant and the Stare: that faint narrowing of those fathomless eyes, shorthand that one of his gunslinging lawmen — say, Raylan Givens of “Justified” or Seth Bullock of “Deadwood” — is about to blow a bad guy to smithereens.

headline: Doping Claims Involving Chinese Track Stars Re-emerge, Decades Later
text: BEIJING — Lunar New Year blessings in red and gold at the entrance to the Chinese Athletics Association wish visitors “Glorious Business Improving Year by Year” and “Splendid Future Reaching Up and Up.”

headline: Prosecutors Will Move to Dismiss Charges in Brownsville Rape Case
text: Prosecutors in Brooklyn plan on moving to dismiss first-degree rape charges against all five teenagers accused of attacking an 18-year-old woman on a playground in Brownsville, Brooklyn, in January, officials said on Wednesday.

headline: At Cavalli, Individual Beauty With a ’70s Vibe
text: Today’s Roberto Cavalli show was set inside the 16th-century Palazzo Spinola in Milan, where giant chandeliers hung overhead and every cornice was covered in gold leaf. And the collection didn’t shy away from extravagance either: Clothes were dripping with beads, sequins and tiger prints, harking back to a 19th-century bohemian spirit. Backstage, the hairstylist Duffy explained the philosophy behind the hair look for the season. “It’s Peter’s girl,” he said, referring to the brand’s designer, Peter Dundas. “She’s very cool, very relaxed.” He turned to ’70s London — and, more specifically, the famous store Biba — as an inspiration for the free-spirited opulence of the collection.

headline: Review: ‘A Bronx Tale: The Musical’ Doo-Wops Down Mean Streets
text: MILLBURN, N.J. — The tug of war for the soul of a young man on the mean streets of the Bronx may not sound like a subject that sings. But Chazz Palminteri’s “A Bronx Tale,” originally a solo show, later a movie, and after that a solo show once again on Broadway, has proved to be comfortably malleable material. Now it has been given a hefty infusion of music and dance and — presto! — the familiar-as-red-sauce story, with most of its rough edges intact, can be found finger-snapping and doo-wopping its way across the stage of the Paper Mill Playhouse here, with plans, no doubt, for a quick trip through the Lincoln Tunnel to the big time.

headline: Vanessa Moody Transforms at Cavalli
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall/Winter 2016 Fashion Week in Milan.

headline: Oscars Too Boring? A Guide to Spicing Them Up
text: This is the last Carpetbagger column of the Oscar season, praise be, and there is absolutely nothing left to say. Well, maybe a couple of things. Final Oscar voting has closed, all that’s left to get through are a few parties, the red carpet and finally, on Sunday night, the ceremony.

headline: Struggle Over Supreme Court Pick Enters a New Level of ‘Hardball Politics’
text: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats were slightly surprised when Republicans told the White House budget director this month not to bother making the ritual presentation of a spending plan. They were absolutely astonished when Senate Republicans took the power struggle to an entirely new level by announcing that they would not even shake hands with a Supreme Court nominee selected by the duly elected president of the United States.

headline: Apple Is Said to Be Trying to Make It Harder to Hack iPhones
text: WASHINGTON — Apple engineers have begun developing new security measures that would make it impossible for the government to break into a locked iPhone using methods similar to those now at the center of a court fight in California, according to people close to the company and security experts.

headline: What Microsoft’s Xamarin Purchase Says About the Cloud Computing Fight
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Microsoft announced on Wednesday that it was buying Xamarin, a company that helps software developers write applications for mobile devices. The price was not disclosed, but is believed to be more than $300 million.

headline: Kesha Speaks Out About Dr. Luke Case as Adele Voices Support
text: The pop singer Kesha spoke out on Wednesday for the first time since her legal fight with the producer Dr. Luke became the talk of the music industry, earning the singer public encouragement from her brand-name peers, including Lady Gaga, Miley Cyrus and Taylor Swift.

headline: In an Improving Economy, Places in Distress
text: As the most prosperous communities in the United States have gotten richer since the end of the Great Recession in 2009, economic conditions in many distressed areas have deteriorated even further.

headline: Michael Skakel’s Lawyer Says Trial in Killing of Martha Moxley Wasn’t Fair
text: HARTFORD — More than 40 years after 15-year-old Martha Moxley was found beaten to death near her home in Greenwich, Conn., a lawyer for the man convicted in the killing laid out a litany of reasons that his client, Michael C. Skakel, “did not get a fair shake” during his 2002 trial.

headline: Commodities Agency Advised to Drop Plan to Limit Futures Contracts
text: A long-running fight between regulators seeking to curb speculation in the commodities markets and traders is heading into its next round.

headline: Clinton, Sanders and Southern Voters
text: Bernie Sanders’s campaign is making incredible strides, but huge hurdles remain.

headline: Assessing the Shifting Military and Political Calculus in Libya
text: Fractured, chaotic Libya has leapt back into the headlines this week, with a breakthrough in its tangled civil war and a vicious display of Islamist extremism’s lengthening shadow.

headline: Proof Needed to Enroll in Health Plan Post-Deadline
text: WASHINGTON — People who want to buy health insurance in the federal marketplace outside the annual open enrollment period will now have to provide documents to show they are eligible, the Obama administration announced on Wednesday.

headline: Andrew Miller, Demoted After a Strong Season, Isn’t Fazed
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Since Andrew Miller arrived in New York a year ago, he has been a model employee.

headline: Workers Who Reserve Parking Spots for Film Sets Denounce Conditions in Suit
text: For Christian Pellot, most weeks begin the same way, with a text from an unfamiliar number telling him to show up at a specific address. When he arrives, he is told to sign a wage form, with the hours and pay rate to be filled in at a later date. Then his work begins, sitting for days and nights in a parked vehicle to save street spots for any one of the scores of television, movie and commercial productions filmed around New York each year.

headline: Mets and Yoenis Cespedes Rev Up to Resume Title Quest
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Before he elevated the driver’s side door of his black Lamborghini Aventador and vroomed out of practice Wednesday, Yoenis Cespedes celebrated a pretend birthday.

headline: Treasury Plan for Puerto Rico Favors Pensions Over Bondholders
text: WASHINGTON — If it’s up to the Treasury Department, public employees in Puerto Rico who were promised pensions could be better off than investors who bought the island’s bonds.

headline: At Harvard Dorms, ‘House Masters’ No More
text: The title “house master” as used by generations of Ivy League students to describe their residential administrators is fast becoming an anachronism. Harvard University announced Wednesday that, in a spirit of diversity and “an inclusive community,” the term was being replaced with “faculty dean.”

headline: Henry Diamond, Lawyer at Forefront of Conservation Movement, Dies at 83
text: Henry L. Diamond, a lawyer who went from the vanguard of a nascent environmental movement half a century ago to become New York State’s first environmental conservation commissioner, appointed by Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller on the inaugural Earth Day in 1970, died on Sunday in Washington. He was 83.

headline: U.N. Agency Hires Wife of Top Figure in Syrian War to Assist the Displaced
text: UNITED NATIONS — When the World Health Organization wanted to know how the war in Syria was affecting the mental health of those forced to flee their homes, the agency hired someone known less for her expertise than for her connections: The consultant, Shukria Mekdad, is the wife of Faisal Mekdad, the deputy foreign minister of Syria and a powerful defender of the government’s war effort.

headline: Poorest Areas Have Missed Out on Boons of Recovery, Study Finds
text: The gap between the richest and poorest American communities has widened since the Great Recession ended, and distressed areas are faring worse just as the recovery is gaining traction across much of the country.

headline: Alisa Bellettini, Creator of MTV’s ‘House of Style,’ Dies at 61
text: Alisa Marie Bellettini, a former television producer who created the popular MTV fashion show “House of Style,” naming the supermodel Cindy Crawford as its first host, died on Feb. 16 in Sacramento. She was 61.

headline: In Reversal, Egypt Says Terrorists Downed Russian Jet Over Sinai
text: CAIRO — After months of cautious silence, Egypt acknowledged for the first time on Wednesday that terrorists had downed the Russian jetliner that broke up over the Sinai Peninsula in the fall.

headline: Elizabeth Eisenstein, Trailblazing Historian of Movable Type, Dies at 92
text: Elizabeth L. Eisenstein, a historian best known for her work on the seismic effect of printing on Western civilization — a novel contention when she began her research more than 40 years ago — died on Jan. 31 at her home in Washington. She was 92.

headline: CNN Seeing Dividend From Its Investment in Politics
text: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Jeff Zucker scowled over a laptop in a CNN truck here recently, scouring a new report by BuzzFeed: Donald J. Trump, contrary to his campaign trail boasts, initially supported the invasion of Iraq. A wall of monitors still showed Jeb Bush, but Mr. Trump would take the stage in CNN’s latest Republican town hall-style meeting in minutes.

headline: Networks Seek to Breathe Life Into FIFA Presidential Election
text: Bob Ley, who will anchor ESPN’s coverage of the FIFA presidential election on Friday, has a few delicious ways of describing what might happen.

headline: Democrats Press G.O.P. to Consider a Supreme Court Pick
text: WASHINGTON — From the White House to the Capitol to the campaign trail, the entire Democratic power structure on Wednesday mobilized to break through Republican opposition and clear a path for President Obama to name a Supreme Court successor to Justice Antonin Scalia.

headline: American in Iran Jail With Son
text: The 80-year-old father of an Iranian-American detained in Iran since last fall has himself been arrested in Tehran, his family said on Wednesday.

headline: Canadian Court Says Some Can Grow Marijuana at Home, With a Prescription
text: OTTAWA — Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has not yet fulfilled his promise to legalize marijuana in Canada, but the country’s Federal Court ruled Wednesday that prescription holders could grow their own supply.

headline: 25 Plead Not Guilty in Standoff at the Oregon Wildlife Refuge
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — Defendants charged with leading an armed occupation at a federal wildlife refuge in rural southeastern Oregon this year formally pleaded not guilty on Wednesday in a hearing here at Federal District Court, saying little and sitting obediently — a stark contrast to the days when they drew world attention by broadcasting their view that the United States government had illegally usurped lands across the West.

headline: Babysitter Tortured Staten Island Boy Who Died, Prosecutors Say
text: A babysitter charged with murdering a 16-month-old boy whose family lived in the same Staten Island building subjected him to hours of physical and sexual abuse while he was left in her care over the weekend, prosecutors said on Wednesday.

headline: New Ad Promotes John Kasich, and It Makes Him Uncomfortable
text: GULFPORT, Miss. — Howard Benson, a retired middle school guidance counselor, went up to Gov. John Kasich of Ohio after an event in Massachusetts last weekend to offer some advice: His campaign should fashion a commercial out of the footage of an emotional moment Mr. Kasich had with a young supporter last week.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “This is the latest very serious attack on freedom of expression. During the Franco dictatorship, troublesome artists went to prison, but not in democratic Spain.”

headline: Phil Mickelson Never Met Harper Lee, but the Admiration Was Mutual
text: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla. — Shushing down a mountain run of fresh snow never gets old for Phil Mickelson, but it is not his favorite part of skiing trips with his three children. What he likes best are the chairlift rides to the top, which facilitate conversations that can take wide and wondrous turns.

headline: Bolivian President Concedes Defeat in Term-Limit Referendum
text: ORURO, Bolivia — President Evo Morales, facing mounting pressure to concede defeat in a referendum that would have allowed him to run for a fourth term, accepted the loss Wednesday but said he would use the remaining years of his presidency to advance his Socialist-inspired agenda.

headline: Modern Love: The Podcast | In Darkness and in Light
text: Welcome to the seventh installment of Modern Love: The Podcast. This week the actress and Tony Award winner Patina Miller (“Madam Secretary,” “The Hunger Games,” “Pippin” on Broadway) reads “Together Always, in Darkness and in Light” by Nicole C. Kear.

headline: Focal Points of Many F.A.A. Investigations
text: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Yesterday we merged SUBs and today we are CRASHing SITES. I may need a nap after all this activity.

headline: ‘black-ish’ Show Runner Kenya Barris on Police Brutality and ‘The Cosby Show’
text: In December 2014, “black-ish” creator Kenya Barris was watching TV news coverage of activists protesting a Staten Island grand jury’s decision not to indict a white New York police officer in the death of Eric Garner, when one of Mr. Barris’s five children, 6-year-old Beau, turned to him and asked, “Why are these people so mad?”

headline: How a Commuter Rail Station Became a $4 Billion Colossus
text: The World Trade Center Transportation Hub was supposed to be a diaphanous structure that would be finished in 2009. Is only now beginning to open.

headline: Carmelo Anthony’s Shot Hits Air, and Knicks’ Chances Evaporate
text: INDIANAPOLIS — A cold rain was falling outside Bankers Life Fieldhouse on Wednesday morning when the Knicks arrived for their shootaround. Carmelo Anthony opened a door, ducked his head inside the arena and then shuffled across the court in socks. Some teammates were quietly warming up. Anthony eventually retrieved his sneakers.

headline: A Key Player in Cuomo’s Economic Revival Plans Quits Two Nonprofits
text: ALBANY — A state university president who has been a linchpin in the Cuomo administration’s efforts to stimulate economic growth has resigned from the boards of two nonprofits that manage major real estate developments aimed at building tech hubs in faded upstate cities.

headline: Australia Announces Rise in Spending for Military
text: SYDNEY, Australia — Responding to the military challenge from China, the Australian government on Thursday announced a robust increase in military spending, including the biggest expansion to its navy since World War II.

headline: Woman Whose Daughter, 2, Died Alone in Fire Was Under Investigation
text: A woman whose 2-year-old daughter died in a fire after being left home alone in a Brooklyn apartment was already the subject of an inquiry initiated this month by New York City’s child welfare agency that focused on whether the girl had been left unattended, a law enforcement official said on Wednesday.

headline: Edward T. Foote, Who Led and Lifted University of Miami, Dies at 78
text: Edward T. Foote, who spent two decades as the president of the University of Miami lifting its academic standards, stabilizing its finances and helping dispel its reputation as Suntan U., died on Feb. 15 in Cutler Bay, Fla., near Miami. He was 78.

headline: Library of Congress Puts Rosa Parks Archive Online
text: The Library of Congress has digitized the papers of Rosa Parks, enabling free online access to everything from her first-hand recollections of the Montgomery bus boycott and personal correspondence with the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. to family photographs, tax returns and a handwritten recipe for “featherlite pancakes.”

headline: Word of the Day + Quiz | spectrum
text: spectrum • \ˈspek-trəm\ • noun

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Day 2 with Prada and Fendi
text: MILAN — Proceedings kick off bright and early on Thursday with the 9:30 a.m. show by Max Mara, an Italian label long known for its steadiness, reliability and sartorial conservatism, which, as of late, has been trying to move beyond that reputation. From there, it is on to Costume National and then to Fendi at 12:30 p.m., where Karl Lagerfeld will, no doubt, offer up lashings of leather and fur for its latest fall extravaganza.

headline: What to Watch Thursday
text: Steven Spielberg is in top form with “Bridge of Spies,” his latest best-picture Oscar nominee. “The Big Bang Theory” celebrates its 200th episode. And if you like your detectives female and fierce, check out “Prey” on BBC America.

headline: Corrections: February 25, 2016
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Cuba: Some Dissidents Will Be Allowed a Single Trip Overseas, an Activist Says
text: Cuba has given some prominent dissidents one-time permission to travel overseas, weeks before President Obama is expected to visit and call for greater freedoms in Cuba. Officials contacted half a dozen dissidents who were imprisoned during a 2003 crackdown and  released as part of a deal brokered by the Roman Catholic Church in 2010 and told them they could make one trip abroad, said Hector Maseda Gutiérrez, one of the dissidents. He turned down the offer because it excluded four other former prisoners, including José Daniel Ferrer, leader of the Patriotic Union of Cuba.

headline: Finding Oscar Moments From the Red Carpet to Backstage
text: Monica Almeida, a New York Times staff photographer, has been covering the Oscars since 1999, finding new positions and using new technology to keep ahead of the pack.

headline: Ex-Official in China Blames Torture for Graft Confession
text: HONG KONG — A former high-level Chinese energy official accused of receiving hundreds of thousands of dollars in bribes said this week that he was tortured into confessing to the crime, a Chinese news outlet reported.

headline: Foxconn Hesitates on $5.5 Billion Bid for Sharp
text: TOKYO — For a few hours on Thursday, it looked as if Sharp, the ailing Japanese consumer electronics company, had secured a $5.5 billion takeover from Foxconn of Taiwan, the giant contract manufacturer that churns out products for Apple and other foreign brands.

headline: Indonesia’s Top Court Rules Against Educators in Sexual Assault Case
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — The Indonesian Supreme Court has overturned a lower court’s decision to free two educators who had been convicted of sexually assaulting kindergartners at a prestigious international school, a court spokesman said on Thursday, the latest twist in a contentious case that the school and the men’s lawyers say was based on false accusations.

headline: Finding Oscar Moments From the Red Carpet to Backstage
text: Monica Almeida, a New York Times staff photographer, has been photographing the Academy Awards since 1999 and is scheduled to cover her 17th Oscars on Sunday. Her conversation with James Estrin about covering the ceremony has been edited.

headline: Easy-Reading Road Signs Head to the Offramp
text: Durham, N.C. — STARTING this week, a familiar face will begin to disappear from America’s roadside signs. It's not particularly noticeable — certainly not as memorable as the goateed Colonel Sanders or smiling Big Boy or pigtailed Wendy pushing their fried chicken, hamburgers and French fries. Rather, it is a typeface named Clearview, which has graced many of our highway signs and directed us to our destinations since 2004, when it was granted interim approval by the Federal Highway Administration.

headline: A Bad Effort in Congress to Thwart States on Food Labels
text: The Senate could soon join the House to try to make it harder for consumers to know what is in their food by prohibiting state governments from requiring the labeling of genetically modified foods. This is a bad idea that lawmakers and the Obama administration should oppose.

headline: What Is Marco Rubio Waiting For?
text: New Hampshire has fallen. South Carolina has been overwhelmed. Nevada has surrendered. And the Republican establishment, like the British Empire in the darkest days of 1940, finds its strength scattered on the beach at Dunkirk, desperately awaiting evacuation and hoping for a Churchill to rise to its defense.

headline: Private Prisons Are Cashing In on Refugees’ Desperation
text: Berlin — IMMIGRATION and Customs Enforcement calls the detention site in Dilley, Tex., a “family residential center.” But to the 2,000 migrant children and mothers who live there, it’s something else: “People who say this is not a prison are lying,” Yancy Maricela Mejia Guerra, a detainee from Central America, told Fusion last year. “It’s a prison for us and a prison for our children, but none of us are criminals.”

headline: The Party of ‘No Way!’
text: WASHINGTON — Perhaps the most important thing Washington will do this year is decide whether to approve President Obama’s nominee for the Supreme Court. But Republicans have already announced their decision: “No way!”

headline: The Secret Side of Donald Trump
text: Sometimes in a particularly awful presidential race you’re forced to take the most bleak and cynical view of the candidates running for the most powerful job in the world. And then you discover you’re overestimating.

headline: The Last Train Before the War
text: There is a photograph of my father and grandfather, taken on Sunday, Aug. 27, 1939, at a spot overlooking the Rhine above the Lorelei Rock, where the chasm of the river tightens and the quickened flow makes a murmuring sound, which has mystical resonance for the Germans.

headline: Does Money Really Matter in Politics?
text: If Jeb Bush's enormous campaign treasury could not even get him a single victory, is the role of electoral donations exaggerated?

headline: Free Coffee? Starbucks Saves Its Loyalty for Big Spenders

headline: China Stocks Fall Steeply in Renewed Instability
text: HONG KONG — Chinese stocks dropped steeply on Thursday, days after the ouster of the country’s top securities regulator and just ahead of Group of 20 meetings in Shanghai. The drop reversed some of the gains made since the Lunar New Year holiday this month.

headline: News Q’s | Young Saudis See Cushy Jobs Vanish Along With Nation’s Oil Wealth
text: The following lesson activities are based on the article “Young Saudis See Cushy Jobs Vanish Along With Nation’s Oil Wealth.”

headline: Super Rugby Sees an Exodus of Familiar Faces and an Influx of New Teams
text: WELLINGTON, New Zealand — With new teams, a new format and new bonus point rules, Super Rugby has entered a new era.

headline: ‘Playing to the Edge,’ by Michael V. Hayden
text: If Michael V. Hayden were a businessman, he might be called a turnaround artist. When he was named by President George W. Bush to take over the Central Intelligence Agency in mid-2006, it was in wide disrepute. It had failed to break up the 9/11 plot. It couldn’t find Osama bin Laden. It had rubber-stamped phony intelligence about Saddam Hussein’s nonexistent weapons of mass destruction, enabling the catastrophic war in Iraq. Revelations of waterboarding and other “enhanced interrogation techniques” carried out at C.I.A. “black sites” had provoked revulsion.

headline: In Mix of Russian Sports, Politics and Business, a Bobsled Leader in Exile
text: MOSCOW — In December, Grigorii Bedzhamov, the president of Russia’s national bobsled federation, disappeared. He stopped coming to work, stopped answering his cellphone, stopped answering his emails.

headline: An Actor on the Upper West Side
text: When he arrived in New York about three years ago from Knoxville, Tenn., the actor Conrad Ricamora crashed briefly with friends in Brooklyn. He then settled into a studio in a high-rise rental building in Long Island City. It cost a little more than $2,300 a month.

headline: Why Women Proposing Is Still Rare
text: When uttered by a man, the words “will you marry me” serve to signal a tradition that is both widely accepted and ages old. Having the same spoken by a woman however — except in a leap year like 2016, when an old Irish tradition of having the woman ask is known to emerge — are still surprisingly rare.

headline: 10 Enviable Oscars Looks From Years Past
text: We all remember Barbra’s see-through pants, Bjork’s swan dress and Cher’s headdresses. But what about the more-wearable looks of the Academy Awards?

text: BEIJING — This month, Chinese banking officials omitted currency data from closely watched economic reports.

headline: Donald Trump to Foreign Workers for Florida Club: You’re Hired
text: Donald J. Trump’s Mar-a-Lago Club in Palm Beach, Fla., describes itself as “one of the most highly regarded private clubs in the world,” and it is not just the very-well-to-do who want to get in.

text: Here’s our analysis of the Republican debate, and our fact checks.

headline: Mother of Girl Berated in Video Assails Success Academy’s Response
text: Nadya Miranda thought she had found a safe haven for her daughter: a Success Academy charter school in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, where she hoped her daughter would get a good education and be put on a path to college.

headline: Student Question | What Are Your Reactions to the Results of the Primaries So Far?
text: The 2016 primaries and caucuses have begun, as candidates seek to win delegates in each state’s contest to capture their party’s nomination for the presidency.

headline: A Kurdish Convergence in Syria
text: On Feb. 17, a bus filled with Turkish soldiers stopped alongside a car at a red light in Ankara. Moments later, a dark column of smoke rose over what had been considered the most secure district of the Turkish capital. A suicide car bomb had ripped through the military bus, killing 28 and injuring more than 60.

headline: China Gives Glimpse of Its Solutions to Economic Problems
text: SHANGHAI — Chinese economic policy makers tugged back the curtain a bit on Thursday on their plans to stabilize the country’s economy and financial markets, even as shares plunged more than 6 percent late in the day.

headline: Living With Cancer: A Farewell to Legs
text: On a bright, cold Sunday in mid-January, I returned home from visiting a frail member of my cancer support group and opened the garage to haul the recyclables up the steep driveway to the street. After a few steps, my feet started to slip and I fell with a thud on my bottom. The big bin toppled over me, scattering plastic containers and cardboard boxes, as my hands reached down to feel a sheet of ice that had been invisible on the asphalt.

text: Here’s what you need to know to start the day.

text: FOXCONN DELAYS TAKEOVER OF SHARP | The ailing Japanese consumer electronics company Sharp had agreed to be taken over by Foxconn of Taiwan for $6 billion but Foxconn postponed a definitive agreement,Jonathan Soble and Austin Ramzy report in The New York Times.

text: In our insiders’ guide, Times reporters also discuss what to expect in tonight’s presidential debate.

headline: Our Third Annual Student Editorial Contest: Write About an Issue That Matters to You
text: Updated, March 2, 2017 | We have announced our Fourth Annual Student Editorial Contest, open to student entries from March 2 to April 4, 2017.

headline: Big Health Benefits to Small Weight Loss
text: Obese individuals who lose as little as 5 percent of their body weight can improve their metabolic function and reduce the risk of developing Type 2 diabetes and heart disease, a new study has found.

headline: New York Today: A Sweet Sleep for Winter
text: Updated, 9:48 a.m.

headline: The New Dream Jobs
text: When the National Society of High School Scholars asked 18,000 Americans, ages 15 to 29, to rank their ideal future employers, the results were curious. To nobody’s surprise, Google, Apple and Facebook appeared high on the list, but so did the Central Intelligence Agency, the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the National Security Agency. The Build-A-Bear Workshop was No. 50, just a few spots behind Lockheed Martin and JPMorgan Chase. (The New York Times came in at No. 16.)

headline: Tracking a Parasite That Turns Bees Into Zombies
text: Call it “The Buzzing Dead.” Infestations of what scientists have dubbed “zombie bees” have spread across both the West and East coasts in recent years.

headline: The Post-Cubicle Office and Its Discontents
text: ‘I have known the inexorable sadness of pencils,’’ begins Theodore Roethke’s ‘‘Dolor,’’ the best poem in English about the grayness of the office. ‘‘All the misery of manila folders and mucilage,/Desolation in immaculate public places,/Lonely reception room, lavatory, switchboard.’’ For a century or more, office design has been our most useful metaphor for workers’ frustration. The color-sapped tedium of office life runs like a flickering current through the warrens of white-collar fiction — from Bartleby impassively facing his brick wall to Frank Wheeler caged in his dark cubicle in ‘‘Revolutionary Road.’’ The fluorescence, the screens, the fabric-wrapped plywood dividers: They’re demoralizing, humiliating.

headline: Managed by Q’s ‘Good Jobs’ Gamble
text: ‘Baumol’s cost disease’’ is a phenomenon that economists sometimes cite when they want to underscore the unequal effects of technological change. William Baumol, the New York University economist for whom the concept is named, uses a classical string quartet as his paradigmatic example. As he points out, no matter how fast our computers become or how many people worldwide plug into broadband-Internet access, it will still take roughly 30 minutes for four human beings to play Mozart’s String Quartet No. 14. If your business is playing string quartets for live audiences, there’s a fundamental limit to how much more productive, in raw economic terms, your work can become.

headline: What Google Learned From Its Quest to Build the Perfect Team
text: Like most 25-year-olds, Julia Rozovsky wasn’t sure what she wanted to do with her life. She had worked at a consulting firm, but it wasn’t a good match. Then she became a researcher for two professors at Harvard, which was interesting but lonely. Maybe a big corporation would be a better fit. Or perhaps a fast-growing start-up. All she knew for certain was that she wanted to find a job that was more social. ‘‘I wanted to be part of a community, part of something people were building together,’’ she told me. She thought about various opportunities — Internet companies, a Ph.D. program — but nothing seemed exactly right. So in 2009, she chose the path that allowed her to put off making a decision: She applied to business schools and was accepted by the Yale School of Management.

headline: Rethinking the Work-Life Equation
text: Phyllis Moen, a sociologist who was widowed when her two children were young, has made a career studying the challenges of working full time while raising a family. She was an early voice calling for the government to provide paid maternity leave and offer benefits for part-time workers, but eventually, when she saw no signs of progress, she began considering instead the ways that corporations could reconfigure work to address the realities of the modern employee, who was more likely than ever to be a single parent or part of a dual-income couple. ‘‘We wanted to do a field experiment at a corporation that reduced its hours,’’ she said, ‘‘but realized nobody would let us do that. We thought they would be more willing to experiment with giving workers more control.’’

headline: Is Blind Hiring the Best Hiring?
text: A few years ago, Kedar Iyer, an entrepreneur in Silicon Valley, became acutely aware of a problem in his industry: A surfeit of talented coders were routinely overlooked by employers because they lacked elite pedigrees. Hiring managers, he thought, were too often swayed by the name of a fancy college on a résumé. To try to address the problem, he created a software company called GapJumpers, working with employers to create challenges for applicants that mimicked what people would do on the job. Companies using GapJumpers wouldn’t see candidates’ résumés, just their names, photographs and test results. In theory, this process would shift employers’ focus from résumés to skills. Then, two years ago, he came across an idea that caused him to rethink his business.

headline: Failure to Lunch
text: For 11 years, June Jo Lee, an ethnographer, has been traveling the country, talking to Americans about how they eat. She has often been in offices, observing white-collar workers. In one interview, a 20-something administrative assistant at an architecture firm in Seattle told her, ‘‘I don’t think I ate at a table at all this week if you don’t include my desk at work.’’ In Chicago, Lee talked to an I.T. specialist who lunched in front of his computer and assiduously avoided the break room; anyone who ate in there was odd. Another guy said that each week he would bring in a crudité party platter from Costco and graze from it when he got hungry.

headline: The Robots Are Coming for Wall Street
text: When Daniel Nadler woke on Nov. 6, he had just enough time to pour himself a glass of orange juice and open his laptop before the Bureau of Labor Statistics released its monthly employment report at 8:30 a.m. He sat at the kitchen table in his one-bedroom apartment in Chelsea, nervously refreshing his web browser — Command-R, Command-R, Command-R — as the software of his company, Kensho, scraped the data from the bureau’s website. Within two minutes, an automated Kensho analysis popped up on his screen: a brief overview, followed by 13 exhibits predicting the performance of investments based on their past response to similar employment reports.

headline: Meet Is Murder
text: Early this year in the sun-streaked offices of Spring, a handsomely capitalized shopping start-up in Manhattan’s Flatiron district, Octavian Costache, the company’s chief technology officer and one of its founders, claimed a spot near the bright new kitchen to make a speech at a weekly all-hands meeting. For several months, I’d been working as a consultant to the company, and, though this was my last day, it was the first time I’d heard Costache address the team. I was excited. Costache, a 34-year-old Romanian with a dimpled, affable face, previously worked at Google, where he helped build Gmail’s multiple-inbox capability and various features of Google Maps. He commands rapt attention at Spring. But on this morning, Costache didn’t want to talk about software. He wanted to talk about meetings.

headline: How Prince Ali Could Win the Election to Be FIFA President
text: ZURICH — Every candidate, in every election, tries to picture a path to victory. The  FIFA presidential election here on Friday is no different.

headline: Loretta Lynn Mines a Legacy of Heartaches and High Notes
text: HURRICANE MILLS, Tenn. — “I really didn’t mean to knock his teeth out.” Over a lunchtime bowl of chicken noodle soup in the glass-walled dining room of her modern, hillside mansion here, Loretta Lynn was recounting a scuffle she had with her hard-drinking husband a few years before she started writing and singing the succinct, forthright songs that made her the undisputed queen of country music. Her eyes, a brilliant star-sapphire blue, still blazed at the memory.

headline: Think You Know the Movies? Take Our Oscars Quiz
text: You’re Leonardo DiCaprio. This quiz is a bear. Try to survive.

headline: The Mississippians of Cahokia
text: John Hendrix illustrates Cahokia, the Native American “Manhattan” of early America and a collection of over 70 mounds and earthworks.

headline: Debate Could Serve as Final Bulwark for Donald Trump’s Rivals
text: Donald J. Trump will take the stage Thursday night at the CNN-Telemundo debate in Texas with a new title: three-time winner. The stakes for many of the debates have been high, but none so high as this one. It represents one of the final chances for Senator Marco Rubio of Florida to produce a galvanizing, breakout moment. And it is the last chance for Senator Ted Cruz, whose home state of Texas votes on Super Tuesday next week, to try to fend off Mr. Trump there.

headline: Jimmy Savile Inquiry Accuses BBC of Failing to Report Sexual Abuse
text: LONDON — A culture of fear that persists to this day at the BBC and a permissive attitude toward stars allowed Jimmy Savile, the disgraced British television personality, to sexually abuse 72 victims, including children, according to a long-awaited report published on Thursday.

headline: China, Facing Land Shortages, Encourages Saving Space 6 Feet Under
text: BEIJING — Whether you are alive or dead, the Chinese authorities have made clear that there is just not that much room for you.

headline: Burundi Strife Is Turning More Sinister, Report Finds
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — Security forces and their allies in Burundi have beaten people with rocks, bricks, gun butts and iron bars; they have abducted suspects and extorted money for holding them; and they have buried victims in mass graves, a leading human rights group said on Thursday.

headline: The Iran Election: What’s at Stake
text: On Friday, Iranians will go to the polls to elect members of Parliament and the Assembly of Experts. Here’s why this matters.

headline: With Police Brutality Episode, ‘black-ish’ Shows How Sitcoms Can Still Matter
text: For “black-ish,” its characters and its audience, it was finally time to have The Talk.

headline: Coast Guard Vessel Capsizes During Fishing Boat Rescue Near Queens
text: The crew of a fishing boat whose ship ran aground off Rockaway Beach in Queens overnight was airlifted to safety early Thursday after a harrowing rescue by the Coast Guard.

text: Karl Lagerfeld presents his fall collection for Fendi.

text: The deal to put Sharp in Taiwanese hands would be a messy milestone.

headline: Printing Gmail Backup Codes
text: Q. I use Google’s two-step authentication to protect my Gmail account, but I got temporarily locked out the other day when I was asked to re-enter my password, and the corresponding text code from Google didn’t arrive until hours later. Where do I get a set of those preprinted backup codes in case this happens again?

headline: South Dakota Bill on Transgender Students’ Bathroom Access Draws Ire
text: SIOUX FALLS, S.D. — For Thomas Lewis, a high school senior who plays trumpet in the marching band and works evenings at a grocery store, South Dakota’s contentious debate over transgender rights is personal.

headline: Colonial Architecture Fades From Ho Chi Minh City, and Residents Mourn
text: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam — When Nguyen Viet moved back to Vietnam from Britain in 2014, he was hired to write design guidelines for a redevelopment project in downtown Ho Chi Minh City. He had just earned his master’s degree in urban design and planning, and was eager to make an impact.

headline: Transgender Students and ‘Bathroom Laws’ in South Dakota and Beyond
text: The South Dakota Legislature approved a bill this month that would require public school students to use bathrooms and other facilities that correspond to their biological sex, defined in the bill as “a person’s chromosomes and anatomy as identified at birth.”

headline: 1941: ‘Final Plan’ for Siam Peace
text: TOKIO — Japan has presented a ‘‘final mediation plan’’ for settlement of the border dispute between French Indo-China and Thailand (Siam), and expects representatives of both countries to accept the Japanese proposals without further delay, the Japanese press indicated today [Feb. 26]. A government spokesman said the Tokio plan, which was described as ‘‘based on full and serious considerations of the demands of both sides,’’ probably would be accepted and that an agreement might be reached today or tomorrow. Japan’s mediation of the conflict was hampered by the fact that Tokio was engaged in important trade negotiations with Indo-China and found it necessary to proceed tactfully. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 26, 1941

headline: 1966: New Regime in Syria
text: DAMASCUS — Syria’s new military regime tonight [Feb. 25] named a new head of state and premier to replace former President Amin Hafez and ex-Premier Salah Bitar, ousted in Wednesday’s coup d’état. Damascus radio announced a decree naming Mr. Nureddin Atassi, 36, as new head of state and Mr. Youssef Zeayen as new premier. Mr. Zeayen, 35, is the youngest premier in Syria’s history. Mr. Atassi and Dr. Zeayen are both physicians and longtime doctrinaire Ba’athists. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 26, 1966

headline: When the Apple and F.B.I. Fight Really Began
text: In many ways, the current battle between Apple and the F.B.I. really began in June 2013, when the former defense contractor Edward J. Snowden revealed the scale of government spying on domestic Internet traffic.

headline: Girl Scouts Face Opposition From St. Louis Archbishop
text: The Archdiocese of St. Louis is encouraging Roman Catholics to scale back ties with the Girl Scouts, advising church members to think twice about membership and even about buying their cookies.

headline: Bronx Rabbi Who Had Sauna Chats Is Quitting
text: The prominent senior rabbi of a Bronx synagogue who drew scrutiny for having naked sauna chats with boys as young as 12 is stepping down.

headline: Video Review: Restoring Diesel’s Good Name With a New Range Rover
text: Diesel is a dirty word these days thanks to the Volkswagen scandal.

headline: In Season of Upsets, No. 1 Perch Resembles an Ejection Seat
text: Remember when a No. 1 team being upset was a cause for storming the court, television bulletins and front-page headlines? This season, a loss by the top team in men’s basketball seems to bring little more than a shrug.

headline: Post-Enron Accounting Rule Requires Companies to Report Leases
text: The Enron accounting scandal happened nearly 15 years ago, but the announcement on Thursday of a new accounting rule shows that its impact is still being felt in corporate America.

headline: Amid Gloomy Rhetoric, John Kasich Sticks With Optimism
text: The most valuable currency in politics is emotion. And the coin of the 2016 Republican presidential race has been anger and fear.

headline: More Overdose Deaths From Anxiety Drugs
text: Fatal prescription-drug overdoses in the United States have increased sharply in recent years. But while most of the deaths have involved opioid painkillers like oxycodone, a new study suggests that anti-anxiety medications now are playing an outsize role in overdose deaths.

headline: Jailed for Stealing Tools in 1980, ‘Prison Houdini’ Is Denied Release
text: At 19, Mark DeFriest was sentenced to four years in prison after stealing some tools.

headline: The Baur au Lac and Me
text: Sam Borden has a special relationship with the Baur au Lac hotel in Zurich, which has become synonymous with the FIFA corruption scandal. He returned this week.

headline: Spellbinding Treasures From Japan’s Kamakura Period at Asia Society
text: In different times and places a combustive mix of realism and religion has given rise to some of the world’s greatest art. The European Renaissance was one such era. Another was the brief Kamakura period of Japan, from 1185 to 1333. “Kamakura: Realism and Spirituality in the Sculpture of Japan,” a spellbinding exhibition at Asia Society, features wonderfully vivid representations of Buddhist divinities.

headline: U.S. and China Agree on Proposal for Tougher North Korea Sanctions
text: UNITED NATIONS — The United States and China reached an agreement to impose tougher sanctions against North Korea, in what appeared to be a diplomatic shift by Beijing regarding its intransigent ally.

headline: The Art of War (Elevator Edition)
text: I’ve come across a lot of militaristic-sounding classes at the gym lately — Boot Camp Ballet, Older Adults Special Ops — but the course I want to take is Close Combat Elevator Warfare.

headline: Twin Sets, Subscription Vinyl and Laundry Room Melody
text: ORCHIDS AND VIOLENCE

headline: In Milan, Fendi and Cavalli Just Say No to Athleisure
text: MILAN — It’s evening in Milan — or at least on the runways it is. Forget athleisure, wellness and wheat grass (though green juice is having a moment in the land of espresso); there are other things in life to dress for. Like dark, louche nights of the soul, a cabaret in Weimar Berlin or sunset dreams of swooning and spooning in a misty cityscape — to name a few of the scenarios that showed up in early shows. We can’t all be jogging all the time.

headline: The Minnesota Orchestra Rebounds From a ‘Near Death Experience’
text: MINNEAPOLIS — Outside the office of Kevin Smith, the president and chief executive of the Minnesota Orchestra, a creed hangs on the wall: Enrich, Inspire, Serve. Elsewhere that mission statement — part management cliché, part heartfelt philosophy — might be cast on a plaque. Not here, at an organization where permanence has been shown to be an illusion. No, these guiding principles are drawn in block letters on three large, slightly crumpled pieces of paper, as if to say that, like the medium, the message is fragile and, once damaged, a challenge to repair.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Gucci, Alberta Ferretti and Roberto Cavalli in Pictures
text: A photo diary of the fall/winter 2016 collections that were presented Wednesday.

headline: Emilio Pucci: Fall 2016
text: The label’s fall show.

headline: Americans Are Still Flying Blind on Drones
text: One of the least understood aspects of American security policy is the use of armed drones for killing alleged terrorists overseas. These covert executions have long raised grave questions of morality, legality and secrecy. Yet President Obama is failing to adequately address them despite promises to make the program more transparent and accountable.

headline: Farruquito, Dance Career Interrupted, Makes His Return
text: The dancer Farruquito is heir to one of the most renowned Gypsy flamenco dynasties in Spain, but when he performs at City Center on March 10, it will be his first New York appearance in 13 years. His dancing in the 2001 New York Flamenco Festival, when he was 18, inspired superlatives and heated comparisons: a charging bull, Heathcliff from “Wuthering Heights.” His return in 2003 was that year’s hottest ticket, and soon his brooding allure was hailed on People magazine’s “50 Most Beautiful” list. So why have his New York fans had to wait so long?

headline: Sound Bite: Dylan and Hopper Penn at Milan Fashion Week
text: MILAN — After Gucci postponed its show on Wednesday for more than an hour over a late plane from London, the first day of Milan Fashion Week tipped into delay after delay with dominolike effect.

headline: Leche y Miel Restaurant
text: A quiet Latin spot in Kingsbridge, the Bronx.

headline: Sweet Simplicity at Leche y Miel in the Bronx
text: To begin, mofonguitos: green plantains fried, mashed with garlic and olive oil, then popped into a lemon squeezer, making rough cups that look like craters. Into their maws go knots of hot, plump shrimp and a web, quickly melting, of Parmesan.

headline: Sepp Blatter, on Eve of FIFA Election, Is Exiting ‘a Happy Man’
text: ZURICH — A day before he was to relinquish his title as the most powerful man in sports, Sepp Blatter already had his final morning as FIFA president planned. He said he would wake up and dance a little, as he always does (Frank Sinatra’s “My Way” is a favorite). He would monitor the election, he said. But he turned down several offers from friends, journalists and, he said, even a priest, to give him company while his FIFA career was to officially come to a close.

headline: The Whitney Will Be Alive With the Sounds of Sing Sing
text: The fearless performance and video artist Andrea Fraser specializes in satirizing the rituals and myths of the high-art world, with withering attention on its political and social blind spots. “Down the River,” Ms. Fraser’s site-specific audio installation at the Whitney Museum of American Art, consists of ambient sounds recorded at Sing Sing Correctional Facility, which is 35 miles up the Hudson River from the museum’s new building. It’s meant to address the accelerated construction of museum buildings and prisons in the United States since the 1970s, parallel trends of cultural expression and incarceration. Running from February 26- March 13, it’s the first installment in “Open Plan,” a series of five short shows, each of which will occupy the whole of the museum’s 18,200-square-foot gallery, the largest unobstructed museum exhibition space in New York. After Ms. Fraser in “Open Plan” are renowned names in their genres: the painter Lucy Dodd, March 17-20; the sculptor Michael Heizer, March 25 to April 10; the musician Cecil Taylor, April 15-24; and the filmmaker Steve McQueen, April 29 to May 14. (whitney.org.)

headline: Hank Aaron’s Hard Road to Baseball Glory
text: Spring training has begun, and the sports channels are turning their thoughts to baseball, but so is the Smithsonian Channel. On Monday, it begins a four-part docu-series called “Major League Legends” with a moving episode on Hank Aaron. Every fan knows his triumphant trot around the bases when he broke Babe Ruth’s major league home run record in 1974, but this program traces the difficult road he traveled to get to that moment.

headline: Piotr Anderszewski’s Riddles of Bach and Schumann
text: Piotr Anderszewski is an uncommonly poetic pianist, one with so awkward a stage presence that he can seem like a riddle. The program he presents for his solo recital at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday, March 3, is a riddle of sorts, too, a musical palindrome. After opening with one Bach Partita (No. 6), it moves on to early Schumann, pauses on the Impressionist-Symbolist reverie of Szymanowski’s “Metopes,” then reverses its steps through late Schumann and back to Bach (Partita No. 1). “Metopes,” based on three Classical friezes depicting stages of Homer’s “The Odyssey,” are lovely works that are too rarely played and that seem to look both forward and backward. The first is inspired by Odysseus’s encounter with the Sirens. It will be haunting to hear it followed by Schumann’s “Ghost Variations,” the last work he wrote before being confined to a mental institution; according to experts, Schumann tried to drown himself in the Rhine between the composition of the fourth and fifth variations. (7:30 p.m.; lcgreatperformers.org.)

headline: ‘The Crucible’ Returns to Broadway
text: It’s turning into the season of the witch. Earning the kind of raves for a horror movie not seen since “It Follows,” the period piece “The Witch” takes audiences back to the days when people thought covens were not just the stuff of spooky stories. The finest satire in Judd Apatow’s new Netflix show, “Love,” takes place on the studio lot of a tween-courting television series about witches with the spectacularly awful title “Wichita.” And there’s a new Broadway revival of Arthur Miller’s “The Crucible,” the most famous play about the anxiety of witchcraft this side of “Macbeth.” The last time this was on Broadway, in 2002, Richard Eyre directed a worthy production starring Laura Linney and Liam Neeson. Expect something more adventurous from the director Ivo van Hove, who staged the stripped-down revival of Mr. Miller’s “A View from the Bridge.” He has an equally impressive roster to work with, including Saoirse Ronan, Ben Whishaw and Ciaran Hinds. (Previews begin March 1 at Walter Kerr Theater; thecrucibleonbroadway.com.)

headline: A Dance and Music Pairing of Steps and Keys
text: Chamber-music performances — say, by a fine string quartet or trio — can be magical in the way they combine intimacy of scale with emotional expansiveness. Two dancers and a pianist will offer what could be called choreographic chamber music in Trio ConcertDance. The participants — Alessandra Ferri, a former principal dancer of both American Ballet Theater and England’s Royal Ballet; Herman Cornejo, a principal dancer with A.B.T.; and Bruce Levingston, an American pianist — are known for their expressive range. The international group of choreographers for Trio includes the French-based Angelin Preljocaj; Demis Volpi, a resident choreographer of the Stuttgart Ballet; Russell Maliphant, associate artist of London’s Sadler’s Wells Theater; Stanton Welch of the Australian Ballet; and the Taiwanese choreographer Fang-Yi Sheu. All but one of their dances were commissioned for Trio. Mr. Levingston’s versatility will be on display as he cycles through Bach, Chopin, Philip Glass and more. (Wednesday, March 2, through March 6; Joyce Theater, joyce.org.)

headline: Vicente Amigo Plays Flamenco Guitar With a Personal Flair
text: The flamenco guitarist Vicente Amigo, from Seville, Spain, has called his engagement with his instrument “beloved torture.” You can imagine why when you hear him play: He reaches for depth of expression within ultimate precision, and sometimes at frightening speed. Now in his late 40s, he has worked with some of the great traditional flamenco singers of the last several decades — Camarón de la Isla, Enrique Morente, Diego el Cigala and Carmen Linares — but has also been part of the genre’s modernizing wave: He encompasses the tradition while trying other languages and techniques. (His last album, “Tierra,” combined flamenco with Celtic music.) He’s played in New York before, but his appearance this week, at Carnegie Hall’s Stern Auditorium, is part of his first major United States tour. It won’t be Celtic or any other kind of fusion: He’s bringing a traditional ensemble, as well as the dancer Antonio Molina, known as El Choro. (8 p.m., March 4; Carnegie Hall, carnegiehall.org.)

headline: Learning to Act, but Hungry for Roles to Practice
text: BOSTON — The playwright Kirsten Greenidge was in high demand. Over in the South End, her Obie-winning drama, “Milk Like Sugar,” was in previews at the Huntington Theater Company. A couple of miles west, at Boston University, her new play, “Baltimore,” was edging toward opening. In both places, there was work she needed to do.

headline: Bluffer’s Guide to the Oscars: Best Picture
text: Everything you need to know about the contenders in one quick rundown.

headline: One Cocktail, Two Spirits: Bartenders Go for a Blend
text: When you’re ordering an old-fashioned, the first and main question facing you is this: bourbon or rye? At Valkyrie, a bar in Tulsa, Okla., you don’t have to make that decision. You get both.

headline: A Family Adds Five Children, Special Needs and All
text: Diane Stanley has seven children in her home: her biological son, Cooper, 18; her foster son, David, 22, who is intellectually disabled; and five younger children whom she and her husband adopted in November 2015. Those five include the biological siblings Demetries, 8; Caleb, 4; and Maya, 2; as well as the biological sisters Julianna, 7, and Juliette, 6. She is also the mother of two adult children and the stepmother to two adult children, and she has one stepdaughter, 14, who lives with her mother.

headline: Setback for Picasso’s Daughter in Battle Over Sculpture
text: A French court has rejected a plea by the daughter of Pablo Picasso to void a seizure order for a valuable sculpture at the center of a dispute over ownership between the New York dealer Larry Gagosian and an agent for the Qatari royal family.

headline: Donald Trump Leads in Florida, While Ted Cruz Has Edge in Texas, Polls Show
text: Donald J. Trump holds a wide lead over Senator Marco Rubio in his home state of Florida, but trails Senator Ted Cruz on his turf in Texas, according to two new polls of coming primary contests that could ultimately determine the Republican presidential nomination.

headline: Sinn Fein Gains Popularity in Ireland Through a Desire for Change
text: DUBLIN — Sean Crowe, a member of the Irish Parliament, has been around long enough to remember just how tough it was to attract votes when his party, Sinn Fein, was known only as the political arm of the Irish Republican Army as it waged a guerrilla campaign against Britain in Northern Ireland, only an hour’s drive from his Dublin constituency.

headline: Ted Cruz Fights in Texas, Hoping It Won’t Be His Alamo
text: HOUSTON — Senator Ted Cruz cannot stop talking about the Alamo.

headline: New Baseball Rules Take On Rolling Slides and ‘Neighborhood Plays’
text: When Chase Utley’s slide broke Ruben Tejada’s right leg in Game 2 of a National League division series between the Los Angeles Dodgers and the Mets, the relatively common tactic of trying to break up a double play was put under a microscope, with many assuming that a change in baseball’s rules would result.

headline: Jeremy McQueen’s Ballet Collective to Foster Black Works
text: The Black Iris Project, a new ballet collective aiming to foster and present new works about black lives and history, takes its name from a Georgia O’Keeffe painting, “Black Iris III” (1926).

headline: Technology Problems Top a List of Car Complaints
text: Craig Sakowitz could be considered a technologically adept driver. As an e-commerce project manager for the Gap in San Francisco, he often rents cars and relies on hands-free technologies to get work done.

headline: Some Calais ‘Jungle’ Camp Migrants Get Eviction Reprieve
text: CALAIS, France — Somewhere between the Good Chance Theater and the One Spirit Ashram Kitchen sits the School of Arts and Trades, not to mention the Hamid Karzai Restaurant and Arts in the Village.

headline: Science in the National Interest
text: To the Editor:

headline: Leaving Las Vegas for Natural Beauty and More
text: Las Vegas is not only about gambling, partying and making certain that everything that you do there stays there: it’s just mostly about those things. If you’re feeling a little grimy from the previous night or need to soothe your hurt pride from losses incurred at the blackjack table, take solace in the knowledge there’s a wealth of natural beauty and interesting side trips at your disposal. Last week I discussed the underappreciated gems off the Strip — but if you’re willing to travel a bit farther, the rewards become a lot more beautiful. The Hoover Dam, Lake Mead and the Grand Canyon are among the most popular — but here are a few more options that are both less obvious and, in some cases, a lot closer.

headline: On Assisted Dying
text: To the Editor:

headline: Swedish Girl Who Ran Away to Iraq Says She Had Not Heard of ISIS
text: A Swedish teenager rescued from the Islamic State said she had never heard of the militant group known as ISIS before running away with her boyfriend to join the extremists at their base in Iraq.

headline: A Ski Trip, but Work
text: My mother recently ended a long-term relationship. She and her ex-boyfriend loved skiing together, and she really misses it. Last week, my boyfriend’s firm invited us to a ski retreat in Park City, Utah. It is a work event with significant others only. It is also the first time my boyfriend qualified to attend. (It’s a prestigious invitation; all expenses are paid by the company.) My mother asked if she could come along. We explained the context to her, but she keeps pushing to join us. What should we do?

headline: What Binds a Marriage
text: To the Editor:

headline: Why Tech Degrees Are Not Putting More Blacks and Hispanics Into Tech Jobs
text: Technology companies employ strikingly few black and Hispanic workers. They blame the recruitment pipeline, saying there aren’t enough of them graduating with relevant degrees and applying for tech jobs.

headline: Pop Art International: Far Beyond Warhol and Lichtenstein
text: PHILADELPHIA — “Remember how insane the 1960s felt, every day?” someone asked me at a preview of the traveling exhibition “International Pop,” which is making its final stop here at the Philadelphia Museum of Art. Absolutely I remember, and the show — brash, manic and acid-tinged — took me right back there.

headline: Will Shortz: Everything You Want To Know About Crossword Puzzles
text: What rhymes with orange? Times crossword puzzle editor and self-described “puzzlehead,” Will Shortz answers readers’ questions.

headline: New Movie House in Manhattan: Metrograph Theater
text: Quietly, New York City is adding movie theaters. True, the Ziegfeld has closed, but last month, Brooklyn gained the Syndicated; this week, the Lower East Side welcomes the Metrograph Theater. To mark the occasion, the Metrograph begins its life with “Surrender to the Screen,” 16 films whose plot lines feature the film-going experience.

headline: Rachel Weisz to Star in ‘Plenty’ at the Public Theater
text: Rachel Weisz will star in a revival of David Hare’s “Plenty” at the Public Theater this fall, the Off Broadway nonprofit announced Thursday.

headline: Met Opera Names Ennead Architects to Redesign Lobby
text: The Metropolitan Opera has selected Ennead Architects to design the renovation and expansion of its lobby, the opera house said on Thursday.

headline: Program Offers Free E-Books to Low-Income Children
text: Open eBooks, a program making thousands of best-selling books available for free to low-income children, signed up roughly 50,000 users on its first day, according a report by the project’s partner organizations.

headline: Luxurious Italian Pajamas, Inspired by Literature
text: Sitting on a long velvet sofa and looking out over Lake Como, Francesca Ruffini calls this her “place of serenity.” Her villa, perched on a steep mountainside that plunges into the lake’s eastern edge, is an oasis in the grand Como style: tiled with large slabs of black-and-white marble, neatly lined with paintings, statues and books. A row of indoor palms behind arched glass doors opens to a topiary garden with sweeping views of the water and snow-capped mountains.

headline: Francesca Ruffini, at Home on Lake Como
text: T visited the designer before her F.R.S presentation, which showed today in Milan, to learn about the influences for her fall collection.

headline: Breanna Stewart Completes Her Run of Dominance
text: Breanna Stewart’s four-year record with UConn was 151-5, and every victory but one was by 10 or more points.
