text: Senator Ted Cruz quotes “Scarface” and boasts of his beer pong prowess.

headline: Wallflower Bunny Finds a Home and a Companion
text: Tonya, always the bridesmaid rabbit, is finally a bride.

headline: Jazzercise Lives On in the Age of Zumba
text: If you have an ear to the ground, you can still hear the commands — “Grapevine!” “Step-ball-change!” — in New York, where Zumba and Tracy Anderson-inspired dance cardio classes long ago trumped Jazzercise as the choreographed workout of choice.

headline: How Clinton and Sanders Are Courting Black Votes
text: Charleston, S.C. — ON Thursday night, a few blocks from Mother Emanuel A.M.E. Church, Charlie Wilson, in a shimmery white blazer, was trying to get out the vote for Hillary Clinton. And trying to get the former secretary of state to do some shoulder shrugs. She bopped her head along gamely, smiling wide.

headline: The Arbiter of Invention
text: Robert Quintero works out of a tiny office overlooking West 34th Street that is filled with big ideas, and bigger dreams.

headline: Apple Shareholders Show Their Support for Tim Cook
text: CUPERTINO, Calif. — Even before Timothy D. Cook, Apple’s chief executive, began his speech on Friday at the company’s annual shareholder meeting, he got a standing ovation.

headline: The History of the Archbishop Who’s Concerned About Girl Scouts
text: Archbishop Robert Carlson’s recent caution to his parishes in St. Louis about the “troubling pattern of behavior” of the Girl Scouts is stirring stark recollections of the prelate’s past role in managing accusations against priests for sexually abusing children. In a deposition two years ago, he insisted that he was not certain sexual abuse of a child by a priest constituted a criminal act in 1984, when he was auxiliary bishop for St. Paul and Minneapolis handling sex scandal cases.

headline: Japan Lost Nearly a Million People in 5 Years, Census Says
text: TOKYO — Japan’s population shrank by nearly a million during the last half-decade, official census figures confirmed on Friday, an unprecedented drop for a society not ravaged by war or other deadly crisis, and one that helps explain the country’s persistent economic woes.

headline: Justice Scalia’s Death Prompts Dow Chemical to Settle Lawsuit
text: Antonin Scalia’s empty Supreme Court seat has cost Dow Chemical $835 million.

headline: Golfers Say Trump Reneged on Deal
text: When last we left Donald J. Trump, at least here on the sports page, we were recalling the time he owned the New Jersey Generals in the short-lived United States Football League. Trump bought the Generals in 1983, after their first season, and immediately began pushing the league to move its season from the spring to the fall and take on the mighty N.F.L. His campaign generated a tremendous amount of publicity for Trump, but produced nothing but misery for the other owners. After a Trump-orchestrated antitrust suit against the N.F.L. backfired spectacularly, the once-promising U.S.F.L. went kaput.

headline: Better Care or Onerous Restrictions? Texas Abortion Law Going Before Supreme Court
text: For all the furious debate over constitutional rights rekindled by the first Supreme Court  abortion case in nearly a decade, the stated goal of the law at issue is a medical one: ensuring patient safety.

headline: Family Says Death of Black Woman in South Carolina Jail Was Easily Preventable
text: The chain of events that led to the death of a black woman in a South Carolina jail last July began with a desperate bid to save her life from alcoholism.

headline: How Mark Norell, a Paleontologist, Spends His Sundays
text: The titanosaur recently unveiled at the American Museum of Natural History was nearly as long and heavy as two subway cars when it roamed the earth, making it one of the biggest dinosaurs ever discovered. But Mark A. Norell, 58, the curator and chief of the museum’s paleontology division, is just as excited about an exhibition opening March 21, “Dinosaurs Among Us,” which he curated and which explores how one group of dinosaurs evolved into birds. Dr. Norell says technology has brought paleontology closer to biology, allowing scientists to examine topics like the evolution of dinosaur brains, and, yes, dinosaur feathers. He lives in the NoMad neighborhood with his wife, Vivian Pan, a partner in a capital management firm. Their daughter, Inga, 20, is a student at Barnard College.

headline: An Easy Fix for Vertigo
text: The first time it happened, in 2011, Bob Amberger thought he might be having a stroke.

headline: Sora Choi Transforms at Versace
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall/Winter 2016 Fashion Week in Milan.

headline: The Myth of the Hero Teacher
text: Maybe you have had the fantasy: Chuck your day job to teach in a public school in a blighted neighborhood. The money is lousy, of course, but that’s part of the fantasy — no one wants to turn around the lives of poor children just for a paycheck. Then you decide that maybe today is not the day, and go back to your life. Sound familiar?

headline: Paul L. Whalen, Architect, at Home in Greenwich Village
text: Living in a Greenwich Village apartment with a distinguished pedigree is something Paul L. Whalen savors. “I am very aware of being in a Bing & Bing building,” he said, referring to the developers who built numerous apartment buildings in Manhattan during the early 20th century. “Bing & Bing buildings offer the formal qualities of grand Upper East Side apartments on a practical scale. They were designed for single people or young couples. They have classic layouts, often with fireplaces and rooms large enough to furnish nicely.”

headline: What I Love | Paul L. Whalen
text: Paul L. Whalen, a partner in Robert A.M. Stern Architects, lives in a prewar Bing & Bing building in the West Village.

headline: Where the Art Starts
text: Apple Art Supplies, in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, has served art and design students in the neighborhood for 15 years.

headline: Apple Art Supplies in Brooklyn Is Hub for Matte Knives and Gossip
text: On a short stretch of DeKalb Avenue near the campus of Pratt Institute in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, is a trio of establishments essential to students: a pizzeria with good, cheap slices; a diner with an all-day breakfast and free refills of coffee; and Apple Art Supplies.

headline: A Top N.H.L. Rookie Skates In From the Heat
text: Shayne Gostisbehere’s unusual journey from South Florida to the N.H.L. actually started in Montreal in the 1950s when a woman named Cleo Brodeur went to the doctor seeking a treatment for severe asthma.

headline: Review: Black Sabbath’s Metal Séance of Fear, Dread and Joy
text: The freaked-out entrance line of the first song of the first Black Sabbath album, sung by Ozzy Osbourne over the guitarist Tony Iommi’s creepy-crawly interval of a tritone, is: “What is this that stands before me?”

headline: Washington Streetcar Stumbles Could Benefit de Blasio’s Plan
text: WASHINGTON — The empty streetcars started their test runs down H Street more than a year ago, a slow-rolling taunt for a fast-changing neighborhood left to wonder when the line might finally open.

headline: Margin of Victory Will Matter as Clinton Counts on Black Voters in South Carolina
text: After three contests, Hillary Clinton leads Bernie Sanders by the slimmest of margins in the Democratic primary, 51 to 50 in delegates.

headline: The T Takes on Four Oscar-Nominated Writer/Directors
text: Household names and newcomers alike have made it onto the 2016 Academy Awards ballot — and into the pages of T. Ahead of Sunday night’s ceremony, a guide to the some of the talent we’ve met along the way.

headline: Jersey City Warehouse Converted to Rental Lofts
text: When the Butler Brothers building rose near the Jersey City waterfront 111 years ago, the immense brick structure was a testament to the city’s manufacturing prowess. Shaped like the letter E, the eight-story warehouse spanned a square city block and was a distribution center for the Chicago-based company’s catalog business and its Ben Franklin five-and-dime stores and Federated stores.

headline: Modera Lofts, Jersey City
text: The 1905 Butler Brothers Building at 350 Warren Street in Jersey City is being converted to 366 residential lofts.

headline: Before There Was Trump, There Was Gingrich
text: The New York Times columnist Gail Collins recently wrote a takedown of Donald Trump. Her focus was Mr. Trump’s rationale for his professed support of Obamacare. “I don’t want people dying on the streets,” he said.

headline: What’s the Point of Moral Outrage?
text: HUMAN beings have an appetite for moral outrage. You see this in public life — in the condemnation of Donald J. Trump for vowing to bar Muslims from the United States, or of Hillary Clinton for her close involvement with Wall Street, to pick two ready examples — and you see this in personal life, where we criticize friends, colleagues and neighbors who behave badly.

headline: Betting Markets Weigh the Odds of Vice President Christie

headline: Questions Nag in Sweden 30 Years After Leader’s Assassination
text: GOTEBORG, Sweden — Three decades after Prime Minister Olof Palme was gunned down on a Stockholm street, his unsolved killing continues to reverberate through Swedish politics and society.

headline: Soprano Gets Two More Turns at Met “Butterfly”
text: Ana María Martínez, who received rave reviews earlier this month when she filled in for an ailing soprano in the title role of Puccini’s “Madama Butterfly” at the Metropolitan Opera, will extend her run and sing the role two more times, the company announced on Friday.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: These Days, John Baldessari Cribs From the Masters
text: LOS ANGELES — Having taught many generations of Los Angeles artists, John Baldessari proudly displays a few of their creations on the walls of his large studio in Venice. One piece, by Analia Saban, consists of white paper cleverly made to look like a stained gym towel.

headline: Friday Night Music: White Rabbit
text: Definitely a good week to start dropping acid, although it might be hard to tell the difference.

headline: Review: Baiba Skride Wrestles Bartok’s Art of Darkness
text: Young musicians are often told they should wait to perform certain works that require technical or psychological maturity, like late Beethoven or Schubert. The piece the Latvian violinist Baiba Skride, 34, yearned to play as a student was Bartok’s Violin Concerto No. 2, but her teachers deemed it too emotionally taxing.

headline: English National Opera’s Chorus Votes to Strike
text: LONDON — Chorus members at the English National Opera here voted on Friday to strike over proposed layoffs and salary cuts.

headline: Review: Jason Isbell, Slowing Down to Feel the Americana
text: It’s standard practice for a band to play its songs a little faster in concert than on record, as a matter of courting excitement or surrendering to it. Jason Isbell and the 400 Unit tacked the other way on Thursday at the Beacon Theater, in his first of two consecutive nights there: digging deep furrows and hunkering down.

headline: Allergic to Dogs on a Flight? What Travelers Need to Know
text: A 7-year-old boy and his parents were asked to leave their Allegiant Air flight from Bellingham, Wash., to Phoenix last week after the boy developed an allergic reaction to a dog, a service animal, on the plane, according to several news reports. The flight was delayed about 90 minutes and some passengers were said to have applauded when the child was leaving.

headline: Review: Mariinsky Celebrates a Prima Ballerina
text: The Mariinsky Ballet has been variously known as the wellspring of ballet classicism and the finest home of ballet romanticism. On Thursday, however, it became the celebrant of sensationalist kitsch in the triple bill that opened its four-program season, “A Tribute to Maya Plisetskaya,” at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The evening was bizarre in several ways.

headline: Versace: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Donatella Versace’s vision for fall 2016.

headline: Donald Trump and Chris Christie Start a Bully Bromance
text: Those who have witnessed Gov. Chris Christie’s performance both in New Jersey and in the national arena over the past couple of years almost could have seen Friday’s sweaty embrace of Donald Trump coming. Almost.

headline: Review: The New@Graham Series Is Helped by an App
text: Did you know that the Martha Graham Center for Contemporary Dance has a free downloadable mobile app? I didn’t until Thursday night, when the Graham company hosted a virtual tour of its latest technological endeavors, in particular its new partnership with the Google Cultural Institute.

headline: Rauschenberg Foundation Eases Copyright Restrictions on Art
text: Museumgoers tend to be unaware of the vast network of copyright protections that underlie images of much of Modern and contemporary art, until they try to shoot a cellphone picture of a favorite painting and receive an embarrassing tut-tut from a guard.

headline: Review: ‘I’ll Never Love Again,’ From a Teenage Girl’s Diary
text: Should it choose to adopt the Broadway business model for self-promoting souvenirs, the Bushwick Starr could surely do a brisk trade in “I Am Clare” buttons. These artifacts might be sold, along with the usual choices of bottled beer, from the bar in what passes for a lobby in this tiny walk-up theater in Brooklyn.

headline: Evening Hours | The Orchid Dinner, the Viennese Opera Ball and More
text: Plus: the Purim Ball and the annual winter ball hosted by the Museum of the City of New York.

headline: Success Academy Loses in Pre-K Battle With de Blasio Administration
text: Success Academy suffered a defeat in a high-profile skirmish with New York City on Friday, when the state education commissioner ruled that the city could require the charter school network to sign a contract to receive funding for its prekindergarten program.

headline: Review: ‘City of Glass,’ Down a Rabbit Hole of Meta-Noir
text: In “City of Glass,” an adaptation of Paul Auster’s 1985 novel by Untitled Theater Company No. 61, a wrong number plunges a thriller writer into a mystery of his own. When a man first telephones Daniel Quinn (Robert Honeywell), asking to speak to “the detective, Paul Auster,” Quinn informs the caller of his mistake. But the next time the phone rings, Quinn pretends to be Auster and soon finds himself embroiled in the tale of a monstrous father, a damaged son and an alluring wife.

headline: Prada’s Wistful Tough Girls
text: The label’s fall/winter show incorporated iconic markers of femininity like brocade, roses and pearls — but the effect was still unsettling.

headline: Review: You See ‘The Encounter’ With Your Ears
text: LONDON — Someone is blowing in your ear, and it isn’t anybody in your immediate vicinity. You can feel this distant person’s breath (hot) and his urgency (hotter), and the sound of him is all over the place — behind you, before you, to either side of you, close and distant, shouting and whispering, sometimes in several voices at once.

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing: Sepp Blatter, Academy Awards, Syria
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Review: Mozart, a Little Bit Symphony, a Little Bit Opera
text: You would think that a Mozart symphony should be heard as an entity, a single composition in four parts. But at concerts in that composer’s day, it was fairly common for movements of a symphony to be interspersed with opera arias, orchestral dances and whatnot.

headline: The Young Minimalist Designer Being Compared to Armani
text: All weather reports indicated spring on a recent Saturday in Milan, but February’s gloomy cloud cover said otherwise. Still, Lucio Vanotti, the 40-year-old minimalist clothing designer, appeared for a stroll in Parco Sempione with his perpetual sidekick, a tiny taupe-colored, bowlegged Italian greyhound named — in true minimalist fashion — Clean. Both man and dog were dressed rigorously in black, but color was all around — it was Carnival week, and brightly costumed children threw thick trails of rainbow confetti on the park’s walkways.

headline: Donald Trump Might Not Keep Paying for His Campaign Himself, Chris Christie Suggests
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey told his finance team late Friday that he anticipates that Donald J. Trump, who often boasts that he is funding his own campaign, will begin to solicit campaign contributions as the race heads into a general election if Mr. Trump becomes the nominee.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Shaggy Streets
text: The fur (faux and natural) was flying on the runways and on the guests at the recent New York collections, despite anti-fur sentiments. There were patchworks of fur everywhere, and at Marc Jacobs, three or four different furs were combined into single coats. Zero-degree weather during fashion week only encouraged the fur-bearing.

headline: Ted Cruz, Running a Distant Third in Friday’s Insult-a-Thon, Still Takes His Shots
text: NASHVILLE — Donald J. Trump plucked a mega-endorsement from across the Hudson River. Senator Marco Rubio established himself as the front-runner’s new chief tormentor, insulting Mr. Trump’s spelling and questioning his bladder control.

headline: Baseball’s First Threshold
text: The first day of spring training is often linked with the smell of fresh-cut grass. Cut grass means well-manicured baseball fields. Well-manicured baseball fields mean we are about to get serious.

headline: Marines Toast Iwo Jima Veterans on Anniversary of Flag Raising
text: Angelo Ciotta, 90, leaned against the bar inside a restaurant in Queens as fellow Marines offered a series of taut salutes and a bottle of red wine — a Marine Corps-themed vintage called Jarhead Red.

headline: A Better Way to Control the Banks
text: Nearly eight years after the financial crisis, behemoth banks still dominate the global economy. They are still immensely complex, highly leveraged and politically powerful. They are still difficult, if not impossible, to manage and supervise. For those reasons, they remain a threat to the economy, and the notion of breaking them up appeals to many voters, policy makers and politicians.

headline: Rejected Proposals for Penn Station
text: As the city considers overhauling the station, it seems like a good time to review ideas that didn't make the cut last time.

headline: A Georgia Bill Shields Discrimination Against Gays
text: After Indiana’s disastrous attempt last year to enact a religious-freedom law protecting business owners and others who refuse to serve same-sex couples for religious or moral reasons, one might reasonably have assumed that other states contemplating similar legislation would be chastened into dropping it.

headline: Two Deaths, One Overlooked, Remain Unsolved After J’ouvert Festival
text: It was a little after midnight when Denentro Josiah peeked into his parents’ bedroom in their Bronx home and told his mother he was heading to Brooklyn for the street party taking place before the West Indian American Day Parade, she recalled.

headline: Fed’s Transparency May Give Investors False Confidence, Economists Say
text: The Federal Reserve may be guilty of sharing too much information.

headline: Mets’ Zack Wheeler, Recovering From Surgery, Practices Patience
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — As Matt Harvey threw a routine bullpen session this week, Zack Wheeler stood 10 feet behind him, holding a clipboard. With each pitch Harvey threw, Wheeler marked a box on a sheet of paper, indicating where it was. Coaches typically fill out the form, but Wheeler figured that if he was just standing around, why not help?

headline: Officials Report 9 New Cases of Zika Virus Among Pregnant Women Tested in U.S.
text: Nine pregnant women in the United States have tested positive for the Zika virus, American health authorities reported Friday. One of the women gave birth to a baby with microcephaly, a defect that has been associated with the virus, and at least one other had an abortion after severe brain atrophy was detected in the fetus.

headline: Retired Police Sergeant Pleads Guilty to Tapping Into Confidential Databases for Money
text: A former New York City police sergeant pleaded guilty on Friday to conspiracy, admitting that he had accepted money to tap into restricted law enforcement databases to furnish information to a former officer who was working as an investigator for criminal defense lawyers.

headline: For a Yankees Prospect, Training Camp Involves Part Healing, Part Hope
text: TAMPA, Fla. — While the Yankees were on the baseball fields on Friday, throwing, catching, running and hitting, Greg Bird was doing none of those.

headline: George C. Nichopoulos, Elvis’s Last Doctor, Dies at 88
text: Dr. George C. Nichopoulos, Elvis Presley’s personal physician in the decade before his death in 1977, who lost his medical license for overprescribing addictive drugs for years to numerous patients, died on Wednesday in Memphis. He was 88.

headline: Apple’s Privacy Fight Tests Relationship With White House
text: WASHINGTON — Timothy D. Cook, the chief executive of Apple, was relentless during a private meeting of tech giants and President Obama’s top national security officials last month. Encrypted devices like the iPhone are here to stay, he insisted. Law enforcement needs to find a way to do its job in a new world.

headline: Unclassified Clinton Emails May Have Consequences for a Key Deputy
text: WASHINGTON — In May, 2011, John Kerry wrapped up a trip to Pakistan intended to calm tensions over the secret raid that had killed Osama bin Laden just weeks before. But as he took off to fly to Dubai, the Central Intelligence Agency carried out a pair of drone attacks in North Waziristan.

headline: Buy Local? South Bronx’s New Councilman Makes It a Habit
text: The newest member of the New York City Council, Rafael Salamanca Jr., will be sworn into office in a new blue suit. Like most everything in his life, it has a South Bronx connection.

headline: Syria Truce Comes With Price, but Not for Assad
text: WASHINGTON — If the temporary cease-fire in Syria begins to take hold on Saturday, despite the low expectations of the American and Russian officials who negotiated the agreement, it will be a landmark event. For the first time, diplomacy will have succeeded in abating the killing and misery that have already led to more than 250,000 deaths and millions of refugees pouring out of the shattered country.

headline: Emails Show Michigan Aides Worried About Flint’s Water a Year Before Acting
text: A full year before the state took significant action, some top aides to Gov. Rick Snyder of Michigan were alarmed at the quality of Flint’s water, with a lawyer for the governor calling the notion of drinking it “downright scary,” newly released emails show.

headline: Trump Meets the Mean Boys
text: Chris Christie has endorsed Donald Trump! Well, really, what did you expect? He’s a sworn enemy of Marco Rubio, and we have long since established that nobody likes Ted Cruz.

headline: Andy Bathgate, Standout on Dismal 1950s Rangers, Dies at 83
text: Andy Bathgate, the hockey Hall of Famer whose scoring touch gave Ranger fans something to cheer about while watching usually lackluster teams in the 1950s and early ’60s, died on Friday in Brampton, Ontario. He was 83.

headline: B&H Electronics Store Sued for Discrimination of Hispanic Workers
text: For the second time in nine years, the owners of B&H Photo Video, a popular electronics store in Manhattan, have been sued by the federal government for discriminating against Hispanic workers.

headline: Alfred E. Mann, Pioneer in Medical Devices, Dies at 90
text: Alfred E. Mann, who started medical device companies that pioneered in the development of pacemakers for erratic hearts, insulin pumps for diabetics, cochlear implants for the deaf and retinal implants for the blind, died on Thursday in Las Vegas. He was 90.

headline: Buna Ziua and Mad Props
text: SATURDAY PUZZLE — There is only one way that I know of to gain a toehold in a Saturday crossword, and that is to scan and re-scan the clue list for an entry that you definitely know. Sometimes, you might have to perform this exercise two or three times before you find a single entry to write into the grid.

headline: Elias Demetracopoulos, 87, Dies; Journalist Linked Greek Junta to Nixon
text: Elias Demetracopoulos, an enigmatic journalist who fled Greece after a military coup in 1967 and accused the ruling right-wing junta of illegally funneling a half-million dollars into Richard M. Nixon’s 1968 presidential campaign, died on Feb. 16 at a nursing home in Athens. He was 87.

headline: John Kasich Says He’s Surprised but Unfazed by Chris Christie’s Endorsement of Donald Trump
text: MEMPHIS — John Kasich, the only governor remaining in the Republican presidential field, said on Friday that he was “a little bit surprised” that Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey decided to endorse Donald J. Trump.

headline: ‘The Revenant’ Author Michael Punke Has a Day Job
text: There are five literary adaptations in the Oscar race for best picture this year, including movies based on Emma Donoghue’s “Room” and Colm Tóibín’s “Brooklyn.” But among the hopeful novelists who will be closely watching Sunday’s Academy Awards ceremony, only one has negotiated a $1.3 trillion global trade deal.

headline: Knicks Find Balance and Break Free Fall
text: When Kurt Rambis took over as interim coach of the Knicks this month, he set a lofty goal of steering the team with a 23-31 record to the playoffs.

headline: Dean at University of Texas Resigns in Part Over Handgun Law
text: A highly regarded dean at the flagship campus of the University of Texas announced this week that he was leaving the school in part because of his concerns over a new state law allowing people to carry concealed firearms in classrooms and other buildings on public college campuses.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “A new era has been started as we speak. You will be proud of FIFA. You will be proud of what FIFA will do for football.”

headline: Corrections: February 27, 2016
text: WEEKEND ARTS

headline: Eddie Einhorn, a Creator of College Basketball on TV, Dies at 80
text: Eddie Einhorn, who created a sports network that propelled national interest in college basketball, laying a foundation for the immense popularity of the annual tournament known as March Madness, died on Wednesday in Norwood, N.J. He was 80.

headline: What to Watch Saturday
text: Our best-picture Oscar catch-up concludes with “The Big Short,” Adam McKay’s thrill ride through the 2008 financial crisis. And Essence magazine honors black women in Hollywood.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: The Weekend
text: MILAN — Saturday starts in a highly civilized fashion at 9:30 a.m. with a show by Bottega Veneta, one of Kering’s star performing brands, which happens to have some of the best baristas in the business at its sleek headquarters on the Via Privata Ercole Marelli here.

headline: Suicide Bombings in Afghanistan Kill at Least 26
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Two separate suicide bombings in Afghanistan on Saturday left at least 26 people dead and nearly 50 injured, officials said, days ahead of expected talks between the government and the Taliban.

headline: Our Best Comments of the Week
text: In this new feature, we’ll list the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment.

headline: For Some Men, Mark Zuckerberg Is a Lifestyle Guru
text: Anyone who has ever taken to social media to announce a self-improvement project knows that your “friends” cannot be relied upon to hold you accountable. Almost as soon as you proclaim your intention to learn French or cut out carbs, the world moves on, leaving you with only your empty promises and scone crumbs on your shirt.

headline: Lupita Nyong’o and Trevor Noah, and Their Meaningful Roles
text: The most intriguing stars seem to appear from out of nowhere.

headline: Poll Watch: Trump Tries to Court Hispanic Voters
text: Donald J. Trump bragged during Thursday night’s Republican debate that he had won almost half the Hispanic vote in the Nevada caucuses on Tuesday. “Nobody else was close,” he said. Looking forward, he said, “I will do really well with Hispanics.”

headline: Bottega Veneta: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Designs for fall 2016 from the mind of Tomas Maier.

headline: The Week on Instagram
text: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took our followers from Yosemite National Park to fashion week in Milan.

headline: Inside the Republican Party’s Desperate Mission to Stop Donald Trump
text: Get live updates about the Florida primary.

headline: Antonio Marras: Fall 2016 RTW
text: The latest collection from Antonio Marras.

headline: Hillary Clinton Wins South Carolina Primary
text: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Drawing overwhelming support from the African-American voters who deserted her here eight years ago, Hillary Clinton won her first resounding victory of the 2016 campaign in South Carolina on Saturday, delivering a blow to Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont as their fight turns to the 11 states where Democrats vote on Tuesday.

headline: The Daily Shoe: Versace
text: Donatella Versace and a kitten heel aren’t exactly synonymous. And yet these zip-up ankle boots are just as sexy as one of her many vertiginous designs.

headline: A Little Variety
text: A LITTLE VARIETY PUZZLES — This week’s puzzles include:

headline: Farhad and Mike Hash Out the Week’s Big Topic: Apple
text: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

headline: G-20, Rejecting Major Policy Shifts, Plays Up Basic Strengths
text: SHANGHAI — Through the winter, world financial markets have tumbled and churned with a succession of worries. The Chinese economy seemed to be faltering. Commodity exporters like Russia and Brazil suffered sharp slowdowns. And with oil prices falling, banks that have lent heavily to energy companies could be hurt.

headline: Dropping the Curtain on a Singing Neighbor
text: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: Equality in Marriages Grows, and So Does Class Divide
text: The Don Drapers of the world used to marry their secretaries. Now they marry fellow executives, who could very well earn more than they do.

headline: The Daily Bag: Tod’s
text: We love the classic Tod’s satchel’s fall look: stitched up and strung with tassels.

headline: Three’s a Trend: Multicolored Oversize Knits
text: This season, oversize multicolored knits — historically the opposite of cool — have caught our attention. In London, where we first saw the trend take shape at Joseph, the designer Louise Trotter showed sweaters in baggy proportions — including this childlike alphabet version that felt more thrift-store cool than designer. At Prada, a classic mosaic knit was made luxurious with the addition of fur cuffs. And at Etro, horizontal stripes and frayed edges recalled the grunge heyday — to great effect.

headline: The Daily Jewel: Sportmax
text: These metal crescent earrings perfectly complemented Sportmax’s sculptural fall collection — as they would almost any outfit.

headline: Boston Suburb Bars Filming at Site of Post-Marathon Shootout
text: The makers of a movie about the Boston Marathon bombing have scrapped plans to film the traumatic shootout scenes on location in Watertown, Mass., because the town has decided not to cooperate.

headline: The Cases for Public Investment
text: One of the annoying aspects of the Sanders/Friedman flap was the assumption of many Sanders supporters that anyone who doesn’t accept extravagant economic projections is against a big program of public investment. Actually, it was destructive as well as annoying; aside from being an insult to progressive economists who believe in infrastructure but also believe in arithmetic, it created at least the possibility that other people would take the crash-and-burn of a particular piece of analysis as evidence that the whole case for spending more is wrong.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Marco de Vincenzo, Etro and Versace in Pictures
text: A photo diary of the fall/winter 2016 collections that were presented Friday.

headline: In ‘Good Old Days,’ Donald Trump Says,  Campaign Protesters Got More Than Just an Escort Out
text: OKLAHOMA CITY — The crowd at Donald J. Trump’s rally here Friday night quickly began booing the young protester clad in the “KKK supports Trump” T-shirt, who was escorted from the event.

headline: Jil Sander: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Jil Sander’s take on fall 2016.

headline: Violence in Syria Abates on Day 1 of Cease-Fire
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Violence significantly decreased in much of northern and western Syria on Saturday, the first day of a truce brokered by the United States and Russia, even amid reports of scattered violations, including incidents of bombing, shelling and at least one aerial attack.

headline: Variety: Diagramless Puzzle
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — Are you one of those D.I.Y.ers, someone who would rather build something yourself than be content with a mass-produced object? Have we got a variety puzzle for you.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: Curtain Call Remembered Fondly

headline: Warren Buffett, in Annual Letter, Rejects Candidates’ Message of U.S. Decline
text: Warren E. Buffett took aim on Saturday at the “negative drumbeat” of this year’s presidential campaign, saying that the view that children today would not live as well as their parents was “dead wrong.”

headline: FIFA, Knowing Prosecutors Are Watching, Makes Some Changes
text: ZURICH — Soccer’s governing body used an election on Friday to try to break with the past. FIFA chose a new president, the Swiss administrator Gianni Infantino, while approving reforms intended to overhaul the multibillion-dollar organization that the American authorities said last year was overrun with criminals.

headline: Early Results Show Reformists and Moderates Drawing Votes in Iran Elections
text: TEHRAN — Preliminary results released Saturday in Iran indicated that reformist and moderate candidates were set to expand their influence after two important elections, state news media quoted the Interior Ministry as saying.

headline: Warren Buffett Vows to Stick to Friendly Strategy, Rebuffing Activism
text: Activist investors may be on the rise and takeover efforts may have become more aggressive, but Warren E. Buffett is committed to a strategy he has pursued for the better part of 51 years.

headline: What It’s Really Like to Risk It All in Silicon Valley
text: Before Nathalie Miller decided to walk away from Instacart, the grocery delivery start-up now worth more than $2 billion, she made a spreadsheet to analyze how much money she was leaving on the table.

headline: Disney Introduces Demand-Based Pricing at Theme Parks
text: LOS ANGELES — For the first time, tickets to Walt Disney World in Florida and Disneyland in California will cost more during holidays and some weekends — up to 20 percent more — than during slower periods, as the bursting-at-the-seams parks seek to spread out demand.

headline: Ensconced in Family, Top Prospect Tries to Grow Into a Man, and a Met
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — In the fall of 2013, after the Mets selected Dominic Smith out of high school with the 11th overall pick in the first round and gave him a $2.6 million contract, one of his first big purchases was a new six-bedroom, five-bathroom home in a gated community here. It was about 10 minutes from the Mets’ spring training facility, and it was big enough that his mother, two siblings and a young nephew could live with him. Smith was only 18, after all.

headline: I.R.S. Calling to Demand Cash? Don’t Pay Up. Hang Up.
text: A tax adviser in Orlando, Fla., named Craig Smalley received a call about 10 months ago from a panicked client. Someone from the I.R.S. had just phoned, she said, to say a warrant for her arrest had been issued for failure to pay back taxes.

headline: Lindsey Vonn Suffers Hairline Fracture to Knee
text: Lindsey Vonn, the American skier who is leading the overall World Cup standings as part of a spectacular comeback season, sustained a hairline fracture of her left knee Saturday during a high-speed crash in a super-G race at Soldeu-el Tarter, Andorra.

headline: Republican Candidates Deeply Entrenched Against Gun Controls
text: Realistically, no one studying politics should have expected the remaining Republican presidential contenders to speak up at their latest debate about the nation’s harrowing problem of mass shootings.

headline: The Sad Demise of the Summer Job
text: President Obama touched on a national crisis last week when he called on business leaders to help connect young people with summer jobs that give them not just money, but also valuable work experience. Private companies can help. But they are hesitant to hire inexperienced applicants at a time when seasoned, middle-aged workers who lost good jobs during the recession are desperate for any work. The only solution to youth unemployment is for Congress to reinstate some version of the summer jobs program it abandoned in the late 1990s.

headline: Abdifatah Mohamud: Captain of the Call Center
text: Abdifatah Mohamud, 30, is a supervisor for Alliance Data Systems in Columbus, Ohio.

headline: That Coke Can Is Back
text: HOLLYWOOD — THEY were dramas that drilled into the most sensitive parts of the national psyche, searing and dividing us with lurid sexual images and racial grievances as old as the nation.

headline: If Donald Trump Changed Genders
text: IMAGINE, for a moment, the presidential candidacy of a rich, brash real estate magnate and reality TV star named Donna Trump.

headline: Showdown on Abortion at the Supreme Court
text: The decades-long crusade to end legal abortion in America after Roe v. Wade has again reached the Supreme Court.

headline: From Obama to Trump
text: THE spectacle of the Republican Party’s Trumpian meltdown has inspired a mix of glee and fear among liberals — glee over their rivals’ self-immolation, and fear that what arises from the destruction will be worse.

headline: Who Are the Gay Evangelicals?
text: THE anti-gay ideology that has long held sway in American evangelicalism seems to be crumbling. Conservatives’ insistence that the Bible proscribes homosexual acts and their claim that protecting gay rights infringes on their own religious liberty have depended on another assumption not found in Scripture: that homosexuality is not a biologically rooted identity but a sinful temptation, an addiction that one must control.

headline: Why Courts Shouldn’t Ignore the Facts About Abortion Rights
text: At the core of the most important Supreme Court abortion case in a generation is a series of questions about facts. In deciding the constitutionality of a law that would shut down most abortion clinics in a state in the name of protecting women’s health, which facts about the law’s rationale and its impact may a court consider? Which facts must a court consider? Are there facts a court must ignore entirely?

headline: The Killing Field
text: LEER, South Sudan — THE killing field on the edge of town is marked by skulls and bones littering the ground, attracting vultures and hyenas.

headline: Deniz Gamze Erguven
text: Deniz Gamze Erguven is a Turkish-French filmmaker whose debut film, “Mustang,” has been nominated for an Academy Award for best foreign language film.

headline: Trigger Warnings
text: ACCIDENTAL gun deaths are not all that common, but stories about them are.

headline: What Prodigies Could Teach Us About Autism
text: MANY parents remember a moment when their toddler astounded them. Maybe he outpaced his playgroup at mastering a song. Maybe she knew an esoteric fact about outer space. They might quietly wonder: Is my child a prodigy?

headline: Even When Shots Miss, Intentionally Fouling May Not Pay Off
text: Every time a poor free-throw shooter is fouled intentionally, it seems to reopen the debate about whether the N.B.A. should take action against the strategy.

headline: What Women Find in Friends That They May Not Get From Love
text: SARA and I met as office drones in 1999. We became friends in a period of our lives when the demands of our jobs were just heating up, when the roots we were putting down in the city were just getting deep. In each other, we found respite, recognition, a shared eagerness to relax, take stock and talk about it all.

headline: Early Tallies Show Irish Voters Rejecting Government
text: DUBLIN — Early results in Ireland’s general election indicated Saturday that voters had firmly rejected the center-right government, but it remained unclear if any party will have enough seats in Parliament to form a government.

headline: Davis Cup Returns to a Scene of Its Grassy Past
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — It will be the United States versus Australia in the first round of Davis Cup this week at Kooyong Stadium.

headline: The Wrong Way to Teach Math
text: HERE’S an apparent paradox: Most Americans have taken high school mathematics, including geometry and algebra, yet a national survey found that 82 percent of adults could not compute the cost of a carpet when told its dimensions and square-yard price. The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development recently tested adults in 24 countries on basic “numeracy” skills. Typical questions involved odometer readings and produce sell-by tags. The United States ended an embarrassing 22nd, behind Estonia and Cyprus. We should be doing better. Is more mathematics the answer?

headline: Don’t Call Me the ‘Black Seth Rogen’
text: Los Angeles — YEARS ago, I was in a cast in what’s called a “network showcase.” Hollywood does tons of these types of showcase shows. The networks bring in young actors to create material and perform for agents, managers and casting directors. The goal is to get actors signed or brought in for auditions for pilots and eventually to create a star.

headline: Fixing the Iraq Mess
text: Readers discuss a letter from a retired Marine colonel about the need to pursue a “managed breakup” of Iraq and what America’s role should be.

headline: Marco Rubio on Day 3 of Trump Offensive: ‘He Should Sue Whoever Did That to His Face’
text: KENNESAW, Ga. – Senator Marco Rubio of Florida, his momentum seemingly stunted by Gov. Chris Christie’s endorsement of Donald J. Trump, said Saturday that he would not stop ridiculing Mr. Trump as he tries to capitalize on  fears among Republicans about the businessman’s candidacy.

headline: Ask Your Doctor if This Ad Is Right for You
text: A LITTLE more than a decade ago, most health care advertising was confined to mass-market drugs, and hospitals and doctors generally considered the practice tacky or ethically dubious. More often than not, the ads appeared in unassuming places like cheaper women’s magazines or the New York subway — for decades New Yorkers sat beneath ubiquitous rainbow posters for Dr. Jonathan Zizmor that promised to conquer blemishes: 212-594-SKIN!

headline: Talk Grows About Who Will Succeed Palestinians’ Fading Mahmoud Abbas
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank — The past five months of Palestinian attacks on Israeli Jews have undermined the already weak political position of Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian president, who rules ineffectively over a divided people and failing institutions.

headline: John Kasich Says If He Doesn’t Win Ohio, He’s Going Home
text: NASHVILLE — Facing pressure to leave the presidential race, Gov. John Kasich on Saturday singled out next month’s primary in his home state of Ohio as a make-or-break moment for his campaign.

headline: Sam Beall, Farm-to-Table Restaurateur Right on His Farm, Dies at 39
text: Sam Beall, who turned Blackberry Farm, his parents’ country inn in Walland, Tenn., into a national destination for fine dining and a leader in the farm-to-table culinary movement, died on Thursday in Vail, Colo. He was 39.

headline: Wesley A. Clark, Who Designed First Personal Computer, Dies at 88
text: Wesley A. Clark, a physicist who designed the first modern personal computer, died on Monday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 88.

headline: Baffling the Yankees: A Select Group
text: Dallas Keuchel of the Houston Astros dominated the Yankees last year, defeating them three times. We take a closer look at those games as well as a list of other pitchers who have managed to confound the Yankees.

headline: Guile Sharpens Perpetual Thorn in Yankees’ Side
text: KISSIMMEE, Fla. — He stifled the Yankees in the summer, eliminated them in the fall, haunted them in the winter and looms over them in the spring. Even when he visited New York in January, the city stood still for Dallas Keuchel.

headline: Zack Wheeler’s Warm-Up Commands a Stage
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — As the other Mets pitchers scattered to take part in various drills Saturday morning, Zack Wheeler reported to a relatively empty bullpen area. Standing on the slope of the mound, not even on the rubber, he made about 10 throws, as if simply warming up.

headline: No Trouble Seen in Brooklyn Home Where Fire Killed Girl, 2
text: The anonymous calls to the New York State child abuse hotline claimed that Kalenah Muldrow’s mother was not taking care of her young daughter: Their home was squalid, the callers said, and lacking adequate food. In the most recent call, on Feb. 15, the caller raised concerns that Kalenah was being left with people other than her mother for extended periods of time.

headline: Strangers Extend a Helping Hand to Struggling New Yorkers
text: For Margaret Macaluso, driving her sons to and from their college classes and part-time jobs requires patience and compromise. The family has only one vehicle. Fortunately, she does not mind being a chauffeur. Ever since Ms. Macaluso learned in August that she had Stage 3 ovarian cancer, she has viewed every car ride as extra time with her sons.

headline: Smiles Come, and Smiles Go. Soon, Carmelo Anthony Might Follow.
text: Carmelo Anthony was back to being the last Knick out of the shower Friday night, as opposed to being the first one through the Madison Square Garden exit, as was the case earlier in the week. Normalcy was restored. He had returned to his standard postgame speaking slot as the resident star.

headline: Neediest Cases Fund: How to Give
text: For more than 100 years, The New York Times has asked readers for contributions to its Neediest Cases Fund, to give direct assistance to troubled children, families and elders. The first year’s contributions totaled $3,630.88. The total now is about $6 million a year, and over the years the Fund has raised more than $282 million.

headline: The Strip
text: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: Court Jesters
text: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Today, Timothy Polin merges wacky definitions and sports in a crossword puzzle. Some of you might find this easier than others (and by that I mean me), especially if you are a basketball fan.

headline: Donald Trump Has Big Lead in Massachusetts, and Marco Rubio Is Distant Second, New Poll Shows
text: BOSTON — Donald J. Trump is the clear favorite among likely Republican voters in the Massachusetts primary on Tuesday, according to a poll released on Saturday by Suffolk University.

headline: With Fewer Members, a Diminished Political Role for Wisconsin Unions
text: MILWAUKEE — Gov. Scott Walker’s foray into the Republican presidential field ended months ago, but he may yet have sway over the outcome.

headline: South Carolina Primary: Highlights
text: Hillary Clinton won her first resounding victory of the race in the South Carolina primary, dealing a blow to Bernie Sanders ahead of Super Tuesday.

headline: Donald Trump, Despite Impieties, Wins Hearts of Evangelical Voters
text: OKLAHOMA CITY — It is one of the prime paradoxes of the 2016 election: A twice-divorced candidate who has flaunted his adultery, praised Planned Parenthood and admitted to never asking for God’s forgiveness is the favorite of the Christian right.

headline: Female Pilot Unit Gains Support in Congress for Right to Arlington Burials
text: SILVER SPRING, Md. — Shortly after Elaine D. Harmon died last April at the age of 95, her family found a letter in a fireproof box with explicit instructions: She wanted her ashes placed at Arlington National Cemetery.

headline: Assassination of Putin Critic Remembered in Moscow
text: MOSCOW — Tens of thousands of people flooded the streets of central Moscow on Saturday, joining a solemn march to commemorate the anniversary of the assassination of Boris Y. Nemtsov, a Russian opposition leader.

headline: C.D.C. Urges Pregnant Women to Avoid Travel to Olympics Over Zika Fears
text: Health officials in the United States have advised pregnant women who are scheduled to attend the Olympic Games in Brazil to reconsider their plans because of the Zika virus epidemic.

headline: Scientists Protest Cuts and Commercialization at Australian Climate Center
text: SYDNEY, Australia — Perched on a wild, windy promontory on the rugged tip of northwestern Tasmania, the tiny Cape Grim research station has been measuring airborne greenhouse gases since 1976.

headline: Monarch Butterfly Migration Rebounds, Easing Some Fears
text: MEXICO CITY — After years of being ravaged by severe weather and shrinking habitats, the monarch butterflies hibernating in the Mexican mountains rebounded last year, kindling cautious hope that one of the insect world’s most captivating migrations may yet survive.

headline: South Carolina Exit Polls
text: Surveys of Democratic voters exiting voting locations throughout South Carolina on Saturday.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Winning Numbers in South Carolina Suggest Sweep in South
text: After winning South Carolina’s Democratic primary eight years ago, Senator Barack Obama declared that “after four great contests, we have the most votes, the most delegates, and have the broadest coalition for change.” Tonight it is his former opponent, Hillary Clinton, who can now make the same claim.

headline: Italy Growers Wary of Olive Oil Fraud as New Law Is Weighed
text: BLERA, Italy — For some of the 300 olive growers who toil here in the rolling hills of the Lazio region, making olive oil is a year-round labor of love.

headline: Ex-Official Calls for Malaysian Prime Minister to Step Down
text: BANGKOK — A prominent member of the governing coalition in Malaysia who has been removed from a top party job lashed back on Saturday with a strongly worded Facebook post saying he had seen “proof” that Prime Minister Najib Razak committed a crime in his dealings with the country’s sovereign wealth fund.

headline: Yemeni Civilians Killed by Airstrike on Market, Witnesses Say
text: SANA, Yemen — A United States-backed Arab military coalition bombed a busy market north of Yemen’s capital early Saturday, killing at least 30 people, witnesses said.

headline: Donald Trump Returns Ire Against His Latest Enemies: New York’s Attorney General and ‘Little Rubio’
text: Donald J. Trump suggested Saturday a lawsuit filed against him by the New York attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, over his Trump University was part of a conspiracy involving President Obama.

headline: Marco Rubio and Donald Trump Open New Fronts in War of Playground Insults
text: In a campaign season without peer in insult tragicomedy, consider Saturday’s candidate-on-candidate exchanges:

headline: Marco Rubio Pushed for Immigration Reform With Conservative Media
text: A few weeks after Senator Marco Rubio joined a bipartisan push for an immigration overhaul in 2013, he arrived alongside Senator Chuck Schumer at the executive dining room of News Corporation’s Manhattan headquarters for dinner.

headline: What Hillary Clinton’s South Carolina Win Means
text: Hillary Clinton notched her first big primary victory in South Carolina’s contest on Saturday, with exit polls suggesting an even bigger win than Barack Obama’s 29-point victory over her in 2008.

headline: A Bolivian Town’s Emergence Under Evo Morales
text: Residents of Cobija, which has prospered under ​President​ Morales, expect his leftist policies to survive his political departure.

headline: Bolivian Town Drifts From President Evo Morales, Despite Promises Kept to Left
text: COBIJA, Bolivia — When Evo Morales, Bolivia’s first indigenous president, took office a decade ago, he vowed to put this impoverished town in the Amazon Basin on the kind of pedestal often reserved for a capital city.

headline: A Famous Voice Praises Hillary Clinton as a Voice for Blacks
text: It is a choir of two, singing for millions. “She says their names,” Morgan Freeman intones, and Hillary Clinton’s voice, clipped from the campaign trail, seems to blend in with his: “Trayvon Martin,” they both say. “Shot to death,” says Mrs. Clinton, as pictures of victims of police brutality, and their grieving mourners, flash on screen. Dontre Hamilton: “Unarmed,” she says. “Sandra Bland did nothing wrong,” she says. Mr. Freeman drives home the point: Mrs. Clinton “makes their mothers’ fight for justice her own.”

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Legacy in Libya
text: As the secretary of state in 2011, Hillary Clinton pressed the Obama administration to intervene militarily in Libya, with consequences that have gone far beyond the fall of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

headline: Three Stabbed at Ku Klux Klan Rally in Southern California
text: Five people were injured at a Ku Klux Klan rally in Southern California on Saturday when protesters attacked members of the white supremacist group, the police said, unleashing chaos on a popular park and leaving three people with stab wounds.

headline: Hillary Clinton, ‘Smart Power’ and a Dictator’s Fall
text: By the time Mahmoud Jibril cleared customs at Le Bourget airport and sped into Paris, the American secretary of state had been waiting for hours. But this was not a meeting Hillary Clinton could cancel. Their encounter could decide whether America was again going to war.

headline: A New Libya, With ‘Very Little Time Left’
text: It was a grisly start to the new era for Libya, broadcast around the world. The dictator was dragged from the sewer pipe where he was hiding, tossed around by frenzied rebel soldiers, beaten bloody and sodomized with a bayonet. A shaky cellphone video showed the pocked face of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, “the Leader” who had terrified Libyans for four decades, looking frightened and bewildered. He would soon be dead.

headline: In Their Own Words: The Libya Tragedy
text: Architects of the Libyan intervention lament its aftermath.

headline: Marco Rubio PAC Unleashes Its Ad Playbook Against Donald Trump
text: In New Hampshire, Gov. Chris Christie felt the full force of the “super PAC” supporting Senator Marco Rubio: It ran two negative television ads, printed mailers, made digital display ads and ran two separate websites against Mr. Christie that meshed with the broadcast ads.

headline: Jessica Hendricks, Patrick Yee
text: Jessica Ann Hendricks,a daughter of Dawn E. Hendricks and Charles H. Hendricks of Larchmont, N.Y., was married Feb. 27 to Patrick Wei-Bun Yee, a son of Anna Yee and Bing Yee of Lexington, Mass. Cantor Fran Chalin officiated at Casa de Monte Vista, a vacation resort and event space in Palm Springs, Calif.

headline: Emily Eyerman, Gregory Schneider

headline: Jennifer Piro and Michael Balkin: A Match Backed by Experience and Data
text: Jennifer Beth Piro and Michael Golding Balkin were married Feb. 27 in Scarsdale, N.Y. The ceremony, at the Rowsley Estate, the headquarters of the Scarsdale Woman’s Club, was led by two friends of the couple who became Universal Life ministers for the event. Jessica H. Hirschey legally solemnized the couple’s New York City marriage certificate and led the couple in their exchange of rings; Jacob Condon led the couple in their vows.

Guffanti of Manahawkin, N.J. The Rev. Jim Sexton, who was ordained by the One Spirit Interfaith Seminary, officiated at Gedney Farm in New Marlborough, Mass.

Koskoff and Robert D. Morris, both of Rochester. E. Leo Milonas, the retired chief administrative judge of New York State in New York, is to officiate at the Garrison, an event space in Garrison, N.Y.

Cox of St. Paul. Matthew T. Nathanson, a Universal Life minister, officiated at the Royal Palms Resort and Spa in Phoenix.

Hugentobler of Paris, was married Feb. 27 to Jason Reinert Trost, a son of Roberta L. Trost and Donald C. Trost of East Lyme, Conn. Philippe Pivert, a government representative, officiated at City Hall in St-Germain-en-Laye.

headline: Amanda Grey, Stephen Wolf

headline: Erin Bevacqua, Ari Astles
text: First Lt. Erin Elizabeth Bevacqua and Ari Isaacman Astles were married Feb. 22 at the Sixth & I Historic Synagogue in Washington. Rabbi Deborah Reichmann officiated at a ceremony that incorporated Jewish and Catholic wedding traditions.

text: Lynne White and Joel Kenneth Schnell are to be married Feb. 28 at the Riverpark restaurant in Manhattan. Tony LeRoy, a Universal Life minister, is to officiate.

text: Columbia, S.C. — As the great poet Shawn Carter (aka Jay-Z) once said, “On to the next one.”

headline: Olivia Merns, Daniel Berger
text: Olivia Jonquil Merns, a daughter of Karen Benz Merns of Manhattan and the late Stephen A. Merns, was married Feb. 27 to Daniel Haines Berger, a son of Miriam J. Haines and Michael G. Berger of Manhattan. Rabbi Ethan H. Witkovsky led the ceremony at the Liberty Warehouse, an event space in Brooklyn.

headline: Jessica Crenshaw, Richard Dunne
text: Jessica Lee Crenshaw and Richard Joseph Dunne were married Feb. 26 at All Saints Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Back on the Auction Block, a 19th-Century Document Essential to Baseball’s Rules
text: When it was auctioned in 1999, a document called “Laws of Base Ball” had no known author but obvious significance.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “There is no mechanism. There is no smoke-filled room. If there is, I’ve never seen it, nor do I know anyone who has. This is going to play out in the way that it will.”

headline: Corrections: February 28, 2016
text: NATIONAL

headline: ‘Spotlight’ Wins Big at a Diverse Indie Spirits Ceremony
text: “Tonight’s nominees are more diverse than the cover of a brochure for a liberal arts college,” the wonderfully oddball comedian Kate McKinnon, of “Saturday Night Live,” told the crowd boozing it up Saturday at the Independent Spirit Awards. She would later kiss the actor Paul Dano through a mouthful (her mouthful) of ham.

headline: Overdraft Practices Continue to Gut Bank Accounts and Haunt Customers
text: Angelina Lemus was puzzled. She had no idea why every month as much as $96 was disappearing from her Citibank checking account.

text: Many young dreamers have flocked to the area with the hope of starting a successful start-up or striking it rich by joining the right company at the right time. This is what they look like.
