headline: 1916: Henry James Dies in Britain
text: LONDON — Mr. Henry James, the essayist and novelist, who became a naturalized British subject in July of last year, died to-day [Feb. 28], aged seventy-three.

headline: Your Weekend Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.

headline: The School Conference Blues
text: Middle school parent-teacher conferences are tomorrow and I can’t bring myself to think about going.

headline: Donald Trump Retweets Post With Quote From Mussolini
text: Donald J. Trump on Sunday morning used his Twitter feed to post a quote attributed to Benito Mussolini, the founder of the fascist movement, from a parody account. The tweet compared the Italian dictator to Mr. Trump, the Republican front-runner for the presidential nomination.

headline: Rainy Day Annoyance Haiku
text: Dear Diary:

headline: China Deletes Microblog of Critic of President Xi Jinping
text: BEIJING — The microblog account of an outspoken property tycoon and critic of President Xi Jinping, which had nearly 38 million followers, was deleted by China’s Internet control bureau on Sunday.

headline: Stella Jean: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Looks for next fall from Stella Jean.

headline: The Daily Shoe: Bottega Veneta
text: The sharp endpoint to Tomas Maier’s neat, fashionably restrained new lady.

headline: Philipp Plein: Just Don’t Call Him Normal
text: MILAN — “I just want to get bigger and bigger every time. It’s for my fans,” said the 38-old-year German designer Philipp Plein, the unapologetic king of nouveau riche bling. The subject was his shows.

headline: 1941: British Planes Set off 150 Fires in Cologne
text: LONDON — In the fifty-sixth raid on Cologne since the war started Royal Air Force bombers concentrated their fire on that important German manufacturing city for two and a half hours last night, dropping hundreds of high explosive and incendiary bombs. Pilots reported that 150 fires were set, and the Air Ministry termed it ‘‘a heavy and successful attack.’’

headline: At Bottega Veneta and Versace, the Soft Power Suit Also Rises
text: MILAN — On and on they came, the Versace hordes, striding out in pencil skirts and lace-up bootees and then circling left and right, tracing their way between rows, swarming the room. Donatella Versace set her show in the round, and paced it accordingly, so that at any given point wherever you looked was a streamlined silhouette, moving purposefully forward. The effect was to invert the usual runway equation: Instead of the audience surrounding the clothes, the clothes surrounded the audience. There was no escaping the import.

headline: The Daily Bag: Jil Sander
text: Jil Sander’s designer gets the modern working woman: This season’s practical purses in drab neutrals — especially this one little black bag, with a twist — seem made for the ever-on-the-go minimalist.

headline: The Daily Jewel: Bottega Veneta
text: When almost all the models in Bottega Veneta’s fall show have long scarves wrapped around their necks, it’s nearly impossible not be pulled in by this multistrand necklace worn by only two. It was styled for daytime, but looks just right for evening wear — and spring, summer and winter too.

headline: Marni’s Old Hollywood Beauty
text: “Amazing” is how the makeup artist Tom Pecheux, laughing just a bit, described the look he created for Marni’s fall show today. The designer Consuelo Castiglioni pointed to the 1940 black-and-white film “Rebecca” as a spark for the new collection, and the movie’s dramatic lighting and silver-screen glamour were translated into a classic Hollywood look: pale skin, intense lips, waves of hair set about the face — all thrown a little off-balance.

headline: What Happened to the Great Divergence?
text: That’s the title of a very interesting speech by Lael Brainard of the Fed, who has been warning for a while that international finance — in particular, the importation of overseas weakness via the strong dollar — made the case for rate hikes very dubious. Now she expands on that theme:

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Bottega Veneta and Jil Sander in Pictures
text: A photo diary of the fall/winter 2016 collections that were presented Saturday.

headline: Three’s a Trend: Leopard Coats
text: This season, as ever, the timeless animal print is back — on coats at Bottega Veneta, Prada and No. 21. The common denominator: a strong lapel (and heavy dose of attitude).

headline: A Former Calvin Klein Underwear Model Ages, if Only in a Leap Year
text: Antonio Sabato Jr. remembers unveiling the huge photograph on a billboard in Times Square in 1996 — the 90-foot-tall image of him with a defiantly seductive look in his eyes and almost no clothes on, only black bikini briefs. He was Calvin Klein’s newest underwear model, and the world took him for a 20-something heartthrob.

headline: Stephen Curry Can’t Be Stopped, by Any Generation
text: Stephen Curry heard the criticism last week — that his success was due in part to a lack of legitimate perimeter defense in the N.B.A., that today’s stars do not play tough enough to stop him.

headline: Israel Museum’s Director to Make Way for Successor
text: James S. Snyder, the director of the Israel Museum in Jerusalem for 20 years, will assume the newly created role of international president for the museum’s worldwide activities next year, the museum announced on Sunday. A search will begin shortly for his successor.

headline: What to Cook This Week
text: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Donald Trump Wavers on Disavowing David Duke
text: Donald J. Trump came under fire on Sunday for declining to disavow the support of David Duke, the white nationalist and ex-Ku Klux Klansman who has called him “by far the best candidate.”

headline: In Iran Elections, Conflicting Forecasts Emerge Along Rival Lines
text: TEHRAN — A day after results in the capital showed a landslide victory for reformist and moderate allies of President Hassan Rouhani in Iran’s parliamentary elections, state television on Sunday reported a nationwide triumph for hard-liners.

headline: After Tense Weeks, Melissa Harris-Perry’s MSNBC Show Is Canceled
text: It all began to unravel for Melissa Harris-Perry four weeks ago.

headline: MSGM: Fall 2016
text: Designs for fall 2016 from MSGM.

headline: Salvatore Ferragamo: Fall 2016
text: Salvatore Ferragamo offers its take on fall 2016.

headline: Rescue Workers and Miners Are Killed in Russia Accident
text: MOSCOW — Descending into the smoking pit of a coal mine after methane explosions set off underground fires, six rescue workers were killed on Sunday in a failed attempt to reach 26 stranded miners in northern Russia.

headline: Ondria Hardin Transforms at Marni
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall/Winter 2016 Fashion Week in Milan.

headline: Putting Donald Trump’s Promises Under Scrutiny
text: A powerful force driving Donald J. Trump and Senator Bernie Sanders in the presidential race is the frustration of grass-roots voters that politicians in Washington haven’t kept their promises.

headline: Tulsi Gabbard, Rising Democratic Star, Endorses Bernie Sanders
text: Representative Tulsi Gabbard, Democrat of Hawaii, resigned as a vice chairwoman of the Democratic National Committee on Sunday in order to endorse Senator Bernie Sanders for president.

headline: Meg Whitman Assails Chris Christie for Backing Donald Trump
text: Meg Whitman, the Hewlett-Packard executive who was a top supporter of Gov. Chris Christie’s presidential campaign, on Sunday criticized Mr. Christie for supporting Donald J. Trump, assailing him for “political opportunism” and calling on Mr. Trump’s other supporters and donors to walk away from him.

headline: Berlin’s Museum Tours in Arabic Forge a Bridge to Refugees
text: BERLIN — The Pergamon Museum is home to the famous Ishtar Gate, a monument of blue and white tile decorated with golden lions and daisies that was once the entrance to ancient Babylon. When Kamal Alramadhani, a 25-year-old Iraqi economics student, saw it for the first time this month, “I got goose bumps,” he said, pointing to his arm.

headline: Facing the Taliban and His Past, an Afghan Leader Aims for a Different Ending
text: LASHKAR GAH, Afghanistan — When mujahedeen guerrillas captured this southern provincial capital in 1993, Gen. Abdul Jabar Qahraman was the Afghan government commander on the last flight out, surrendering the city.

headline: Netanyahu Welcomes Cease-Fire in Syria, but Adds a Warning
text: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said on Sunday that he welcomed the efforts to achieve a long-term cease-fire in Syria but warned that Israel would continue to defend its own interests there.

headline: ‘Gods of Egypt’ and ‘Eddie the Eagle’ Struggle at Box Office
text: LOS ANGELES — As Hollywood prepared to celebrate its artistic accomplishments at the Academy Awards on Sunday, three movie studios were licking box-office wounds. Arriving in wide release over the weekend and struggling were Lionsgate’s big-budget “Gods of Egypt,” 20th Century Fox’s “Eddie the Eagle” and Open Road’s “Triple 9.”

headline: Trying to Revive H.M.O.s, but Without Those Scarlet Letters
text: An H.M.O. by any other name is still an H.M.O.

headline: Academy Awards 2016: Highlights and Analysis
text: Chris Rock hosted the 88th Academy Awards in Hollywood. “Spotlight” won best picture and Leonardo DiCaprio finally secured an Oscar for his performance in “The Revenant.”

headline: Rangers Trade for Eric Staal, Hurricanes’ Captain
text: Five months after signing a seven-year, $57.75 million contract extension, center Eric Staal beat Martin Brodeur with a wrist shot with 31.7 seconds remaining in regulation to lift the Carolina Hurricanes over the stunned Devils in Game 7 of a first-round playoff series in 2009.

headline: Report Cites Dangers of Autonomous Weapons
text: A new report written by a former Pentagon official who helped establish United States policy on autonomous weapons argues that such weapons could be uncontrollable in real-world environments where they are subject to design failure as well as hacking, spoofing and manipulation by adversaries.

headline: Missoni: Fall 2016 RTW
text: Angela Missoni’s vision for fall 2016.

headline: Oscars 2016: Chris Rock Scores and ‘Spotlight’ Takes Center Stage
text: LOS ANGELES — In a ceremony that became a raucous diversity lesson under the guidance of its host, Chris Rock, “Spotlight,” a newspaper drama about the Roman Catholic Church cover-up of sexual abuse by priests, snatched top honors at the 88th Academy Awards on Sunday. It beat out “The Revenant,” which had been widely viewed as the favorite, but which nevertheless earned a best actor prize for Leonardo DiCaprio, his first Oscar, and a best director award for Alejandro G. Iñárritu.

headline: Review: ‘Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon: Sword of Destiny,’ a Fight-Ridden Sequel
text: When “Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon” opened in 2000, it carried surprises: that Ang Lee, a director known for high-minded literary adaptations, could make such a vibrant and exciting martial-arts movie, and that a Chinese-language film could be a box-office hit in America.

headline: Review: ‘Battle for the Airwaves,’ a Rock ’n’ Roll History
text: Several rows of empty seats at Saturday evening’s opening performance of the 92nd Street Y’s Lyrics & Lyricists series suggested the lingering hostility of older patrons toward rock ’n’ roll. Some cultural conflicts never end. And the program, “Battle for the Airwaves,” hosted by the actor and singer James Naughton, rekindled memories of a time when the ascent of Elvis Presley was regarded by popular music’s old guard as a nothing less than a barbarian invasion.

headline: Review: ‘The Heart’ Offers Portraits in the Race to an Organ Transplant
text: Why are hospitals so rarely the settings for works of serious contemporary fiction? There are exceptions to this rule — Abraham Verghese’s “Cutting for Stone” comes to mind — but not many, which is strange, given that we’re at our most vulnerably human once we’ve burst through those automated doors, either wretched from grief or ecstatic from relief, release, new life.

headline: 3 Killed and 2 Injured in Hit-and-Run Crashes Across New York City
text: Three people were killed and two were injured on Sunday in separate collisions across New York City in which pedestrians and a cyclist were hit by motorists who fled the scene, the police said. No arrests had been made, and each of the five episodes remained under investigation.

headline: Only Separation Can Lead to a Two-State Solution
text: Jerusalem — The Israeli-Palestinian conflict in its post-1967 incarnation has been raging for nearly 49 years, with no solution in sight. Several Israeli prime ministers, including Ehud Barak and Ehud Olmert, made great efforts to reach a permanent agreement, only for the Palestinians to decline, while Ariel Sharon’s unilateral withdrawal from Gaza was met not by peace and quiet, but by rockets and terror tunnels. The terror wave of recent months, in which Israeli civilians have been victims of stabbings, shootings and car attacks, has further eroded the faith of Israeli moderates in the prospects of attaining peace.

headline: Donald Trump Elicits Shock and Biting Satire in European Media
text: LONDON — He has been depicted as a snarling demagogue in France, equated with Donald Duck in Spain, and described as worse than Lord Voldemort in Britain.

headline: See That Billboard? It May See You, Too
text: Pass a billboard while driving in the next few months, and there is a good chance the company that owns it will know you were there and what you did afterward.

headline: Review: In ‘Pow,’ Keely Garfield Combines Tough and Awkward
text: After 30 years of making dances, Keely Garfield has found a way to wake herself up. The trigger was a Zen koan, a kind of riddle: “How is it when the tree withers and the leaves fall?” the student asks. The master replies, “Body exposed in the golden wind.”

headline: Lil Yachty, Lil Uzi Vert and Playboi Carti, Oddball Rap’s Children, at Play
text: In the way that the Internet has scrambled pretty much everything, it has remade the textbook of oddball rap. For this generation, the tree of influence is short and irregularly shaped: Soulja Boy for self-started, Internet-driven fame; ASAP Rocky and the rest of the ASAP Mob for flamboyance and for eradicating regional loyalty; Chief Keef for the disassembly of traditional ideas about verse structure; Young Thug for radiant weirdness and genuine indifference.

headline: Review: Pacific Northwest Ballet Plays With Limits and Dystopia at City Center
text: During intermission at City Center on Friday, some fragments of distressed conversation floated my way. “Where’s the danger?” one audience member asked another. After watching David Dawson’s “A Million Kisses to My Skin,” the first work on Pacific Northwest Ballet’s “Contemporary Innovators” program, I was wondering the same.

headline: Viceland, a New Cable Channel, Aims to Stand Out
text: Vice Media’s march toward world domination of news and lifestyle coverage for the 18-to-34 demographic continues at 6 a.m. Monday with the introduction of Viceland, a new cable channel inhabiting the slot formerly occupied by H2 (in the 70 million homes where H2 had a slot). It further expands Vice’s already-substantial efforts in video programming, joining the company’s highly popular online library and a documentary series, “Vice,” on HBO.

headline: Finding Beauty in Georg Friedrich Haas’s Darkness
text: Was that a frisson of tension that ran through the audience at the start of Friday’s concert at the Bohemian National Hall when the composer Georg Friedrich Haas took the microphone and said he had an “uncomfortable announcement” to make? After all, Mr. Haas had jolted some readers earlier that week when he spoke openly to The New York Times about “devilish desires,” his interest in playing with pain and the happiness he has found in his fourth marriage, which is based on a dominant-submissive power exchange.

headline: Start-Up Lessons From the Once-Again Hot Field of A.I.
text: In 2010, Kris Hammond, an experienced artificial intelligence researcher, and a few partners founded Narrative Science. The Chicago start-up’s software ingests and interprets numbers for things like investment holdings, billing records and sports statistics and transforms them into written summaries or stories.

headline: Obama’s Tangled History With Supreme Court Sets Stage for Nominee Fight
text: WASHINGTON — The first time President Obama sat down to pick a new Supreme Court justice, surprised aides discovered that he had gone beyond the briefing memos to read the leading candidate’s past judicial rulings. The president, a onetime constitutional law teacher, was in his element, a “legal nerd,” as one aide called him, putting theory into practice.

headline: Why a Push for Online Privacy Is Bogged Down in Washington
text: In February 2012, the White House introduced a blueprint for the Consumer Privacy Bill of Rights, intended to give Americans the ability to exercise control over what personal details companies collected from them and how the data was used.

headline: The Promise of Artificial Intelligence Unfolds in Small Steps
text: When IBM’s Watson computer triumphed over human champions in the quiz show “Jeopardy!” it was a stunning achievement that suggested limitless horizons for artificial intelligence.

headline: February 29, 2016
text: MONDAY PUZZLE — This is a special year, as 2016 has an extra day in the month of February which, to most people is a fun and lovely thing. To me, it’s just an extra day of winter, but if you happen to celebrate a birthday or anniversary on Feb. 29 and you’ve waited four years for this, happy day to you.

headline: Democrats Fight for Young Voters in Massachusetts Primary
text: WELLESLEY, Mass. — Here among the historic brick towers and wooded hills of Hillary Clinton’s alma mater, Wellesley Students for Hillary has a robust campus organization. But so has Wellesley Students for Bernie.

headline: Hillary Clinton Holds Eight-Point Edge Over Bernie Sanders in Massachusetts
text: A poll on released Sunday shows Hillary Clinton having an advantage of eight percentage points over Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont in the Massachusetts Democratic primary on Tuesday.

headline: Hillary Clinton Vows to Tackle ‘Systemic Racism’
text: MEMPHIS —A day after black voters delivered Hillary Clinton an overwhelming victory in the South Carolina primary, she spoke at two black churches here, vowing to “tackle the continuing challenge of systemic racism” and denouncing the leading Republican candidate’s ubiquitous slogan.

headline: Al Sharpton Berates Hollywood and Urges Oscar Protests
text: LOS ANGELES — “Clorox could not have made it any whiter.”

headline: Slide Show: Oscars 2016 Red Carpet
text: This is it: the red carpet to end all red carpets (until the Tonys, that is).

headline: Oscars Red Carpet 2016: See the Stylish Celebrities Arrive
text: Well, this is it: the denouement of countless other awards shows, red carpet watches and weeks (make that months) of who-will-wear-what designer speculation. Check out our slide show in which we open the envelope, if you will, for those answers.

headline: Two Bombings Kill Dozens at a Baghdad Market
text: Dozens of people were killed Sunday in two bombings at a crowded market in a Shiite neighborhood of Baghdad, the police said. The Islamic State claimed responsibility for the attacks.

headline: With Humility, Starbucks Will Enter Italian Market
text: MILAN — Standing in the art-soaked splendor of a Milanese parlor as an array of A-list Italian business leaders listened intently, Howard D. Schultz, chairman and chief executive of Starbucks, recited a remarkable statistic on Friday: Each week, roughly 90 million people pass through a Starbucks somewhere on earth.

headline: Wanted: Supreme Court Nominee. Must Not Bruise Easily
text: WASHINGTON — Would you apply for a job when the application process includes attacks so vicious that your spouse weeps and the hiring committee has already announced that it won’t even consider you for the position?

headline: Jeff Sessions, Virulent Opponent to 2013 Immigration Bill, Endorses Donald Trump
text: MADISON, Ala. — Donald J. Trump unveiled his first Senate endorsement at a rally here Sunday night, bringing Senator Jeff Sessions of Alabama up onstage with him and praising him as “really the expert as far as I’m concerned on borders.”

headline: Administration Protests Limits on Its Power to Fill Vacancies
text: WASHINGTON — A federal appeals court ruling that limits the president’s power to appoint officials to temporarily run federal agencies when high-level government jobs become vacant has prompted growing concerns among Obama administration officials.

headline: Bernie Sanders Stands Alone as Hillary Clinton Gains Senate Endorsements
text: Join us for live updates and analysis of Super Tuesday.

headline: A Change at Second Base for the Mets, but Only a Slight One
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The Mets would not have reached the World Series without Daniel Murphy. His joy ride through the National League playoffs, when he belted seven homers in nine games and hit .421, was every hitter’s dream.

headline: Sanders and His Son in a 1980s Show
text: In 1987, Levi Sanders was a guest on his father's television program, which he produced as mayor of Burlington, Vt.

headline: Levi Sanders in 2001 Documentary
text: Levi Sanders was an assistant manager at the Burlington Emergency Food Shelf when he was interviewed for the 2001 documentary “People Like Us: Social Class in America.”

headline: In Long Political Career, Sanders Relies on Son as a Constant Witness
text: When Bernie Sanders first raised his hand to run for office, his towheaded 2-year-old, Levi, was there, sitting on his lap.

headline: A Chilean Ex-Soldier Guiltily Recalls His Unit’s Atrocities
text: SANTIAGO, Chile — The scene has haunted Guillermo Padilla for over 40 years.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Feb. 29
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: ‘Vinyl’ Season 1, Episode 3: Rock Star Karaoke
text: “Vinyl” isn’t the first TV show to fill out its cast of characters with a parade of real-life music stars from the past: “American Dreams,” for example, which ran on NBC from 2002 to 2005, was centered on the 1960s era of Dick Clark’s music program “American Bandstand,” and included modern singers impersonating older ones (John Legend as Stevie Wonder, Usher as Marvin Gaye, Jennifer Love Hewitt as Nancy Sinatra). When a show pulls off this stunt, it can bring the past and the present into a dialogue — when it fails, it can feel like one long Halloween episode. “Vinyl” hasn’t carved any pumpkins yet, but I worry that the show has a jumbo bag of fun-size Nestle Crunch stashed in the pantry.

headline: Once Upon a Greek Island, Migrants and Tourists
text: It’s hard to imagine enjoying a holiday getaway in an area rife with suffering. But it happens all the time, and not just in the developing world where verdant, gated resorts exist not far from impoverished shantytowns. Consider the Greek island of Lesbos, where sunbathers laze by azure waters while not too far away boats arrive daily full of families fleeing violence in Syria and other hot spots.

headline: Planet on the Ballot
text: We now have a pretty good idea who will be on the ballot in November: Hillary Clinton, almost surely (after the South Carolina blowout, prediction markets give her a 96 percent probability of securing her party’s nomination), and Donald Trump, with high likelihood (currently 80 percent probability on the markets). But even if there’s a stunning upset in what’s left of the primaries, we already know very well what will be at stake — namely, the fate of the planet.

headline: H.I.V.’s Toll on Black and Latino Men
text: There is encouraging news in the fight against H.I.V in the United States: Over all, fewer people are contracting the virus, which causes AIDS. But H.I.V. continues to take a devastating toll on men who have sex with men, particularly among African-Americans and Latinos. If current rates persist, one in every six men who has sex with men will become infected with H.I.V., the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said last week in its first lifetime risk analysis. One out of every two black men and one out of every four Latino men in this segment of the population is projected to become infected.

headline: ‘I’m Not a Super Predator’
text: Days before Hillary Clinton thundered to an overwhelming victory over rival Bernie Sanders in South Carolina — largely on the strength of black voters who supported her by an even higher percentage than they supported Barack Obama with in 2008 — a young, proudly queer, black activist, Ashley Williams, was in Charlotte, N.C., plotting an action that would make a statement of its own.

headline: From ‘Je Suis Charlie’ to Attacks on Free Speech
text: After the murderous attack on the offices of the satirical French magazine Charlie Hebdo in January 2015, “Je suis Charlie” became a rallying cry in France and across much of Europe in support of free speech and freedom of expression. It is a sad and depressing sequel to that display of solidarity that so many European nations seem willing today to curtail those same freedoms in the name of fighting terrorism.

headline: Clinton, Sanders and the Fight Over Obama’s Legacy
text: Picture a largely unknown, black first-term senator with a surname that rhymes with “Osama,” who spent part of his childhood living in a Muslim country, crisscrossing the country calling for “revolution,” perhaps with a guy called Killer Mike in tow. Now imagine that person becoming president of the United States.

headline: The Broken System of Classifying Government Documents
text: EVERY few years, a news event demonstrates how dysfunctional, arbitrary and counterproductive the country’s system of classifying information really is. Sometimes it’s an article or book about government conduct that causes hand-wringing among intelligence officials. Sometimes it’s a prosecution under the nearly 100-year-old Espionage Act for mishandling classified information, instead of for actual spying. Now we have calls for prosecuting Hillary Clinton because, when she was secretary of state, she had documents on her private email server that have since been declared top secret.

headline: A Better, Not Bigger, Military Budget
text: Given recent history, the next president can expect to face an even more unpredictable world than the one President Obama is dealing with. Russia, China, Syria, Iran, North Korea, the Islamic State — the list of security challenges is daunting. It will require smart policy choices backed by a powerful military to protect American interests.

headline: ‘A Conversation With Latinos on Race’
text: Last year we set out to make a series of short documentaries that we hoped would foster a discussion about race relations in the United States. To date the series has focused on the personal nuances of systemic racism as reflected in the relationship between blacks and whites. And while that dynamic is a significant part of the American story of race, it does not fully reflect the country’s varied history and rapidly changing demographics. So for our next installment of our “Conversation on Race” series, we decided to go broader, and hear from Latinos on their experiences here.

headline: Student Question | Should Displays of Art Be Welcome in All Public Spaces?
text: Many public spaces such as parks are home to art such as sculpture or site-specific installations. Finding a way to bring art appreciation to the “drudgery” of commuting, for example, is behind a collaboration presented in a German subway. There are even degree programs in social practice devoted to creating and presenting communal art.

headline: Identidad y Raza: Una Conversación Entre Latinos
text: El año pasado nos propusimos hacer una serie de documentales cortos con la esperanza de fomentar una discusión acerca de las relaciones raciales en los Estados Unidos. Hasta la fecha, la serie se ha enfocado en los pormenores personales del racismo sistemático que se refleja en las relaciones entre personas blancas y negras. Mientras que esa dinámica es una parte significativa de la historia racial estadounidense, no refleja del todo la diversidad histórica y la configuración cambiante de nuestra nación. Así que para nuestra siguiente entrega de la serie “Conversaciones en torno a la raza”, decidimos ir más allá y escuchar las experiencias de los latinos de este país.

headline: ‘The Civil Wars of Julia Ward Howe,’ by Elaine Showalter
text: “It needed a very serene or a very powerful mind to resist the temptation to anger,” Virginia Woolf wrote in 1929 in an essay about 19th-century women writers. A woman might start out writing about one thing or another but, before she knew it, she’d find herself “resenting the treatment of her sex and pleading for its rights.” This was a pity, Woolf thought, and a trap she hoped women were on the verge of escaping.

headline: ‘Constance Fenimore Woolson’ and ‘Miss Grief and Other Stories’
text: If the American writer Constance Fenimore Woolson is remembered at all, it’s mostly for her dresses. And these weren’t just any ­dresses. These were the dark silk ones that, after her sudden death, Henry James presumably tried to drown in a Venetian lagoon, hurling them from his gondola and jabbing them with a pole to keep them from rising. But he failed, and to Woolson’s admirers his failure is symbolic: You can’t keep this good writer down.

headline: Trump’s Il Duce Routine

Contempt for the excesses of America is a European reflex, but when the United States seems tempted by a latter-day Mussolini, smugness in London, Paris and Berlin gives way to alarm. Europe knows that democracies can collapse.

headline: Daughter of Abe Vigoda Is Upset About Oscars ‘Memoriam’ Snub
text: The daughter of Abe Vigoda, the sad-face actor who died last month at 94 and was known for his roles in “The Godfather” and the television show “Barney Miller,” said on Monday it was wrong for her father to have been left out of the “In Memoriam” segment of the Academy Awards on Sunday night.

headline: Woman Waving Child’s Severed Head Is Arrested in Moscow
text: MOSCOW — A visibly disturbed woman was arrested on Monday after witnesses said they saw her waving the severed head of a small child outside a Moscow subway station. A Russian television network, REN TV, posted images from video that appeared to show the woman dressed in black and shouting incoherently. The Interfax news agency identified her as Gulchekhra Bobokulova, 38, a native of Uzbekistan, and said she was the child’s nanny. The child’s body was found near the subway station in an apartment that had been set on fire, the news agency said. Investigators issued a statement saying the woman had been charged with killing the child, who was 3 or 4, and that she appeared to be mentally unstable.

headline: Deepwater Horizon and Dewey & Leboeuf Cases Share Challenges
text: The explosion of the Deepwater Horizon drilling rig in the Gulf of Mexico in 2010 and the demise of venerable New York law firm Dewey & Leboeuf in 2012 could not be more different. One causing widespread pollution along with 11 deaths, while the other involved questionable accounting to keep the firm afloat as it struggled to deal with a changing marketplace.

headline: Bernie Sanders Collects $36 Million in February as Fund-Raising Successes Continue
text: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont raised more than $36 million in February and was hoping to hit the $40 million mark by the end of the day on Monday, his campaign announced.

headline: Souq, Online Retailer in Middle East, Gets a $275 Million Boost
text: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates — Souq.com, an online retailer based in the United Arab Emirates, said on Monday that it had raised $275 million from international investors. It was a vote of confidence for digital commerce in the Middle East, which has made little headway compared with elsewhere.

headline: Beyond the Red Carpet, at Giorgio Armani and Missoni
text: MILAN — It was probably always going to be anticlimactic. Stuck between the Oscars (rock) and Super Tuesday (hard place), not to mention the news that the unthinkable was happening and Starbucks was coming to Italy, there wasn’t much the final Milanese shows could do to claim people’s attention.

headline: Even as He Rises, Donald Trump Entertains Conspiracy Theories
text: It was a question that most major presidential candidates would have quickly dismissed as absurd, even offensive: What do you make of these theories that Justice Antonin Scalia was murdered?

headline: What China Has Been Building in the South China Sea
text: China has been feverishly piling sand onto reefs in the South China Sea, creating seven new islets in the region and straining already taut geopolitical tensions.

headline: 1916: Kaiser’s Goal Is Verdun
text: Despite the instructions which have been issued to the German press to diminish the importance of the attack upon Verdun and even to deny that the capture of this stronghold has been the German high command’s objective; despite also the semi-official statement published in the ‘‘Norddeutsche Allgemeine Zeitung’’ that the ‘‘object of the attack has been attained’’ and that ‘‘the present attack is not of exceptional importance’’; the Kaiser has just admitted in a telegram that his hopes, now doomed to disappointment, were centred in the capture of Verdun. — The New York Herald, European Edition, March 1, 1916

headline: Make a Plan on How to Handle Risk, Then Stick to It
text: I ski the backcountry a lot, so I pay close attention to reports of avalanches. In particular, I pay attention when a skier is caught and killed by one. This year alone there have been 20 avalanche fatalities in the United States. In January, there were nine fatalities in nine days.

headline: Donald Trump’s Conspiracy Theories
text: From hinting that Justice Antonin Scalia may have been murdered to suggesting that George W. Bush knew the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks were coming, Donald J. Trump has shared many outrageous conspiracy theories.

headline: Argentina Reaches Deal With Hedge Funds Over Debt
text: Argentina has agreed to pay $4.65 billion to four hedge funds in a deal that could put an end to more than a decade of mudslinging and legal attacks that had cut the country off from global financial markets.

headline: The Daily Jewel: Salvatore Ferragamo
text: These swinging pendulum earrings at Ferragamo were simultaneously intricate and entirely simple.

headline: The Daily Shoe: Dolce & Gabbana
text: These Cinderella shoes are a sheer delight, from their fairy-tale flowers to their blue pompoms.

headline: The Daily Bag: Marni
text: Just think of all the bangles you won’t have to wear when toting around this mini bucket bag by its oversize ring of a handle.

headline: Nicole Aragi’s Family History in a Jar
text: In her kitchen, Nicole Aragi keeps a jar of olive oil from a village in Lebanon whose name she cannot pronounce, high in the mountains above Beirut where her father was born.

headline: 8 Recipes for Now
text: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: The Pocket Watch, a Gentleman’s Best Friend
text: In the early 18th century, when a handmade pocket watch was the ultimate luxury for a gentleman, master clockmakers engineered one that could tell time at night, even after the candles had been extinguished. With the touch of a button, the divinely complex mechanism would chime a mellifluous pattern counting off the hour, and then, in increments of five, the minutes. Baume & Mercier’s new Clifton 1830 pocket watch is an updated version of that marvel, showcasing the five-minute repeater, a ‘‘complication’’ long vaunted by aficionados. The Swiss house has made just 30, set in 18-karat red gold. It makes telling time by the glaring face of a smartphone seem strangely passé.

headline: Oscar Ratings Fell, but All Eyes Are on the Academy
text: LOS ANGELES — The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences survived, just barely, Sunday’s tumultuous Oscar telecast. Overall ratings tumbled to near record lows but did not completely implode, as some movie executives had feared.

headline: At Giorgio Armani, the Romantic Side of Fall
text: When he first envisioned the beauty look for his flower-filled fall collection, Giorgio Armani drew a woman with an upswept pouf of hair and handed the sketch to the Aldo Coppola hairstylist Roberta Bellazzi. To create the look, she loaded hair with product: Elnett spray, mousse, and — she admitted sheepishly — sugar water, which turned out to be the key ingredient for what she called a “cotton candy effect.” The back of the head was pulled into a tight, upswept twist and held in place with copious amounts of micro bobby pins, while on top, hair was shaped into spirals with a curling iron and sculpted into its final fluffy form, delicately falling to one side of models’ faces.

headline: The Best and Worst of the Oscars
text: Chris Rock provoked, “Spotlight” stunned — and not every joke landed quite right. Here are some of the most memorable moments of the night.

headline: Capturing the Academy Awards — in Real Time
text: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how daily news, features and opinion pieces come together at The New York Times. Today, Craig Allen, a photo editor, describes the process behind The Times’s photographic coverage of the Academy Awards.

headline: Digital Ads for Hillary Clinton Focus on Young Women and Equal Pay
text: Two outside groups supportive of Hillary Clinton’s campaign are running their first ads as part of a multimillion dollar advertising effort hoping to energize the millennial female voting base.

headline: Fighting the Incredible Shrinking Airline Seat
text: Can plane seats get any smaller?

headline: Narendra Modi Struggles to Fulfill His Plan to Rejuvenate India
text: MUMBAI, India — A flash fire sent the star-studded audience at Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s “Make in India” convention fleeing into Mumbai’s streets last month. But that was minor compared with the political firestorm caused by his government’s arrest that same weekend of a student leader accused of participating in a university rally in support of a man put to death for a terrorist attack in India years ago.

headline: Cabbage and Potato Gratin Makes a Rich Vegetarian Meal
text: “Why is this sweet?” a friend of mine asked as he spooned a second helping of cabbage and potato gratin onto his plate.

headline: How the Supreme Court’s Decision Will Affect Access to Abortion
text: The case centers on a Texas law that has resulted in half its clinics closing.

headline: The Rajah’s Pearls
text: This week’s puzzle was suggested by Fred Gluck, a math educator who works mainly with grade-school children. I really enjoy Fred’s challenge because there’s more than one way to crack it. How many can we come up with? Let’s find out by trying on —

headline: ‘Fight the Power’ Roars Back to Relevance at the Oscars
text: As Chris Rock strolled onto the Dolby Theater stage Sunday night and prepared to lay waste to the Academy Awards, there was a hint of what was to come in the music playing in the background: Public Enemy’s “Fight the Power.”

headline: On New York’s Bustling Streets, a Soccer Megastar Roams Freely
text: To many people around the world, Andrea Pirlo is a god. As a soccer player for some of the planet’s biggest clubs, he has two Champions League trophies and six league titles. In 2006, he won the World Cup with Italy, where he has three times been player of the year, and where his nicknames include ‘‘Mozart’’ and ‘‘The Professor.’’ His 2013 autobiography, ‘‘I Think Therefore I Play,’’ was a best seller in Italy. There are social media accounts devoted entirely to his beard. A quick Google search of his name returns results like ‘‘37 Reasons Why Andrea Pirlo Is the World’s Greatest Living Human Man.’’ He has met two popes.

headline: Antico Noè Panini From Florence Now Sold in New York
text: The logo and the name of the panini shop Antico Noè, off Piazza San Pier Maggiore in Florence, Italy, came from an old mirror on the wall. It advertised an Italian vermouth, Antico Noè. Michael Grant and Vinny Dautaj, who lived in Florence and became devotees of the 71-year-old shop, have opened a New York branch with the blessing of the original’s owners. They offer 10 of the shop’s 25 panini, made on sub-style breads, white and seven grain, pressed and crisped in a press. “Finding someone to bake the bread was not easy,” Mr. Grant said. “It has very little salt and is light enough to press flat”: Antico Noè, 220 East 53rd Street, 212-750-0802, anticonoe.com.

headline: Why Liberal Massachusetts Is Poised to Give Donald Trump a Big Victory
text: It might strike some people as a misprint: Donald Trump has a giant lead in the polls heading into the Massachusetts primary on Tuesday.

headline: Sam Smith, the Only Openly Gay Oscar Winner? Not Really
text: Viewers of the 88th Academy Awards had two words for the singer Sam Smith’s performance Sunday night: off pitch.

headline: For Bronson Arroyo, a Comeback at 39 Would Be Pure Gravy
text: VIERA, Fla. — Bronson Arroyo dresses next to Lucas Giolito in the Washington Nationals’ clubhouse at spring training. Both pitchers are tall right-handers, but that is where the similarities end. Giolito was born in 1994, in the summer before Arroyo’s senior year in high school. He has not yet pitched in the major leagues. Arroyo has logged 15 seasons.

headline: Riots Erupt on Greek Border
text: Conflict on the border with Macedonia surged as the Greek government warned that as many as 70,000 people could be trapped in the country within a month.

headline: Clarence Thomas Breaks 10 Years of Silence at Supreme Court
text: WASHINGTON — Breaking a decade-long silence, Justice Clarence Thomas on Monday suddenly started asking questions from the Supreme Court bench.

headline: Nail Salon Sweeps in New York Reveal Abuses and Regulatory Challenges
text: When a New York State labor investigator entered a Long Island nail salon last July, she spotted two women sneaking out the back. The owner insisted that they did not work there.

headline: Partisan Classiness
text: Many people in the commentariat are utterly committed to the view that the two major parties are mirror images of each other, despite vast evidence to the contrary. But until Harry Enten directed me to this interesting paper by Grossman and Hopkins, I hadn’t really registered the extent to which the same assumption of symmetry is often made by political scientists. What Grossman and Hopkins do is try to document the very real differences in the two parties’ structure — not in terms of value judgments, but in terms of how they work:

headline: Clubbed Thumb’s Summerworks Festival Announces Lineup
text: Three in-demand playwrights will debut new plays at the Clubbed Thumb’s Summerworks Festival, which runs May 27-July 9 at Wild Project in Manhattan. Julia Jarcho, Ethan Lipton and Eric Dufault will join an impressive list of playwrights who have worked with this festival, which emphasizes the discovery and showcasing of rising writers.

headline: In Zimbabwe, Mugabe’s Birthday Is Rife With Political Jockeying
text: MASVINGO, Zimbabwe — The lavish annual birthday parties for President Robert G. Mugabe of Zimbabwe, who has been in power since the country gained independence in 1980, have been a stage from which he has swatted away challengers and secured his larger-than-life hold on his nation.

headline: Three’s a Trend: Vibrant Graphic Prints
text: Despite rain in Milan this week, bright, kaleidoscopic patterns have dominated the runways. Massimo Giorgetti’s second outing for Emilio Pucci (left) offered a colorful collection that took cues from ski wear, including this boxy jacket and pencil skirt in blue and yellow stripes. Marni (center), another brand fond of graphic motifs, showed a knee-length tunic in a pattern that recalled abstract art. And at Salvatore Ferragamo (right), Massimiliano Giornetti presented a vibrant, zigzag cape and skirt that were just as colorful as the runway.

headline: Sumner Redstone Competency Case Will Go Forward
text: The lawsuit challenging the mental competence of the ailing 92-year-old media mogul Sumner M. Redstone will go to trial in May because of a “plethora of disputed factual issues” over his capacity and current medical care, a California judge ruled on Monday.

headline: Let’s Talk About the Oscars: An Evening of Squirming
text: The story so far: In January, when the nominations for the 88th Academy Awards were announced and not a single nonwhite performer was recognized, a lot of people voiced their outrage about the omissions. The oversights weren’t new for this predominantly white organization, but the intensity and volume of the criticisms were.

headline: Reviewing the Oscars From Afar
text: MILAN — On Monday, barely hours after the Oscars show had ended halfway across the world, the fashion flock had to hie themselves to the Giorgio Armani show, with barely a chance to scan the slide shows to see what they had missed (Cate Blanchett in floral-strewn mint Armani, for one).

text: The Alabama legislature has voted to nullify a law passed last year in Birmingham that would have set the city’s minimum wage at $10.10 by mid-2017.

text: Voters participated in the Republican caucuses in Nevada and in the Democratic primary in South Carolina.

headline: Iranian President and Moderates Make Strong Gains in Elections
text: TEHRAN — Nearly three years after Iran’s reform-minded president was elected, the most reactionary voices in Iranian politics are losing ground to moderates buoyed by the sweeping nuclear deal with big powers, including the United States.

headline: Hope and Fear Await a Basque Leader on His Release From Prison
text: MADRID — A terrorist to some, an independence leader to others, Arnaldo Otegi has been in and out of Spanish courts and prisons for three decades for his links to ETA, the separatist group that has led a violent campaign for an independent Basque homeland.

headline: Derek Hough to Play Gene Kelly Role in ‘Singin’ in the Rain’ on Broadway
text: Derek Hough will make a splash on Broadway next January: He has been cast as the lead in the Théâtre du Châtelet’s production of “Singin’ in the Rain.” Mr. Hough, a two-time Emmy winner (for “Dancing with the Stars”), has stage experience from the 2006 West End production of “Footloose.” Here, he’ll step into the role of Don Lockwood, which Gene Kelly made famous in the 1952 film.

text: This week, the biologist Edward O. Wilson, professor emeritus at Harvard University and recipient of two Pulitzer Prizes, will publish his 32nd book, a personal exhortation to conserve biodiversity titled “Half Earth: Our Planet’s Fight for Life.”

headline: Woman, 77, Fatally Struck by Livery Cab in Midtown
text: Carol Dauplaise was crossing Madison Avenue at 36th Street just after 8:30 a.m. on Monday, a few blocks from her apartment and the costume jewelry company that she started more than 35 years ago, when a black livery cab turned and struck her, pinning her under the car.

headline: Another Trip Cut Short on Anthem of the Seas
text: It happened again: Less than a month after Royal Caribbean’s Anthem of the Seas vessel returned earlier than scheduled to its port of origin in Cape Liberty, N.J.,  after facing 120 m.p.h. winds off Cape Hatteras, N.C., the ship ended another cruise early in anticipation of a severe storm expected in the same location.

headline: Donald Trump Carries Big Leads in Alabama and Oklahoma, Polls Show
text: Donald J. Trump is in position to sweep to victories in the Alabama and Oklahoma primaries on Tuesday, according to a new polls that show strong support from evangelical Christians potentially helping him win a big haul of delegates.

headline: Curtis Granderson’s Eye Malady Underscores Mets’ Outfield Depth
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — When Curtis Granderson arrived at the Mets’ complex Monday morning, he was wearing glasses because he was worried about redness around his eye. The Mets worried it might be pinkeye, and given how contagious that can be, they sent him away and asked him to skip his normal drills for the day.

headline: ‘Female Viagra’ Only Modestly Increases Sexual Satisfaction, Study Finds
text: WASHINGTON — Half of one satisfying sexual encounter a month. That is the average benefit a woman gets when she takes the new female libido drug, sometimes called the “female Viagra,” researchers reported Monday.

headline: A Men’s Store for the Everyguy
text: Willy Chavarria, 48, the tattooed owner of Palmer Trading Company, at 137 Sullivan Street in Manhattan, set up shop in 2010. “When we started, it was all vintage,” Mr. Chavarria said.

headline: France Faces Protests as It Dismantles ‘Jungle’ Migrant Camp
text: PARIS — The French authorities faced angry protesters on Monday as they began to dismantle part of a vast migrant camp near the northern city of Calais after a court order last week that at least partially allowed the government to move forward with its plans to vacate the settlement, known as “the Jungle.”

headline: A Decade Later, Clarence Thomas Speaks Again
text: Ten years and one week after it began without warning or explanation, Justice Clarence Thomas’s unofficial vow of silence has ended.

headline: Argentina’s Debt Settlement Ends 15-Year Battle
text: The announcement of a $4.65 billion agreement between the Argentine government and four “holdout” hedge funds promises to end a 15-year battle that started when the government defaulted on $100 billion in debt in 2001.

headline: Hillary Clinton Rallies Large Crowd in Boston Before the Primary
text: BOSTON — A buoyant Hillary Clinton plunged into the crowd here after a barnstorming speech, posing for selfies and shaking hands on the eve of what she hopes will be a pivotal victory in the 11 states, including Massachusetts, that hold Democratic nominating contests on Tuesday.

headline: Invasive Species Aren’t Always Unwanted
text: Invasive species are bad news, or so goes the conventional wisdom, encouraged by persistent warnings from biologists about the dangers of foreign animals and plants moving into new territories.

headline: Does This Species Belong Here?
text: Many common animals, plants and insects are not native to the environments in which they are now found. Take this quiz and learn more about the living things that surround you.

headline: The Birth of Postwar Italian Style
text: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. — Bonnie Clearwater cast a covetous eye on a pair of wool coats. “I’d love to own one,” she said. “Wear it and you won’t end up looking like a box.”

headline: Parents of American Held in North Korea Unable to Speak With Him
text: The parents of an American college student who tearfully apologized on North Korean state television on Monday for having plotted to steal a political banner said they had been unable to speak with their son since the North Korean police seized him two months ago.

headline: Women Waiting Longer to Have Children
text: American women are having their first babies at increasingly older ages.

headline: Goldman Sachs Puts Worker Linked to Donald Trump on Leave
text: A financial adviser who was recently highlighted in an article in The New York Times as the only Goldman Sachs employee to contribute to Donald J. Trump’s presidential campaign has been placed on administrative leave, according to people familiar with the matter.

headline: Bernie Sanders Tells Minnesotans They Can ‘Make History’
text: MINNEAPOLIS — On the eve of voting in 11 Democratic contests, Bernie Sanders told hundreds of supporters here on Monday that he was counting on them to defeat Hillary Clinton and start a political revolution.

headline: Sikh Soldier Sues Defense Dept., Citing Religious Discrimination
text: A combat soldier who is Sikh sued the Defense Department on Monday, saying his beard and turban had made him the subject of religious discrimination because the Army was putting him through arduous helmet and gas mask testing that no other soldier goes through.

text: In the late ’60s, this one peculiar designer redefined men’s fashion — silk blouses, swishy florals and all. His look is back.

text: He went by the name of Mr. Fish. And today, his gender-bending look — silk blouses, swishy florals and all — is back.

Chris Rock’s Asian Joke at Oscars Provokes Backlash
text: Amid generally positive reviews of his jabs at Hollywood and #OscarsSoWhite, the host of Sunday’s Oscar ceremony, Chris Rock, is being taken to task for some of his material involving Asian-Americans.

text: If Republicans are worried about a Donald J. Trump presidential nomination damaging the party down the ballot in November, Representative Ann Kirkpatrick, the Arizona Democratic who is challenging Senator John McCain, is offering a prime example of why they should be.

text: The culinary capital has embraced its fitter, more Zenned-out side.

headline: Eric Staal Opens His Rangers Career With a Victory
text: After Eric Staal told his family he had been traded to the Rangers, Levi Staal, who is 4 years old and is the second of Eric and Tanya Staal’s three sons, told Eric time after time that he did not want his father to move away. Eric assured Levi that he would not be leaving North Carolina without him.

headline: Catalog Interview With Gloria Steinem Has Lands’ End on Its Heels
text: The retailer Lands’ End was scrambling to disentangle itself from the feminist icon Gloria Steinem after an interview printed in a recent catalog prompted criticism from parents at Christian schools and anti-abortion activists.

headline: Judge Grants Delay of Sodium Warnings for New York City Restaurants
text: An appeals court on Monday ordered a temporary halt to New York City’s enforcement of a measure requiring some chain restaurants to post warnings on menu items with high levels of sodium.

headline: SEAL Who Wrestled Gunman and Shielded Hostage Is Awarded Medal of Honor
text: WASHINGTON — Edward C. Byers Jr., a senior chief special warfare operator, was the second Navy SEAL team member to enter a Taliban compound on a frigid night in December 2012, part of a mission to rescue an American doctor being held hostage in eastern Afghanistan. The first, Petty Officer First Class Nicolas Checque, was shot in the head after he burst through the door.

headline: Valeant Chief Returns to a Difficult To-Do List
text: J. Michael Pearson is back as chief executive of Valeant Pharmaceuticals International, but with less power and no glory. He is no longer chairman of the drug maker’s board.

text: Photos from Greece, France, Italy and the United States.

text: The worst hotel experiences can be caused by an insect smaller than a fingernail clipping.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Review: Dana Spiotta’s ‘Innocents and Others’ Explores the Dynamics Between Life and Art
text: In her stunning 2001 debut novel, “Lightning Field,” Dana Spiotta wrote of her film-obsessed heroine Mina: “She sometimes thought that if someone saw all the movies she had seen, the number of times she had seen them and in the order she had seen them, that person might know exactly who she was.” It’s an observation that could serve as a keystone for every one of Ms. Spiotta’s strobe-lit novels — all of which concern the search for identity, and the mysterious dynamics between life and art.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Salvatore Ferragamo and Missoni in Pictures
text: A photo diary of the fall/winter 2016 collections that were presented Sunday.

headline: Oscars’ Best Dressed Men? Common, Eddie Redmayne and Jacob Tremblay
text: According to the tacit protocols of gala dressing, women, and not men, are meant to shine. Thus — whether by instinct or because that is what their Svengali stylists taught them — the best-dressed men at the 88th annual Academy Awards ceremony evinced faith in the simplicity of proper evening clothes, with the result that this was among the most stylish Oscars ceremonies in recent years.

headline: The Inseparable Sisters Bringing Bright, Graphic Designs to London
text: Interviewing Nikita and Tina Sutradhar feels less like a formal assignment and more like being welcomed into their family. The sisters, 25 and 27, trade off the retelling of childhood anecdotes, reminiscing about their local Mumbai bookshop in the ’90s that sold American Teen Vogue and watching Miss World as middle schoolers, enraptured by the parade of outfits. They describe how they crafted a dress from newspapers in their teens. “Our father came home and we showed it to him,” Tina says, “and he was like, ‘That’s it. You have to go to design school.’”

headline: Review: In the Met’s ‘Figaro,’ a Scene Stealer in Her Element
text: Few operatic characters are better equipped to steal scenes than the adolescent page Cherubino in Mozart’s “Le Nozze di Figaro”: a young man ridden by hormones and given gorgeous arias pulsing with sensuality. That the role is allotted to a grown woman only increases the opportunities for sophisticated humor and low farce.

headline: Brandee Younger, a Harpist Finding Her Way to Jazz
text: Brandee Younger was a teenager — an aspiring classical harpist, growing up on Long Island — when she came across an eye-opening issue of Harp Column magazine. A trade bimonthly with a loyal constituency (motto: “practical news, for practical harpists”) had published a readers poll celebrating the instrument’s most influential figures of the 20th century.

headline: Anna Netrebko, a Towering Soprano, in Her New York Recital Debut
text: As she began Rachmaninoff’s “Lilacs” during her program of Russian songs at the Metropolitan Opera on Sunday afternoon, Anna Netrebko stepped away from her accompanist and walked to one side of the stage, where two enormous vases of flowers stood. Caressing some blossoms in her hands, she tenderly sang the lyrics, the thoughts of a sorrowful young woman comforted by the happiness that “lives in the lilacs.”

headline: Valeant Pharmaceuticals Is Under S.E.C. Investigation
text: Valeant Pharmaceuticals International said on Monday that it was being investigated by the Securities and Exchange Commission, the latest turn of events for the Canadian drug maker, which has come under recent scrutiny for its sky-high drug prices and a once-secret relationship with a mail-order pharmacy.

headline: Eiko, Koma and Soloists Perform in Sacred Space
text: Even if you frequent St. Mark’s Church in the East Village, you’ve probably never been inside the Priest’s Room or walked around the second-floor balcony. You’ve passed the lion statue guarding the entrance, but have you ever really looked at it?

headline: City Ballet’s Season of Renewal
text: Who is Miriam Miller? She became a member of the New York City Ballet corps only in January — so recently, in fact, that her brief biography on the company’s website has no photo attached. This is odd for two reasons. One: From the auditorium of the David H. Koch Theater, where the company finished its six-week winter season on Sunday, she appears to have the perfect, theatrically legible features of a model. Two: It’s been apparent since June that she’s going places.

headline: Apple Wins Ruling in New York iPhone Hacking Order
text: A federal magistrate judge on Monday denied the United States government’s request that Apple extract data from an iPhone in a drug case in New York, giving the company’s pro-privacy stance a boost as it battles law enforcement officials over opening up the device in other cases.

headline: George Pell, Aide to Pope, Is Put on Defensive in Abuse Inquiry
text: ROME — When Pope Francis was chosen to lead the world’s 1.2 billion Catholics three years ago, he pledged to reform antiquated and troubled Vatican institutions.

headline: Your Monday Evening Briefing: Donald Trump, Academy Awards, Stephen Curry
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Officer in North Carolina Fatally Shoots Black Man During Chase
text: RALEIGH, N.C. — A crowd gathered here on Monday to denounce the killing of a black man shot earlier in the day after a foot chase with a police officer.

headline: Young Lawyers Ready to Argue a Major Abortion Case Before the Supreme Court
text: Facing off before the Supreme Court on Wednesday, in what could be the most momentous abortion case in a quarter-century, will be two lawyers who are still in their thirties and are described by colleagues as whip-smart masters of the law and unflappable under pressure.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Review Agency Faults New York Police Department on Unlawful Searches
text: A team of plainclothes New York City police officers, tracking the signal of a stolen cellphone, pushed past a man who denied the officers permission to enter his home and searched it floor by floor. A sergeant forced the man to wait outside in his underwear in the rain.

headline: Quiz: How Much Grit Do You Have?
text: Here’s a sample of the Grit Scale, developed to identify traits that might predict success.

headline: Ideas Help No One on a Shelf. Take Them to the World.
text: Have you thought of a clever product to mitigate climate change? Did you invent an ingenious gadget to light African villages at night? Have you come up with a new kind of school, or new ideas for lowering the rate of urban shootings?

headline: Magistrate Judge James Orenstein’s Order
text: A federal judge has denied the United States government’s request to open up an Apple iPhone in a drug case in New York.

headline: Jets Are Said to Be Planning on Franchise Tag for Muhammad Wilkerson
text: The Jets’ contract impasse with the standout defensive lineman Muhammad Wilkerson, spanning years and regimes, will reach an expected stage Tuesday. The Jets intend to designate Wilkerson as their franchise player before the 4 p.m. deadline, according to a person in football with knowledge of their plans, in a maneuver that allows them to retain his rights while extending the window for brokering a long-term contract.

headline: George Kennedy Dies at 91; Versatile Actor Won Oscar for ‘Cool Hand Luke’
text: George Kennedy, who played tough guys, oafs, G.I.’s and a bonanza of cowboys as one of Hollywood’s most versatile and durable character actors, and who won an Oscar as the best supporting actor of 1967 for his performance in the Paul Newman film “Cool Hand Luke,” died on Sunday in Boise, Idaho. He was 91.

headline: New Study Links Zika Virus to Temporary Paralysis
text: A new study of 42 cases of Guillain-Barré syndrome in French Polynesia offers the strongest evidence to date that the Zika virus can trigger temporary paralysis, researchers reported on Monday. But experts cautioned that more evidence from other locations was needed to be conclusive.

headline: It’s Stephen Curry’s Game Now
text: If you have somehow missed watching the Golden State Warriors this season, you might have a quaint notion of how basketball is played.

headline: Auto Safety Agency Resists Broader Recall of Takata Airbags
text: Under pressure from some lawmakers to recall all Takata airbags, the nation’s top auto safety regulator responded that such a recall would not improve public safety, and might exceed the agency’s authority.

headline: Artists’ Children, Depicted By Their Parents
text: Inspired by the paintings of Vigée Le Brun, 13 contemporary artists portray their own kids.
